PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill is to provide for the grant of inalienable freehold title to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community over an area of some 403 hectares in Jervis Bay Territory. The Wreck Bay Aboriginal community is an established community comprising mainly descendants of the Jervis Bay and other tribes who once inhabited the general area. The land concerned at one time was gazetted as an Aboriginal reserve and administered by arrangement with the New South Wales Aborigines Protection Board. The land has always been regarded as a distinct Aboriginal area separate from other land in Jervis Bay Territory. Negotiations for land tenure, by way of a perpetual lease, commenced in 1973 and proceeded for about 10 years without resolution. During this period of negotiation a number of Ministers under previous Liberal governments with responsibility for the administration of Jervis Bay Territory gave support to the proposed tenure arrangements at Wreck Bay. Those Ministers included Senator Withers, the late Hon. Eric Robinson, the Hon. Tony Staley, the Hon. Bob Ellicott and the Hon. Michael Hodgman and I am sure on that basis that this Bill will have the support of the Opposition.

This Government began negotiations with the community almost as soon as it assumed office in 1983, and in 1984 offered a land package, including a grant of inalienable freehold title to an area of approximately 403 hectares, to the Aboriginal residents of the Wreck Bay community. During this time there has been ongoing consultation with the community in relation to the land to be granted and the arrangements to apply after that date. It is appropriate in this case that, as the land concerned is under the direct control of the Commonwealth, the Government is able to give effect to its policy of providing secure tenure to land in respect of Australia's indigenous population.
Scheme of the Legislation

Under the arrangements proposed, title to the land will be vested in the Wreck Bay Commun- ity Council under a trust arrangement. The functions, powers and administrative arrangements in respect of the Council are detailed in the Bill. No sale or mortgage of any part of the land will be permitted. However, the Council will be empowered to issue leases of land to members of the community for residential purposes and other leases to persons wishing to obtain an interest in the land for commercial purposes subject to the approval of the Minister. Public roads through the grant area will be excluded and members of the Public will continue to have access to facilities in the Summercloud Bay area which they currently enjoy. Because of the importance of some places of special significance from an Aboriginal point of view in the area of the grant the Bill makes provision for those places to be protected. In addition, the Bill provides for the grant of title to further land adjoining the grant area if justified to the satisfaction of the Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs and Territories.
Financial Impact

New or additional costs to the Commonwealth in providing title to land to the Wreck Bay community will be minimal. Annual costs associated with the administration of the Council will be met by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Commonwealth assets on the land, including houses, will vest in the Council.
Conclusion

This Bill secures the land to be granted for present and future generations of Aboriginal people at Wreck Bay. I commend this Bill to the House. I should apologise to the House. I was proposing to present an explanatory memorandum accompanying this Bill. However, it is still in the process of being printed and has been delayed in its expedition to the House as a result of the fog. I undertake to table the memorandum as soon as it becomes available so that honourable members will have the benefit of it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Cadman) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair) has taken up a few minutes I might mention a few other things. TALK.START.PARA: —The Procedure Committee will be reporting this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: We will be looking at the report of the Procedure Committee as to the sitting of the Parliament, better use of time and better access to the Parliament by the back bench. DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 2. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —`And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax!' Those were the words of R. J. L. Hawke, Leader of the Opposition, in his policy speech at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February 1983. Those were the words of the present Prime Minister, promising beyond doubt that there would be no new capital gains tax. Today in this House we have a capital gains tax in 103 pages of legislation. This is a day of infamy for this Government. Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion: We are opposed to this capital gains tax. We will vote against it here and in the Senate, and should the legislation pass we will repeal it on our return to office. Make no mistake: After our Bicentenary in Australia there will be no capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I also say that we lodge in this House the strongest possible protest against the manner of introduction of this tax. For over eight months the people of Australia have been told that there will be a capital gains tax and they have been given only the barest outline of that tax. Individuals and businesses throughout this land have had to make decisions for the past eight and a half months on the basis of legislation the details of which were unknown. Month after month we have asked the Government for details of this legislation. We have asked questions in the House week after week which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been unable to answer. Finally, last Thursday night at 8 o'clock the Treasurer came into the House with 103 pages of legislation but with no explanatory memoranda.

On Sunday the Opposition was provided with a proof copy of one explanatory memorandum, which was on its way to the printer. I might say that, to the eternal disgrace of this Government, of the six Bills presented last Thursday night only one had attached to it an explanatory memorandum, and might I say that as I was winding up the debate at the end of last night the final explanatory memoranda for these six Bills were put before the House. In other words, yesterday we were debating over the whole day four Bills, three of which had no explanatory memoranda. That is a record of failure to inform the House and the public which has not been equalled by any previous Treasurer of this nation. The Treasurer has had eight months and more to prepare the details of this legislation. It is immensely complex. It comes into the House in the form of a Bill of 103 pages without any explanation.

Might I say that for members of this House to receive only last night an explanatory memorandum of 155 pages for this Bill and to be expected to debate the legislation here today is an absolute disgrace. We have had 275 pages of new taxation legislation with us since last Thursday night. We have been expected to debate the legislation on Wednesday-that is, yesterday-and today. We have not had a chance fully to examine all the details of the legislation or its implications for the Australian people. We have not been able, as we ought to be able, to go out into the community, to talk to the experts, to talk to people who know about these things in detail and who are accustomed to examining legislation, and to seek their advice on the arguments we might present in this Parliament on behalf of the Australian people. That is a total disgrace. The Treasurer will bear the burden of this disgrace for the rest of his very short term in office.

I want to protest against the uncertainty on this matter caused in the community. Indeed, I want to protest in regard to one particular matter which is very serious indeed, a new element of this Bill which was not known when the Treasurer made his original remarks last September; that is, that any bequest made to a charity will be taxable from the estate. This means that for the last eight months and more people would have been making decisions about bequests without the knowledge of how they would be treated under the taxation law. I regard that as a total disgrace. I will come back to that specific matter because it is a further attack by this Government on charities and religious organisations. As well as being a very serious matter in that regard it also breaches taxation principles.

For over eight months people in Australia have had to make decisions affecting their lives, their futures and their children and grandchildren without knowledge of the legislation, which will have effect from 20 September, the day after the Treasurer made his speech. Certain transactions that will be affected by this legislation would have been initiated after that date and completed already without any knowledge of the taxation effects on those transactions. This is a disgrace, as has been pointed out by the Taxation Institute of Australia. I have here a letter, dated yesterday, to the Prime Minister from the President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, Mr I.V. Gzell, QC. He said:

The Taxation Institute of Australia, representing some 9,000 lawyers and accountants practising in the taxation field, deplores your Government's proposal to guillotine the taxation bills through the House of Representatives today and tomorrow.

It has taken the Government almost a year since the Taxation Summit to bring down the bills in relation to capital gains tax and foreign tax credits. It has taken it since 16 December 1984 to bring down the amendments in relation to income accrued on discounted and other deferred interest securities.

Why then the unseemly haste in introducing these important Bills on Thursday night and pushing them through the House on the next Wednesday and Thursday? Why is the Australian public being denied the opportunity for informed debate on the actual legislation effecting the most significant tax changes this Country has seen?
True it is that the Treasurer has made statements about the proposed legislation. But there is a world of difference between a statement of intent and the actual legislation.

The Taxation Institute of Australia is concerned that the legislation may cause undue hardship by its application in unintended situations. It has not had the opportunity to analyse the 175 odd pages of bills.
In fact, there are 275 pages. To continue:
Nor has it had the opportunity to read the Explanatory Memorandum in relation to capital gains tax which only became available yesterday.
I might say that it became available only on the day before this letter was written because we were able to make proof copies available. The letter continued:

But the Institute's experience leads it to believe that there will be aspects of the legislation which require further consideration. Its experience also leads it to believe that there is a reluctance in Government to amend legislation to overcome unforeseen problems once it has passed both Houses.
The Taxation Institute of Australia calls upon the Government:
(a) to delay the passage of the bills through the House of Representatives to allow proper times for analysis and comment;
The Government has ignored that request. To continue:
(b) in the alternative, to entertain appropriate amendments to the bills before their passage through the Senate and to allow sufficient time for consideration of proposed amendments;
The whole thing is to be rammed through the Senate before the Parliament rises at the end of this session. To continue:

(c) to announce when it intends to introduce the remaining elements of its tax reform package and, in particular, the full imputation system of company tax to offset the proposed increase in corporate tax to 49 per cent.

Those Bills have still not been introduced into the Parliament, a year after the National Taxation Summit and eight months after the Treasurer's statement of 19 September last year. The letter from which I have just quoted was from the President of the Taxation Institute of Australia. Overall, Labor's so-called tax reform has added to the complexity and volume of tax law. It has also increased the general level of taxation. In examining this measure, I will do so against the Prime Minister's nine principles for taxation as mentioned at the Taxation Summit.

The first principle states that there must be no increase in the overall tax burden. I must say that that principle has already been broken, and taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product will be higher than it was last year; so principle number one has been breached. The second principle states that any reforms must continue the process already begun by the Government and provide further cuts in personal income tax. The actual proposals put by the Treasurer last September provided phoney cuts-all they did was allow for the effects of inflation on income tax scales. Also, those phoney cuts are not to be introduced on the promised date of 1 September; so that is the second breach of a principle. I move to the fourth principle, which says in part that any reform must lead to a simpler system. Heaven forbid that we have a simpler system! Before this so-called reform we had 1,100 pages of taxation legislation, to which we have since added 625 pages; the reform has increased taxation legislation by 57 per cent. I will quote from the draft White Paper on taxation reform where, under the heading `Simplicity', some remarks appear that honourable members will find most instructive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sums up your economics.

—Let us turn to the Government's White Paper of last year before the disastrous Tax Summit of July. Under the heading `Simplicity' the White Paper states the following, in words that even the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) will be able to understand, if he stops interjecting and listens:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.8 A good tax system should be as simple as possible. A complex tax system makes it difficult for people to understand the law and apply it to their circumstances. The present law has become so complex that it is difficult to convey its meaning simply and adequately on tax return forms and in other printed matter. Complexity imposes high compliance costs on the community and high administrative costs on the tax authorities. Complex tax laws also result in socially unproductive and costly tax litigation. These considerations suggest that, where possible, tax reform measures capable of ready comprehension and application should be preferred over more complex alternatives.
None of us would disagree with that statement. It continues:
This review-
meaning the whole review of taxation in Australia-

affords an opportunity to see what can be done to reduce the burden of record-keeping on ordinary taxpayers, to increase the certainty of what is or is not taxable, and to increase the clarity of the tax system.

That is what the Government's White Paper said before the Tax Summit-make it easier for people, reduce their burden of record keeping, increase the certainty of what is or is not taxable, and increase the clarity of the tax system. What have we got? We have the fringe benefits tax, a tax measure comprising 139 pages, 176 pages of explanatory memoranda and a 56-page booklet which has been sent to all taxpayers to help them work out how the system will work. That will be impossible; the complexity is unbelievable in this measure before the House on capital gains tax-103 pages of legislation, 155 pages of explanatory memoranda. The second reading speech states that the Government is preparing a booklet on the capital gains tax to send out to people to help them work out what their compliance would be.

Honourable members who enjoyed reading the purple tombstone booklet on the fringe benefits tax know that it provided very interesting reading for 700,000 or 800,000 small businesses and farmers around Australia. They know what it is like. It cost, I understand, $3m to send it out. Now, a capital gains tax booklet will be prepared by the Government which will tell people that they have to keep records of their postage stamps, coin collections and works of art. That is what they will be told to record. When they receive that booklet, they will realise that it is not just the big people who might be caught by this tax; it might affect every citizen in Australia. So much for the fourth principle of simplicity of the Prime Minister. Let us look at the sixth principle:
. . . any tax reform must not disadvantage recipients of welfare benefits . . .

Heavens above, a fringe benefits tax will be imposed on charities, for a start. This Bill provides for death duties on bequests to charities. Therefore, people who are recipients of welfare benefits and people who are disabled and reliant on charities will be disadvantaged under at least two of these measures. So that is another principle that has been breached. The eighth principle reads:
. . . any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia.
What a joke! I will come back to that a little later.

Honourable members will laugh at the ninth principle. I am referring to the Prime Minister's nine clear principles. Everybody applauded them at the Tax Summit. Everybody said that they were great. This is a corker:
. . . any reform package must have widespread community support . . .

All over Australia people are lighting bonfires in support of the fringe benefits tax! People are holding rallies all over Australia, applauding the capital gains tax! They are lighting bonfires-but those bonfires contain the fringe benefits tax guide booklets. If they are lighting bonfires because of the capital gains tax, it is to try to burn the people who are introducing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know about it?

—I explain to the honourable member for Calwell that the honourable member for Mackellar has the call. I understand the honourable member for Calwell is listed to speak later. He should wait until then.

—A capital gains tax is levied at the top marginal rate after allowing for inflation. This capital gains tax is the toughest capital gains tax in the Western world. I do not know what happens in communist countries in regard to these matters because they do not recognise capital. In this country we are introducing a capital gains tax which is the most savage in the world. There are some exemptions-the sole or principal residence, proceeds from superannuation or life policies, certain motor vehicles and personal use assets of less than $5,000 unless they are listed. The ones that must be listed, to make sure that one pays one's tax, are works of art, coin and stamp collections, antiques and jewellery. They must be recorded and taxed on disposal. So anybody who buys any of those items from now on, even if their value is under $5,000, will be required to keep a record of the price for which he bought them, and if he sells them, he will have to pay capital gains tax on the proceeds. In regard to deceased estates, the tax is not payable by the deceased, but is payable on disposal by the beneficiary. So there is a delayed death duty as well. Improvements of less than $50,000 to property are not taxable. But if a person is quite inventive and improves the property by an amount above $50,000 he is caught by the tax. The Government made a concession in regard to good will. It said: `We will aid small business by exempting certain elements of good will'. The new good will component of a business sold for less than $1m will be exempt. Some concession! There are certain rollover concessions.

SPEECH.PARA: The question, I suppose, is this: What are the arguments for a capital gains tax? It is said that the absence of a capital gains tax favours those receiving income in the form of capital gains. It is said that it favours the wealthy. It is said that it encourages investment in non-income earning assets, and it is also said that it can be used for tax avoidance purposes, using devices to dress up taxable income as a non-taxable capital gain. These are quite serious arguments in favour of a capital gains tax. The Opposition acknowledges them. They are seriously put. They have also been put by senior businessmen reporting to the Economic Planning Advisory Council. I have read their remarks and I do not dismiss those arguments lightly. They are important economic arguments.

It has to be pointed out, however, that over quite a long period the Fraser Government introduced quite comprehensive legislation to take action to close the major loopholes. The purpose of most of the major devices was to turn income into capital and have it untaxed. This Parliament, under the Fraser Government, introduced a long series of measures which virtually brought that kind of activity to a close. The present Treasurer has introduced a few measures. He claims he has done it all, but in fact the record of the two governments shows that it was the Fraser Government that reduced those loopholes and removed them.

The extension of capital gains tax to all and sundry, which this proposal puts forward, really revolves around whether the equity principle should be taken any further than it has been. After action has been taken to remove the major inequities, taking further steps can stifle incentive, and introduce appalling bureaucratic complexity. The Opposition does not dismiss the arguments in favour of a capital gains tax at all, because those economic arguments exist. It merely says that we have got well to the point of the law of diminishing returns and that to introduce 103 pages of immensely complex legislation to try to catch all the tiddlers will have a disincentive effect on this community which will outweigh any possible economic benefit from the introduction of the tax. That, purely and simply, is the Opposition's argument.

Let me examine this issue in the context of Australia's stage of development. Australia is a capital hungry country. Australia, unlike the old advanced countries of Western Europe and North America, which have vast supplies of surplus capital, is capital hungry. I have brought into the House the business investment and capital stock paper of EPAC. If any honourable members wants to understand one of the reasons why unemployment is so high, why we are desperately short of investment and why yesterday's investment figures from the Australian Statistician were so dreadful-investment still has not recovered to the levels before the last recession-this booklet published by the Government shows the desperate need for capital formation and investment of that capital. This measure strikes at the very heart of those objectives. We share with the Government a belief that there should be incentive for investment in Australia. We say to the Government that the introduction of a measure of this kind strikes right back against that objective.

What does this tax do? First of all, it does not even meet one of the requirements for a capital gains tax because, for very good political reasons, it excludes the family home. We want it to exclude the family home. Might I say it does not exclude the family farm. The two big sticking points in political terms against those economic arguments that some people have put forward for a capital gains tax are what to do about the family home and what to do about the family farm. This Government has excluded the family home for political reasons, but it has included the farm. In a country which relies on family farming and on a farming community that exports 70 per cent of its product whose work is desperately required with our balance of payments problems and on whom we are still relying to meet most of those payments, what do we do? We strike at the family farm by imposing a capital gains tax. It is a stupid thing to do.

On the other hand, the exclusion of the family home means that more and more money will be put into new wings on existing dwellings instead of going into more productive investment. There will be a Keating wing in every home. Instead of putting money into productive investment what will the people do? They will say: `We will have an exempt capital gain on our family home. So we will increase the capital value of our home'. Honourable members opposite cannot deny that as an economic argument-they know it is true.

What does this tax do? The Treasurer says that it will not be levied on any existing holdings prior to 20 September 1985. In effect he is saying: `Do not worry, all you people with existing riches, because they will all be excluded.' Very well, but those people still have to worry if they still have any entrepreneurial spirit left in them because any major improvements they may make will be caught by this tax. Who does this tax really strike at? This tax strikes at the next generation of entrepreneurs. It strikes at the young person starting a business, wishing to build it up and wishing to see some incentive. It strikes at the person who is prepared to work in the early stages of that business for much less than union controlled wages in the hope and expectation-up until now-that there will be a capital gain somewhere at the end of it all, either for himself or herself or their children. Men and women together, building up businesses, working hard and starting new businesses in the cities or new farms-what motivates them to work harder and longer hours for a great deal less money than many people who are under awards? What about the people who run corner shops? They stay open late at night to serve the needs of organised unionists who work five days a week in ordinary working hours and who want good service after hours or a cheap meal in a restaurant. Behind those services there is often a family working for less than award wages. One of the things that motivate such families is the possibility of an untaxed capital gain as a reward for their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—There is nothing wrong with that. In fact, this country needs more of those people. This country needs them desperately. If we look at the investment figures this Government must now face up to and which it should be discussing at next week's mini-summit, we realise that it should wipe this measure off before it even gets on to the books.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a turning point in Australia's entrepreneurial history. This country has been built up by people who are prepared to work harder, to risk their money, to mortgage their homes, and to use that capital to invest in productive endeavour in businesses which have previously not been subject to any capital gains tax. Those businesses are, however, subject to all sorts of other taxes-income tax, payroll tax, stamp duties and State taxes-all of which provide an immense source of revenue to governments, State and Federal. At least at the end of the rainbow those people had the possibility of having an untaxed capital gain and that possibility is now being taken away from them. Let us not underestimate the psychological importance of this. This whole package of measures, which came in on 19 September, is anti-entrepreneurial. Consider the person of incentive and dedication who is prepared to work hard with his or her family often in the business. Before 19 September that person would not have faced a fringe benefits tax, the prospect of a capital gains tax or negative gearing legislation. That person would not have faced this vast array of new imposts on entrepreneurship and risk, which have all been brought in as part of the so-called tax reform.

People might think that this package will not affect them. Well, it will. It is not only the entrepreneur who will be attacked. The charities also will be attacked. Let me deal with the matter of charities and bequests. Section 160y provides that where a post-19 September 1985 asset of a person who dies after that date passes to a tax exempt beneficiary-that is, a church, charity, school, university, art gallery or sporting club-the asset is deemed to have been disposed of by the deceased for its market value at the date of death. The special provisions otherwise dealing with assets of a deceased do not apply. The estate of the deceased would have to pay any capital gains tax on such assets. What will this do to the incentives for bequests? There will be death duties on bequests to charities. Combined with the fringe benefits tax which is being levied on charities by this Treasurer, it represents an unprecedented attack on churches and charities. We learnt during the course of this week that under the fringe benefits tax two-thirds of each manse, presbytery or rectory would be liable for fringe benefits tax, despite the guarantee from the Treasurer that religious bodies would be exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —That couldn't be right.

—That is correct, according to advice received from the Commissioner of Taxation. Now we find in this Bill that, aside from all the other things in it, any bequest made to a church, charity or whatever will be subject to death duties and that, of course, will affect the level of those bequests.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to many other things in this Bill, but I do not have time. I merely say that over the course of this day speaker after speaker from the Liberal and National parties on this side of the House will point out why this Bill must be defeated and why, if this Bill is not defeated in this House or in the Senate, it will be repealed by us on our return to office. This Bill will not stay on the statute books into Australia's third century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tax system in Australia when the Hawke Government came to office was little better than when Rome was flourishing and Cato wrote perceptively that `those who stole from private individuals spent their lives in stocks and chains while those who stole from the public treasury went dressed in gold and purple'. Cato was right then and his view would sit comfortably today. Professor Yuri Grbich also perceptively diagnosed the mess our tax system has become, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why did death duty get a fatal case of paralysis? Why were contrived paper tax avoidance schemes (including, significantly, a healthy dash of sales tax schemes) allowed to degenerate until they sunk to the slime at the bottom of the harbour? Why did fringe benefits entrench themselves as a multi-billion dollar tax problem? Why have abusive tax shelters been allowed to grow like a cancer in front of our collective eyes, so that they have given a bad name to some entirely necessary tax subsidy measures?
The problems certainly had design aspects to them, but essentially they were management problems. Professor Grbich also said:
The basic flaw in our past tax reform and tax maintenance strategies was that we did not address the hard economic and political problems at the political level.

Let me ask a few more pertinent questions. Why is it that we regard and befriend the tax dodgers and hammer the shop lifter? Why is it that we unleash our corporate affairs and taxation officers on petty transgressors and shower tax evaders with honours, tax loopholes and tax free incomes? The capital gains taxation measures before us today, along with the perks tax legislation, are an attempt to redress this imbalance. The measures proposed by the Government in its tax reform package are aimed at those areas where the tax system has suffered the most in recent years from the attacks of tax avoiders, particularly fringe benefits and capital gains.

The huge tax evasion rorts of the Fraser years, such as the Curran, Westraders, Slutzkin and bottom of the harbour schemes-I would like to debate them, but I do not have time-which deprived the revenue of hundreds of millions of dollars, all relied on converting income into capital gains to avoid paying tax. Tax shelters are no longer the domain of the rich or clever entrepreneur. Through intensive marketing over the years a proliferation of avenues, such as equity and property trusts, are now well established to offer the investor of more limited means a sample of capital gains.

As with the Government's attack upon fringe benefits, it faces a difficult task in eliminating anomalies within legislation, as well as coping with the flak from vested interests. The tragedy of the present situation is that the range and spread of fringe benefits and methods of converting income into capital gains have escalated enormously over the past decade under the neglect of the previous Government. Had this neglect continued, we would eventually have reached the situation where virtually every non-salary and wage earner in the country would have been paid substantially in kind rather than in cash. Paying tax would have become the exclusive preserve, as indeed it was, of the pay as you earn taxpayers. Paying tax was and would have continued to be optional for the rich.

Because of past neglect, not only are many more entrenched groups now fighting tooth and nail for the preservation of their privileged pos-itions, but also whole industries have had time to develop around these anomalies in our tax system. The important lesson is not that we should tolerate inequalities and inequities in our tax system because innocent people will get hurt when we close off loopholes, and regrettably they will; rather, the lesson is that maintenance of our tax system must take a much more important place on the agenda of government.

In essence, the debate on capital gains is about equity. Even the Opposition cannot deny that, on the basis of equity, taxes should be paid on capital gains. There may be arguments about the details of the imposition of this tax. There may be arguments about how much we can expect to reap from such a tax. There may be quibbles about the cost effectiveness of such a tax. There may be a concern about the effects of inflation on capital gains. But there can be no serious ethical objection to the fairness of a capital gains tax. It is as simple as this: Capital gains represent gains, just as income from wages and salaries does. If one form or type of gain is taxed all should be taxed.

It ought to be acknowledged that the better-off members of society are more likely to have capital gains. As the law stands, those gains are rarely taxed. Why should a greengrocer buying cabbage at one price and selling it at a higher price be taxed when a speculator buying shares or property at one price and selling them at a higher price is not? It is high time that the media-dominated public debate focused on the economic costs of defects in our tax system in general and our income tax in particular. As my good friend Professor Grbich has so cogently put it, and honourable members opposite ought to take this into account:

The original rationale and only conceivable continuing justification for according this outrageously generous tax shelter for speculative profits was to encourage productive investment and the creation of long term community prosperity. Equity in the treatment of wage earners and investors was traded off in the short term for economic growth. But the tax shelter developed like topsy. With some judicious nudging from articulate advocates for the shrewd and the wealthy, the umbrella was extended indiscriminately and nobody asked hard questions about its rationale and limits. Now the shelter is much too wide and is very seriously flawed. If a camel is a horse designed by a committee of bureaucrats, then the mis-shapen, haggard, scarred face of our apology for a capital gains shelter is a tax policy created by a courtroom of barristers. By comparison, at least the camel has a quaint functional elegance. The tax shelter for capital gains over a large area of its operation achieves precisely the opposite result of its only conceivable rationale (to stimulate economic growth). It encourages sterile channelling of effort and scarce capital into unproductive (indeed highly destructive) speculation in urban land, antiques, precious metals and the like. It channels would-be venture capital into high debt/equity gearing in assets which show an inadequate real return (without the tax expenditure subsidy) in order to convert tax deductible income losses into tax-free capital gains. Hence it seriously inhibits Australian economic performance. It is pregnant with the possibilities of paper tax avoidance by converting income into capital gain with various artifices.

Is anybody opposite seriously arguing with that assessment? This method of avoidance is all the worse because it is more readily available to the rich who can pay expensive advisers to help them avoid their fair contribution to society. This unholy alliance worked for years to undermine the progressive nature of the tax system.

We have dozens of cases in the law reports describing fanciful and unscrupulous manoeuvrings to convert what is income into capital gains simply to avoid the imposition of tax. Australia already taxes some capital gains under section 26aaa and section 25a of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I understand the latter is to be abolished. We do not need to get involved in the pointless debate of whether or not those provisions are true capital gains provisions except to point out that if we tax a gain on property bought without even an intention or purpose of making a profit, as we do with section 26aaa, that has to be a capital gains tax. Call them what we like, they are capital gains tax provisions.

The Opposition, when in Government for so many years, did not remove these existing provisions; quite the reverse. Thus, it is strange indeed to hear the Opposition's cries against a more thorough and fair capital gains tax. As I recall, we have taxed short term and some long term capital gains since the 1930s. It does not wash with us, or the Australian public, for the Opposition to plead ignorance of and abhorrence at capital gains tax like a gaggle of Lady Macbeths at the handbasins.

As in overseas legislation, our capital gains tax will have exemptions. The owner-occupied residence and the family's personal goods and chattels up to the value of $5,000 will not be taxed. We also have averaging and `roll over' relief provisions. They will help relieve any perceived `lock in' problem where equity demands such relief and where the impositions of the tax may arguably impose a potentially damaging burden on the property owner. The Asprey Taxation Review Committee and Canada's Carter Commission suggested such relief and we have acted on those proposals. Generally we are allowing exemptions where there is no change in the continuity of the investment but there has been a change in the technical form of the investment. I think that is the best way to put it. We even allow for the effects of inflation. This is a very significant concession, certainly when we compare it with most overseas capital gains tax impositions.

A tax system must strive to be equitable and just. It should not pick on the easy targets and forget the others, just because they are too hard to get at. That has been one of the problems with the Australian Taxation Office for too long. Such a tax should not catch only wage and salary earners and the like, and let those who profit by capital gain escape their responsibilities. Certainly we must do all we can to make the collection and measurement as efficient and simple as possible. We will work on that, but in the meantime we will not let such technical arguments cloud the issue or undermine our intention to do justice for all.

It is also interesting to note that we have not seen the conservative governments of the United Kingdom or Canada rushing to dismantle their capital gains tax impositions. They recognise the overwhelming equity of the tax. They implicitly acknowledge that the collection of the tax can be efficient; that the discouragement of tax avoidance and the increased revenue the tax offers is real and valuable.

It is neglect of practical aspects of tax administration by past governments which has caused so much damage to the existing tax structure and left us with so perverse a system. Professor Russell Mathews best summed up the mess we inherited as follows:
It would be difficult to improve on the present arrangements if we deliberately set out to design a tax system that requires the poor to pay more taxes than many of the rich.
If we deliberately wanted to discriminate against wage and salary earners and to distort production decisions and consumer choice.

If we deliberately sought to destroy incentives to save, invest, innovate, take risks, and undertake productive activity while simultaneously rewarding speculative activity and providing incentives as well as opportunities for avoiding tax.
If we deliberately set out to make the tax system as complex, cumbersome, confusing and costly to administer and comply with as possible.

The extent of tax evasion-that is, fraud or failure to declare income-was estimated in the draft White Paper at, as I recall, $3,000m. This tax fraud is just one part of the problem of corporate crime in this country. It is important that Australian taxpayers recognise that all forms of corporate crime have contributed to an excessive dependence on PAYE taxpayers for raising government revenues. Not only are honest taxpayers required to make up the shortfall in revenue resulting from tax fraud-they have been doing so for two to three decades-but also they are required to pay for the frauds on government expenditure and for the growing costs of investigating and prosecuting these frauds on the Commonwealth.

How then can we minimise fraud in the tax system? The secret of effective anti-avoidance strategies is to act quickly before expectations create their own bandwagon effect. This requires much better drafting techniques, a proper institutional focus and sound strategies. The public sector, because of its institutional rigidities, finds it difficult to match the mobile, smart and resourceful guerrilla tactics of the more subtle operators in the tax avoidance industry. Special Prosecutor Redlich pointed out in his 1984 report, and regrettably this is my view of the operations of the Australian Taxation Office:

The Taxation Office too often elects not to unravel the corporate structure which a criminal employed to hide his assets, because tax officers could spend that time dealing with straightforward returns of other taxpayers and thereby recover the same or greater revenue.

That situation has to be reformed. If the big tax evaders are not punished many smaller taxpayers lose faith in the system and look for opportunities to evade tax themselves. As old Cardinal Richelieu once put it:
Nothing so upholds the law as the punishment of persons whose rank is as great as their crime.

There is little point in introducing major changes to our tax system, if we are still unable successfully to prosecute those who hold our tax laws in contempt. Millions of dollars have been put into the investigation and prosecution of frauds on the Commonwealth. Bottom of the harbour frauds alone involve $600m in defrauded tax revenues.

While looking for ways to save some of these vast sums lost to the Commonwealth, I have spoken to leading prosecutors. A major reason for tax fraud being so prevalent and requiring such a huge commitment of resources in investigation and prosecution is that there are not uniform and binding accounting procedures for individuals, corporations, trusts, banks and other financial institutions and the professions to adhere to when dealing with an account for assets and asset movements. In my view, a code, backed up where necessary with criminal penalties, standardising the manner in which such things are accounted for is an urgent priority if this type of conduct is to be eliminated. This code should also have within it provisions sanctioning the knowing creation of false bank accounts and these provisions should be backed up with penalties. Furthermore, there is currently no code of conduct for co-operation by private and public institutions, particularly banks and financial institutions, with law enforcement authorities that have been properly authorised to obtain information about those institutions dealing with, or on behalf of, individuals, trusts and companies. The lack of clear guidelines is presently a cause of real problems to investigators and prosecutors.

To deter further those who would seek to act illegally behind the veil of companies and trusts there need to be provisions requiring regular reporting of beneficial interests and, in the case of nominees, a declaration of principals to the Corporate Affairs Commission. There may be good reasons why principals and beneficiaries may not wish to have their interests on publicly available records, so any move in this direction may need to countenance provisions restricting access to authorised State and Commonwealth agencies that have a bona fide need for such information. The point is, though, that if such records were available, not only would there be a deterrence but also, if criminal conduct was suspected, there would be a much better starting point for investigators than exists at present.

I would like to conclude by making a number of observations. Beyond question, the Opposition's policies and approach to the critical need for tax reform can be very simply and bluntly summed up: The Opposition's rhetoric is long on tax reform but it is dismally and pitifully short on the issue of specific tax reform. Or to put it more cogently, as old Colonel Blimp once put it:
Gad Sir, I'm a conservative, after all I believe in reform, provided it changes nothing.

There has been a succession of tory governments in this country and their whole policy on tax reform has been predicated on the simple dictum that Napoleon once passed on to Kleber when Napoleon had to go back to France. Kleber had a rather sensible approach to tax as a means of raising funds to sustain his army. Napoleon said to Kleber: `Let me warn you. To tax the poor is safe, but to tax the rich beyond acceptable limits is decidedly dangerous'. I commend the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on these measures but I say to some of my colleagues on this side of the House that there are some rightful concerns by my colleagues, electorally, about the impact of these measures. Old Dr Jowett from Balliol College once said: `You will only get these issues of tax reform through with political courage because you will never get them through on consensus'. Dr Jowett also said:
Never retreat, never apologise, get it done, and let them howl.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the 1982 Australian Labor Party National Conference in Canberra the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), the present Prime Minister, tried to alter the Australian Labor Party platform and make capital gains tax the official policy of the Labor Party. One of the reasons he proposed this move was to curry favour with the Party's left wing. Although he narrowly lost the vote to the faction led by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), his attempt to have the capital gains tax adopted as official Labor Party policy served him well. It helped him to maintain his momentum towards the leadership. In an impassioned plea as convenor of the Party's economic committee, he made this interesting comment:

SPEECH.PARA: If we cannot sell this proposition against Malcolm Fraser and what he has been doing to prop up the privileged and make 95 per cent of the people pay what 5 per cent should be paying, then we should not be in the bloody business of politics if we cannot beat Fraser on that.
Let me turn to the Labor Party's policy statement on 16 February 1983 at the Sydney Opera House. The present Prime Minister made this very categorical statement:
. . . let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.

What a change of heart! Can we trust the present Prime Minister, given those two clear positions? Let me give some background to the taxation Act. In March 1983 the Act was 1,100 pages and now that we have a simpler, fairer tax package we have legislation with another 623 pages. Accountants and lawyers will enjoy those 1723 pages of the new tax arrangements. This year, 1986-87, the Government is going to raise $5m and, in five years time, the Government is going to raise $25m. This is against a background of $44 billion of budgetary revenue in 1982-83. In the present budgetary climate of 1985-86 we have $64 billion worth of revenue being collected by this high spending Labor Government-an increase in three Budgets of $20 billion.

The great danger with the Government's capital gains tax legislation is that once this tax becomes law there will be an irresistible temptation for the Government to change the rules and widen the net. Does anyone in this House seriously believe that the left wing of the Australian Labor Party-the converts to the Prime Minister's call at the Australian Labor Party Conference in 1982 for a platform change to embrace a capital gains tax-will be satisfied with a tax which produces only $5m in its first year; a sum equivalent to only 0.008 of one per cent of the Government's budgeted tax revenues for 1985-86? Even at its zenith, the capital gains tax, as proposed, will generate revenue which will be less than 10 per cent of the income derived from the Federal Government's bank accounts debit tax. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has expressed contempt for the amount of revenue that this tax will produce. Last year he was quoted as saying that, in terms of revenue gained, capital taxes were `peripheral' and `marginal' and could not raise the revenue necessary to fund worthwhile tax cuts.

The precedent that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is proposing to establish with its 3 per cent productivity claim to fund a superannuation program should be noted. The life insurance industry, the superannuation fund managers and actuaries, will tell anyone prepared to listen that 3 per cent will be the thin edge of the wedge for a 3 per cent contribution could not possibly fund a viable superannuation scheme. The message is therefore clear: Once a 3 per cent claim is accepted, employers will later be compelled to increase their contributions progressively to 5 per cent, then 7 per cent, then 9 per cent, and higher. So we can expect a capital gains tax to be expanded to satisfy the continuing demands of the Hawke Government.
In the Australian Tax Review, Mr T. E. Bostock wrote:

Why Australia does not need a capital gains tax. Equality demands no tax be paid on illusory gains, that losses and inflation be taken into account. Secondly, the tax be paid on realised gains only. Thirdly, that the legislation to incorporate this tax will be too complex, and fourthly, the house and household effects should be exempted.
I think the House could accept the summary document in the Economic Planning Advisory Council in its paper No. 9, which sets out the capital gains tax as proposed by the Government:

A tax at full marginal rates on inflation-corrected realised capital gains will be introduced. The tax only applies to assets purchased after 19 September, 1985 and is not payable on the death of the owner. Capital losses are only creditable against capital gains and only nominal capital losses are deductible. There are no rollover provisions. The capital gains tax will allow averaging of gains effectively over a five year period and 20 per cent of the goodwill of new business will be exempt from the tax.

Let us look at some of the factors involved in the new tax. The marginal income tax rate will apply. It will be the toughest in the world by any standards. In the United States of America, where they have some form of capital gains tax with a background of high consumption taxes and lower income tax rates, they reduce the rate of capital gains tax from 35c to 20c, whereas here in Australia we are about to introduce a new tax of this kind. In the UK they have a problem with the inflation index, the problem of the administrative difficulty of determining what would be the inflation rate used in indexing the capital gain. What criterion do they use? In this country the Government's not going to index capital losses. Therefore, a `no-man's area' in the calculation of losses may be reached. I shall quote from the Australian Tax Forum, where the problem is identified in the UK:

The most continuous debate on CGT has centred round its inflation-proofing. With inflation, CGT was taxing nominal gains which could, indeed, represent real losses. After a departmental review, including the publication of a consultative document, Mr Healey, as Chancellor, declined to index the tax but improved the exemption limit. He argued that insulation against inflation could not logically be confined to CGT payers; if they enjoyed it, in principle inflation-proofing ought to be extended to holders of building society and savings bank deposits. But, he said, `We cannot afford to go down this road'-
That is just what will happen in Australia. The article continues:

Sir Geoffrey Howe did not have the same inhibitions. In 1982 he provided for the indexation of the acquisition price of assets provided they had been held for more than one year. However, the provision was not retrospective and applied only to price rises after March 1982.

So, we can see what would happen. If future Labor governments changed the inflation index it would make a major change to the tax gathering potential of this new tax. The measure introduced on 19 September 1985 created two classes of capitalists. Class 1 is those with capital and assets prior to 1985, and class 2 is those who are starting out anew and subject to changing provisions of the new capital gains tax. Obviously this new arrangement has a tendency to lock in previous investments, which was a factor in the recent Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover battle. The new classes of capitalists have no incentive to create new business under the shadow of increasing capital gains taxes. At least there has been some 20 per cent reduction in the `goodwill factor' involved in the capital gain tax in business sales, but this discriminates against anyone starting a new business. Mr Burges, Chairman of the Tax Committee of the Law Council of Australia, had this to say about the goodwill aspect of the tax:

The tax will be very hard on a person who starts up a business from virtually nothing and builds it up to a significant enterprise. On disposal, he will pay tax on the whole of the goodwill component, as he would have no base costs to which the indexation adjustment can be applied. This discourages entrepreneurial effort at the very time it should be encouraged.

In an article published in the Australian on 14 March 1985, Dr Ian Spry, QC, editor of the Australian Tax Review quoted the then recently expressed views of the United States economist, Mr George Gilden, who had this to say:

Regardless of theory, however, the US stock market has just begun to revive after more than a decade when it dropped 50 per cent in value in real terms. More than any other measure, the capital gains costs of 1975 and 1981 were responsible for the revival of US technical and entrepreneurial leadership in the world economy. One economist, Michael Evans, estimates that these tax cuts directly created about two million jobs in the first six quarters of the recovery. Even Francois Mitterand is attempting to create similar venture and new-issue markets in France. For the US to throw aside this superlative asset is foolhardy.
Dr Spry went on to say:
The experience abroad has been that reductions in capital gains taxes-in those countries that have them-has increased investment and employment in critical respects.

Let us now look at a couple of aspects of the Bill. First, I refer to the distortion of the home market by the fact that home owners are exempt from the tax. This will lead to larger dwellings, extensions and renovations being the order of the day. In relation to employee participation in share issues, the Bill will penalise those who wish to take up shares in the companies for which they work. The Government suggests that it is encouraging worker participation, but by this legislation it is positively discouraging it. The provisions in section 160y actively discriminate against contributions to churches, schools and charities, because those contributions will be subject to capital gains tax at marginal rates at the estate level. A short term capital gains tax is covered under section 26aaa, so there is no need for the Government to introduce the new legislation. We will need an army of public servants to interpret, to administer, and to extract the $5m. As one tax expert said: `If we make it simple it will lack fairness; if we make it fair it will lack simplicity'.

In this investment climate, where Simon Crean has been demanding that employers and businessmen make more investments, we have the situation of a capital gains tax being introduced, a 3 per cent superannuation claim is demanded by the unions, a 2.3 per cent wage rise, the highest interest rates for 50 years, and a position where small businessmen and farmers will be discriminated against by the capital gains tax because they will not have the access to capital. On return to government we will repeal this legislation. We will oppose it most vigorously in the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) in this House this morning quoted what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said several years ago. Both those honourable gentlemen failed to quote what the Prime Minister said in his policy speech before the last election. They conveniently did not refer to his speech before that election, and they did that because there was no promise in regard to this tax. The Prime Minister made two promises at the last election in regard to taxation-one that there would be a thorough review of the taxation system, and the second that there would be a taxation summit. Both have occurred. First. there was a taxation summit, and secondly, all of this thorough review has been put before the Australian people. In fact, it has been put before the Australian people for the past 12 months. The draft White Paper was put out 12 months ago, yet the honourable member for Mackeller showed his intellectual deficiency by saying that before he can make a grand speech he needs the appropriate information, that is, the attachments to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously he has not been in this place long enough to read the legislation correctly. It is extraordinary that he is quoting selectively and not putting the facts before the people.

I commend the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) on his speech. Everyone in Australia should have been listening to and should receive a copy of that speech by the honourable member. He touched on every point salient to this debate. I will be sending out copies of that speech to a number of people in my electorate. The draft White Paper on the Reform of the Australian Tax System pointed out:
Australia is virtually unique among OECD countries in having no general capital gains tax.

A 1979 comparative study of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries showed that Australia, Italy and the Netherlands were the only countries that did not have any specific tax on, or any provision to tax, capital gains. It should be remembered also that, of those three countries, the Netherlands has a comprehensive wealth tax which taxes the increased value of individuals' wealth, including their homes. Although it is fair to say that only general comparisons can realistically be drawn between the taxation systems of different OECD member countries, generally capital gains in the hands of individuals are taxed or treated as income in almost every country.

In the countries in which a specific capital gains tax applies, including the United Kingdom, those taxes are relatively recent-mostly they have been introduced since 1960. Other countries incorporate capital gains taxes within their existing income tax structures by declaring that capital gains are to be treated in the same way as other forms of income, subject to varying conditions. Again, many of the OECD member countries added those provisions in the last two decades. It must be pointed out that nearly all member nations have strengthened or increased the provisions of their capital gains tax in the last decade. I move to an examination of the situation applying in the United States-probably the greatest and most extensive free enterprise system in the world-where capital gains legislation dates back to 1913.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back how far?

—That legislation dates back to 1913. I will quote from the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 13 May this year-a newspaper not generally known for its radical left wing views. The article, entitled `Business bears brunt of US tax reforms' and written by Malcolm Maiden in New York, compares the United States and Australian tax reform processes. In a rather lengthy feature article Mr Maiden said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike Australia, which actually had to debate the desirability of a capital gains tax, the US system already embraces capital gains-short and long term.

In Australia, the Government deferred to historically powerful and emotional anti-capital gains tax pressure by introducing a gains tax that applied only to assets acquired after the date of introduction and then only taxing gains above the rate of inflation.
In the US, there will be no real debate about the desirability of capital gains-

I repeat: `There will be no real debate about the desirability of capital gains'. The United States system already embraces a capital gains tax. In fact, people in the United States think that their flat or lower rate of taxation is wonderful because capital gains are taxed at a reduced rate from their normal marginal rates. They think that that lower rate is a concession. However, we have the conservative Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, coming into this Parliament and putting before the people of Australia the suggestion that we should be treating income that is received in capital form as exempt income. Tax avoidance is rife. One of the reasons we have had this massive tax avoidance over the last decade, as the honourable member for Hawker said, is that people were able to take their income in the form of a capital gain and receive tax free exemptions. I return to the Draft White Paper on the Reform of the Australian Tax System which in paragraph 7.6 on page 78 states:

The lack of a general capital gains tax represents a structural defect in the income tax system which lies at the core of many avoidance arrangements; if income can be converted into or dressed up as capital gains, income tax can be avoided completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they want.

—That is what they want. We have heard a nonsensical speech by the honourable member for Mackellar, the Opposition spokesman on economic affairs. He really did not put forward any arguments against the tax at all except that it would blow investment out of the window. What nonsense. This tax is embraced in virtually every other country and in every other OECD member country. However, before the 1980 election the previous Fraser Government, of which the honourable member for Mackellar was a member, put before the Australian people outrageous full page advertisements, trying to frighten them into believing that any incoming Labor government would tax their homes and take their money. It is absolutely outrageous. It is not true now, as honourable members opposite know. That was never the intention. This situation is a little like the situation in, I think, 1977 when Fraser promised tax cuts and six months later took them back. That is the form of conservative governments going back many years.

SPEECH.PARA: No previous government has come to an election and said: `We will not promise anything. We will have a thorough review'. We spent two months saying that during that campaign. We could quite easily have said: `Righto, we will promise this, that or the other'. The result is that the tax package that this Government has been implementing over the last few months, in particular the last few weeks, is all part of an overall tax package. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in this House yesterday-and I have said so on a number of occasions-it is all part of an overall tax package and must be looked on as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's $20m.

—I am glad the honourable member said that. The tax will bring in $5m in the first year-not $5 billion. After five years it will bring in $25m. I am glad the honourable member raised that matter because in the United States in 1983 capital gains tax on individuals raised nearly $US14 billion. In regard to corporations it raised another $US4.75 billion. In 1983 in the United Kingdom the capital gains tax on individuals raised #644m. The capital gains tax on corporations raised #194m. That is what the capital gains tax raised in those two countries. It will raise $5m here. As is stated on page 43 of the attachment to the Treasurer's speech in September last year:

SPEECH.PARA: The restriction of the tax to assets acquired after today, the decision not to deem realisation at death, the exemption for the principal residence and reasonable curtilage, the concessional treatment of personal-use assets including motor vehicles and the taxation of only real capital gains means that, for most taxpayers, the capital gains tax will have little or no impact.

That is the reality. The honourable member knows that that is the reality. In talking about the taxation package overall, let me just list a couple of the items involved: The fringe benefits tax; the entertainment expenses tax; the capital gains tax; the rationalisation of the wholesale tax system; the tax free threshold which goes in the reorganisation of the taxation scales and the taxation cuts; the prescribed payments system; the quarterly provisional tax; the tax concessions for the Australian film industry; the foreign tax credits system; the imputation system of company tax-which honourable members opposite conveniently forget-and the negative gearing and depreciation on residential income-producing buildings. They are just some of the things in the whole taxation package, which we will see as the biggest revolution in taxation in this country. It is the most equitable treatment of taxation by any government in this country. All we have seen from honourable members opposite are scare tactics and screams, as the honourable member for Hawker said. This legislation is long overdue. It is part of the overall tax package and will be thoroughly endorsed by the people of Australia. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that it will be difficult for this Labor Government to agree that there should not be a capital gains tax, because it is totally opposed to the capitalist system that we on this side of the House support-it is the only way that Australia will get back on its feet and the only way that we will get this country going again. Because of his comments, the Treasurer, of course, will go out of office at the next election. He is known for his comments on Australia and for referring to it as a banana republic. I can tell honourable members that the only republics amongst the countries operating in Central America where there are lots of bananas growing, and where this reference came from, are tax-free countries. The Bahamas, for instance, is a tax free country, and that is the only reason it has prospered. It has done damned well being tax free. One does not have to pay these exorbitant taxes for a country to prosper. The tax free countries of the world prosper merely through not having to pay the sorts of ridiculous taxes that we are paying. However, what are we doing in Australia? We are going further and further down the gurgler-`down the hole', as the Treasurer put it. How true that remark was. Down the hole we go, and we will continue to go down the hole after today. This is a black day for the House of Representatives when a new capital tax is being debated in this House. What a ridiculous situation the Government has got this country into.

Nobody is suffering more than small business and farmers in this community. We are the people who must have capital to earn a living-we are not employed by anybody; we have to own capital. We have to have capital to make a living, yet the socialists on the other side of the House want to tax, tax, tax and tax us until we are completely dead. It does not need me to tell honourable members that rural Australia is dead; it has been hounded into the ground by excessive taxation and has nothing left. There is not a dollar left in us-the Government has squeezed it out of us by using oil parity pricing and by way of a number of other costs that this Labor Government has imposed on rural industry since it came to office. I reiterate that list of increased costs to primary industry: Tax averaging withdrawn by the Government, $55m; sales tax imposed on lubricants, $5.6m; removal of tax concessions for land clearing and swamp drainage, $3m; withdrawal of depreciation allowance, $142m; rural adjustment scheme, $27m; sales tax imposed on wine, $15m; petrol products freight subsidy scheme, $27m; export inspection charges, $36m; income equalisation deposits $20m; and so the list goes on.

This list includes the fuel excise on petrol. The current fuel excise on petrol being charged to farmers in this country amounts to $167m. The taxes that the farming community is paying total $440m, yet this Government has the gall to say through the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that it is treating farmers fairly and giving them a fair go. What nonsense! While I am on this subject I will also mention-and I have said this here before-that we are presently exporting no crude oil because of the taxes imposed by the Labor Government by way of the ridiculous parity pricing arrangement that we have here. People wonder why our balance of payments is down the drain.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation we have got ourselves into, and people wonder why we are a banana republic. One does not need to be a genius to work out why. I will point out a few matters in these new Bills that I believe are wrong. Proposed new section 160a defines `asset'. A capital tax is applied to a loan forgiven. A station worker who is given a loan by his employer to buy a car will have to pay a fringe benefits tax on that loan. It will also be assessed as capital and he will have to pay a capital tax on it. Proposed new section 160zs applies to leases and the premiums on leases. The premiums on leases will now be termed capital and a capital gains tax will apply. I particularly direct these remarks to the Treasurer. I only wish that he were present to listen to this debate. TALK.START.PARA: —He is talking to Chipp in his office.

—Yes, that is right. He is talking to Senator Chipp and making deals with the Australian Democrats. I say to the people of Australia that, at the next election, not only the Australian Labor Party but also the Democrats must be thrown out of office. SPEECH.PARA: In regard to proposed new section 160p, I make it perfectly clear that people should not misunderstand the socialists. They have said that no capital gains tax will apply to land which was owned before 20 September 1985. —As the Minister says, one always looks good in comparison. The honourable member for Maranoa is obviously one of those great members of the National Party of Australia who firmly believe in capitalising their profits and socialising their losses.
