SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill represents another important step along the road to restoring morality to the taxation system. Along with the other taxation measures introduced, this Bill aims to restore incentive and investment to productive areas. It will negate the tax evasion which has resulted from diverting income into low yielding capital investments for tax sheltering purposes. The tax will take effect from 20 September 1985, and is totally prospective. In 1987-88, it is expected to yield the modest sum of $5m, rising to $25m in the fifth year of operation. The tax will apply only to real gains on an asset-that is, the amount left over after inflation has been washed out of it. It will be the fairest capital gains tax in the world and is long overdue in Australia.

The tax ensures that, in a capital scarce country like Australia, investment will be directed into productive areas of the economy. We are seeking to encourage business people who are pie makers and not pie slicers. For example, in my State of Queensland, according to the Queensland Retailers Association, investment capital being poured into shopping centres has ensured that shopping outlets are at saturation level. The over-abundance of these centres has caused Queensland to have the highest number of bankruptcies in Australia. In Queensland, superannuation funds have invested in large centres. In particular, the Westfield shopping centre at Indooroopilly was run by one large superannuation fund. Small business operators faced massive overheads as a result. In some instances, in order to repay the capital amount, their rents were based on turnover.

In my electorate, Logan City has seen this proliferation, with many small operators struggling to make a living. In nearby Sunnybank, there are three major shopping centres on each corner of a very busy intersection. The point is that investors have found it easier to purchase land, put their money into retail space and sell it off for a quick capital gain. They are not to blame. There has been every incentive for them to do this. If investment money had been placed into export-oriented manufacturing industry or into high technology, I believe that the Queensland economy would not be suffering from the structural imbalance it is suffering from today. It would also be making a contribution towards reducing the current account deficit problems.

The farmers organisations have had their fears of a capital gains tax allayed. Inter-generational transfer is not affected by the tax. I express my appreciation both to the farmers and to the Government's primary industry, rural and provincial affairs committee. Both groups were instrumental in putting reasoned cases on this matter to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government. I am pleased that the Government has recognised these representations. I notice also that there is provision for five-year averaging for the capital gains tax. This brings the treatment of capital gains even closer to that of other forms of primary producer income, which is consistent with the Government's overall aim in respect of the tax.

Many farmers have expressed concern about the tax and its effects on property values. Studies suggest that agricultural land prices may fluctuate but over the long term do not appear to increase in real terms. There was evidence of a significant real appreciation of land prices in some areas in the late 1970s and early 1980s, especially in the Queensland cane growing areas. There is also evidence that the present lack of liquidity of many farmers is caused by high prices paid for land at that time. To the extent that the expectation of untaxed capital gains contributed to that short term appreciation of land prices, the absence of a tax on real capital gains caused these problems. High land prices, though good for sellers, are bad for land buyers. This includes those who want to remain or become farmers.

At the same time as the Government's White Paper on Taxation was released, many farm leaders were exhorting their members to take to the streets in farm protests. I find it regrettable that many decent, hard-working farmers suffer because of the actions of the fools who lead them. Many of these farm leaders in my own area are card-carrying members of the National Party. Some are more interested in making a political point defending the National Party than they are in standing up for their own farmer members. They say privately to me and to other Government members that the Government is doing everything possible for them, but, publicly, they urge farmers to participate in actions that are against their best interests. Of course farmers are not the only ones being misled by their leaders over these taxes. In Queensland, the whole State is being misled by the aging Queensland Premier, who is urging people to break the law. Once these Bills are passed and become law, I urge the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to have the Premier arrested if he is in contravention of the Crimes Act.

This legislation also relates to a capital gains tax on shares. It is worth recalling that the stock exchange today has seldom been more buoyant; yet investors have known about the tax for eight months. This effectively refutes any suggestion that a capital gains tax would drive investment away. It has always seemed unfair that a person can make a windfall on the stock exchange and not have to pay tax, yet an employee obtaining a wage rise is taxed that very week. An example of windfall profits on the stock exchange is best illustrated by the following case. The person involved was issued with an authority to prospect by a State Minister and, after obtaining the authority, he entered into an agreement with an American company, Gene Goff Pty Ltd, to form a company to acquire the prospecting authority. He agreed to transfer this interest to the new company for a nominal $4 and then to sell 51 per cent of his shares in it for $25,300. There appears to be a deception in the stated $4 nominal value, when the true value was $49,608. The same day this person incorporated a company, Artesian Basin Oil Co. Ltd, in which he was the beneficial owner of all the issued shares and sole director. The following day he requested the State Minister's consent for the transfer of the authority to the company for a consideration of $4. The consent was given.

Five days earlier at a meeting of this person's company at which he was sole director, beneficial owner of all shares, and sole voter, he announced that he was satisfied that the inherent value of the authority was $49,608-not a bad capital gain. It was resolved that the value of authority in the company's books be written up accordingly, that the surplus from this revaluation be placed to the credit of an assets revaluation reserve account and that a dividend of $49,604 be declared payable wholly and exclusively out of the profits and that such dividend be satisfied by the issue of 24,802 fully paid shares of $2 each in the company. This person immediately acquired a beneficial interest in all of these shares-51 per cent of which were transferred to another company he had dealt with. For this he received $25,300 plus a reimbursement of about $2,778-51 per cent of the sum he had spent obtaining the authority to prospect. He retained a 49 per cent interest in his company, called Artesian Basin Oil Co. Ltd.

A few years later, the company's prospecting authority was acquired by Exoil NL. For this this person's company was to receive payment of $500,000 and was granted a royalty of 5 per cent-not a bad capital gain. He received $56,000 for the sale of rights to a new issue of shares. Ten years later, this person held one million 50c shares in Exoil. These were valued in 1968 at $720,000. Thus from the deceit of falsely advertising that he was transferring his interest in the authority to prospect for a nominal consideration, there has flowed to him a windfall gain.

The person concerned is none other, of course, than the Queensland Premier. Members of the Premier's own Party regarded the windfall capital gains as so reprehensible that they urged him to sell his shares in the company. Indeed the current Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing, Mr Hinze, moved a motion at the National Party Conference urging Ministers to refrain from accepting purchasing or dealing with shares in public companies which could be expected to be involved in business with the Government. The Local Government Minister's principled stance was ignored by the Premier. Is it any wonder that as a result Queenslanders have seen a moral decline in the standards of ministerial conduct under the Bjelke-Petersen Government. Nowhere is this more evident than in the constant cloud which hangs over the ministerial conduct of Mr Hinze.

Little wonder that the Queensland Premier's conscience has become so dulled when it comes to the principle of taxation morality enshrined in this Bill. If the current tax measure had been applied to the Premier's company, he would have had to pay a capital gains tax on his windfall gains. He would nevertheless have benefited from lower marginal tax rates, lower rates of company tax and the imputation of his dividends. The Premier should reflect on this before he encourages lawlessness in others with respect to taxation. These measures will restore morality to the tax system. They will encourage investment in productive areas. They will restore equity and they deserve support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to add to the already lengthy and justified criticism of the Government's capital gains tax legislation. Further, I want to draw attention to the fact that the threat of this tax has already had serious effects on the private residential rental market and to the further effects that it will have if the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill become law. Before talking in more detail, I want to draw the attention of the House to the economic climate in which this tax is being introduced. That climate must be of real concern to all Australians. We have an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent, about triple the average of that of our major trading partners. Despite growth in the economy, unemployment remains jammed at about 8 per cent. Youth unemployment, at 23 per cent, is a blight on the Australian social and economic landscape. Interest rates remain at very high levels. For example, the interest rate on new loans for housing is now 15 1/2 per cent, compared with 11 1/2 per cent 18 months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Enough has been said about the Government's broken promises on the capital gains tax, but let me remind the House that it is not only the capital gains tax on which promises have been broken. Time and time again in the lead-up to the last Federal election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) assured the nation that interest rates would come down. I repeat that in the last 18 months interest rates on new home loans have increased by 4 per cent. Uncertainty in our economic situation is also due to our current account imbalance and our ever-increasing overseas debt which is well on target to be $100 billion by our Bicentenary.

Governments in Australia are now taking annually about 44 per cent of our national income. They are choking initiative, stifling incentive, and strangling small business and farmers. As a result of the huge government grab of our national income an investment drought has been created. Private investment in Australia is at disappointingly low levels. I draw the attention of the House to the headlines on page 3 of this morning's Age, which read: `Private investment fall deepens gloom'. The article starts by saying:
Falling investment by private industry during the March quarter added to the pall over Australia's medium to long-term economic outlook . . .

Unless private investment starts to increase before too long we will not have the capacity for further economic growth. In this uncertain economic situation, the Government now proposes to impose a further disincentive to investment. The capital gains tax is the wrong tax at the wrong time. Poor timing is increasingly characteristic of the performance of this Government. What will happen is that the capital gains tax will send the wrong signals to the economic market-place. In the first place, it will slow down investment even further. What additional incentive can there be to make an investment if one knows that one will be taxed on it when that investment is realised? Secondly, whatever funds may be available for investment will tend to be channelled into unproductive areas which do not attract the capital gains tax-for example, the family home. Thirdly, the capital gains tax will reduce the number of entrepreneurs who would turn their ideas, their skills, their drive and their energy into a small business. Who would take the risks associated with those kinds of ventures, knowing that the reward would not be appropriate for the risk taken? We must ask ourselves: Why is the Government introducing this wrong tax at the wrong time? Why is the Government, in the current difficult economic situation, introducing a tax that will further slow investment growth? Why is the Government discriminating against the decreasing number of risk-takers in our community who want to take their chance at exercising their own freedom of choice in our free society?

The Government is introducing this legislation for two main reasons, both of them to fulfil the quite impractical but ideological disposition of its constituencies. It is introducing this tax because the Australian Council of Trade Unions has told the Government it must do so and to placate the restiveness of the left wing of the Caucus. The Government has been warned again and again that the capital gains tax will have a significant and detrimental effect on the private rental market. For example, let me quote what the President of the Real Estate Institute of Australia had to say at the National Taxation Summit in July 1985-nearly a year ago. He said to the Government:
In short, your proposals for a capital gains tax and quarantining negative gearing will attack-and very seriously damage-the private residential market in Australia.
Despite continued warnings of this type, the Government now persists in introducing this punitive taxation measure.

Over the past 20 years there has been a seemingly ever increasing amount of legislation which has had the effect of discouraging landlords from providing residential rental accommodation. The private rental market in Australia has nearly one million units of the total housing stock in the country. Yet over the past 20 years interest rates have climbed steadily; rates, taxes and stamp duties have become extortionate; zoning controls have restricted medium density development, various tenancy legislation has focused on the private rental landlord rather than on protecting tenants in public housing; and now we have the capital gains tax. The result of the threat of this capital gains tax has been a reduction in the construction of new flats around Australia and a reduction in annual investor yield. There are now 156,000 people on the waiting lists for public housing in Australia. The public housing waiting list is growing at nearly 20 per cent a year. At that rate there will be a quarter of a million Australians on the public housing waiting list at the time of our Bicentenary. In fact, we could celebrate those two things together-an overseas debt of $100 billion and a public housing waiting list of a quarter of a million people. What a grand Bicentenary we will have. At a time when public housing waiting lists are increasing, the Government chooses to introduce this punitive taxation measure, which will cause the stock of private rental properties to decrease. As I said, this is the wrong tax at the wrong time.

Furthermore, the threat of this capital gains tax is already having an effect on the private rental market. Vacancy rates in the major cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Perth have come down since the measure was announced. For example, in Perth the vacancy rate in September 1985 was 1.7 per cent and in March 1986 it was 0.5 per cent. Falling vacancy rates have put pressure on rents. Again quoting Perth, the increase in rents from the March quarter of 1985 to the March quarter of1986 was 22 per cent. In Sydney the increase over the same period was 14 per cent. One final figure from Perth deserves mention. In November 1985 the median weekly rent of a three-bedroom house was $84.75 and in March 1986 it was $102. That is an increase of $17.25 a week over four months-an increase at a staggering annual rate of more than 100 per cent.

The threat of this legislation is now turning into stark reality. The capital gains tax will go on to cause a major crisis in private rental accommodation. This crisis will put further pressure on public housing, cause rents to increase with increased hardship for low income earners, and mean a slowdown in the construction of rental accommodation. The Government should be reducing taxes on investment and savings, not increasing them. All the other Western democracies are heading in the direction of taxing consumption and spending and removing taxes on investment and savings. This Government has got its economic policies wrong. We are headed in the wrong direction. The Government should try putting us right and, as a first step, not proceed with the passage of this wrong tax that is being introduced at the wrong time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is an historic occasion in the House of Representatives because we have before us historic legislation-legislation which is long overdue, which is of enormous importance to this nation, and which, I believe, will establish a fair and equitable tax system in this nation for the first time. What we have had for many years is an inequitable system, a system which relies excessively on taxing those who earn their income through wages and not taxing those who earn their income through capital accumulation. In fact, for many years people have been able to make enormous gains-millions of dollars in some cases-through capital accumulation and not pay a single penny of taxation on that accumulation. For many years it has been part of the consistent philosophy of the Australian Labor Party to end this injustice. For the six years that I have been a member of this Parliament--
—What happens in Greece? You tell me what happens in Greece.

—We will talk about Greece later. For the six years that I have been a member of this Parliament we have consistently campaigned to change the situation where capital gains have not been taxed. Our campaign has finally come to fruition with this legislation, which imposes a moderate and fair capital gains tax-in fact, in world terms it is extremely moderate.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been talk from the Opposition about so-called broken promises. Let me make it clear that this talk is dishonest rubbish. The Government has given sections 26(a) and 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act a chance to work. Let me go through the process the Labor Party adopted. In 1982 at the national conference of the Australian Labor Party several people, including the present Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), argued for the introduction of a new capital gains tax. Other people at that conference argued that the Labor Party, on assuming government, should strengthen the provisions of sections 26(a) and 26aaa in order to ensure that these provisions actually worked. That was the intention of the ALP. The Prime Minister made his statement in 1983 that for the term of that Government there would be no new capital gains tax, and we met that obligation. It is nonsense to claim that the Labor Party has been dishonest. What happened when we came into government? We found that not only had there been direct tax evasion through the absence of a capital gains tax, but also there had been massive indirect evasion through the conversion of income into capital gains. Various schemes, including the bottom of the harbour scheme and many others, had been used to convert income into capital gain and thereby avoid the payment of taxation. Not only that, but also we found enormous evidence of distortions in the economy in relation to this matter; distortions in the investment patterns in the economy which lead to insufficient investment in manufacturing industry. Because of those distorted patterns the manufacturing industry, under the previous Government, was virtually destroyed. That is what happened. Between 1980 and 1982 the previous Government virtually destroyed manufacturing industry in this country and we are now having to try to build it up after that absolute destruction. For what the Opposition did to industry, it deserves not to be in government for at least another 30 years.

I turn to what happened in that period. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), after looking at the situation, made the following statement: `It looks as though we will need a more effective capital gains tax'. He made that statement and I also made a statement which was referred to in the newspapers during that period when I was the chairman of the Caucus industry committee. I was quoted in the Australian as saying:

. . . a capital gains tax would have a dramatic effect on manufacturing industry by rechannelling investment funds away from opportunistic speculation gain (for example on land) and towards productive employment-creating investment in industry.

What has happened? When the Government went to the people in December 1984 the Government made no commitment not to introduce a capital gains tax. It did not repeat that commitment. On the contrary, the Government said that it would set up a tax summit, would examine all of the options and would have discussions with all groups in the community to see which taxes ought to be introduced and which taxes were important, not only to ordinary people but also to industry and business. That is what the Government said and of course the Opposition attacked us. The Opposition said at the time: `You will be introducing all kinds of taxes; you will be introducing death duties, capital gains tax and all of those things'. We said: `We will not rule out anything'. As a consequence of that it could be argued that we lost a few votes and a few seats, but we had the courage of our convictions to say to the people that we would examine all options.

When we examined all the options and it became absolutely clear that the existing provisions of section 26a and section 26aaa were not working, it became necessary to introduce a new capital gains tax. In fact, that came out of the determinations of the National Taxation Summit. Therefore, it is wrong for the Opposition to say that there was no consensus at the Summit on that matter-of course there was. Indeed, business leaders agreed with the importance of a capital gains tax in order to get rid of the distortions in the economy. I make it perfectly clear that the argument by the Opposition that the Government has been dishonest on this matter is rubbish. The Labor Party has tried everything it can to work within the existing provisions.

The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), came into this House and presented an incoherent set of arguments. He said on the one hand that there are fundamental and important economic reasons for introducing a capital gains tax. Then he said that it could be done under the existing legislation. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition's experience in government and our experience in government has shown that it cannot be done; that schemes are created which get around the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Therefore, it is nonsense to claim that we can have the economic benefits of the tax and hold on to the existing legislation. We cannot. The honourable member for Mackellar cannot have it both ways. If he agrees that there are important economic reasons, as there clearly are, for the introduction of the capital gains tax, he ought to have the courage of his convictions and ought to support the legislation going through this House today.

No economy can survive on distorted patterns of investment of the kind which have been introduced over many years because of the absence of a capital gains tax. We are in a very difficult position in this nation because of insufficient investment and manufacturing industry. I put it to many people here that speculative investment of the kind that has taken place, whereby people have been overworking their brains to think of schemes to get around the tax laws, would not have taken place and we would not be in the difficulty in which we are now if provisions had been made within the tax laws to have a capital gains tax.

The introduction of a capital gains tax will have enormous benefit for this nation. It is a fair tax which excludes the family home and certain personal assets. It will not apply to any property which people owned in September last year when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense, and you know it.

—It is not nonsense. It does not apply to that property; it applies only after property has been sold. The tax will be introduced at an extremely slow pace over many years. The arguments of the Opposition have been mistaken. We need this tax, and this legislation will make for a fairer and more equitable system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. This seems to be the fourth or fifth time I have been scheduled to speak in between the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). The honourable member for Calwell demonstrated that he has certainly never known anything about economics, and I am sure that the honourable member for Charlton will demonstrate in a little while that he has forgotten everything he knew.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address a few of the myths that are currently running in this debate. The first myth we should address is the myth propagated that the tax cuts are somehow dependent upon the passing of this taxation package which we have been discussing today, yesterday and over the past few weeks. In fact, the tax cuts which have been promised-although we are yet to see them-by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) represent approximately $2 billion in the 1986-87 tax year and approximately $4.5 billion in 1987-88. This group of taxes will raise approximately $400m in 1986-87 and approximately $650m in 1987-88. In other words, we are talking about $1 in $5 in 1986-87 and $1 in $8 being raised in 1987-88.

The real truth of the matter is that this Government has been spending far too much. In the seven years of the Fraser Government, Budget outlays increased by an average of approximately 2.1 per cent in real terms per year. In the three years of this Government, under this Treasurer, the equivalent rate of increase, after inflation, in the annual outlays of government has been 4.8 per cent. Had the Treasurer been able to maintain the spending limits on his spending Ministers, such as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, and had he been able to maintain a simple 2.1 per cent increase in real terms over the last three years, in the last two years he would have been able to reduce the Budget deficit by $5.3 billion. He would have been able to produce a Budget surplus if he had been as good as the Fraser-Howard Government at controlling spending. Alternatively, he could have maintained the deficit he has and he could have introduced this year all of the tax cuts he has promised for 1987-88, without affecting the financial position of the Government at all. In other words, had he been able to control his spending Ministers we would have had the tax cuts now that are promised for 1987-88 and would not have had one significant difference in the Budget deficit. Of course, he could have had a combination of a deficit cut and lower taxes.

In fact, the myth that the Treasurer has been propagating reminds me of the $9.6 billion deficit myth that was put forward just after the Labor Government was elected in 1983. There was never any $9.6 billion deficit. In fact, it is this Treasurer who has introduced the highest deficits that Australia has ever seen. He has brought down three Budgets and they have contained the three highest deficits that this country has ever had. I know it is dangerous to do so, but I will make an economic prediction to the honourable member for Charlton. I guarantee that when the Treasurer brings down his fourth Budget in August this year he will go for four out of four-four Budgets and the four highest deficits that this country has had.
The Treasurer made the following statement in his second reading speech:
Australia is a capital scarce nation.

How true that is. With this in mind, it is absolutely incredible that the Treasurer should actually use this capital gains tax Bill to start to tax capital. He put a tax on capital accumulation. He will put a tax on the accumulation of capital stock in this country. In other words, the response to our being capital scarce is to tax capital accumulation. Let us look at the record of capital accumulation in Australia in the last decade or so. In 1971, private business investment in Australia peaked just before the election of the last Labor Government. During that period of the Whitlam Labor Government what happened? Business investment in Australia absolutely plummeted. It was not until the Fraser Government was re-elected that investment stabilised, and, in fact, under the treasurership of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), business investment began to increase.

What has happened now? Under this Hawke-Keating-Crean-Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions Government, or whatever, business investment has again plummeted. This fact is confirmed in the statements of the Government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council. Why has investment plummeted? It is because this Government has destroyed incentive to invest in Australia. This high taxing Government has gone back to a policy of high inflation. Also, and very importantly, the former head of the ACTU, now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), helped in the Whitlam period and in the Fraser period to destroy the cost competitiveness of Australia. Manufacturing costs rose in Australia and business investment plummeted. Of course, the present Treasurer learned well in that period. He was, after all, a member of and a Minister, albeit for a brief period, in the Whitlam Labor Government. He learned to be a high taxing, high spending, high deficit Treasurer as a member of that high deficit Government.

We need to be encouraging capital formation in Australia. We need to be increasing the after tax return on capital in Australia. Instead, this Government is moving in the opposite direction. The Treasurer will argue-I am sure that the honourable member for Charlton will argue-that the after tax return will be increased by the proposed taxation cuts. Let us examine this argument just for a moment. Income tax paid on average weekly earnings will actually rise, even after the tax cuts are introduced. It will rise from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings to 24.5 per cent. Professor Michael Porter who, with his colleagues at the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University, has done a lot of research in this area, stated:

In 1987-88, when the new 24-29-40-49 rate scale is fully in operation, around half of all taxpayers will face marginal rates of 40 per cent or more. Unless further action is taken, this percentage will increase thereafter by around 4 per cent of taxpayers annually. Further reform of the income tax rate scale will be needed by the late 1980s.
In the limited time available to me I would like to address a final myth which is contained in the Treasurer's second reading speech. He stated:

The tax will apply only to capital gains realised on assets acquired after 19 September 1985. Accordingly, assets acquired by taxpayers on or prior to that date will be exempt from the tax when disposed of by them. This will substantially reduce the immediate impact of the tax and allow the community a lengthy period in which to adjust to its application.

The Treasurer is either an economic illiterate or someone who is prone to bending the truth to suit his own purposes. The facts are that the imposition of a capital gains tax has already impacted on everyone who owns an asset which is potentially subject to this tax. The price of an asset is determined by the current demand and supply and, just as importantly, the future expectations regarding the after tax rate of return on that asset. The imposition of the capital gains tax on future purchases and the subsequent selling of these assets will drive down the after tax returns and thus it will drive down the current value of those assets. Ask anyone who intends to buy a small business or a farm whether he would be willing to pay the same price for that business or farm after 19 September last year as he would have been willing to pay before 19 September last year. The answer will obviously be no.

Who have actually been hurt by the imposition of this tax? Obviously they have been the current owners of assets. These are the people who have suffered the losses. The Treasurer is trying to fool the average Australian that it is only future generations-we have a few members of the younger generation in the gallery at the moment-who will be affected. The truth is that the present owners of capital assets, the owners of small businesses or small farms are also losers. Contrary to the incorrect assertion by the Treasurer, the majority of Australians owning assets not exempted from the capital gains tax already have been impacted by the imposition of it. Any person who owns personal assets of $5,000 or more, except for his house, is affected.

While the points briefly noted are important for the current holders of capital assets, it is perhaps the future negative implications which are even more important to Australia's future development. This tax will undoubtedly help inhibit capital accumulation in Australia. This tax has been introduced at a time when net apparent capital inflow into Australia is falling. In 1984-85, the net capital inflow was some $550m less than it was in the previous year. Net capital inflow seemed to have fallen even further by the end of the last calendar year.

The imposition of a capital gains tax will inhibit entrepreneurs going into high risk ventures. This will particularly apply in instances where there is a low capital money base and where the predominant asset or future asset of the venture is goodwill. Eighty per cent of the growth in goodwill will now be subject to the tax and this will affect the vast range of small manufacturing businesses, professional firms and, of course, some firms in the new high technology areas. The discouragement of entrepreneurship and risk taking in these areas is diametrically opposed to Australia's long term interests. Eventually it will lead to lower rates of growth and will thus lead to lower relative living standards, higher unemployment and, unfortunately, a further decline in Australia's international competitive position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, members of the Opposition have been extremely strong on rhetoric and extremely lacking in substance. I would like to go into some of the details of the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. However, because of the time constraint, obviously this will not be possible. I would like to refer members of parliament and members of the community generally to the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 19 September last year, to the booklet which accompanied that statement and to the second reading speech that the Treasurer made in introducing this legislation, because both of these statements and the accompanying explanation in the booklet give the lie very clearly to a lot of the absurd propositions that have been put by members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The person leading for the Opposition in this debate, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), made a fairly emphatic statement that the Opposition would not only oppose this legislation but also repeal it. I would like to ask honourable members opposite why they have not already repealed section 26 (a) and section 26aaa in the existing taxation Act, which deal precisely with this same sort of area. Section 26 (a), from the early 1930s, and section 26aaa, from the early 1970s, were supposed to address the question of profits being made on capital gains. Honourable members opposite have made no declaration to repeal those sections of the Act because those sections have never worked. Of course, that is the sort of taxation legislation that they have been most comfortable with. They have deliberately engineered and orchestrated a situation in Australia where taxation provisions would not work if those taxation provisions were directed against their members, their benefactors and their supporters. But, of course, they have always been most concerned to make sure that the taxation provisions against the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers, the ordinary wage and salary earners, operate most efficiently.

I just want to draw attention to a point of contrast between these cynical members of the Opposition and some of the Young Liberals, some of those young idealists who have found themselves attracted to the great concepts of liberalism and who believe, in their misguided way, that perhaps there may be some sort of expression given to those great principles of liberalism through that party which masquerades as the Liberal Party of Australia. What have the Young Liberals said about the capital gains tax? I am sure that the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) would, on occasions, have given a great deal of encouragement to these young people. He may have advised them; he may even have advised them on this question. Early last year, the Young Liberals, at the Young Liberal Movement convention, voted overwhelmingly to support a capital gains tax. They are the young idealists of the Liberal movement in Australia. They are not the cynical people who sit on the Opposition benches at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not been corrupted.

—As is suggested by the honourable member for Chifley, they are the young people who have not yet been corrupted. I wonder how long it will take them to wake up. I wonder how long it will take them to realise that those people who masquerade as the guardians, the advancers of small `l' liberalism in Australia are nothing of the kind. What did these Young Liberals, these young idealists, say? The successful motion which was moved by Mr Darrell Williams stated that if a new or wider capital gains tax is introduced people's homes should be exempt, gains through inflation should be excluded and capital losses deductible. Let me say to Mr Williams if he is tuned in: Join us, Mr Williams. Join us, sir, because that is what we have done. Mr Williams's motion stated that the tax should be levied only when a gain was realised-join us, Mr Williams-but that the gains should only be liable on property bought after the tax was introduced. Join us, Mr Williams, because those are our provisions. He said that gains below a certain amount should be exempt and the exemption should apply to all property of a purely personal nature. Join us, Mr Williams. That is one of the provisions of our legislation. He said that the revenue raised--
—Who is Mr Williams?

—Honourable members opposite ask: `Who is Mr Williams?'. That is the amount of respect and regard that they have for the young people in the Liberal movement. Honourable members opposite ask: `Who is this Mr Williams?'.
—Andrew used to be an idealist like that.

—Fortunately we still have our great idealists within the Labor movement. Mr Williams's motion stated that the revenue raised should be more than the administrative cost of collection so it could be used-I ask honourable members to listen to this-to provide tax relief in other areas. Join us, Mr Williams. That is precisely what we propose to do.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested by members of the Opposition benches, as part of their rhetoric, as part of their deliberate attempt to misrepresent and to mislead the Australian people, that this is tough legislation. In fact, the honourable member for Mackellar went so far as to say that, not only was it tough legislation but also it was the toughest capital gains tax anywhere in the world. Let us just examine whether the legislation introduces a tough capital gains tax. In the first year of its operation it will raise $5m out of a total Commonwealth revenue of $60,000m and five years down the track it will be raising the enormous amount of $25m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you bringing it in?

—Let me give the fundamental reason why we have introduced this legislation. It is not for revenue purposes but to make sure that all those distortions in the investment pattern in Australia which were being encouraged by the absence of a successful capital gains tax would be lifted out of the system. That was reason No. 1. In future people will know that there is no sense in them putting their investments into purely speculative areas. In future they may be encouraged to put their investment into productive areas. When they do that they will be making a great contribution to the future development of Australia. So that was purpose No. 1.

SPEECH.PARA: Purpose No. 2 was to make it possible for this Government to honour that commitment which it quite clearly made to the Australian people on a number of occasions-a commitment which was so emphatically and so repeatedly endorsed by the Australian people-that when we got into government all those ramps and rorts, all the lurks and perks and all the abuses of the taxation system which those people on the Opposition benches had built into the system, which they had consolidated into the system, which they had entrenched into the system and which they had institutionalised into the system, would be hauled out. We undertook to lift them all out and we are in the process of doing precisely that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they do not like it.

—As my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Hunter has said, they do not like it. I will tell the House why they do not like it. It is because most of those people who benefitted from the system, the rorts and the ramps, the lurks and the perks and the rip-offs in the past have been themselves, or their members, or their benefactors, or their supporters. Whenever they introduced tax legislation in this chamber they had to be dragged in here to put it into place.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I seek your guidance in this matter. As I understood it, the honourable member accused members on this side of the House of being rorters and ripping off the tax system. As I understand it, that casts a very serious reflection on honourable members on this side of the House and I ask that those words be withdrawn.
—The honourable member for McPherson takes offence at the use of those words.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Hansard greens will show that no such accusation was made. As the honourable member knows, he is simply trying to use my time because honourable members opposite are very sensitive about these issues. I have been allocated 10 minutes and if the honourable member continues to use my time I will take 15 minutes and I will compensate for any amount of my time which he wastes.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the words, as I understood them, were that people on this side of the House were rorters of the tax system. I ask that those words be withdrawn.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, no such claim was made as the Hansard greens will indicate.
—My recollection was that the words were of general application. If the honourable member takes personal offence I think he is entitled to ask for a withdrawal.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that that is quite contrary to previous practice in this chamber. If a general claim of that kind is made either against the Government or against the Opposition, no individual member can claim to have been personally upset-as he is not-or to have been personally misrepresented. Mr Deputy Speaker, I appeal to you to apply the practices of the chamber on this occasion as they have traditionally been applied in the past.

—My understanding is that if a member is personally upset at an allegation he can ask for an allegation in relation to himself to be withdrawn. I think it might speed the process if that practice is followed.

—The honourable member is just wasting time. Whatever it is that is upsetting him is withdrawn. I said that the other reason why this legislation was introduced was to ensure that all those people who have been ripping off the system would not be able to use the recourse of capital gains in order to avoid their taxation responsibilities. Of course, the overwhelming majority of my constituents who earn their income in the form of a taxable wage or salary know that now, as a result of this legislation, all the rip-off merchants in the community, who have been protected by honourable members opposite, will no longer be able to operate with the sort of impunity they had under honourable members opposite. We undertook to lift out the rorts and the ramps, and we are going to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider whether honourable members on the Opposition benches speak for the Australian business community. First, I refer to the Business Council of Australia, which is an organisation of some conscience. The Business Council of Australia is a legitimate, honest organisation of integrity. When the Business Council of Australia speaks I think we can listen to it with some degree of confidence. I wish we could say the same for the political expression of conservatism in Australia-those people who, as I say, masquerade as defenders, supporters, protectors and promoters of honest business men and women and an honest business community. Of course, they do nothing of the kind. They have found themselves out of step on so many occasions that the Australian people have rejected them and will continue to reject them. The Business Council of Australia in its submission to the Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council, in connection with capital gains taxes, said:

A system such as the present one, which taxes interest receipts and largely exempts capital gains encourages individuals to shift funds from interest income assets to assets where most of the income appears as capital gains.

In other words, what they are saying is that the absence of a capital gains tax encourages investment funds to flow into land and property rather than into more productive areas. This not only drives up land and property values--

TALK.START.PARA: —Prices are down.

—The honourable member for Maranoa knows that as a result of all the speculation in land in Australia people who are operating farms have been very seriously disadvantaged. Perhaps the honourable member might adopt a more responsible attitude in this chamber. The honourable member knows, as do all the rest of the honourable members in cockies' corner, that the speculators coming in, because of the opportunity for them to make non-taxed capital gains, has not only seriously distorted the pattern of investment in rural Australia but has also very seriously disadvantaged all the people whom those in cockies' corner claim they represent. Of course they do not represent them. They are just as honest and have the same level of integrity as those who sit on the Liberal benches. We know that they are all tarred with the same brush. The failed book- keepers who declare themselves to be professional accountants, the failed businessmen who see themselves as pillars of industry-all those people who have congregated over there on the Liberal benches-have adopted a certain position. What is the alternative position adopted by some people in Australia who do qualify to be called captains of industry-people of integrity, people of substance and competence, people who are providing a lot of the engine work for Australian industry? I refer to people such as Bryan Kelman and Alan Coates. In relation to the taxation system, Bryan Kelman, Managing Director of CSR Limited, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia must have proper and sensible safeguards, including--
