DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION FUNDING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) condemns the Government for lowering CSIRO's funds for continuing research by $9 million, and
(2) calls on the Government to take a more constructive approach to science and technology to ensure the continued effectiveness of our vital scientific institutions.

I advise the House that I will be assisted in this debate by the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who will second the motion, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), all of whom have a strong interest in the vital role of science in the future development of this nation. But by way of introducing the subject, I feel bound to comment that no corporation would accept a situation where a notice of motion for general business could be made on 22 February 1985 and not be debated until 8 May 1986, almost 15 months later. At the time that I gave notice of that motion, the matter of a $9m cut in research expenditure for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in the 1984-85 Budget was a burning issue which needed to be debated at that time, not today, 15 months later. Indeed, it became such a contentious and discussed subject that in October 1984 the CSIRO and the Department of Finance formed a joint working party to examine and report on, inter alia, the interpretation of the 1984-85 budgetary outlays to the CSIRO. That joint working party reported in March 1985. It was then that the CSIRO appropriation should have been fully debated, by way of this motion. Unfortunately it was not. Regrettably for the CSIRO, the continuing mismanagement by this Government of its research policies has permitted the unsatisfactory circumstances of 1984-85 to persist to this day.

My motion, therefore, is not only still appropriate-it is now a matter of some importance that the Government's handling of the CSIRO in particular, and science in general, should be debated by this House. There will be those on the Government benches who will argue that there was not a cut in funding of 3.2 per cent, or $9.2m, to the CSIRO in 1984-85. They will undoubtedly argue that the joint working party agreed that, rather than suffer a cut, the CSIRO received an increase of 6.6 per cent in Government funding in that year. But it is clear how the joint working party achieved this miraculous turnabout. It simply identified so-called non-recurring expenditure and deleted this from the appropriated expenditure. The ground for doing that was apparently that one-off expenditures distorted annual figures and prevented a proper comparison from year to year. Yet the report itself throws into doubt the value of that adjustment by admitting, at paragraph 3.4, that a major difficulty lies in identifying non-recurring expenditure. Despite that admission, the joint working party selected one of several options and proceeded to make its adjustments. The alleged 6.6 per cent increase in funding is the net result of that calculation.

Even if one were to accept this managed increase of 6.6 per cent-and I certainly do not-the fact remains that the adjusted dollar increase represents zero increase in real terms, after allowance is made for inflation. This manipulation of financial data is a crude attempt to hide the unarguable fact that, without such an adjustment for so-called non-recurring expenditure, the joint working party report confirms that the net appropriated expenditure for the CSIRO was $9.2m less in 1984-85 than it was in the previous year. It is there in the report. It is not imagined. It did not go away simply by an application of the financial wizardry of the Department of Finance. It is real and had a real and adverse effect on the CSIRO, an impact that in turn forced a cut in the research programs of that body. Let me quote from the organisation's annual report:

CSIRO's Budget allocation provided no additional funds to meet increased operating costs in 1983-84 and 1984-85 and insufficient funds were provided to cover the full costs of the Government directed Repairs and Maintenance and Occupational Health and Safety Program in 1984-85, thereby requiring the CSIRO Executive to cut programs.

These cuts amounted to 3 per cent in real terms. Let me emphasise that. The effect of the Government's 1984-85 appropriations was to cut the research programs of the CSIRO by 3 per cent in real terms. So much for its concern for the continuing effectiveness of Australia's most important scientific institution. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who is at the table, talks long and hard, writes lots of articles and is quoted frequently as saying how strongly he supports Australia's research efforts. What have been the effects of his strong support-a 3 per cent cut in real terms in the research programs of the CSIRO? The Government has attempted to deceive Australians by rearranging the financial facts to suit its own needs. The CSIRO's Executive was left to manage the task of spreading fewer dollars in such a way as to continue an effective commitment to its many research projects. How did it do this? Dr Wild, the then Chairman of the CSIRO, said:

The CSIRO Executive decided to exempt certain areas of research from cuts because they are identified by CSIRO, Government and industry as of the highest national priority. These are: Information technology, manufacturing technology, biotechnology, advanced materials, oceanography, soils and water, and plant pathology.

These areas represent about 20 per cent of CSIRO's research. The other 80 per cent will suffer staff cuts and serious reductions averaging 4.3 per cent in real term funding. If some are to be protected others must have less.

What really dismays me is that the last Budget isfurther evidence that, electorally, science and technology count for almost nothing in Australia. With that disregard we, the Australian community, are imperilling the future health and well-being of our nation and sliding into Third World nationhood.
Imagine that-sliding into Third World nationhood!

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a familiar ring about it.

—Yes, it has a very similar ring about it. It reminds me very abruptly of the Treasurer's (Mr Keating) recent statement about banana republics. Here is Dr Wild, the then Chairman of the CSIRO, giving him the nod a little in advance. That was the real world that had to be faced by Dr Wild, the Executive and the research scientists, technicians and other staff working on those programs-a 4.3 per cent cut in real term funding. The Minister at the table has had the effrontery over these many months to say that he strongly supports the scientific effort of Australians and to tell us how well he is doing in protecting them in this regard. How many honourable members on the Government benches can recall support being given to that research community by the Minister for Science during those difficult times? What did he say in the course of the post-1984-85 Budget National Science Forum? He said in response to a question:

SPEECH.PARA: I have often said to people in the scientific and academic community-`You are the wimpiest collection of lobbyists imaginable. You should recall Archimedes and the lever'. Archimedes has obviously had very little impact on Australia. Scientists never apply any kind of leverage.

That was not the most constructive or supportive advice to give that community after it had had to face a 3 per cent cut, in real terms, in research programs. The Minister was brave enough to return to the same forum after the 1985-86 Budget was presented, and admit:
The 1985-86 science budget will attract a higher degree of support than last year's and should be a factor in raising the current level of morale among scientists and research workers.

What did the Government do in that Budget to lift the admitted low morale of that institution? Not much by my reckoning, or by any reckoning. I refer to the official explanatory notes on CSIRO's Estimates of Expenditure for 1985-86. These are based on the same manipulatory formula as was used by the 1984-85 joint working party and thereby allow a precise comparison of the two years of funding to be made. We find that there is a net expenditure increase, from all sources, of 7.1 per cent in 1985-86. This is less than the Government's own foreshadowed inflation rate for 1985-86, a rate which we now know erred on the conservative side, as the mismanagement by this Government took Australia's actual inflation rate to its present annual level of 9.2 per cent, and rising. So the CSIRO has again suffered a cut in real terms. If that were not serious enough, I have closely examined the detailed figures contained in this 1985-86 estimates document and have discovered just what this deplorable situation will mean for the CSIRO's ongoing research programs. Of the 10 research programs identified in table 1 of those estimates, only four areas have enjoyed total funding dollar increases that have been in excess of the inflation rate. That is to say, only four program areas enjoyed an increase in real terms in 1985-86, and that after even more serious cutbacks had occurred in the previous year.

One of the four areas which did enjoy a real increase in funding was that of CSIRONET, which has been the subject of considerable media publicity in recent weeks-publicity which suggests that the $8m Cyber 205 super computer is largely idle and is operating at a substantial loss. Further, if my research is correct, those Estimates show that the largest areas of increased funding are directed to CSIRO's headquarters-to its bureaucracy-and to salaries and allowances. The poor relations in this formula are research equipment and operational expenditures. They are almost starved of worthwhile additional funds. This is in turn reflected in declining staff resources. The Estimates show that as at 30 June 1983 7,341 staff were employed by CSIRO. By 30 June 1984 this had fallen to 7,275. One year later it had fallen to 7,195. The critical area of research scientist and other professionals is virtually static in terms of numbers, while technical staff have been seriously reduced in each of those three years. That is not exactly a picture of a dynamic scientific institution which is being constructively reshaped into a form suitable to fulfil its first five-year strategic plan, covering the period 1985 to 1990.

Mr Deputy Speaker, effective and productive research is clearly an amalgam of dedicated scientists backed by the necessary equipment and facilities. This Government has obviously got its chemistry all wrong. It is allowing valuable staff resources to waste away while those who remain are being starved of the hardware essential to match their dedication and true potential. This seems hard to accept in the face of so much rhetoric from this Government, and this Minister in particular, about the importance of science and the priority it holds as the basis of Australia's future industrial development. That bastion of refreshing forthrightness, from time to time, the Minister for Science, has in fact publicly revealed the answer to the contradiction. `Science is important', he says, `but the Government is not going to pay for it-private enterprise is'. I quote from the Minister's statement to this House when tabling the CSIRO's 1984-85 annual report:
The amount of tactical research CSIRO will carry out will depend largely on industry's willingness to pay for it.

Just consider what the CSIRO and its staff have been subjected to over recent years. The period of change began with the Birch inquiry of 1977-78. That was the catalyst for much orderly and effective reviewing of CSIRO's functions over the ensuing years. To give just one example, a review of CSIRO's commercial practices and policies was initiated by the coalition Government in 1982-83, with the aim of ensuring that they were effective in promoting industrial applications. The outcome was the establishment, jointly by the CSIRO and other parties, of SIROTECH Ltd, whose principal objective was to provide a business-oriented approach to commercialising CSIRO- generated technology. The point I am making is that the CSIRO was well aware in the late 1970s and early 1980s of the rapidly changing environment for research in Australia and had taken the initiative in responding to those changing demands long before the election of the Hawke Government occurred in 1983. The naivety of this Government was reflected in a frantic series of reviews and inquiries immediately after coming to power. They continue to this day. This is a classic case of a steroid science policy, one which can generate prodigious effort but be artificially stimulating and capable of doing immeasurable harm to the parent body. Many in the CSIRO would endorse that sentiment and even suggest that the political and public debate about the CSIRO has gone far beyond its most productive point. For example, the Chairman said in the CSIRO's annual report:
But public debate can harm the best interests of the country when it is ill-informed and excessively partisan. I think this danger has existed in the debate about Australia's science and technology.
In what might be regarded as a cautious acknowledgement to those who hold the purse strings, the Chairman added:
But I am pleased to sense that the debate has now reached a better informed and constructive stage.
Having offered a conciliatory tone the Chairman concluded his report with an undisguised plea for an end to the frenetic years of examination, re-examination and cross-examination:

The road we have travelled has been mainly uphill and the hope for my successor is that the gradient may now ease-for what the Organisation needs is a period of consolidation, stability and untroubled creativity.

I endorse those sentiments totally. Finally, I ask Government supporters to reflect on what that sort of thing does to the CSIRO community. The Minister himself referred to poor morale in 1984-85. I would believe that this has continued into 1985-86. I feel great sympathy for the situation of the people of the CSIRO. They have suffered two years of funding cuts, in real terms. They are starved of much of the equipment and facilities that they need to produce first class results and are subjected to so many reviews, inquiries and task forces that they have every right to feel beleaguered. The institution is not growing. It is under political siege with reduced real dollar funding and a slow erosion of staff resources. There is nothing in the Government's management of the CSIRO to reassure us that the Government has either the ability or sincerity to take Australia's premier research institution into the twentieth century. The CSIRO research community is not suffering from what the Minister described as wimpiness. It is suffering from a surfeit of political interference and parsimonious Government funding. It has an expectation that the Australian inquiry will not only avail itself of this facility, but will do so to a timetable and with a financial commitment that will meet a planning strategy largely determined by a politician.

As my motion suggests, I implore the Government, in the interests of this nation, to take a more constructive approach to science and technology in order to ensure the continued effectiveness of our vital scientific institutions. One of the ways in which it could do this, one of the ways in which we could demonstrate a real interest in science and technology, would be to set up a joint standing committee of this Parliament to look, on a continuing basis, at our science and technology. Then more people and members of this Parliament could be better informed of the situation relating to science and technology throughout the nation. I appeal to the Government to get its hands off the CSIRO, to give to that organisation the sinews of war and to enable the CSIRO to do the job which it is so eminently capable of doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I welcome this motion by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) which was placed on the Notice Paper, as he said, as far back as 22 February 1985. After 15 months it is a period piece. The mover was then the shadow Minister for Science and we had recently passed through what was the toughest budget for science in living memory. I now have my third shadow Minister, somebody in the Senate. The Opposition has no science spokesman at all in this House. That is a telling indication of how seriously the Liberals and the Nationals take science issues. We have not even had the draft science policy leaked to us-another serious indication of lack of concern. Perhaps none has been drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the 1984-85 Budget the then shadow Minister, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) engaged in what was, compared to the catatonic state of his colleagues, an absolute frenzy of activity-three questions in the House, two short speeches on the Budget and one speech on a computer bounty Bill-that is all. We also had, in 1985-86, a Budget which was very much better for the Department of Science, which came in the top half of the 28 departments in increased allocations. This was universally applauded. Oppositions are in a strong position to determine the political agenda for debate in the House. The rising degree of media coverage reflects heightened community interest in science and science-related issues but it has not been followed up by this sluggish and ill-informed Opposition. I await eagerly my first Opposition question in this Parliament on science issues. There has been no motion of public importance on science since my time as shadow Minister. Science is not, I regret to say, part of our political culture; I wish it were. We are getting there, but very slowly, and I welcome this debate.

Back in 1982 I made five predictions to the Royal Australian Chemical Institute in Canberra: That Labor would win the next election; that we would inherit a budgetary shambles; that our science and technology policies would attract broad support; that competing priorities in welfare and other sensitive political issues at a time of budget stringency would restrict our ability to find new money for research; and that there would be a backlash from the research community. All five predictions came true, but prophets are notoriously without honour. The first point in today's motion, one that has been superseded by events, can be disposed of briefly. Perhaps the honourable member for Berowra could pass it on to the honourable member for Warringah, who is no longer with us. In 1984-85 there was perceived to be a $9m cut overall in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation but the figure is misleading. Originally it was made up of $2.7m, which Cabinet had directed was to be devoted to extra spending on repairs and maintenance, of $1.4m to cover inadequate provision for salary related costs and of $4.7m related to a lack of cost increases in operating funds. The CSIRO was later released from the $2.7m related to repairs and maintenance. A fundamental disagreement between CSIRO and the Department of Finance about the interpretation of its Budget allocation was subsequently resolved by a joint working party, as the honourable member of Warringah has said. As a result of the new formula, CSIRO in 1984-85 had a dollar increase for ongoing activity of 5.8 per cent, a figure which meant a real increase of 1.5 per cent, given the increase in the consumer price index of 4.3 per cent-a disappointing figure, as I freely conceded at the time-but in the overall context of the Budget it was realistic and CSIRO was able to adjust accordingly.

There are a couple of problems to which I should allude. The first is Cyber 205, a super computer-the most powerful in the world south of Texas-in that it is seriously under-used. The previous computer in this range, the Cyber 76, was fully utilised and the belief was that when upgrading occurred from the 76 to the 205 the former users would upgrade as well. Considerable extra expenditure on software is required, also considerable rethinking about what one can do with the super computer capability. Many of the potential users have not upgraded their software capacity. They have not made that quantum leap nor, I must report, have government departments, and eager users in the academic world cannot pay for Cyber 205. At the moment we are working out the best solution to the problem. I hope in the course of the next few weeks to be able to make an announcement which will satisfy everybody. The completion of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory, ANAHL, or AAHL, as it is now more euphoniously called, led to a reduction in the amount provided to CSIRO for capital works as well. I do not need, I think, to restate but will say anyway, that I am very deeply committed to CSIRO and am its very strong defender.

The second point addressed by the motion, one that is of continuing relevance, calls on the Government `to take a more constructive approach to science and technology to ensure the continued effectiveness of our vital scientific institutions'. This is being done and will be done even more. In the Australian Labor Party's science and technology policy for 1982 I made a point that has been made even more effectively in recent weeks by Senator Button and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-that there are alarming structural weaknesses in the Australian economy and that science and technology could play a major role in upgrading our performance. We promised that:

Labor would increase Australia's total investment in research and development by 100 per cent over a five-year period, on the basis that industry itself will contribute virtually all the increase and that appropriate economic incentives should be worked out in collaboration with industry.

This is well on track. I am amazed at my own moderation. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures of Tuesday last concerning private sector investment in research and development indicate that in 1984-85, for the first time in many years, there was a change in direction-not enough, but at least a change. There was a 36.3 per cent rise in person hours devoted to research and development and an actual expenditure rise of 51 per cent. The 1985-86 year will be far better, and 1986-87 better again, thanks to the 150 per cent research and development tax incentive. We promised that spending on scientific research in Antarctica would increase by 300 per cent over a three-year period. We have achieved that-just-in dollar terms, by accomplishing a rise of 313 per cent. An increase in real terms will have to wait but we can achieve that when we cut back on some of the intractable infrastructure costs, especially in transport, and the massive rebuilding program. But science remains our great rationale for being there and that is our priority.

We promised that the Australian Research Grants Scheme, ARGS, would receive a real increase of 10 per cent per annum for the first three years of the Labor Government. We delivered that in the first and third years. The fourth Budget is coming up. We could only have delivered in the 1984-85 Budget at the cost of scrapping the National Research Fellowships. There was a trade off. I am glad that the NRF scheme, with its valuable links with the outside world, especially industry, was preserved and now we have both schemes operating. I know that ARGS is of particular significance to the honourable member for Berowra, who sat on the ARGS board for some years before he descended to the political arena. I have been a strong advocate of selective targeting in areas where the private sector or market response is sluggish or ill- informed and we identified a number of areas for future development which looked promising.
I referred, in 1982, to 16 `sunrise' industries with a cautionary note that:
. . . the list should not be regarded as exhaustive. Some areas not on the list may well emerge unexpectedly, as has often been the case in the past.

Of the 16 `sunrise' industries, 10 or 11 are standing up rather well. Biotechnology was the first on the list. When I began talking about it in this place it just sounded like a buzz word. Nobody in the Fraser Government or the Confederation of Australian Industry knew what it was. In our 1982 policy document I endorsed suggestions that we should aim at funding projects to the extent of $30m over three years-$5m in the first year, $10m in the second and $15m in the third. I am pleased to advise that in 1985, our third year in government, Commonwealth investment in biotechnological research and development totalled $42m. In that one year, 40 per cent more than was suggested for the whole period was spent. It was also 280 per cent above the final year target we set in 1982. None of this includes private sector investment, which is considerable and will rise. Nor does it include investment on the part of the States, which is considerable, especially in Victoria, in New South Wales and in your own State, Mr Deputy Speaker, of Western Australia. Biotechnology may well take off even faster than did the commercial film industry-my previous success story in getting a sunrise industry going.

Targeting, however unfashionable it may be with hard-line free marketeers and many Canberra-trained economists, is now very much in fashion overseas. When I attended the `Summit' of Science Ministers in Ottawa, all of the northern seven were advocating targeting in what are now called `generic technologies'. Many of the areas to be targeted are found on my 1982 list. President Reagan's then science adviser, Dr George A. `Jaye' Keyworth II, insisted that in science and technology the United States was `no longer laissez-faire' and intended to move away from a free market approach, recognising the need to target particular technologies. As he said, relying on `the natural course of events' just does not make things happen fast enough; `Governments are often in an excellent position to judge general trends because of their access to a wide diversity of data, while businesses are inevitably quite limited'. Talent and technology were the only factors, he said, which could overcome comparative disadvantages in capital and labour costs. American industrialists, like our own, have now recognised the unique importance of science and technology to the national economic future. Keyworth said:
Science has never before moved with such speed and breadth . . . Virtually every field is attractive.

The generic technologies on which CSIRO is placing considerable emphasis include such areas as, I repeat, biotechnology, new materials especially industrial ceramics, fibre optics, artificial intelligence-in regard to which Australia has a small but significant development project, and medical technologies, which are being pursued with great success, particularly in the Parkville strip of Melbourne. So CSIRO is involved in targeting. I have been carrying out discussions with ARGS also about targeting. That may be getting into a politically sensitive area, at least I hope so. I am not satisfied that the dribble approach-just giving a little to a large number of projects-is working very well. Obviously if you have $25m to spend you can have, if you want to, 25,000 projects and devote $1,000 to each. Whether they would be able to do anything worthwhile with it is another matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had $70m you could do a lot better.

—Of course, but we have to live in the real world, as they say-at least occasionally. Perhaps we can form a revolutionary party of two to bring that about but I do not see it happening. Not even the Democrats would suggest it in the current political climate. It is simply not realistic. At one extremity you can have 25,000 projects at $1,000 each, at the other 25 projects at $1m each, or two and a half projects at $10m each. You can cut your cloth whichever way you like. It may be that in a number of very significant areas, if you want to do things that are important, it may be necessary to reach a certain critical mass. That would be true, for example, in an area like new materials, something which I think, economically, is going to be of vast significance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just summarise where Australia finds itself in the world. A number of clear observations can be made in comparing Australia to other developed countries. Australia's total research and development effort is low and falling while those of the industrial front runners is high and rising. Australian government support for research and development is broadly comparable with that of other medium-sized developed countries but business support of research and development is among the lowest of all industrial countries-rising, as I say, but not fast enough. Related to this, the quality and quantity of Australian research is high but its performance in applying this research in industry is dreadful. Australian science is linked with international science as a major contributor, just as Australian industry is linked to international industry in a dependent, subordinate role, but the links between Australian science and Australian industry are very tenuous. We are changing that direction and we are succeeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I will pass over the rather uncharacteristic remarks of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) at the beginning of his speech, save for this one point. In making reference to my activities in that very shortened Budget sitting in 1984 caused by the Hawke Government's premature rush to the polls, he overlooked a celebrated debate that he and I had on the lawns in front of Parliament House and in which, I venture to recall with some modesty, there was a consensus of opinion that I won. No one doubts the Minister's personal commitment to science and technology for the betterment of the human condition or as a major factor in long-term economic growth, but the fact is that the record of the Hawke Government in the science and technology area over the three years since it came to office is at best patchy, and at worst extremely disappointing, particularly in the context of the high expectations built up by the Minister concerning the great things that would be done for science and technology. By and large the `technology' area has fared better than has the `science' area. The two, science and technology, are conceptually separate, albeit in practice inextricably linked. Without science, that is, the pursuit of research and new knowledge, there would be increasingly little technology in the modern industrial environment. And without technology, science would rarely result in a widespread benefit for society. That close interrelationship is basically why, along with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's examiners, I would still plump for a department of science and technology-one department, in contrast to the separation we now have.

SPEECH.PARA: That separation was the context in which we got certain decisions, on the one hand, that the funding for the Australian Research Grants Scheme-Australia's key research funding program, especially for the universities-to which the Minister has referred, the funding for ARGS was increased in the 1984 Budget on which we are focusing by a lousy $1.5m to an aggregate of about $25m. At the same time some $150m was provided-over five years, $35m in the first year-for `design and research' in the motor vehicle industry, an industry which, in today's technology spectrum, is rather mature and hardly perhaps the most felicitous subject for investment on a forward-looking view.

I do not think that such an incongruous result could possibly have come about with an integrated science and technology department, albeit with the evident underspending in the development-technology area in Australia. That does merit some priority in budget allocation and I come back to it. Of course, the particular result to which I have referred, that achieved by the motor industry grant in contrast to that achieved by the ARGS, would have had not a little to do with the considerably greater clout of the Minister responsible for the technology side, Senator Button, in the other place! The treatment of the ARGS, which flies in the face of the firm election commitment of the Labor Party to a 10 per cent real increase for that program in each of its first three years, represents just one of the litany of broken promises that we have had from this Government. That treatment of the ARGS was one aspect of the outrageous treatment of science generally and, in particular, the CSIRO in that 1984 Budget-which is what occasioned this motion that the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) put down some 15 months ago.

My colleague has dealt fully with the matter of the effective $9m shortfall in the funding of the CSIRO and the resulting 4.3 per cent real cut in its mainstream areas of basic research, and I shall not go over the same ground. It was an unconscionable bleeding of a great institution. But the outrageous treatment of science in that Budget is an object lesson in the distorted priorities of the Hawke Government and its economic mismanagement. That Budget was one of the grandest spend-ups of all time. The broad shape of it was: Total outlays of the order of $63.9 billion and total receipts embodying a record one-off upsurge in personal income tax of nearly 25 per cent, at $57.2 billion-providing a high deficit of $6.7 billion. If one factor has brought this country to the parlous position that it is now in-with, in particular, its record high interest rates and yawning balance of payments deficit-it has been the massive Budget deficits of this Government, especially that produced by Budget 1984, put down as it was in a context of rapidly recovering activity in the private sector. We had the extraordinary spectacle of an increased provision for sport and recreation of $24.3m or 60 per cent. We saw the provision for the community employment program-that great financier of the Labor Party's left wing and way-out causes-increased by $125m, or 44 per cent. Additionally, housing grants were increased by $225m, or 83 per cent. The provision for general administrative services, a large component of additions which represented to the bureaucracy, was up by $348m, a solid 21 per cent increase. Also, the Bicentennial Authority received a 352 per cent increase! And in the midst of all that largesse, plus the giving of $1.3 billion in tax cuts, the provision for science, the matter before the Parliament today, a pursuit that is a basic foundation stone of the nation's economic health, was increased in money terms by a mere 1.6 per cent-not 60 per cent, or 40 per cent as the CEP, as for sport and recreation.

I do not wish to dwell further on that subject or on the only marginally better treatment that was accorded science in the 1985 Budget, as my colleague has reminded us. Nor will I dwell on the viewpoint expressed by my colleague and, I believe, by the Minister, and commanding an increasing measure of agreement that the expansion of CSIRO's activities should be more in the direction of applications-oriented research, including actual technology development; that this should be undertaken in co-operation with industry and largely financed by the industry beneficiaries; and that the CSIRO should participate in the work and share in the returns from the commercialisation of its research results. That would be part and parcel of a process of achieving greater cost effectiveness from government-financed research and development. In the case of the CSIRO, that process would be facilitated if only the Government would stop dithering and make a decision on changes to CSIRO's organisational structure in the light of the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council on future directions for the CSIRO, brought down last November. How much longer, I ask the Minister, is that vital matter to be delayed while uncertainty reigns and vital decisions are postponed in that great organisation? I stress this: While it may be agreed that there should be a beefing up of the applied, in a word technology, side of CSIRO activities, it is certainly devoutly to be hoped that Australia's great strength, indeed its longstanding pre-eminence, in science-in basic research, the well-spring of the nation's science and technology effort, and in so-called strategic scientific research-should not be prejudiced in any way. It would indeed be tragic if that were to occur. I note that the Minister nods his head in agreement. Australia's high standing in science shows up in the sort of statistic, often quoted, that Australia, with 0.3 per cent of the world's population, produces some 2 per cent of the world's science as measured by internationally recognised scientific papers; that is a ratio of output to population that is as favourable as can be found anywhere in the world.

That is the science area. It is well known-the Minister referred to it-that this contrasts very strongly with the abysmal performance in this country of what I refer to as the `technology-development' area. Development, the translation of scientific research and innovative ideas into actual industrial technologies, hopefully leading to profitable job-generating businesses-sometimes entirely new industries-more importantly, however, having the effect of furthering structural change and upgrading, revitalising and renewing existing industry-that is where our performance has lagged. A quantitative measure in that area is the statistic that we originate about 0.7 per cent of patents in the world, in contrast, as I have said, to 2 per cent of world science. Science is largely government financed, by the CSIRO, the universities, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation-DSTO-and so on. The development-technology side is predominantly the province of the private sector. So we have a situation here where the science and technology funding picture in Australia is apparently extremely unbalanced, with a ratio of 80 government to 20 private sector, whereas in other leading OECD countries it is typically 50 : 50, and in Sweden, indeed, it is 40 : 60. While this contrast is often remarked, the implication is not to reduce the public funding of science-which, as a proportion of gross domestic product, is basically in line with the public funding of science in other countries such as the United States of America, Germany, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands-but rather, in striving to encourage a manifold increase in private sector research and development, because that is where this country lags. That is why I am prepared to concede that the favouring of technology in the incremental expenditure on science and technology over the recent past has not been without justification.

However, even if that activity in the development-technology area were brought up, as with science, to the order of 2 per cent of the world effort, the other 90 per cent plus of technology-development is done elsewhere and we would still be, and always will be, dependent on other countries as the principal source of new technology in Australia. It is not a matter of `colonial dependence on overseas' or any other such pejorative term that some may choose to use. In other words, we will always be a net importer of technology. There is nothing wrong with that. It is true even of Japan and West Germany.

I point out, however, that in contending what we should strive for a manifold increase in private sector research and development in pursuit of a more constructive, effective science and technology effort as referred to in the motion before the House, it should be recognised that there are inherent constraints on this in Australia, including in particular the small scale of the Australian economy and the very high cost of developing new products and pro- cesses. But while those constraints are real they are not decisive, as experience in smaller countries overseas indicates, and indeed as our own experience indicates. Thus as far back as 1968-69 the business sector financed a level of spending on research and development equal to 0.5 per cent of the GDP, more than double that of recent years. That prevailed up to 1973-74. Thereafter it was in fact the onslaught on industry under the Whitlam Government which brought it low. It has stayed there, more or less, since. I recognise the specific measures that the Government has, in fact, introduced to encourage industry R and D, including the establishment of the management and investment companies-MICs-framework, which sprang from the Espie report of the preceding Fraser Government, and the 150 per cent write-off tax incentive for industry R and D-which I might say was a steal from the 1984 science and technology policy of the coalition-and so on.

But, in concluding, the central point I make is that all of these measures to which I have referred will not be enough. All of these Government interventions will be ineffectual unless the economic climate, the overall economic environment is gotten right. Industry research and development, new business investment, and growth in a dynamic economy, all flourish together. While there was a welcome lift in R and D between 1981-82 and 1984-85, as was reported the other day, the level is still barely three-fifths of what it was in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It is still very low-appalling I think was the word Senator Button used. It is no coincidence that in 1984 and 1985, the level of business fixed investment as a proportion of GDP was the lowest for more than two decades. We have had today news of a further fall in business investment. It gives the lie to the talk of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), based only on a reference to growth, that the Australian economy is healthy; whereas we have this low level of business investment, the yawning balance of payments gap, the 30 per cent depreciation of the Australian dollar, the very high interest rates, inflation at 9.2 per cent, and costs rising, accelerating, with the March quarterly figures showing average weekly earnings increasing at an annual rate of 10.8 per cent. It is imperative that the Government act to get the macroeconomic settings of the economy right, which realistically means taking drastic action in the incomes and Budget areas.

Beyond that, in the pursuit of this more constructive science and technology approach, it is important to address other fundamental features of the Australian economy, including business taxation-the so-called risk-reward structure-and depreciation schedules, the inflexible and restrictive Australian wages and industrial relations system, the profusion of regulations and interventions restricting competition and stifling enterprises; and so on. In sum, getting the macroeconomic settings of the economy right and addressing such fundamental features and rigidities in the Australian environment is the real requirement, not the pursuit of science and technology alone, or even primarily.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think today's debate is going to be a very enlightening one for the people of Australia. The notice of motion that is being debated today is a very old one. It was placed on the Notice Paper, as I understand it, on 22 February 1985. It would appear, from the contribution by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), that he wrote a speech around that time, put it in his top drawer, and did nothing to revise its content since. Many of the things that he has said in the course of this debate are simply factually incorrect. I would like to respond specifically to the points that he raised and to highlight the tremendous successes of the Hawke Labor Government in the area of science and technology policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Before doing so it would be remiss of me not to pay tribute in the most glowing and fulsome terms to the Minister for Science, (Mr Barry Jones). There are few people whose intellect, commitment and driving energy are able to take them from Australia to strut the world stage in the discipline and calling of their choosing. Such is the record of the Minister for Science. I refer honourable members to a publication called `Vital Speeches of the Day'. It contains speeches by some of the prominent citizens of the world-`The best thoughts of the best minds on current national questions'. It is dated 1 May 1986 and one finds in it a few familiar names-Ronald Reagan, John Paul II, Geoffrey Howe and Barry Jones. Such is the standing of the Minister for Science. I might say that the Minister's contribution to this publication is a longer and more substantial one than that of any of the first three named people. But it is not just that publication that has given recognition to our Minister for Science. The meeting of the Science and Technology Ministers of the Seven Summit Nations that was held in Canada in October of last year was attended by the Minister for Science following a personal invitation issued to him in his own right because, as was stated publicly at that meeting, he was the greatest science Minister in the English-speaking world. I am not seeking to anoint the Minister in the same way as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given recognition to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), but there is, indeed, a very great parallel.

The reputation of the Minister for Science, as I have indicated, enjoys world-wide recognition. Professor Kenneth Boulding, one of America's most famous economists, said that Sleepers Wake, which of course is one of the Minister's many books, was the most important intellectual contribution that he had come across in his year in Australia. The Minister's work was praised explicitly in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development examiners' report on science policy in Australia, also the world's leading scientific journal Nature. In Australia, Sir Macfarlane Burnet, Sir Mark Oliphant and Sir Gustav Nossal have praised the Minister's commitment to, knowledge of and vision in science, a rare quality in public life. I say those things of the Minister because I believe that if anyone in the history of this Parliament is capable of bringing about a bipartisan approach to science policy, it is our Minister for Science. I refer honourable members to a function that the Minister has organised in the Parliament tonight. Sir Gustav Nossal will be talking to members of all parties about the very important question of biotechnology. That is one of many matters that the Minister has sought to highlight in terms of public discussion.

I am going to be saying some things in this debate, Mr Deputy Speaker, that need to be said. I do apologise for the partisan nature of some of my comments, but regrettably this has been made a partisan issue. What I will do is perhaps put in the slipper, explain the bankruptcy of the Opposition on this question and then move on to what ought to be a proper subject of continuing debate in this place. One of the things that I would claim to have done, and I would venture to say no other Australia has ever done, is stump the Minister for Science in asking him a question relating to the administration of his own portfolio. He did not know the answer! I stumped the Minister for Science!

TALK.START.PARA: —How about that!

—The honourable member for Berowra says: `How about that'. It is a pity he interjected because before this debate commenced I walked up to the Minister and said: `Barry, which member of the House of Representatives represents the shadow Minister for Science, Senator Archer, in this House?' The Minister, whose grammar on this occasion left a bit to be desired, said: `I dunno'. He did not have a clue as to who was the representative of the Opposition parties, because there have been no speeches, there have been no questions, there has been no debate, there has been no probing and raising of the issues that the Opposition now comes here to raise today. I did something else: I sought information about the number of questions that had been asked on what is now this very important burning issue of funding, resources and performance of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I went to the Parliamentary Library-its officers took some five minutes to respond-and inquired as to what questions had been asked on notice in the House of Representatives between 1 November last year, seven months ago, and now. The answer was that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), a Labor member, had asked a question; the honourable member for Hughes, I must modestly confess, had asked four questions, specifically on the CSIRO; the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) had asked one question; the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott)-all are Labor members-had asked another question; and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the one representative of the Opposition parties, had also asked a question. The tragedy is that his question suggested a lack of competence on the part of the CSIRO to undertake research in a very important area of the nuclear winter concept. So we have not had one single supporting question, one probing question, in seven months from the Opposition.
—They have never cared.

—I am pleased that my colleague and friend the honourable member for Jagajaga interjects because I know that he is champing at the bit to take part in this debate. It was the policies of the former Fraser Government that put the member for Jagajaga in this Parliament. He was one of the dedicated young scientists who worked in the CSIRO but the policies, the cutbacks, the obstruction and the frustration that the CSIRO experienced during his employment there drove him into the House of Representatives. He is one of the champions of the CSIRO and will never let the Opposition forget its record regarding that organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise another very specific matter and compliment the honourable member for Warringah upon suggesting that there ought to be a greater parliamentary presence and involvement in the area of science and technology. That was a wonderful suggestion. The honourable member suggested that a joint committee be formed. On that proposition I have a slightly different view. There is, of course, already a Senate committee which undertakes research, public hearings and discussion in this important area. There is no such committee in the House of Representatives. I am pleased to report that when I raised this matter with my Caucus colleagues, including the honourable member for Jagajaga, who is the Chairman of the Caucus Education, Science and Youth Affairs Committee, I got the full support of his Committee-all Labor members. We got the full support of the Industry Committee, also the backing of the trade union movement, and last November the Labor Caucus supported the establishment of a committee on science and technology as an important standing committee of the House of Representatives. I had hoped that that would have the support of all members of the Opposition but despite the acquiescence of the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) who nods his support, the tragedy is that the Opposition spokesman immediately made a statement to the media opposing the establishment of such a committee. Possibly the honourable member for Berowra did not know that. He should check what I have said. It was opposed on the ground of a need for cuts in government expenditure, the same old hobby horse that is so often trotted out by the Opposition.

Before I move on to talk about the achievements of the Government, let me meet that argument head on. I appeal to those members of the Opposition who have integrity, and there are many, to re-assess where the Liberal Party is going. Not one single member of the National Party is present in the Parliament at the moment. We know of its appalling record in this area. It has no questions on the Notice Paper relating to the CSIRO. The only question that has been asked about rural research in the CSIRO was that put by myself, and I represent an urban, Labor electorate. That is how much the National Party cares. There are some people in the Liberal Party, and people participating in this debate, who have integrity and would support a far greater expenditure of public funds in this important area. But they have to be honest. They cannot just keep jumping on the bandwagon championing the cause of reduced government expenditure in all areas. Many members on this side of the chamber would agree that in some areas government expenditure could and should be reduced, but in respect of others we ought to have a bipartisan approach to national expenditure. Science and technology research and development, and the associated public debate and discussion, represent one such area. So let us not engage in this phoney debate about cutting back government expenditure when it relates to these important matters.

I emphasise that when one compares the level of public expenditure in Australia on research to that of other OECD countries Australia is not seen as a big spender. In fact, we are one of the lowest spenders in the OECD group. We rank eighteenth among the 24 OECD countries in terms of government expenditure on this activity, taken as a proportion of gross domestic product. People have to realise that if they keep supporting reductions in government expenditure, they will really be cutting back effectively their standard of living. In no other area could this be more explicit and directly relevant than in the important area of science and technology, which relates not just to our quality of life but also to economic policy, industry policy, jobs, employment and all of the mainstream political issues that we ought to be concerned about. I am very privileged, Mr Deputy Speaker, to represent the electorate of Hughes in which there is, of course, a division of the CSIRO. Recently I undertook to visit that division, spoke with its very committed employees and inspected the research that is being undertaken into the conversion of shale oil.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 109, as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Barry Jones) agreed to:
That the time for the discussion of Notice No. 1, General Business, be extended until 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Hughes.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thank the Minister also. The research that is being conducted at that division includes research into the extraction of oil from shale. I was concerned that such a vital and exciting project was not getting the support that it needed so I asked some questions about where the funding was coming from. Between 1981 and 1986 $11,297,000 of public money has been expended in that important area of research. When I compared the funds that had come from private sources I found that not $11m, not $10m, not $8m, not $9m but in fact as little as $692,000-barely half a million dollars-had been expended by the private sector. It is not as if we are talking about companies that are on the bread-line. We are talking about companies such as CSR Ltd and Esso-major companies that are involved in the development of world energy and resources. I had hoped in the course of this debate to be able to talk about so many of the Government's achievements in the area of science and technology policy.
—You have not got time.

—I have not, but I do hope that in the course of this debate I have shown the genuine commitment of members of the Government to the cause of the CSIRO and scientific research. I also hope that my plea for the establishment and formation of a national and a bipartisan approach to science and technology policy will be heeded by the Opposition because if we can reach that stage the whole scientific community and all Australians will be the better for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little disappointed in one aspect of the speech of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). He spent much of the scarce time that he had available to him in making party political points, in a debate that I would have hoped would have displayed a degree of bipartisanship-something, rather ironically, he appealed for at the end of his speech. But it is with pleasure that I rise in this debate to support the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). I would like very briefly to look at the relationship between science and technology and industry and general economic growth. It is axiomatic that science and technology are in the longer term absolutely central to economic growth in any nation. They are extremely important to the process of developing and adapting technologies so that we can increase the competitiveness of our industries and they can therefore grow effectively in the international market-place.

SPEECH.PARA: Technological innovation and scientific research are also vastly important in developing new products altogether. If in this country we can develop new products and, we can get those products into the international market-place, we can, of course, enhance the export earnings of Australia and move towards resolving some of our chronic balance of payments difficulties. But as other speakers have pointed out, in this general area of science and technology and research and development Australia has an extremely disappointing record. It is one of the areas of Australian economic development which for many, many years has been very disappointing.

Our gross expenditure on science and technology amounts to just 0.95 per cent of our gross domestic product. The average for the OECD is 1.65 per cent. That is a fairly poor record. When we look at the balance of spending in this field we see that government funding, as a proportion, is substantially higher than funding by the private sector. Government funding represents 0.72 per cent, while the OECD average is 0.67 per cent. So government funding in Australia is higher than is the OECD average. But when we look at the business sector, the converse applies. As a proportion of our GDP, business expenditure in this area is 0.2 per cent, whereas the OECD average is 0.98, or nearly one per cent.

So we do have a gross imbalance in Australia as between expenditure by government and expenditure by private enterprise. When we look at the way in which this money is expended, it is also interesting to note the balance involved. Some 83 per cent of expenditure in the agricultural area comes from the Government, so very little is expended by the private sector. That, I suppose, is a reflection of the small nature of enterprises in the agricultural sector of the economy and, therefore, the inability of primary producers to provide funds for that purpose. When we look at the manufacturing sector of our economy, we find that the Government provides 23 per cent of funds for research and development, the rest of the course coming from the private sector. The central fact is that what the private sector has done in that area has not been positive. To be quite frank about it, the private sector has a record of failure in Australia in terms of funding research and development in science and technology. When we look at Australia's record in developing new products and modifying existing products in innovative ways, we see that Australian industry is by no means innovative. As the honourable member for Berowra pointed out, Australia produces some 2 per cent of the world's scientific papers, yet we register in Australia just 0.7 per cent of the world's patents. One can see again the imbalance there. That is a constant theme that comes through in any discussion on science and technology research and development in Australia. It is a theme of imbalance.

The consequence of all this is that we in Australia, despite being a developed country, and claiming to be a wealthy country, are net importers of technological know-how. About 0.1 per cent of the OECD's high technology sales are made by Australia. That is an extraordinarily poor record. In 1981-82-these are the latest figures I could get-Australia spent $127m on importing technological know-how. Yet in terms of exporting know-how we receive just $18m. Again, there is a recurring theme of imbalance and, I am sorry to say, a recurring theme over many, many years of failure in this area. Two per cent of new technology introduced in Australia, just 2 per cent, is locally produced. If ever there was an indictment of a nation's performance that 2 per cent figure is it. Of course, one has to be positive about this crisis and see how we can conceivably respond to this really quite chronic national problem. Clearly, there are two approaches that one can take. One can try to stimulate private sector involvement in science and technology research and development and look at the application of taxpayers' funds in this whole area, making an assessment of how appropriately their money is being spent-whether more should be spent or less. There is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that the key to success in the science and technology area lies with the private sector. That point was very strongly made in the recent report on technology and innovation that came from the Economic Planning Advisory Council:

The economic environment is vital in persuading private enterprise to engage in effective technological development and innovation. This challenge has implications for broad ranging industry and macro-economic policies . . .

What EPAC is saying, and I think it is a very important point, is that to get the private sector to invest and participate in this area of economic activity, the appropriate macroeconomic climate has to be provided. Government expenditure is, in the main, a compensation for the failure of the private sector to invest in these areas. It is extremely important that private investment in science and technology should go into areas which will reap profits, so expenditure on research and development has to be worth while. It is an extremely risky area for the private sector to invest in if the climate is wrong. If it is unable to get an appropriate return on its investments, obviously those investments are going to dry up. That unfortunately has been and indeed is, a problem in Australia.

In the short time that is available to me, I do not want to go into the details of what is wrong with that climate. Suffice it to say that the very high cost structure that we have in Australia, related to such things as interest rates, labour costs, our relative inflation rate to that of other countries and the like, is a disincentive. So are the very substantial charges that are levied on any returns by our taxation system. But there are two problems, in any case, in terms of private sector investment which need to be highlighted. These would not necessarily be solved by a changing macroeconomic climate. The first is that in Australia a high proportion of investment in economic activity is carried out by multinationals. Unlike some honourable members opposite, I have no objection to that but the simple fact is that those multinationals in the main do their research at home rather than in Australia. That, of course, is just about an insurmountable problem for us. Secondly, there is an attitudinal problem in the private sector which sees expenditure on science and technology as discretionary. The statistics show that. Whenever economic times become difficult investment in this area slumps. If we take the years of the Whitlam Government, we find that investment in science and technology by the private sector collapsed almost totally. That was a reflection of the general economic problems but also, let me add, the priorities that the private sector applies to that sort of investment.

Those two problems, let me say, are difficult to overcome, but instead of getting the climate right for investment in these areas we have pursued policies of expenditure by government to compensate for our failure. Some of those areas of government expenditure have been positive and successful. Direct funding for bodies like CSIRO-my colleagues have canvassed this at some length-has reaped rewards, I think, for the Australian community, and some of those have been economically positive. Certain scientific expenditure in government departments, such as in the Antarctic division of the Minister's own Department, is in my view also extremely positive. We have, in intellectual as well economic terms, gained rewards from that expenditure. Equally, the $200-odd million that has been spent in university research has reaped some results for the Australian economy and for the broader interests of the Australian community. I have no particular concerns about that. We have, also introduced a whole series of industry incentives to try to stimulate interest in the private sector. I refer to the 150 per cent tax deduction initiative; the new grants initiative announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) just last week; and the management and investment companies-initiatives which have followed from measures the Fraser Government proposed, but never introduced, back in 1983. Those were all designed to stimulate research and development in the private sector and there are early signs that the 150 per cent tax deduction is beginning to have some results.

So we have done things at the governmental level and some have been extremely positive. On the other hand, let me conclude by saying that in my view government expenditure is a second-best solution. It may be the solution that we will, for all time, have to live with but it is a second-best solution because what we have failed to do in Australia is create the right economic climate to stimulate research and development in the private sector. I believe that it is a long haul for us to stimulate that research and development. It will be many years before we are able to get our performance to equal that of the other OECD countries and a large number of very hard decisions will have to be taken for us to achieve that. In the meantime, there will be a great demand on the taxpayer's dollar to ensure that at least research and development continues in Australia. That must happen because research and development is vital to our economic future. It is an area in which we are currently failing and I hope that the Government will pursue solutions for at least as long as it remains in office, perhaps another year, so that we can stimulate that sector of Australian activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, in the very short time left I would like to commend the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) for clearly exposing the weaknesses of private sector research and development, but unfortunately it is something that his colleagues failed to rectify in the all but six of the 37 years past when they were in Government. They failed to do anything about it. It is useless for them to come in here bleating over reduced--
