QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his statement on 9 May, just three weeks ago, to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Overall 1986 is emerging as a year of slower, but still satisfactory growth, a year in which we will see consolidation of the very strong gains of the past three years, and in which the economy can deal with the imbalance on our external account.

That was three weeks ago. Does the Treasurer regard an absolute contraction in the non-farm economy over two successive quarters, as revealed in today's national accounts, as `slower but still satisfactory growth', or are we already in recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do regard it as slower but satisfactory growth. Let me indicate why. The fact is that the economy slowed in the middle of the financial year. In part, the slowing is the product of the Government's inducement of a moderation in private demand by tightening the intensity of monetary policy last October. In the first place let me just make the point that if the June quarter grows by as much as the March quarter did-we expect it will be better, the reasons for which I will go into in a moment-the economy will still grow at 4.5 per cent over the year. The reason I believe June will be stronger is that in the June quarter interest rates will have been down substantially, housing will have started to pick up from the trough it was in with the problem of housing finance, retail sales started to pick up in April and, as we know, car sales are picking up today. Therefore, there is every likelihood that June will be stronger than March. If it is, the Budget forecast probably will be attained.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me repeat: Even if June is as weak as March was, we will still have growth of 4.5 per cent. Therefore, of course, the reference I made in my EPAC speech was entirely appropriate. I think that the difficulty in measuring quarterly movements always is evident in these accounts, in which the Commonwealth Statistician records a decline of 0.3 per cent for December and 0.3 for March but records a growth of 2.4 per cent for September and 2.7 per cent for June. The combined June and September figure of 5.1 per cent represents an annual rate of growth of 10 per cent. One has to ask oneself whether the economy would grow at an annual rate of 10 per cent for June and September and then decline for December and March. Quite obviously that is not going to happen. There may be some clear slowing, but we will not see such a sharp turn-around between one six months and another six months. Obviously we have difficulty in measuring the quarters. That is something which the Statistician quite eloquently refers to in his statistical discrepancy note at the beginning of his bulletin. However, I think I should make the point that, that said, on these numbers, in the first half of the year we will still have growth of 7.2 per cent on a non-farm basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —You think?
—That is on these figures-of 7.2 per cent.
—That is in the past.

—No, that is in the first six months of the year. The honourable member is asking me whether the Budget forecast will be broadly met or whether the things I said to EPAC were unrepresentative of the current condition. I am answering that no, they were not. If one wishes just to leave the quarterly things to one side and add up the actual increments to non-farm product found at page 33 of the bulletin one will find that there is a 4 1/2 per cent increase for these three quarters over that for the last year. Basically, what has happened is that the economy ran very strongly in the early part of the financial year, it slowed up in the middle of the financial year and it probably will quicken towards the end of the financial year, and that, broadly, the Government's Budget time estimate will be met. If it is not met there will be only a slight diminution of that figure. In the light of the terms of trade decline, that would be entirely appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think the most important message coming out of the Statistician's bulletin for this quarter is the heightened attention given to the terms of trade by the Statistician. What they reveal is that we now have the worst terms of trade since the Depression-confirming my remark in the House three weeks ago. That terms of trade decline is so marked that if Australia had the same terms of trade today as it had in December 1984 the current account deficit would be improved by $6 1/2 billion-instead of looking at a $13 billion current account deficit we would be looking at a deficit of $6 1/2 billion. The decline in the terms of trade is marked. It indicates just how the commodity markets around the world have been poisoned in terms of the way in which they are responding. More importantly, it indicates again how important it is for the exchange rate effect to continue working to try to continue to lift export volumes and reduce import volumes and the importance of other offsetting economic policy settings to help the depreciation effect in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism been drawn to reports of the success of the Carlton Estate Residents Association recreational program for young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have had my attention drawn to these reports. I may not answer the question in the way in which the honourable member for Melbourne might like, but I think that it is a rare opportunity to say something in this House about the sometimes anonymous work done in communities by members such as the honourable member for Melbourne and, I am sure, by lots of honourable members on the other side of the House. Therefore, I will preface my answer by telling a very short story. I remember that the honourable member for Melbourne came to see me last year to tell me about a group of street kids in the suburb of Carlton in his electorate who live in the high rise, concrete ghettos that were built in the 1950s and the 1960s. These were kids from depraved backgrounds, in every sense, who came to the honourable member and asked whether he could assist them in getting together an indoor cricket team. It was rather strange because none of them had ever played cricket or involved themselves in sport of any kind. The honourable member said yes, he would see what he could do. They needed $1,200. He thought he would get it from the local estate agent, or the fish shop or whoever else. Three days later these kids came back in their T-shirts that read `Gerry's angels'. Of course, the die was cast and he had to find the $1,200 himself-which he did.

ANSWER.PARA: The story is that those teams of kids-three teams of boys playing cricket and two teams of girls playing netball-improved their social behaviour immeasurably over one season. He told me that on the night of the final the kids not only won the fight but also won the cricket final. All in all it has been a great social success. I suggested to the honourable member for Melbourne that it might be a good thing for my Department to fund as a pilot scheme to see what we could do in terms of getting kids from this sort of background involved in some sporting endeavour with a view to improving, first of all, their position in life and, secondly, their social behaviour.

I must say, in answer to the direct question, that the report that I received from the social worker was quite illuminating. For a grant of $5,000 about 100 kids have gone through the indoor cricket and basketball teams. The results have been rather stunning. A lot of teams won their competition. More importantly, the improvement in the social behaviour of these kids, who have not had much of a chance in life, was quite stunning, and shows what can be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have joined the Liberal Party, have they?

—No. This is the sort of thing that I am afraid the Liberal Party would never think of funding because it would be too stupid and insensitive. For $5,000, the success was quite stunning. The report in relation to this matter is well worth reading, and states:

ANSWER.PARA: Throughout the games approximately 95 young people have been able to play within the teams and as well many other young people have been involved in supporting and practising. One of the long term aims is to filter young people through the program without causing too much disruption to any teams, thus giving all teams a good chance within the competitions and introducing new participants that can be supported by older team members.
One of the very pleasing aspects of the program is that some of those involved have been young offenders, and they have been both good and responsible, given the situations they are in.

As an aside, I remember the honourable member for Melbourne telling me that when the first team of kids won their competition last year they decided to have a photograph taken and the honourable member had his photograph taken with them wearing the `Gerry's Angels' T-shirts. He wondered why the photograph did not appear in the Press. However, it appeared that some of the kids were worried about getting their photograph in the press because they might have been on the run. The result of all this has been that, for $5,000, and with the assistance of a very compassionate member, whose actions I am sure are reflected over a whole number of people in this House, we have been able to achieve a program that has brought no end of social improvement to the behaviour and lifestyle of kids from deprived backgrounds. I hope that other members of the House can evolve similar schemes. If they do, I would be happy to look at them, because this has been one of the best investments I can think of of $5,000 of government money in this or any other area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer him to his answers concerning the impact of the fringe benefits tax on farm housing. Given the wide definition contained in clause 148 of the legislation, will the Treasurer confirm that where family farms are owned and operated by family companies the imputed rental value of the family homestead, as well as the value of electricity, water, insurance and telephone, will all be subject to fringe benefits tax irrespective of whether or not the company gets a tax deduction for those items, and irrespective of whether the company is running at a profit or a loss? Will the Treasurer confirm that any benefit paid to a working director will also be subject to this new business tax?

—I made it clear the other day in the House that the fringe benefits tax will not apply to homesteads if they happen to be in the name of a company. I indicated that the reason a lot of farms are incorporated is that at the time when there were death duties in this country many farming families formed these companies so that they would not be penalised by a heavy level of duty if a property passed from parent to child. I do not think that is a revelation to anyone here, particularly to farmers. If a homestead is nothing other than a homestead and it happens to be held within the family it will obviously not be subjected to a fringe benefit tax. The point that I was making which may have confused the honourable gentleman when I was giving my answer was that if, under the guise of a family company, the costs of maintenance of a property had been deducted in the past-as they ought not to have been, given the fact that there is no deduction available for private residences in the tax system-of course, there could be no complaint from such a company if the fringe benefits tax was to be paid on that property. That is the point that I was making. I very quickly and firmly say to the honourable gentleman that a homestead will not be taxed in this way.
—Is that in the Bill?
—Yes, that is clear in the Bill. I did not follow the part of the question about directors' fees. Madam speaker, I invite the honourable member to mention that again.
—Will the honourable member please repeat the second part of his question.
—Will the Treasurer also confirm that any benefit paid to a working director will also be subjected to the new business tax?
—I imagine that any benefit paid to a director is subject to income tax today; if it is a benefit in kind, it will be a benefit like any other benefit paid to an employee.

—Would the Foreign Minister be prepared to put to one side his well-known modesty and respond to a description of his recent visit to the South Pacific which was described by a parliamentary colleague as `a sorry tale of ineptitude' and `a trail of disaster'? Are those descriptions justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable member for reminding me of those comments, for it can be readily appreciated the disbelief with which I greeted them when they were first reported to me. That sensation quickly gave way to one of pain when I discovered who was responsible for the comments. It was none other than the celebrated, cultivated and very much underrated member for Kooyong-Mr Forty-one per cent himself. I understand that the day after the poll came out rating him at 41 per cent-and the Leader of the Opposition at 16 per cent, if I may say so sotto voce-there was a big rally in Andrew Peacock futures on the futures exchange. That was enormously impressive until I discovered the day after that the sole buyer was the honourable member for Kooyong. I think there is a lesson in all of that for the Leader of the Opposition, who strives manfully to improve his ratings. However, the more he tries, the more they go down. Since the honourable member for Kooyong has ceased to have a ubiquitous presence around the community, and has become largely invisible, his future prospects have skyrocketed.

ANSWER.PARA: I will keep my modesty intact, because I can leave a lock of concern about that to the honourable member for Kooyong, who, in stricturing me, said this in one of his Press statements:
Mr Peacock contrasted Mr Hayden's much belated trip with his own period as foreign Minister when he had regularly visited the region.

The first think that I did was check on these visits to the region. There were 12 visits to the South Pacific in the five years during which he was Minister for Foreign Affairs. Seven of them are described as transits through Fiji. This is a sort of rest and recreation to recharge the human body after it has been depleted by the demands of the job in the Northern Hemisphere, I dare say. Of the remaining five visits to the region three were for independence celebrations-no independence no visit; one was for a law of the sea meeting; and the final one was to attend the South Pacific Forum meeting. Therefore, I think that the record speaks for itself without much elaboration by me, except to recall in my fetchingly modest way that during my recent trip I visited eight of the nine independent island states of the South West Pacific, the ninth one being Papua New Guinea which I visited earlier this year and will visit again later this year. I also visited Noumea for fairly obvious reasons. I discovered that the honourable member for Kooyong never visited Tonga, West Samoa, Nauru nor cast a foot on the shore of New Caledonia in spite of its importance to us, at least according to the records that the Department of Foreign Affairs has provided. Further advice he gave me ran along these lines:
The Solomon Islands Government has told Mr Hayden that his Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was unacceptable.
It did not. It has yet to resolve a position and there is a difference of opinion in the Solomon Islands. He said:
The Nauruan President's pleas for assistance on the future of his country had been unsympathetically rejected by Mr Hayden.

The plea was that I hand over Fraser Island. I presume from what the honourable member for Kooyong was saying that he would hand it over had he been in the position that I was. The problem was that when I got to Tuvalu Dr Pua Pua, the President, proposed that he too should have a claim on Fraser Island, so presumably in his beneficence the honourable member for Kooyong would be handing out Australian islands all over the South West Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Watch Tasmania.

—I dare say he may have considered handing over Tasmania-an absolutely dreadful thought unless the incentive is added that the honourable member for Denison and the honourable member for Franklin go with the handover. The Press statement of the honourable member for Kooyong continued:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Tongan Government had told Mr Hayden they rejected the Government's SPNFZ Treaty proposal;
It did not. It said that it would sign it in its own good time. It continued:
The Tuvalu and Western Samoan Governments had stated they could not afford to maintain their patrol fleets-only to have Mr Hayden reject their requests for Australian assistance;
I did not. I pointed out that assistance would have to come from within the aid vote. But it gets better:
the Vanuatu Government had announced that it would establish diplomatic relations with Libya.

How dreadful! There is only one problem. When I looked at the record I found that, in 1978, the honourable member for Kooyong, when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs, established diplomatic relations with Libya, allowing it to establish itself in Australia. He was so excited at the development that in a Press release he stated:
The Governments of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Socialist-

People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, guided by the desire to promote friendly relations and the development of co-operation between their two countries, have decided to exchange diplomatic missions at ambassadorial level.

How can I go back to Vanuatu and warn it of the problems we potentially see of an on-the-ground representation by Libya when the honourable member for Kooyong said that it was necessary to have this to develop co-operation and friendly relations? Finally, the Press statement reads:
Mr Peacock was particularly critical of the lack of comment from Mr Hayden on Soviet influence in the South Pacific and the implications for Australia.

I will not delay honourable members, but the fact is that this was widely discussed. I recall again the historical record. In 1978-a bad year for the honourable member for Kooyong, when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs-the Soviets began fishing in the New Zealand exclusive economic zone. They signed an arrangement. The Government at the time did not express any concern as far as the Department of Foreign Affairs can establish. The facts are that there are ground operations; the Soviets have port access to Christchurch and Nelson harbours for provisioning and maintenance; there are also representatives of the Soviet fisheries industries in both places; and, worst of all, they are Soviet nationals.

TALK.START.PARA: —And John Elliott is one of the blokes who make most of the money out of it.

—Andrew always looked after the bank rollers of the Liberal Party, even if there was an ideological conflict somewhere along the line. I merely point out that there seems to be some discrepancy between the cold war principles that the honourable member for Kooyong is now trying to uphold and his record of conduct and performance at that time.

—Is the Treasurer aware that many Queensland accounting practices are un- able to obtain qualified staff due to the nationwide shortage of accountants and, as a consequence, are experiencing excessive work loads? Is the Treasurer aware that requests to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to gain extensions of final notices for lodgment are being denied, even though practices are spreading their work loads under the negotiated lodgment system, and that many of the clients so affected and subsequently summonsed are often due for refunds? Will the Treasurer ensure that such requests are accorded a greater measure of understanding by the relevant officers of the Australian Taxation Office so that full account is taken of the practicalities and vagaries of the working environment of country practitioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a lot of on-the-job training by accountants, of course, in the 1970s under the stewardship of my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong. The fact is that, since the Labor Party came to office, we have dramatically lifted the capacity of the Australian Taxation Office and its administration to deal with the problems of taxpayers and the tax accountancy profession. I am not aware precisely of the difficulties the honourable gentleman mentioned, the Commissioner does try wherever possible to provide the best service, particularly, to accountancy firms, because they handle so much of the business of taxpayers in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the administration will be very greatly simplified by a move to self-assessment which the Government has now approved-this Parliament will consider legislation in this regard-which will free 400 people in the Taxation Office in this coming year. The simplification of the `S' form will also facilitate compliance by taxpayers with the taxation laws. The objective, of course, in moving to a self-assessment system is to have a higher level of audit in the Australian taxation system. We are building the audit rate to 2 per cent, which is comparable with that of the United States and other comparable countries which have moved away from the system of assessment to self-assessment. In that consequence, some of the claims or queries by tax officers which may be occasioned by the assessment system may be diminished. Of course, there will be more in-depth assessments of taxpayers' accounts under the audit system as the proportions of audit rise as the Commissioner is able to build the system over time.

We think that the Commissioner will be able to offer a better service. I know the Commissioner is concerned always to keep his administration in high respect and regard within the accountancy profession. The extra resources which the Government has given him-I think about 1,200 people in three years, because of the paucity of staff provided by the former Government-will facilitate that task, including, of course, the freeing of 800 people from the job of assessment. I will pass the details which the honourable gentleman mentioned to the Commissioner. If he sees a need to improve what he considers to be the service available to accountants in remote areas of Queensland, I am sure he will be happy to oblige.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industry whether he can inform the House of the possible implications for the Federal Budget should the primary industry policies advocated by the Opposition be adopted by this Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a nutshell, the policies would be pretty horrendous. No responsible government would touch them in a pink fit. I have now had a chance to analyse this draft primary industry policy document. The document contains 176 policy commitments. It is no wonder the Opposition's own policy review Committee described it as a shopping list. Of the 176 points, 17 are repetitions of others, giving a total of about 159 specific commitments. Of the 159, some 120-over three-quarters-are entirely consistent with the present Government's policies and attitudes. The words `maintain', `continue' and `retain' predicate at least 31 of the 159 commitments. That is a pretty good endorsement of what we are doing-perhaps the greatest endorsement by an Opposition in history.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, the policies that are endorsed include replacing tariffs on farm inputs, where possible, with bounties, rural adjustment schemes, statutory marketing authority reform, other trade and marketing initiatives, an inquiry into grain transport and handling, research, soil conservation, natural disaster assistance, underwriting arrangements, and a variety of other specific policies. Actually, some of these policies leave me a little open-mouthed in wonder because the Opposition always seems to oppose these things when we debate them in the House. The major areas of difference relate to macro-economic policy. The Opposition wants reduced public spending-that one is always popular-a lower deficit and a range of measures, primarily in the taxation area, which would cost an additional $645m. As usual, the Opposition wants it both ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Walsh said $500m yesterday. You ought to get your act together.
—Senator Walsh and I have the same figures. We will give them to the honourable member, if he wants them.
—You are getting together, are you?
—Yes, we are. We talk all the time. We did it together.
—As you did on the rural package.

—Exactly, John. Do not get cocky just because Bill has praised you a bit. Another part of the Opposition's policy says that the Opposition will `diminish reliance on fuel as a source of Government revenue'. We really do not know what that means. Revenue from all fuel taxes in 1984-85 was about $6.4 billion. I do not think the Opposition would hand all that back, but it is saying that all the recent falls in world oil prices should be fully passed on to Australian consumers. The estimate I saw of the cost of that proposal-I ask honourable members not to hold me to this-was about $2.3 billion. The Opposition proposes tariff reductions. Revenue in 1984-85 was $2,927m. Perhaps the Opposition will not include all of that. It proposes to exempt farmers from the fringe benefits tax. Other Opposition statements have opposed the tax totally, along with the deductibility of entertainment expenses. That would cost something like $935m in a full year.

ANSWER.PARA: So the sad thing about the Opposition document is that a lot of it is simply unquantifiable. Where we can quantify it, it is really grossly irresponsible. One of the things we came up with in our policy statement was a recognition of the family farm-a recognition of how resilient the farmers are in Australia in earning off-farm income. I have the example of a struggling family farm in Queensland. It is a two-income family-Joh and Flo. They have a farm. They have plenty of off-farm income, but now they are really pushing out in a very resilient way. They are endorsing advertisements. I suppose that they get paid for that. That shows how good some of our farmers are in getting additional income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Transport see the four Modest Farmer articles by the Hon. Bert Kelly which began in the Australian during March of this year and dealt with shipping and waterfront problems? Since the tabling of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, has any action been taken to prosecute the Port Adelaide branch of the Painters and Dockers Union for what Costigan called its criminal activities? Does the Minister believe that similar activities by the painters and dockers are still occurring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question because for the first time it evidences, minute though it may be, an interest from the Opposition in international shipping services in this country. It is the first gleam of interest, and for the first time in my recollection, since the days of Peter Nixon, the Opposition has actually raised the issue of efficiency on the waterfront. That is some little credit to the Opposition. I did see something of the articles written by the former member for Wakefield. In many ways they maintain the old mythology that all the problems of exporters and primary producers are transport problems. Even if the transport costs were nil it would be said that the timetables were wrong. We can never satisfy them. The former member for Wakefield did deal with some issues but the articles contained much of the old mythology about shipping costs needing to be lower. Certainly the shipping costs are one leg. The honourable member for Wakefield asked about the articles. There were four of them and they covered a great deal of information. It is a very large issue. Shipping costs are one element of the total transport costs from the farm gate to the ultimate consumer abroad. Historically, in real terms there have been record low rates.

ANSWER.PARA: To turn to the other side of the picture-the on-shore costs-this Government has set up a shore-based shipping task force, chaired by Ian Webber, of Mayne Nickless Limited, to look at those problems. That is an industry task force looking at industry problems. Embraced in the terms of reference of that task force are the matters to which the honourable member referred; namely, efficiency on the waterfront, operations on the waterfront, and how we can improve efficiency and reduce costs. As I said, this is an area that has never been addressed by the conservative parties. If we are going to talk about overall transport costs, that is the area in which attention has to be focused. Honourable members opposite could not face up to it. The only contribution from the National Party to this issue was to enrage waterside workers and to use that area for the purposes of political disputes.

This is an area to which this Government is directing a lot of attention. Efficiency can be improved. There has been an improvement in shipping services as a result of the initiatives of this Government, and that remains a major priority. In respect of the recommendations in the Costigan report, they are not matters within my responsibility; they are matters for the Attorney-General. I suggest to the honourable member that the Attorney-General will have taken notice of the remarks made in the question he raised. The Attorney-General may care to respond to him at another time and in another way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science. What progress has been made to formulate a program to search for extra-terrestrial intelligence by the detection of radio signals? Could such a program be undertaken in Australia? What significance would a SETI program have for Australian science?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are real possibilities for Australia to benefit from this program. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is very interested in developing the SETI program. If that is the case, we will be real beneficiaries of it, because if signals are to be picked up from planets like our own, the Southern Hemisphere is the place to do it. As honourable members will be aware, Australia played an outstanding role in the recent Giotto and Voyager expeditions. As a result, we know a great deal more about the universe than we did before.

ANSWER.PARA: We have an enormous advantage in living in the Southern Hemisphere because the southern heavens are much more interesting to astronomers than are the northern heavens. That is why proportionately there are more astronomical establishments in the Southern Hemisphere than elsewhere, and Australia is well advanced in this regard. Honourable members will be well aware that Tidbinbilla was the place from which Giotto and Voyager were tracked, with such dramatic results. Australia is in the forefront of world astronomy. We have a great international reputation, and I think there will be very considerable advantages to Australia from this program. Any benefits will simply be flowing to us; there will be a net benefit. It has been estimated that the universe has about one million planets capable of supporting life such as ours. Any of them would provide Australia with very valuable export opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to today's national account figures, which disclose that in the last two quarters there has been negative growth in the Australian economy. I refer him to our excessively high inflation rate, which is over 9 per cent at a time when economies such as that of Japan are headed towards a zero inflation rate. I refer him to the alarming statements made by his colleague the Treasurer about the state of the Australian economy. I refer him to the slump in private investment figures released yesterday. I again ask the Prime Minister, as I did earlier this week: As these matters raise issues of legitimate national concern and are above partisan political point scoring to some extent, will the Prime Minister arrange for the Treasurer to make a full statement to this House before the Parliament adjourns for the winter recess to inform us of the state of the Australian economy and what the Government proposes to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I will not seek to direct the Treasurer as to whether he should make a statement to this House. If it is his view that he should do that, that is his decision, as it appropriately should be. I simply make some observations which I believe to be relevant to the question from the Leader of the Opposition. First, as the Treasurer rightly responded earlier in Question Time, if one takes a view of the financial year as a whole, it looks as though the outcome in terms of economic growth will be quite close to that projected at the time of the last Budget forecast. Given the massive impact upon Australia of the dramatically adverse movement in the terms of trade, that is a considerable achievement. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that relevant to any assessment of the Australian economy is the 4.5 per cent increase in employment which has taken place during this period and I suggest to him that from his own personal experience he would know that that sort of movement is not consistent with an economy which is in recession, as he would have us believe ours is.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said all those things, let me say quite specifically on behalf of the Government as a whole that we recognise that there has been imposed upon this country a very severe discipline as a result of what is happening in the external economy. It would be the height of irresponsibility simply to look at the quite magnificent achievement within Australia as a result of the Government's policies and say `Well, that is all we have to do' and ignore what is happening externally. This Government will not ignore those factors. We will do what we have done for the past three years that we have been in government; that is, frame a range of economic policies which is appropriate to the existing and foreseeable economic circumstances. I might point out that it is quite likely in terms of the Australian Statistician's own statement that the national accounts for the most recent quarters may be amended or changed to show a somewhat different picture because that is the record of the past. One thing that will not be rectified or amended is the record of the previous Government over which the current Leader of the Opposition presided because the time for rectification and statistical amendment has passed. What will stand now and for the future is the monumental rectitude of ineptitude for which the Leader of the Opposition was responsible and which he gives no sign of learning from. He was the world's most hopeless Treasurer in office and he is quickly becoming identified as the world's most hopeless Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It seems appropriate in this week in which we have been celebrating the twenty-fifth birthday of Amnesty International to ask the Minister whether he has seen the Amnesty International report on human rights abuses in Chile. What is the Government's view on the situation as reported and what steps is it taking to prevent this situation continuing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has quite frequently expressed its concern about the issue of human rights in Chile. As recently as 20 May in this House the Minister for Defence, then acting for me, expressed the Government's concern about actions by the Chilean Government against two officials of the Catholic Church's human rights organisation in Chile, the Vicariate of Solidarity. Officers of the Australian Embassy in Santiago visited the two officials in gaol and this Government remains concerned about the potential in this situation for the invaluable work of the Vicariate to be undermined. On a number of occasions our diplomatic post in Santiago has, following my instructions, made representations of concern on behalf of Australia and in support of the rights of people whose human rights have been abused and denied in Chile.

ANSWER.PARA: In October last year embassy officers visited two imprisoned trade union officials and made representations to the Chilean authorities on their behalf. I mention these cases as illustrations of the concern that has been consistently expressed by the Australian Government. Of course the situation will not improve decisively until Chile's long-standing democratic tradition is restored. We would welcome that occurring as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. In view of the strong statement of opposition to the iniquitous Bill of Rights Bill and the disastrous Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission legislation issued by the Catholic bishops following a meeting of the Australian Episcopal Conference, and continuing widespread concern throughout all sections of the Australian community, I ask the Attorney-General once again-and this time I hope he will resist the temptation to detour through the Queensland electoral system-whether he will withdraw the Bill of Rights legislative package. If not, will he let the people of Australia express their opinion on this dangerous legislation at a referendum? If not, why not?

—As the honourable member knows, Australia entered into the International Convent on Civil and Political Rights in the United Nations and under the Fraser Government it established the Human Rights Commission. Apparently it is now the policy of the Opposition to do away with the Commission.
—Absolutely!
—Hear, hear!

—I notice the `hear, hears' coming from a particular Opposition group. I do not know what the Opposition's policy is but it would appear that it no longer wants the Human Rights Commission. I do not know what that would do for Australia's image in the sense that this country is a member of the International Human Rights Commission. I would be interested to know what the honourable member for Kooyong, for example, would think of that suggestion because at least in the past those who have had responsibility in government were well aware of the good influence that the Human Rights Commission could establish in countries which do not practise human rights. In this case the Commission is important because we have already entered into an international covenant which, after all, is only talking about the rights of individuals as against governments. Of course I can understand the concern of the honourable member when he talks about Queensland, where there is a malpractice from the point of view of human rights.
—Here he goes.

—That malpractice is well-known, and I would suggest that it might be appropriate to hold a referendum in Queensland to find out whether people favour the electoral redistribution up there. Perhaps we should let the people of Queensland vote on whether they think the Queensland gerrymander is a fit and proper example of adult universal suffrage. The only people who seem to be concerned about human rights are those who do not want to see them practised.
—Ask the Catholic bishops.

—I make this point about the Catholic bishops: There have been frequent discussions with representatives of those bishops and I have answered their recent media release which suggested that there was something unusual about the Human Rights Commission in the way in which it will take evidence or listen to complaints. The answer to that is that that position is virtually the same as that which applies in existing human rights provisions, implemented by Malcolm Fraser and about which no complaint was made. Further, the bishops have made accusations about matters which have been debated in this House at length-namely, the rights of the unborn. The honourable member for Cowper is laughing and does not appear to be very interested, but the issue of the rights of the unborn was clearly debated at the time the International Covenant was entered into. The objection was rejected in the United Nations and that has been known to the Catholic bishops for a long time as well.
— They are not happy about it.

—Maybe they are not happy, but if they are interested in abortion perhaps they should look at the Tasmanian law. It is important for the people of Australia to understand that the Human Rights Commission is an educative force for governments. If a government is performing in accordance with the rights of individuals, it has nothing to fear from the principles in the human rights legislation. That is the issue. We want the Senate to find the time to deal with the Bill again. It has spent some 36 hours on it already, not debating its real merits but debating it clause by clause. It appears to be a filibuster designed to guarantee that the human rights legislation will not become law. I can understand that from the point of view of the Opposition. Apparently the Opposition has a new policy and does not want to see the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission established. Of course, if that is its policy, I have no doubt that that will be a major issue at the next election.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Commonwealth-State Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 7 of the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations Act 1976, I present the tenth report of the Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations entitled `Inter-Government aspects of the provision of post-arrival services for immigrants'.

DEBATE.TITLE: VISIT BY PRIME MINISTER TO JAPAN, CHINA AND THE PHILIPPINES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report on the visit I undertook from 15 to 26 May to Japan, China and the Philippines.

SPEECH.PARA: Visit to Japan

In Tokyo I had cordial and useful discussions with Prime Minister Nakasone and Foreign Minister Abe, Finance Minister Takeshita, Minister of International Trade and Industry Watanabe and Agriculture Minister Hata. I had private meetings with Mr Tsukumoto and Mr Ishibashi, the leaders of the Democratic Socialist Party and the Japan Socialist Party respectively. A valuable new element in this visit was a meeting with Japanese parliamentarians concerned with agricultural issues. I also had the opportunity to meet with and address senior figures in the Japanese business community.

The visit was especially timely. It took place very soon after the Tokyo Economic Summit, chaired by Prime Minister Nakasone. I was able to hear from him at first hand of the discussion which took place at the Summit. The visit also followed closely upon the visits I undertook in April to the United States and Western Europe and this allowed me to complete the process of conveying to the world's major economic powers the Australian Government's views on the need to resist protectionism and, in particular, to address the problems of world trade in agricultural products.

Mr Nakasone assured me that at Tokyo the Summit countries had addressed agriculture in a thorough and positive way for the first time. Japanese leaders assured me of their support for the proposition that agriculture should have a prominent place in a new round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations. I was told that Japan stood ready to work with Australia to achieve this. I welcomed these assurances.

Japan expects there to be decisive progress at the September ministerial meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to launch the new round. Meanwhile both Japan and Australia agree that work done in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development should serve as useful preparation for these negotiations. I emphasised Australia's willingness to participate in the discussion on agriculture in the OECD but stressed that such discussion should not divert attention from the necessity of having agricultural trade issues fully and satisfactorily addressed as part of the MTN agenda. Japanese leaders also agreed with me on the value of further consultation among Asia-Pacific regional countries prior to the September meeting.

The visit was also timely for another reason. Both Japan and Australia are in the midst of major structural changes in their respective economies. In the case of Japan, the recent substantial appreciation of the yen has been a major contributing factor. The market opening measures and action being taken to follow up the report of the Maekawa Committee released in early May have also been important. In the case of Australia, I drew the attention of Japanese leaders to the Government's efforts to diversify our economy and make our manufactured goods and services more competitive in export markets. The consequence for both Australia and Japan of the changes that are in train is substantial opportunities for both countries.

In talking to Prime Minister Nakasone and others I applauded the principles embodied in the Maekawa report and welcomed the opportunities which market opening and structural change presented to Australia. These include opportunities in areas of traditional interest to Australia such as agricultural products and coal as well as in new areas. Mr Nakasone responded that the Japanese leadership was pledged to promote implementation of the report and that this process had only just begun.
