Japan is Australia's largest trading partner and, amongst developed countries, Australia is Japan's second largest trading partner. In discussion with Japanese leaders it was also noted with pleasure that the Australia-Japan trading relationship is broadening, partly because of Japan's market opening measures to which Australia was already well placed to respond as a result of our Japan market strategy. I expressed appreciation for Japan's co-operation with that strategy.

We also noted the very significant increase in tourism between Japan and Australia and agreed that the further growth of this should be facilitated. Reference was also made to the broadening of the relationship through finance and banking, particularly as a result of significant deregulation of the Australian financial sector. I stressed Australia's interest in seeing close financial relations give impetus to new areas of trade and investment.

It was agreed in principle that there should be an exchange of investment missions between Australia and Japan. These missions will identify particular areas of opportunity emerging from the structural changes now occurring in both countries. Preparatory work on these missions has already begun. Importantly, Japanese business leaders indicated directly to us their support for this initiative.

In a number of areas our traditional export sectors, namely agricultural products and industrial raw materials, Japanese policies impose significant constraints on our capacity to expand our exports to Japan. I emphasised to the Japanese leadership that the Japanese market for our traditional exports of raw materials and agriculture products remains vitally important to both our countries, and that we wish to see these expand. I stressed to Japanese leaders Australia's reliability and international competitiveness in these areas. In this regard I underlined the Government's success in radically reducing the historic levels of industrial disputation in Australia.

On agriculture, I expressed regret that this sector had been largely neglected in Japan's market opening measures to date. I welcomed the Maekawa report's recognition that Japan's agricultural policies should be `more befitting an age of internationalisation'. I pressed the view that, given Australia's efficient and abundant supply capacity in agriculture on the one hand, and the growing cost burden to Japan associated with its domestic agricultural support systems on the other, there would be mutual advantage to both countries in a process of winding back agricultural protectionism in Japan. I argued more specifically for liberalisation of imports in a number of commodities of particular interest to Australia. I noted also that Australia would shortly be presenting a submission to the review of Japan's agricultural policy being carried out by the Agricultural Policy Council.

On coal also, I noted that a review of Japanese policies could open up new opportunities. I stressed that Australia would have a very strong interest in competing on a commercial basis for additional tonnages. I said that we would not be seeking any special advantages but would rest on our demonstrable competitiveness and reliability as a supplier. We asked only that Japan make its purchasing decisions on this basis. I received reassurances from Prime Minister Nakasone that Japan would not do bilateral deals with third parties at Australia's expense.

In accordance with the Government's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and to the provision of uranium for peaceful purposes under the most stringent safeguards, as well as with Japan's autonomous decision to continue to generate electricity through nuclear power, I also indicated Australia's interest in securing an increased share of the Japanese uranium market. I also emphasised the importance we attach to the successful development of the North West Shelf project.

I also had useful exchanges on other major matters arising from the Summit, including terrorism, the United States-Soviet talks on arms control, the Chernobyl incident, and the need to strengthen the International Atomic Energy Agency machinery. On terrorism, I pointed out that steps already taken by Australia were in line with the Summit declaration on terrorism.

I discussed with Mr Nakasone and Mr Abe a number of foreign policy issues important to Australia and Japan. We agreed on the need to provide relevant and appropriate support to the new Government of the Philippines in its objectives of social and economic reform. We discussed the important developments occurring in China and our relations with China. I informed Japanese leaders of Australia's views on ANZUS. Relations with the Soviet Union were discussed, as were developments in the South Pacific. With Australia and Japan each trying, in our own way, to play an increasingly active role in international affairs, it is useful to exchange views on matters such as these and to develop the habit of foreign policy consultation and co-operation. I expressed the gratitude of the Australian Government and people for the contribution Japan will be making to our bicentennial celebrations, in particular the planned contribution to the National Science Centre.
Visit to China

I had four basic objectives in my visit to China. The first was to reinforce the excellent relations which exist between Australia and China at the most senior governmental levels. Second, I wished to evaluate the process of economic modernisation on which China is embarked and to facilitate economic ties between Australia and China. The third objective was to conduct a thorough, high level dialogue with the Chinese leadership on international issues. Fourth, I wished to give impetus to the development of a broad, sustainable relationship going beyond commercial and foreign policy matters to include the development of stronger people-to-people relations. These objectives were accomplished.

In opening our discussions Premier Zhao Ziyang said that China attached very great significance to building the relationship with Australia and to realising the full potential of our relationship. China's seriousness about this, which my Government fully reciprocates, was reflected in the exceptional opportunities provided for intensive discussions throughout the visit.

I met Chairman Deng Xiaoping for an hour and had many hours of very frank, informative and friendly discussion with Premier Zhao, as well as with General Secretary Hu Yaobang and Secretary Hu Qili, who accompanied me in the provincial portions of the visit. I had extensive contact with Senior Vice-Premier Wan Li. I held discussions with the Governors and senior political figures in five provinces with a combined population exceeding one-quarter of China's population and drawn from the north, west, east and south. I met a number of other central government Ministers.

The combination of modernisation at home and the opening of China's doors to the outside world is, I am convinced, capable of changing the face of China, adding an extremely important new element to the world scene and providing very important new opportunities for Australia. The determination of the Chinese leadership to pursue modernisation remains very evident. This was particularly clear from my discussion with Deng Xiaoping but it also came through consistently in discussions with other central and provincial government leaders.

I found a ready realisation on the part of China that our two countries are natural partners as Chinese economic modernisation proceeds. Indeed, the Chinese leadership's expectation is that there will be a doubling of the Australia-China trade by 1990. We have taken initiatives to develop co-operation in iron and steel, non-ferrous metals, wool and transport. There is enhanced co-operation in agriculture.

Premier Zhao and others expressed to me their pleasure at the strides already made in developing our economic relations. While noting that there is a substantial trade imbalance in Australia's favour at the moment, both our countries are aiming at a reciprocal increase in trade and economic co-operation. I was able to witness for myself in China tangible evidence that the Australian private sector is alert to the opportunities which change in China presents.

It was particularly appropriate to be in China at a time when many Australian business leaders were there. I opened in Beijing a meeting between senior Australian executives and their Chinese counterparts, a forum designed to focus attention on both the Australian and Chinese sides on the scope for closer economic co-operation.

I was present at the signing of an agreement related to investment by China in the Portland project, saw in operation a high technology manufacturing enterprise in which an Australian company is heavily involved, observed the signing of an agreement aimed at establishing a wool store in China which will enhance Australian exports of wool and opened a woollen textile mill in which an Australian company is also involved.

At the same time I emphasised to Chinese leaders that the relationship still needs to be nurtured carefully. The agreement to establish a high level co-ordinating committee will keep the development of Australia-China economic co-operation under the attention of government at a very senior level on both sides.

Beyond this, I raised a number of specific bilateral matters. I had detailed discussion about further prospects for co-operation in iron and steel. In particular the negotiations on the Kwinana and Channar projects were discussed. It was recognised that these were negotiations between the enterprises concerned and that governments could not direct the enterprises. At the same time it was agreed that the two governments would each continue to provide the appropriate framework within which these negotiations might be successfully concluded.

I noted that Australia had been involved in the feasibility study stage of a major project for the management of urban liquid waste at Shanghai, and that we had put forward a proposal for commercial involvement in the development stage which was very attractive. The Chinese Government welcomed this proposal, which I was told would be considered on the basis of equality and mutual benefit.

Similarly, in the area of transport co-operation, I noted that Australia had funded a feasibility study for the Dongdu Port at Xiamen in Fujian Province and pressed our interest in commercial involvement in subsequent development of this project. The Chinese leadership's response was encouraging. Indeed, I received clear indications while I was in Xiamen of Chinese interest not only in Australian participation in the port project but also in a number of related projects including flour milling, animal feed and animal husbandry projects. Fujian Province is also interested in promoting the sale of Chinese electronic projects in Australia. I raised the suggestion that there might be scope for relevant Australian enterprises to purchase ships from China if they were in turn allowed to carry bulk cargoes from Australia to China. It was agreed to explore this further.

There was also discussion of the conclusion of a double tax agreement between Australia and China and of an investment protection agreement. Premier Zhao indicated Chinese interest in an investment protection agreement. He agreed that work should be expedited on a double tax agreement. This will now be done.

China is already a significant voice in some regional and global issues and I therefore found it very valuable to have extensive discussion on these matters, particularly with Premier Zhao and General Secretary Hu Yaobang. The conversations were very frank and productive. They ranged over disarmament and arms control, the situation in the South Pacific, the policies of the Soviet Union and relations with that country, the situation regarding the ANZUS Treaty, prospects for Indo-China in general and Cambodia in particular, the situation on the Korean Peninsula, the issue of Taiwan and the transition in Hong Kong.

The general thrust of what I put to the Chinese leadership was that Australia welcomed constructive Chinese involvement in Asia-Pacific regional questions, and drew encouragement from the peaceful and stabilising international role China was playing and intended to develop. I specifically commended some recent positions taken by China-for example, its decision to renounce atmospheric nuclear testing, its willingness to participate in negotiations on a comprehensive test ban in the Committee of Disarmament, and its support for the protocols to the treaty establishing the South Pacific nuclear free zone. Australia and China do not see eye to eye on all issues but, as I said during the visit, we are now able to sustain a very good relationship even where different perspectives on particular national and regional issues exist.

During the talks both sides warmly welcomed the fact that much has been done in recent years to develop co-operation and exchange with China beyond the commercial and political areas. Australia now has agreements with China for exchanges in science, technology, culture, education, the media and law. I indicated that Australia would like to see a substantial expansion in the present student exchange program between China and Australia. It was agreed that work would proceed at the level of officials with a view to specific new arrangements being settled by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) when she visits China in September. As with Japan, China too will be participating in Australia's Bicentenary, and I expressed gratitude for China's intended involvement.

To sum up, I am confident that Australia and China are well on the way to constructing a strong and well-rounded relationship covering commerce, foreign policy dialogue and co-operation, and cultural exchange in the broadest sense. Much has been done, the potential exists to do more, and I sought, I believe successfully, to provide impetus to each of these areas through the visit.
Visit to the Philippines

In the Philippines I had very friendly and informative discussions with President Aquino and also met Vice-President Laurel and other leaders in the new Government. I thought it important to take this early opportunity to establish personal contact with President Aquino and to talk to her about her Government's priorities, concerns and plans. President Aquino briefed me on these matters and I indicated the Australian Government's support for her efforts to achieve political and social reform and economic reconstruction in the Philippines. In this connection I informed Mrs Aquino of decisions taken by the Government on an aid strategy for the Philippines following the announcement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in March of a 50 per cent increase in our aid to $25m in 1986-87, and a visit of an Australian aid mission in April to consider how best to deploy these increased resources.

I said that, subject to specific proposals being prepared, aid would be provided in three phases. In the first phase emphasis would be placed on the continuation of existing programs, on the introduction of a community assistance program to help at the grass roots level, mainly through non-government organisations and the church, preparation of longer term projects in key sectors such as agriculture and education, provision of technical assistance, and the introduction of a commodity supply program as a response to the immediate critical economic situation. In the second phase it is envisaged that this last program would be phased down and greater emphasis would be placed on the community assistance program, the further preparation of longer term projects and the provision of technical assistance. In the third phase the strategy anticipates the termination of commodity assistance as the need for balance of payments and Budget support hopefully diminishes, so that our aid program would then consist of fully operational long term projects and a fully operational community assistance program.

I also spoke with President Aquino about international issues. I indicated our appreciation of the fact that the Philippines has offered to host the next round of regional trade consultations in Manila before the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ministerial meeting in September. The question of the future of the security and stability of the region was discussed, including mention of the United States bases in the Philippines, and I outlined to Mrs Aquino the positive experience of the Australian Government in our co-operative defence relationships with the United States, an experience totally consistent with the conduct of an independent Australian foreign policy. I told President Aquino of our repugnance at the actions over a long period of former President Marcos and his cronies in having misappropriated abroad massive assets, the property of the Filipino people. I said that this Government would assist in respect of inquiries about any such assets in Australia to the maximum extent possible within the framework of our legal system, including helping with provision of relevant information.

In short, I have, through this brief visit to the Philippines, indicated not only that Australia wishes President Aquino and her colleagues well in their efforts to overcome the very difficult problems which they inherited, but also that we will provide tangible support to the extent we can. I stressed to her that the Australian people had been deeply moved by her struggle, and that of the Philippines people, to assert democratic values in the face of a deeply entrenched system of corruption and oppression. I told her that the Australian Government and people had applauded her success and that of her supporters then, and we looked forward to a consolidation of their achievement now.

The countries I have just visited are obviously of great importance to Australia. Japan is our principal trading partner and has assumed a vital place in our economy. The far-reaching reforms taking place in China and its associated opening up to the outside world are of immense political importance for the world and our region and offer Australia a great opportunity to assist in China's development and to build a significantly enhanced relationship to the mutual benefit of both our countries. The fortunes of the Philippines, newly liberated from a despotic and deeply corrupt regime but facing grave internal problems are of major significance for stability in our region.

I believe that my visit has strengthened our relationships and our opportunities for co-operation with all three countries. These opportunities will have to be taken if Australia is to achieve the role which I believe it is destined to play as an active, constructive and engaged member of the Asia-Pacific region. The Government intends to do its part to ensure that these great opportunities are seized.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition very genuinely welcomes this statement that has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We think it important that overseas visits by Prime Ministers be the subject of report to the national Parliament and, whatever may be our partisan differences on other matters, there is no doubt that the goals of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia and the goals of the present Government in certain foreign policy areas are similar. I want in my remarks to address the areas of similarity as well as the areas where we part company with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We do welcome this report to the Parliament by the Prime Minister, but I would have to say to the Prime Minister that his willingness to talk to us about his visit overseas is in marked contrast with his unwillingness, and that of his colleague the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to talk to us about the parlous state of the domestic economy in Australia. The more the Prime Minister shows a willingness to report on the emperor's progress overseas, the more culpable is his unwillingness to talk to the Parliament about the problems in our domestic economy. I would say again to the Prime Minister that the domestic problems Australia now faces, which are an important aspect of our international relations, cry aloud for the public to be taken into the confidence of the Government. The Prime Minister has a responsibility to address those problems and to tell the Australian public where he believes our economy stands and what his Government proposes to do about it.

The statement of the Prime Minister says a great deal about the public pressure of the Prime Minister in Japan, China the Philippines. I am sure that a lot of members on this side of the House regret that the statement contains no reference to some of the more interesting things that were done by the Prime Minister, particularly while he was in Japan and China. We are very disappointed that we were not told about those telephone conversations that he had at the end of last week. We are very disappointed that we were not given a report of the background briefing that he gave to all those Australian journalists about how he was putting down the Treasurer and pulling him back in line in relation to the running of the Australian economy.

I have to say that, while this statement is welcome, it is very short on those specifics. It is a great pity that the Prime Minister is not a little more forthcoming about matters which are of great concern to and in great contention with the Australian public. The other thing that was very interesting, of course, concerned the remarks of the Prime Minister when overseas about the state of the Australian economy, which are in such stark contrasts to the dire warning about a banana republic being made at the very same time by his colleague the Treasurer back here in Australia. Some people could easily say that Mr Hawke returned to an Australian economy which can perhaps be categorised as having taken a great leap backwards, to borrow a famous catchcry from the recent history of China.

I now turn to some of the specifics in the Prime Minister's statement. In relation to Japan, it ought to be pointed out that it is now 10 years, or it will be in June, since the basic treaty of friendship and co-operation between Australia and Japan was signed. I remind the House that that basic treaty was an initiative of the previous Liberal-National Party Government. In the context of properly endorsing what the Prime Minister said about the importance of our trading relationship with Japan, I also take the opportunity to remind the House that when one looks at the history of Australia-Japan trade relations since the end of World War II, the contribution of two people to the building of that relationship stands far and away above that of anybody else, and I refer quite unreservedly to the contribution made to that relationship by the late John McEwen and Doug Anthony, former Deputy Prime Minister of Australia. Those two members of previous Liberal-National Party governments have done more than any other Australians in the post-war period to build on the important trading relationship which now exists between Australia and Japan and which is of so much importance to Australia's economic development.

I have to say also that the Prime Minister's record and report of his discussions with Japanese leaders appears to me to be very much one-sided. Little of very real importance is set out concerning the results of any of the discussions, although the Opposition does welcome the assurance given by Japan that it will support the proposition that agriculture should have a prominent place in a new round of multilateral trade negotiations. That, in the view of the Opposition, is indeed a very welcome development. I must, or course, remark that the Prime Minister's comments about the Australia-Japan trading relationship dramatically demonstrate the inherent problems that will result from the fact that Japan's rate of inflation is heading towards zero while Australia's remains at over 9 per cent. I do not think that anybody could analyse the relationship between our two countries without remarking on that discrepancy. As Japan is our best customer and our major trading partner, that enormous gap between our relative inflation performances will assume much greater significance in the future-much greater significance as time goes by.

The Prime Minister mentioned that he had told the Japanese that our industrial scene was getting better. That seems very ironic, of course, delivered by the Prime Minister a day after we had a 24-hour stoppage organised and encouraged by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and not disavowed by the Government of this country, in protest against the alleged slow progress being made by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the recent national wage case. When the Prime Minister waxes lyrical about the improvement he claims has taken place in the industrial scene in Australia over the past three years and when he says that all of it is due to the great benefits of the prices and incomes accord, he conveniently overlooks the fact that over the same period there has been a dramatic drop in the number of strikes occurring all around the industrialised world and that on the strike front Australia is doing no better than many other industrialised countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I can refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to countries that do not have a centralised wage fixation system. The United States has enjoyed a dramatic drop in strikes; it does not have a centralised wage fixation system but it has quite the contrary of a centralised wage fixation system. Even the British Government, which is so roundly criticised so often by the present Government in Australia, has enjoyed a significant fall in the number of strikes over the last three years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition also welcomes the Government's commitment in relation to the export of uranium to Japan for peaceful purposes, although it remains to be seen what the Australian Labor Party Left will say on this issue and whether once again the Prime Minister at the National Conference of the ALP will be able to carry into effect what he has said to the Japanese about the export of uranium for peaceful purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Gorky Square said.

—It will be very interesting to see what Gorky Square has to say about uranium when we get to the National Conference. One can rely on Gorky Square to wake up and come to life every time one mentions uranium. Members opposite are absolute rippers; they cannot help themselves, they spring to life. I thought the honourable member was sleeping or reading one of those boring tomes put out by the Treasurer about the state of the economy, but, no, the honourable member sprang to life. I reckon that uranium is going to be an absolute bobby-dazzler at the National Conference of the ALP, and it will be absolutely marvellous to see what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition warmly welcomes the continued priority being given by the Government to Australia's relationship with China. Those who have studied the development of our relationship with China will know of the enormous contribution that was made to it by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. On behalf of the Opposition I want to take the opportunity of saying that much of the goodwill that now exists between Australia and China is due to the efforts of the previous coalition Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gough Whitlam.

—I also acknowledge, as I have in the past-and I say to my friend from Charlton-the contribution that was made by former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam in developing a relationship between Australia and China. I have never been reluctant to do that. I think it is a remarkable thing that three Prime Ministers as different as Gough Whitlam, Malcolm Fraser and the present Prime Minister could all in their different ways have made a contribution. I can assure the House that I will continue that tradition after the next election. I will be continuing the tradition of Australian Prime Ministers in building upon the relationship that exists, and ought to exist, between Australia and the most populous country in the world. In fact, when I was in China myself last year I had the opportunity to observe many of the things that the Prime Minister observed and I reported in similar vein many of the things the Prime Minister has reported. The importance of our economic, social and political relationship with China in the years ahead will be of immense significance to future generations of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say, however, one or two things about what the Prime Minister did not mention either in China or in his report to this Parliament. I think it is fair to say that, as the Prime Minister has taken a very high profile on human rights matters-he has not been reluctant to criticise human rights abuses in Indonesia or the Philippines-he has been silent on human rights abuses in China. Whilst it is important that we build a relationship, we should also recognise that there are human rights abuses in China. In many cases, they are just as serious and just as objectionable as they are in the Philippines and in Indonesia. The Prime Minister does himself no good at all in adopting this selective attitude towards our relations to different countries. Whilst I commend the importance he attaches to the relationship with China, I draw this Parliament's attention to the fact that, just as his colleague the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) failed to say anything about the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan when he was in the Soviet Union, the Prime Minister failed to say anything about human rights abuses whilst he was in China.

The other general comment I would like to make is that in the course of the Prime Minister's visit to China he said that he wanted the Australian-Chinese relationship to be a model to the world of how two countries with quite different political systems could learn to work together, to respect each other and to get on extremely well. Stated as a goal in terms of our relationship with China, I have no quarrel with that. I agree with the Prime Minister when he says that differences in social systems and political systems should not prevent two countries from coming very close together. To the extent that he wants to apply that principle in relation to the Australian and Chinese people he will have the support of the Opposition.

However, I ask once again: In the name of even-handedness and in the name of consistency, will the Prime Minister apply that same standard to Australia's relations with Indonesia? I ask that because one of the great foreign policy failures of the Hawke Government is the way in which it has presided over the sinking of our relationship with Indonesia. No speech on foreign policy and no speech in this Parliament that remotely touches foreign policy issues can be complete without a reference to the serious deterioration of Australia's relationship with Indonesia. Our relationship with China is important-I do not diminish that for a moment-but so is our relationship with Indonesia. I would hope that the Prime Minister would invest as much goodwill, as much political and diplomatic effort and as much political and diplomatic capital into improving our relationship with Indonesia as he has invested in our relationship with China. Therefore, whilst welcoming in a positive way some of the things the Prime Minister has said about our relationship with China I deplore the fact that he appears to be going in the totally opposite direction so far as our relationship with Indonesia is concerned.

He raises the red herring of grovelling. Nobody has suggested that there should be any grovelling to Indonesia. I say to the Prime Minister: Get the monkey of the left wing's obsession about East Timor off your back and recognise that our relationship with Indonesia surpasses our relationship with virtually any other country in the world, and something has to be done by this Government to bring about a repair in that relationship. It will go down as one of the great foreign policy failures of this Government, when its score card is made up at the next election-when it goes out of office-that it has presided over the virtual dissolution of the close relationship that used to exist between Australia and Indonesia. That is not a matter of pride. That is not a matter about which the Government can be complacent. I say to the Prime Minister that he will do Australia a great service if he invests as much goodwill in building back our relationship with Indonesia as he has invested in developing further our relationship with China.

I have to make those remarks whilst generally welcoming so much of what the Prime Minister said about his visit to China. Whatever views honourable members may have about matters related to the protection of Australian industry, I must say that I agree with the interjection made by my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who said that the Prime Minister had failed to make any reference in his report to the Parliament about the discussions involving Australia's textile, clothing and footwear industry. If parliamentary reports are to be anything-they need to be something other than just anodyne reports of all the favourable things that take place while one is overseas-one has to be fair dinkum and report on exactly what was said. There was absolutely no reference to that industry by the Prime Minister. I think that is a great pity.

I think also it is worth remarking that the expectations of the Prime Minister since his 1984 visit to China have been considerably scaled down. It is a bit like the expectations of the Prime Minister about the Australian economy. They have been considerably scaled down. The Prime Minister's pronouncements in 1984 concerning a possible steel deal with China have still not come to fruition. The Kwinana and Channar projects are still completely up in the air. The Prime Minister's 1984 suggestion-this was an interesting one-that industrial relations contracts with China should cover those industries that export to China also has come to nothing due, no doubt, to the staunch opposition from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to these issues.

I also say that, very disappointingly, the Prime Minister's speech glossed over the crucial question of the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia and the attitude taken by Peking to the occupation of Cambodia by the invading Vietnamese forces. Once again, if one is going to presume to give a serious report to the Parliament one has to report everything, warts and all. The Prime Minister may have enjoyed all the soft publicity he got while he was in China; he may have enjoyed all the cuddling of the pandas and all those other things while a storm raged back here. He may have enjoyed himself giving some background briefings to members of the Press telling them how he dragged the Treasurer into line. However, all the hard issues-the human rights abuses; the Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea and whether we really are to have some kind of worthwhile steel deal with China-were completely ignored in the Prime Minister's report.

Of course, perhaps the real explanation as to why he did not raise the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia to any great extent is that he still remembers the enormous embarrassment caused by the Foreign Minister's clumsy intervention on that particular subject when he succeeded in one stroke in getting the five Association of South East Asian Nations completely offside. I do not think that any Foreign Minister in Australia has ever had five strikes all in one as he did on that occasion. That would have to go down as the most united condemnation of an Australian Foreign Minister by friendly governments in South East Asia since the end of World War II.

Let me simply say in concluding my remarks on China that whilst we welcome, as I said at the outset, the important relationship and the contribution being made by the Government to that relationship we are a little disappointed that we did not get it warts and all. We are a little disappointed that it was strong on travelogue and pretty light on serious detail. Most of all we are bitterly disappointed that the Prime Minister did not tell us about his famous phone call-the `I love you' call-to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) and all his other ministerial colleagues. We are very disappointed indeed that we did not get some report on that or on the background briefing.

I turn very briefly to the Philippines section of the Prime Minister's speech. I welcome, as do all members of the Opposition, the Prime Minister's support for the continuation of United States bases in the Philippines. I say on behalf of the Opposition that continuation of those bases in the Philippines is absolutely fundamental to our views about regional security in our part of the world. We will do everything in the future, as we have done in the past, to encourage a continuation of those very important United States bases in the Philippines. We too welcome the efforts being made by President Aquino and her Government to overcome the enormous social and economic problems which face her nation. We welcome and support the decision of the Government to increase Australia's aid to the Philippines. Overseas aid, properly and intelligently provided, is an important instrument of foreign policy. We have a self-interest, as well as a humanitarian obligation, to provide appropriate levels of overseas aid. The Opposition will always take a very constructive and positive attitude to the provision of overseas aid.

I regret that in the Prime Minister's report to the Parliament he did not indicate that the Australian Government firmly opposes the activities of the communist New People's Army which is currently attacking the forces of the Aquino Government. I think that the Prime Minister should have told President Aquino and her Government that they have the full support of Australia in their efforts to tackle the rebellious and socially destructive activities of the communist New People's Army.

Finally, I say that while recognising the enormous importance of Australia's relations with Japan, China and the Philippines the Opposition regrets that the Prime Minister has paid so little attention to the crucial relationship that exists between Australia and Indonesia. I will continue to pursue this theme on every occasion I can in this House when matters relating to foreign policy and defence are raised. I believe that until this Government seriously addresses the deterioration that has taken place in our relationship with Indonesia it cannot fairly claim to be addressing the foreign policy concerns, demands and imperatives of this country in 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Nehl,Mr Snow and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that persistent rumours suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying the granting of the TPI pension.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Halverson.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
Persistent rumours suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urges the Government to:
Honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Reviewing the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to irrigation systems and the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby and Mr Snow.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace activities:
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self-help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops to assist the greening of Australia.

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost all presently wasted domestic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with mineral-rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock quarries and mines, into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in revitalising impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
