DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The dramatically worsening economic outlook as disclosed by yesterday's private investment figures and today's national account figures.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning we received some very sad news from the Commonwealth Statistician. We learned that the December quarter figures, which were given to us three months ago, have been revised. These figures show that the Australian economy, in fact, contracted during the December quarter. The figures also show that there has been another contraction in the March quarter. In blunt terms, these figures indicate that the Australian economy had already moved into recession at the very time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was hiking interest rates to their highest levels since the Great Depression. The Treasurer, who has been putting forward a line about the brilliant economic management of this Government for the last three years-and more stridently for the last 12 months-is now exposed as having put the hammer of ultra-high interest rates into an economy that was already in decline. These sad figures were brought to us this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has had a Press conference and made a statement which bears no relationship whatever to the actual state of the economy. When the balance of payments is showing a $1 1/2 billion deficit for the month of April and a $14 billion deficit for the whole year; when inflation is three times the average of the major trading nations; when unemployment in Australia has been stuck at 8 per cent for months, and is now beginning to rise; when youth unemployment has risen again to over 22 per cent; when bank interest rates are the highest in living memory; when yesterday we learnt, again from the Statistician, that private business investment on which we depend for economic growth, for jobs, and for improvement in our balance of payments has fallen over the last two quarters; when our overseas debt is up to the appallingly high figure of $70 billion, and forecast to go to $100 billion-South American levels-by the middle of next year; when interest charges in our Commonwealth Budget are $7 billion-more than we spend on national defence; when today the national accounts reveal that for the last two quarters our economy has moved into recession and, when our economy is indeed moving to that of a banana republic, to use the Treasurer's words, what is the Treasurer doing? He has had the House tied up for full two days while 275 pages of anti-business tax legislation was introduced. That is what the Treasurer has been doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Treasurer, in that case?

—Where is the Treasurer to answer these charges? He is not in the chamber. He is again treating this matter with contempt. I must say that, as with the balance of payments figures we had a few weeks ago, he is hiding from the results of his own economic policies. What are his mates doing when we want investment desperately, wage restraint, and expenditure reduction? What are his mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions doing? I certainly do not include the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) amongst his mates. While this has been happening the Prime Minister has been doing a two-week additional tour of provincial China. The business part of that tour could have been done in three days. So in relation to all this, the Prime Minister has been, and continues to be, irrelevant, so I certainly do not include him as a mate of Keating. He is not a mate of Keating's mates any more than is Mr Richardson any more.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar should refer to Ministers and members by their titles.

—The Treasurer is no longer a mate of the Prime Minister. What about his mates in the ACTU? What are they doing when we need investment and wage restraint? Yesterday they called a 24 hour national stoppage. People were walking off the job all over the country. Were they calling for more investment? Were they calling for wage restraint? Were they calling for cuts in expenditure? Of course, they were not. They wanted the national wage case to be advanced. They wanted higher wages across the board, regardless of whether or not they had been earned. Under the accord mark 2 they are asking for greater government expenditure. Of course, they are calling for greater investment from industry. But in order to give some evidence of their good intentions towards industry, they called out all of their members on a stoppage over the course of the last 24 hours.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) say about that? At least he is in the chamber. Maybe he is only present because he is on House duty; I do not know whether he will respond in this debate. He was silent about the stoppage by the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—What did we hear? A mouse speaks.
—A mouse squeaks.

—A mouse squeaks; a mouse speaks. Does it squeak or does it speak? The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations tells me that he made a squeak about yesterday's protest by the ACTU. That is what the Treasurer's mates have been doing while the country has moved into recession.

SPEECH.PARA: What about his mates in the Cabinet? What has the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) been doing? He has been saying to left wing conferences that there should be more social security expenditure. He has been attacking his colleague the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-who is trying to show some sort of fiscal responsibility-and defending rorts in the social security system.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Gietzelt.

—What about the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt)? He has been travelling around the country, saying that the solution to our economic problems is to increase government expenditure and to have quantitative restrictions on imports. That is what he has been saying. The Treasurer at least had to disagree with the second half of that piece of lunatic left wing advice.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Minister who passes for the Minister for Health in Australia today? What has he been doing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Death.

—Dr Death. He has been spending more money on a health system that does not work. He has been offering free health care to everybody. Money is pouring out of the Treasury. The standard of health care has gone down, yet he is asking for more money. That is what the Treasurer's mates have been doing. The ACTU is striking for more pay and additional government expenditure. The seven spending Ministers, who leaked their letter of defiance to the Prime Minister when they were asked to restrain their spending, are travelling all over the country, addressing left wing conferences, attacking the basic policies of the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer. What the devil are we doing with this Government in the present state of the economy?

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite extraordinary, but I do not know whether the Treasurer has yet recognised the problem. His line over the last couple of weeks has been that somehow we have a buoyant internal economy. Everything in the internal economy is wonderful; all we have is this trouble with the external economy. Mind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, this tune is not a constant one. When he had to meet his responsibilities regarding the Economic Planning Advisory Council on Friday, 9 May-which on my reckoning is not very long ago, only a couple of weeks ago-he stated:

Overall, 1986 is emerging as a year of slower, but still satisfactory growth, a year in which we will see consolidation of the very strong gains of the past three years, and in which the economy can deal with the imbalance on our external account.

That is what he said to the Economic Planning Advisory Council on 9 May. A week later we had some crook balance of payments figures. When he appeared on the John Laws program he told Australia that we were moving towards becoming a banana republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —One week later.

—So one week later everything is going down the chute. A week previously, fulfilling his important responsibilities-as we thought-to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, he said that everything was okay. When we pointed out the discrepancy, he told the House: `We have an extremely strong internal economy. You dummies over there don't understand the difference between a weak external position and a sound domestic economy'. I spoke to my wife about this. I said: `Listen, how is it that, when we are going down the chute with the bank manager, we have a sound domestic economy? How is it that when we owe $100 billion abroad we have a sound domestic economy? How is it that when inflation is over 9 per cent we have a sound domestic economy?' The Treasurer says: `That is all right. We have a sound domestic economy because it is booming and we have a weak external account, which is a great difficulty. I am not quite sure whether we are on track or, a la Laws program, we are going towards a banana republic'. So there is a dichotomy in this regard.
—What did your wife say?

—She gave me some very sound economic advice. She is a good handbag economist. Basically, she believes that a person should not spend what he does not earn; he should not borrow what he cannot pay back; and he should set something aside for his children and grandchildren.

SPEECH.PARA: National accounts figures were produced today which, without the slightest doubt, I say to the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), showed that the domestic economy has gone down the chute. For two full quarters, while the Treasurer has been saying that the domestic economy is in fine shape and we need only worry about the external economy, it has been in recession. At the end of November interest rates were hiked up to their highest level since the Great Depression. This occurred after the economy had already begun to slide. The Treasurer said that this was a fine tuning adjustment to bring it back into some sort of balance. That is what he said, at the very time at which he was wielding the hammer on an already fragile economy.

We now have another dichotomy. The Treasurer in the House today cited the figures for the first half of the financial year and said: `We are doing well. We have a booming economy. The figures for the first half of the financial year look very good. If you add those to what are admittedly not very good second half figures, we are coming out on target'. I say to honourable members that this car is rushing down the hill without brakes and the Treasurer is looking out of the back window. He is looking at the signposts of the December national accounts figures. I do not think he has even seen today's national accounts figures. One would hardly know he had seen them, after reading his Press statement today. He referred to the excessively optimistic Press statement issued after the December national accounts were presented during the last quarter.

So we have an internal economy and an external economy. We have the figures for the first and the second half. We have the EPAC statement and the Laws statement. We have a schizophrenic Treasurer. Day by day we have a different picture of what will happen. What will happen next week? What will happen on 5 June when he has to attend the non-summit meeting with his mates? Also, the business community is being dragged into it. What will he say to its representatives? Will he say the same things to them that he said to EPAC? Will he say the same things to them that he has said to the people of Australia and this House for the last 12 months? Will he say what he said to Laws or will he modify it after he has been spoken to on a bad, leaky line from China? Will he say what he said in the House today-looking out through the back window of a car that has no brakes, as it hurtles down the hill? What will he do now about monetary policy? We still have high interest rates. Bank loans are still at a very high level. What will he do?

The first thing he must do-this is what the Opposition has been saying he must do for months and months-is this: He must have a balanced mix of policies. We have said for months that he cannot rely on jamming down on the brake, using high interest rates to put it into reverse. Is that not the most dangerous thing one can do? Is that not what John Stone said? Is that not what Bernie Fraser, the present Secretary of the Treasury, said? Is that not what all the advisers from outside the Government who had any sense said? Has not the Opposition been saying for months that the Government must have a balanced policy, that it must have a wages policy that does not leap into high gear, with inflation and the balance of payments the way they are? Should we not have that? Should we not have a decent wages policy?

Let us call off this national wage case before it destroys us. Let us not take any notice of Simon Crean and his bully boys in the streets yesterday. Let us take notice of economic commonsense. We want a mini-Budget to cut expenses. We want a holding-off of the national wage case. We certainly want a reduction in the tax package that is killing business. We want a relaxation in foreign investment controls, and we want it soon, because we are currently heading towards a very severe economic recession, high unemployment and, certainly, a total betrayal of everything that the Treasurer-the man who should be sitting opposite me at the moment-has said he has been doing in the area of economic policy since this Government came to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather depressing for us to see the role that the Opposition--

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. There is not one Labor Minister in the House at this time. An Opposition front bencher delivered the speech on the matter of public importance and a Government front bencher should be answering the charges that the shadow Treasurer has laid here today.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—They were not charges, they were speculation. Five of the last seven discussions on matters of public importance have been directed against economic policy and against the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and honourable members opposite have not even dented him yet.
—Where is he?

—I will tell the honourable member one of the main reasons why he is not here. He is just fed up with honourable members opposite. If they were to get a little substance into their claims that they make about the Australian economy and about the economic competence of the Government, the Treasurer might feel it encumbent upon him to continue coming into the House to answer some of that rubbish. He has just had it. He is not going to waste his time when the best that honourable members opposite can do is to pick up the Australian Financial Review in the morning and pore through it looking for a couple of little economic indicators which might suggest in some way that something somewhere might be going wrong. Honourable members opposite are wrong. I am very surprised that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) chose to raise this matter of public importance in the way that he did. As I said, it obviously arose from his reading of the Australian Financial Review this morning, or perhaps the Sydney Morning Herald.
—The accounts came out at half past 11. What are you talking about?

—The honourable member for Mackellar claims that his proposing the matter of public importance arose from this observations and from his study of the national accounts figures. It did not, and the honourable member knows it. I have a little too much respect for his competence when reading those national accounts to believe that. If the honourable member had read the national accounts and pushed the statistical discrepancy around in a few different ways he would have come up with something quite different. I am not suggesting that that is the major reason for the figures that have been disclosed today, but the honourable member for Mackellar knows as well as I do that there is a very strong possibility that those figures will be amended later on. In fact, in some cases that I will indicate to honourable members shortly those figures are built upon assumptions which, because of the nature of the circumstances to which the assumptions relate, make them very inadequate indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is very distressing-it is a very sorry spectacle-that an opposition which aspires to provide government leadership for this nation should have sunk to such depths in poring through newspapers and financial papers each morning, hoping to find some economic indicators that will throw some gloom somewhere. Honourable members opposite have been the merchants of gloom and doom. The sorriest thing about this is that if members of the Opposition see evidence, for example, that perhaps unemployment might start to grow, they are joyful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—The shame of it is that they rejoice--
—No, not true.

—They do indeed. The honourable member for Menzies says that that is not the case. It demonstrably is the case. Honourable members opposite have been very despondent and very unhappy. They have been wearing frowns since March 1983. You have seen that, Mr Deputy Speaker; you are one of them-except when you are in the chair, of course. The only occasion when members of the Opposition wear smiles is when they feel that there is some indication that unemployment will grow. The only time they wear smiles is when they see some indication that a business might fail. The only time they wear smiles is when they think investment might lag. What a sorry spectacle it is that honourable members opposite, for their own petty, mean and miserable political objectives, rejoice in the hardships that may be being experienced by people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to the national accounts, honourable members opposite are concerned about the question of growth. If they are concerned about the possibility of negative growth, they may have something to say about it, because they are experts. For the seven years that they were in office real economic growth in Australia averaged 2 per cent a year. In 1975 they inherited an economy which had been averaging real economic growth of between 4 1/2 and 5 per cent for the previous 10 years. In seven years they devastated the economy. We have been in government for three years, and the figures speak for themselves. During our three years we have had average real economic growth of 5 per cent. (Quorum formed). Before the quorum was called I said that the members of the Opposition should be able to say something about negative growth because they are the experts and that after seven years under the Fraser Government the Australian economy was absolutely devastated. In fact this is what happened to real economic growth in the last three years of the Fraser Government: In 1980-81 the rate was 3.6 per cent; in 1981-82 it had dropped to 2.6 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 1982-83?

—In 1982-83, as my colleague has asked me, it had dropped to minus one per cent. Over that whole financial year economic growth in Australia had finally become negative. We know that the Australian economy then was in a state of free fall. It took this Government to reverse the process, resuscitate the economy, promote growth and bring about an upsurge in confidence, employment and all those elements which are so important to the economic performance of any government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one factor to which I wish to draw the attention of honourable members and the Opposition in particular. In the process of doing that, I want to draw this factor to the attention of the Australian people as well so that they know the penalty that was inflicted upon them as a result of the behaviour and economic incompetence of the Opposition members when they were in government. In the 10 years prior to the Fraser Government coming into office real economic growth had been maintained at an average level of between 4 1/2 and 5 per cent. We have now restored that rate of economic growth. Had the Opposition been able to maintain an equivalent level of economic growth-about 5 per cent each year-during its seven years in government every family in Australia, as a result of the productive potential which would have been created by that growth, would have been $170 a week better off at the end of the Fraser years. There is no question that not only does this Parliament generally recognise the magnificent achievements of this Government, but the Australian community has also recognised them.

I wish to make brief reference to some of the matters that were raised by the honourable member for Mackellar when he referred to the national account figures for March and December. While the current account figures at present probably indicate some degree of downturn from the very high level--

TALK.START.PARA: —Some degree? It is a disaster.

—Listen to the absurdity of that interjection. The very reason that the figures have shown a downturn is that we have put into place economic policies which were designed to bring that about. I am quickly losing any regard that I had for the economic literacy of the honourable member for Mackellar. He should know that in the second six months of the last calendar year real economic growth in Australia exceeded 7 per cent. Opposition members talk about difficulty on the external account. The honourable member for Mackellar knows, or he should know, that one of the reasons for that difficulty has been our buoyant domestic economy. The Australian economy has been growing too quickly-literally. We must find, establish, and maintain a level of economic growth in Australia which is sustainable and which will not create all these bottlenecks and pressures on the availability of investment funds in Australia, for example, which will continue to force up interest rates. We must establish a level of growth that will not drag into Australia an unsustainable volume of imports. That is precisely what this Government has been all about. For God's sake, do Opposition members not realise that? Has their economic literacy fallen to such a level that--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Yes!

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues assure me that Opposition members' economic literacy has fallen to such a level that they simply do not understand what is taking place. The other matter to which the Opposition drew attention was question of investment. I will not go into some of the analysis involved in throwing light on those figures except to say that there is no question that there has been a dramatic turnaround in the level of investment in Australia. In the Opposition's last year in government the real level of private sector investment in Australia fell by 10 per cent.
—No!

—The honourable member for Lowe expresses surprise at that, but I assure him that that was the case. Honourable members might believe that no government could be so incompetent but the previous Government was. It presided over a reduction in investment in its last year of 10 per cent. We have brought about a dramatic turnaround. We know that that has been the case, and one of the reasons for the high level of interest rates in Australia is the confidence and buoyancy in the economy and the fact that business people have been trying to attract the funds to carry out the investments that they know, as a result of the policies of this Government, will be productive and successful. These people will then be able to continue to make the magnificent contribution to the development of Australia's industrial capacity that they have made in the past.
—Order! The discussion has now concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the second report of the Committee entitled `Days and hours of sitting and the effective use of the time of the House', incorporating a dissenting report, together with a copy of the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled is the second report of the Standing Committee on Procedure. In this inquiry the Committee has conducted a comprehensive review of the hours the House sits, the pattern of sittings and the effectiveness of the use of its time. The recommendations the Committee has made have three major thrusts: Firstly, the Committee proposes a package of measures which will significantly increase the opportunities for private members in the House-opportunities for them both to raise matters of interest and to sponsor motions and Bills for debate; secondly, the Committee recommends a completely new approach to the programming of the business of the House; and thirdly, the Committee proposes that the House sit for a longer period each year to enable it to better cope with the volume of business before it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee also proposes that there be changes to the public importance procedure, that legislation committees be reintroduced, that there be alterations to the procedures for the presentation of petitions, that time be set aside for the presentation and consideration of committee reports, that there be changes to the quorum provisions of the House and that certain other proceedings be rationalised. On 20 May last the father of the House, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), stated in the House:

The sad thing I have found about centralism in my time is that greater power is going both from the Opposition back benches to the front bench and from the Government back benches to the front bench. The Executive is taking greater authority, both in the Opposition and in the Government . . . the back bench members have to stand up for their rights . . .

I am sure he and other honourable members will be pleased with the Committee's recommendations as they affect the rights of private members. The Committee proposes that there be a guaranteed adjournment debate of 30 minutes each sitting and prohibition on the moving of the closure during that period and that the adjournment debate will be broadcast. It also proposes that approximately two hours each sitting Thursday be set aside for private members' business with an improved procedure for selecting matters for debate, and that there be a 15-minute period set aside each day when members may make 90-second statements to the House as recommended in the Committee's first report.

I believe that honourable members will welcome the proposed changes to the programming of business in the House. The Committee is proposing the establishment of a business committee, with broad representation from the House, to consider and make recommendations to the House concerning the sessional, weekly and daily programming of the business, thus ensuring that maximum time is allotted to substantive and debatable issues and there is a more predictable and definite program set before the House thereby minimising legislation bottlenecks at the end of each sitting period. It is also envisaged that agreement will be reached on times for holding divisions and that proposed division times will be set down on the blue program.

In regard to the days and hours of sitting, the Committee has concluded that, for the House to give adequate attention to the business before it each year, there must be a significant increase in the number of hours it sits. The Committee is proposing that the House sit for a minimum of 20 weeks each year, for a total of approximately 670 hours-a 40 per cent increase over the 1981-1985 average. The Committee has also concluded that the sittings of the House should continue on a four-day week basis, with two weeks of sitting followed by two non-sitting weeks. In considering the proposed sitting pattern the Committee surveyed members of the House on their preferences for sitting patterns and timetables. The results of that survey are at Appendix 4 of the report.

The Committee proposes that in each sitting week the House sit from Monday to Thursday, the advantages of this pattern being that honourable members will be able to schedule Fridays for electorate commitments and other responsibilities knowing that Fridays will always be non-sitting days; the longer break between consecutive sitting weeks will benefit the large majority of honourable members who return to their electorates between consecutive sitting weeks, whilst still allowing honourable members to stay in Canberra should they wish to do so; and time can be gained each sitting fortnight compared with the current arrangements.

In regard to daily sitting hours, the basic choice facing the Committee was between a more compressed day, eliminating meal breaks and rising in the early evening, and the more traditional hours with meal breaks and a later rising. Having considered medical evidence, the Committee agreed that the practice of the House and committees meeting during meal breaks and sitting late into the night should be strongly discouraged. The Committee has therefore recommended the adoption of a sitting timetable similar to that currently in operation and that procedures be implemented that strongly discourage late sittings.
Other recommendations made in this report are:
that the public importance procedure be renamed `matter of public interest' and that one hour's discussion of these matters take place on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays;

that a specific time for the presentation of committee and delegation reports be set aside each week and that part of that time be set aside for the resumption of debates on motions to take note of committee or delegation reports presented at earlier sittings;
that legislation committees be reintroduced to examine in detail Bills referred by the House on the recommendation of the Business Committee;
that the procedures for the tabling of ministerial papers following Question Time be streamlined;
that, with certain exceptions, a prohibition be placed on the reading of speeches in the House-
I say `with certain exceptions', and this is one such instance-

that the petitions announcement be read by the Chair and be restricted to one day per week, that the number of signatories to each petition be included in the announcement, that Ministers be given the option to respond to petitions presented and that certain other changes be made to procedures for presentation and storage of petitions; and

that the quorum of the House be reduced to one-fifth of the whole number of members of the House and that each party represented in the House roster one-fifth of its members for House duties to ensure that a quorum is present at all times.

The Committee does not in any way see the recommendations embodied in this report as the completion of its charter `to inquire into and report upon the practices and procedures of the House generally with a view to making recommendations for their improvement or change and for the development of new procedures'. These reforms are no more than the beginning of our work, but reforms they are nevertheless. Former Speaker Snedden, when commenting on a list of reforms he had put forward, said:

There is much debate on how this Parliament can become more effective and how the practices and procedures of the two Houses and of this House in particular might be made more responsive to the demands made upon a modern legislature. I have been aware of the deepening interest of the members in these matters and their belief that reform must ultimately come from the House itself.

Honourable members will, I am sure, agree with Sir Billy's analysis, for only Parliament can reform its own practices and procedures and only Parliament can bring about the changes that are required not only to meet its own needs more effectively but also, and perhaps more importantly, to improve the public perception of the Parliament.

The implementation of these reforms will require not merely a recognition and desire by all honourable members for reform but also an abundance of goodwill by each section of the House-the Government, the Opposition executive and all back bench members-to acknowledge and provide adequately for the needs of all, because each section of the House has a quite separate and equally important role and need within the practices and procedures of the House. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I think I should commence by simply mentioning the fact that the Committee comprises not only the Chairman, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh), and me, as Deputy Chairman, but also the honourable members for Denison (Mr Hodgman), Throsby (Mr Hollis), Herbert (Mr Lindsay), Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), Wide Bay (Mr Millar) and Banks (Mr Mountford). The membership of the Committee represents several years of parliamentary experience blended with the new blood and enthusiasm as brought by the honourable member for Throsby.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the report of the Committee to the House and express the hope that the Leader of the House (Mr Young)-I hope that the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is listening to this-will be more open-minded in response to this report than he was with respect to the interim report that we brought in last year. Members on both sides of the House will remember when the Special Minister of State and Leader of the House ruthlessly took from us, this Parliament, the right to present notices of motion. Some months later our Committee produced the alternative proposal that we introduce the Canadian system, whereby 15 minutes is set aside each day during which individual members are allowed to rise to their feet for a 90-second speech. A member can get across much in that 90 seconds. But the Minister wiped that proposal.

I guess his reluctance to accept it was based on a fear that Opposition members might take the opportunity to hammer the Government. That is all very well. I guess Committee members and members from both sides of this House bring to the deliberations of the Committee the fact that one day we are in government and the next day we are in opposition, but our supreme thought must be for the benefit of the Parliament-not only the benefit of the government of the day but also the benefit of the individuals who comprise this Parliament. One of the sad aspects of life is that there has been a great erosion, particularly since that rather sad decision to increase the size of this Parliament. As a result, private members in this place are sinking further and further behind in terms of relevance.

I commend to the House the proposed res- toration of legislation committees and the establishment of a Business Committee. A Business Committee is terribly important to this place. No matter who is in power in Canberra, we always witness at the end of a session the introduction of legislation which is pushed through this place as if we were making sausages. The legislation is ground through with great speed, yet we spend the first few weeks of the session doing virtually nothing of importance, when everyone is allowed to speak for as long as they like simply because there is no real legislation before the House. I blame those in the government departments who have to piece the legislation together. They are probably like students facing an examination; they go along quietly through the year and when they know that the examination is just around the corner they speed up. That could well be an explanation for the legislation all seeming to come in together at the very end of a session.

Our suggestion that there be a time set aside each day when divisions would be held covering all pieces of legislation that might have been considered that day is also worthwhile. We all know how committees of this Parliament meet during the day and that members attending to other duties are often interrupted by divisions. Nobody doubts the importance of divisions and registering who voted for what, but to have them all done together at one part of the day would be infinitely better than the disjointed system that prevails at the moment.

The suggestion to reduce the size of the quorum from one-third to one-fifth of the Parliament has much virtue, particularly when it is taken in conjunction with the suggestion that we have an informal approach to keeping at least one-fifth of the members in this House on an informal roster system. That could be done, for example, by having one-fifth of the Government members and one-fifth of the Opposition members in here at all times. It could be done in a one-hour or two-hour stint, but it would be up to the members of the parties to make up their minds on that. There is nothing worse than for the public to come in here and look down and see absolutely nobody. I assure the people in the gallery today that they have a great crowd in here, compared with normal times.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a rough speaker.

—They knew I was speaking, Minister; they have all come in to hear me. All that aside, if we introduce a system which brings respectability to this chamber, I am sure that the public will have a far greater respect for the institution than currently exists. The realities of life are that people come down here to see me and they look in the Parliament and say: `Where are all the members?'. I say to them: `For a start, the member for Moreton is with you-I can account for him on the spot'. The other eight or ten members who comprise this Committee had several meetings during the sittings of the House; many committees meet during that time.
—You should not do that.

—I know that we should not do it, but we had no alternative because all the Parliament does these days is sit, sit, and sit again and we had to complete our report. I recommend strongly that the adjournment debate be broadcast at night. I can see no sense in the radios being switched off during what is probably the most interesting time of the day, when the private members take the stage and bring their feelings and grievances into this place. I conclude by making reference to the small amount of time that is devoted to the interests of private members. I read a short extract from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Compared with other Parliaments private Members . . . in the House of Representatives certainly have restricted opportunities to sponsor motions and bills for debate and decision. In the period 1970-85 3.7 per cent of the House's time was devoted to legislation and motions sponsored by private Members, including the Opposition executive. In the Canadian House of Commons comparable opportunities for private Members take up 7 per cent of the House's time and the figure in New Zealand is 6 per cent.

In the House of Representatives the time set aside for private Members' . . . business is 1 hour 15 minutes each alternate sitting Thursday following the adoption of the Address in Reply. In fact this time is often taken up by government business by order of the House.
That is the Leader of the House at work again. To continue:
During the period 1970-1985 there were 134 scheduled general business days, an average of 8.4 per year. However, government business superseded general business on 34 per cent of occasions.

One has only to look at the Notice Paper and the motions that private members would like to have heard to see the little opportunity available for them to express their views. It is a shame that the Leader of the House is absent, but I am proud that the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Sinclair), who is well steeped in the art of confining conservation in this place, is here. I hope that during the recess he and the Leader of the House will read the report and that we will come back in August and discuss it with an open mind, not thinking just of what is the greatest source of power to the Government, but of what is best for the Parliament and for the members of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence. I have spoken to the Leader of the House (Mr Young), who has assured me that, given the nature of the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure; the fact that it significantly affects sitting practices and procedures; that the report consists of 85 pages, together with its appendices; and that those of us who were not on the Committee obviously have not had the time to peruse it, there should be an opportunity for debate. The Leader of the House has told me that he believed he could accommodate that debate next week, and I hope that is so. I think it is important, as I indicated when speaking on a motion earlier today, that we have some discussion about procedures and practices so that before the Budget session, if any new sessional orders are to be introduced, they can be debated properly. The practice for some years has been that changes are introduced on a sessional order rather than a standing order basis, which would enable an amendment to be introduced at the beginning of the Budget session. I commend to the Leader of the House and to the Parliament that we should have an opportunity to read this report and a few hours should be set aside for consideration before the House rises. If that were done, with a bit of luck we might be able to get some resolutions at the beginning of the Budget session which might meet the convenience of all members. I believe that there is to be a motion for the report to be noted, so that such a debate can be facilitated. I trust that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, might be prepared to move such a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by John Brown)-by leave-proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
