DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:INCOME TAX (RATES) AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (CAPITAL GAINS) BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want just to put on the record the statement made by Mr Kelman. I think he is entitled to that, because the statement indicated a very high level of integrity on his part as far as the general question of capital gains taxation is concerned. This was the point at which I concluded earlier today, when the debate was interrupted to go on to other business. Mr Kelman and Mr Coates both indicated that they had no objection to a capital gains tax; in fact, their statements have indicated that they support it. The statement attributed to Mr Kelman reads:

SPEECH.PARA: He stresses that any capital gains tax `must have proper and sensible safeguards, including no retrospectivity, indexation for inflation, protective clauses for farm properties and the exemption of certain assets such as homes'.

I referred earlier to Mr Darrell Williams of the Young Liberal Movement, when I indicated that he could probably feel a great deal of satisfaction with the approach that this Government has taken. Undoubtedly people of the standing of Mr Kelman would also do that.

In conclusion, I say that on previous occasions I have indicated that under the former Government tax evasion and avoidance in Australia reached the level of $7,000m every year, which represented something like $30 a week that the ordinary Australian household had to pay in tax in order to compensate for that. I indicated as well that this Government had a very clear mandate to lift out of the taxation system all those rorts and all those ramps which have distorted it and which have allowed people to abuse it. While there may be an attempt on the part of members of the Opposition to frustrate us, let me assure them that we have a mandate. The Australian people want the taxation system cleaned up. They want it applied fairly and with equity and we intend to do precisely that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an air of unreality pervading not just this chamber but also, I suspect, all of Canberra. It may be that many listeners to this debate will immediately think that that is nothing unusual, but those who have listened to debates or who have visited this place in the last two weeks when the Opposition was unrelentingly putting a number of questions to either the Treasurer (Mr Keating), or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), or both, will know exactly what I mean. At a time when the economy is suffering to such a degree that the Treasurer of the Government, the man with prime responsibility for its health, declares us to be nothing short of a banana republic, the introduction of a capital gains tax is economic lunacy. A consideration of the figures collated on private investment in this country, the exchange rate, the inflation rate, the balance of payments, foreign debt and interest rates will show that the Treasurer was perfectly correct to describe us as just short of, if not in actual fact, a banana republic.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) asked the Prime Minister, as late as Question Time today, whether he would permit a statement to be made to the Parliament on the state of the Australian economy. The Leader of the Opposition referred to a number of inflation figures which show up the serious position we are in. Australia has an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent; Japan, 1.1 per cent; the United States of America, 2.3 per cent; West Germany, 0.1 per cent; France, 3 per cent; and Italy, 7.7 per cent. Those comparisons are reflected also in interest rate figures. Our major trading partners have interest rates and inflation rates which are a mere fraction of our own. Yet the Prime Minister, in reply to that question, ruled out any possibility of a statement which would allow debate to take place on the basis that Australia has external problems but we have, to quote the Prime Minister, `a magnificent internal economy'. That is the same line that is pushed by the Treasurer ad nauseam, hence the unreality. Why is it not possible for the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and other members of the Government to circulate in the community amongst those who have the responsibility for generating wealth so that they know what state our economy is in?

The reason we have external problems is related not just to world market trends but also to the decline in competitiveness because of our high internal cost pressures. At a time such as this, when our balance of payments shows that by 30 June 1986 we will be some $14 billion in deficit, we find the Government imposing further disincentives and tearing away initiative for the private sector. All I can say is: Will the last businessman leaving Australia lock the door? if he has the time he can pat the dog as well.

The simple fact is that this Government is on a course with its entertainment taxes, its fringe benefits taxes, its capital gains taxes, its negative gearing, and its abolition of the quarantining of farm losses, which will lead to a further drying up of the wealth creating sector on which so many of the jobs and the growth and the export earnings of this country are so dependent. The Prime Minister announced some months ago that, in drawing up changes to the taxation system he would base it upon fairness, simplicity and certainty. When any, let alone all, of those criteria is applied to the fringe benefits tax or this capital gains tax it makes a mockery of his claims for reform. There are more questions that cannot be answered about this capital gains tax than there are questions that can be answered. There is certainly no incentive for a person to set up his own business because the goodwill will not have an indexed cost base.

The Australian Democrats have made much of the fact that they are alleged to have won a major concession from the Government, in that 20 per cent of the goodwill component of the sale of a small business below $1m will not be taxed. Firstly, the Act does not define goodwill. We know that goodwill is commonly taken as being the residual of what is paid over and above tangible business assets. But there are differences in goodwill between different industries. For example, the goodwill component of service industries is both calculated differently and is different in size from that of, say, the manufacturing industries. The first problem is defining goodwill. The second problem is: How does the Government arrive at this magical figure of 20 per cent? Why do we not have a 50 per cent exemption for goodwill? It simply does not make sense but if the track record of the Democrats is anything to go by, anything involving them does not seem to make to much sense at the best of time. The Democrats have supported the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition is committed to repealing the fringe benefits tax. The Democrats supported the capital gains tax. The Opposition is committed to repealing the capital gains tax. Let all listening to this debate understand that the Opposition unreservedly commits itself to repealing these two iniquitous taxes. The Democrats simply have no credibility whatsoever, if they had any to start with.

There are so many important technical questions to be posed in relation to this taxation. Let us look at proposed new section 160m, sub-section (8) of the legislation. That proposed new section provides that a person leaving Australia is deemed to have sold certain assets when leaving. That will force persons who otherwise might maintain ownership of Australian assets to sell them just to pay the tax. What is the logic of that? Section 160y provides the classic disincentive for people to leave assets to charities. As if the fringe benefits tax will not be a sufficient burden for charities, we now have charities being disadvantaged under the capital gains tax. That proposed new section provides that the deceased is deemed to have disposed of the assets at the time of death, thus the estate will bear a liability to capital gains tax. That will surely prove to be a disincentive to persons leaving legacies to charities. I am worried also about proposed new section 160zzu because of the onerous record keeping requirements. It is very much like the fringe benefits tax. We create a whole new administrative burden for the private sector.

Looking at proposed new section 160zh, I find that the legislation is inconsistent because that provision does not tee up with proposed new section 160za. Let me explain. In calculating the cost base, all holding costs should be taken into account. In the case of negatively gearing assets, the holding cost will be deducted but it is not relevant where, for example, land is not income-producing. Further questions are posed by proposed new section 160l, sub-section (3), sub-section (4) and sub-section (5), which should also exclude from the legislation depreciated assets where an amount has been assessed to a taxpayer pursuant to some other provision, such as section 59 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

I am reluctant to continue to pursue these technical aspects of the legislation as obviously they require very detailed consideration. The fact is that this highlights the lack of time given not just to members of this place but also, outside this chamber, to accountants, tax agents, lawyers and small business people to understand properly the legislation. It was introduced into the Parliament by the Treasurer late on Thursday of last week. It is complex, detailed legislation which was introduced together with five other pieces of legislation, all of which had to be carefully considered. We find, going through it, that we simply have not had time to consider the interrelationship of these specific provisions with existing provisions under the whole welter of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Let us have a look at the legislation as it applies to a trust. It is clearly wrong, because any distribution by a trustee to a beneficiary is deemed to be a disposition at market value, thereby attracting tax under proposed new section 160ZX. This will cause assets to remain in trust and not be distributed to beneficiaries. Proposed new section 160ZYA will give rise to double taxation. I find proposed new Division 16 unsatisfactory, because it must include annuities. Furthermore, rollovers are allowed for com- panies so why are they not allowed for trusts? I am also concerned about proposed new section 160ZZO, because distributions of assets in specie, if the consistent line of tax authorities be adhered to, should enjoy the same relief as a transfer to a wholly owned company. That makes a mockery of the Government's claim that this legislation is certain and clear. It is not clear, it is not certain; and the Government stands condemned for introducing it in a slap-dash manner which does not allow proper and careful consideration of all the complex provisions.

It is the philosophy behind the capital gains tax, leaving aside its technical components, which worries the Opposition more than anything else, because the capital gains tax will act as a dampener on the private sector at a time when the dependence of this country on the wealth generated by the private sector has never been greater. We learn from Australian Bureau of Statistics figures that half the Australian adult population receives either a government pension or a government salary. It is not about attacking pensioners or public servants willy-nilly, but we must acknowledge and we need to understand that half the Australian adult population depends on the Government. Governments do not create wealth; they distribute wealth. Of the other half of the Australian adult population, 60 per cent are unionised. So, one can immediately see that the wealth-creating sector, those who provide the initiative, who take the risks and who invest in capital, are a shrinking minority and have a heavier burden than ever before to carry. We need to understand that if we are going to put in place in this country the incentives necessary to ensure the growth of that sector. This taxation simply defeats that purpose.

In any event, what will be gained from this tax? In France, in 1983 the capital gains tax revenue as a percentage of total tax revenue amounted to 0.04 per cent; in Italy in 1983, 0.9 per cent; in the United Kingdom in 1983, 0.7 per cent; in the USA in the same year, 2 per cent; and no figures are available for Canada, Germany and Japan because they are such small amounts. We are imposing a terrible disincentive on the private sector for no real gain whatever, except perhaps a growth in the number of officials to be employed in the Department of the Treasury.

There are a number of hidden traps within the capital gains tax, which my colleagues in the Opposition highlighted in the debate this morning and which they will continue to highlight. It saddens me that there are not as many people outraged by the capital gains tax as there are in regard to the fringe benefits tax, mostly because the Government in a devious manner has hidden true effects by declaring that capital gains taxes will not be paid on assets owned prior to 19 September 1985. However, there are hidden traps. For example, a farm which is realised by family members will be taxed, and so will a family house sold by beneficiaries under a will. Capital improvements on a farm that was acquired prior to 19 September 1985 will be subject to capital gains tax, presuming that if this is left to the discretion of the Commissioner the Australian Taxation Office can evaluate what those capital improvements were that did not exist prior to 19 September 1985.

It is a dark day for Australia. This measure, in line with the other tax imposts brought about by this Government, will do more than anything else to destroy incentive in this country. The Treasurer himself has declared it a banana republic. The Government is delving into the realms of the ridiculous if it thinks that it can reverse the downward trend by taxing the living daylights out of small business, farmers, the manufacturing sector and our export industries. The Government has much to answer for in the levels of poverty, the failure of young people to be able to purchase their own houses and the youth and adult unemployment rates. As long as the Government adheres to this policy of heavy taxation, together with an ever expanding public sector, we will find that the Treasurer's prophecy will be fulfilled. That worries every member of the Opposition. Every member of the Opposition is opposed to this capital gains tax. We will repeal it on returning to government, as we will the fringe benefits tax. Australia will suffer until the time comes when we are able to adhere to that commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a great pleasure to follow the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), because I truly believe that he is earnest in the points of view that he puts across. He goes to some very technical arguments and I am sure that the Government will answer those in good time. However, I feel that the honourable member has missed that main point in relation to the introduction of these pieces of tax legislation over the past couple of days. For example, he talked about the philosophy as to why these tax Bills should be introduced. Quite clearly we on this side of the House believe-and I think unfortunately for him he will find that even some of his most ardent constituents will agree with this-that people perceive that over the years there have been too many rorts in the tax system and that some people have not been prepared to pay their fair share. I think that even the honourable member would agree that we are talking about trying to make the system far more equitable, to ensure that everybody pays his fair share. That is a philosophy that we on this side of the House truly embrace. We are not in the business of protecting the tax evaders and the tax avoiders. We no longer wish to see the massive millions and billions of dollars being lost to this country through the hindrance to the ability of this Government to collect those taxes because of the variety of schemes that have been put forward on paper and, or course the bottom of the harbour tax schemes, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has gone to the people and has been returned with a mandate for tax reform. I indicate to honourable members opposite that they should look to the results of considerations that the Government has given to the introduction of this taxation reform proposal. If they go back to September last year. When details of the reform of the Australian taxation system were tabled and debated at great length and the various parts of the taxation reform proposals were spelled out in great detail, the honourable member for Gippsland and other honourable members opposite would be able to clearly understand what this Government is endeavouring to do. Another point that the honourable member for Gippsland made was that this legislation was dumped on us-all honourable members collectively-that there was no time for consideration. The same whinge was put forward yesterday by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the Opposition Treasury spokesman. All I can say to that is that it is absolute nonsense, because here it is-here is the document that says how it is going to be done. Honourable members opposite did not need the intricate pieces of legislation to get to the basis of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you do. It's like a travel brochure.

—I also point out to the honourable member for Gippsland that back in October 1985 a guide was put out explaining the new capital gains tax and it clearly indicates those points of interest to which the Australian public would like to refer themselves. It goes to the very issues that the honourable member, for one, talked about and said were no longer relevant and that people really had to be frightened about. What nonsense that is. It is the same old tactic; it is the `money under the bed' sort of scare tactics that are being put to the people of Australia, trying to influence them to believe that the Government is doing terrible things, whereas in fact it is a moderate capital gains tax that we are talking about here. It is not horrendous, it is a moderate capital gains tax that is going to get people to pay their fair share.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, honourable members opposite subscribe to the view that the pay as you earn taxpayers are the poor blokes who are going to have to pay that for ever and a day, that those whom they represent-the rorters, the evaders and the avoiders-are the ones who should continue to gain protection, that various other schemes should be put forward so they can walk around the system. It has always been the way for honourable members opposite to take that view. We on this side of the House absolutely and totally reject that point of view.

Some concern was expressed about those in the business community and what effect the tax measures, particularly the capital gains tax, might have on them. It is quite interesting to see what is happening to the business community at this point in time. The all ordinaries index, as recorded each day in the financial papers, throws up some very interesting statistics. When I was talking yesterday to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) he reminded me that at the time this Government came to office in March 1983 the all ordinaries index stood at 723. Yesterday, the index stood in excess of 1,200. That is an indication of how business sees the policies of this Government. Business people see a government giving clear direction to business, not giving disincentive, as was being argued by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). We are talking about making the system fairer so that taxpayers can reasonably expect every member of society to pay his fair share and therefore contribute to the continued growth of the economy.

I recall that last year when these tax proposals were first floated and the document on the reform of the Australian tax system was published honourable members opposite immediately jumped on the bandwagon, saying: `Repeal the lot. No way in the world will we accept these proposals. We will take the tax cuts. We will accept the goodies but we will not have any of the nasties needed to recoup the money needed to give tax cuts'. I think that the effect on the business community is important as well. We are talking about capital gains tax on the business community and those people who make capital. We are not talking about imposing a capital gains tax on people who do not make capital. It would be absurd to suggest that that might be the case.

What people have failed to recognise, however, is that businessmen have hardly acknowledged the fact that in the main they are the ones who will benefit from the massive tax cuts that this Government will pass on. We are talking about those same people who are being represented by honourable members opposite and who are whingeing about the terrible impost of a capital gains tax. They will be the recipients of the biggest slice of the tax rebates that will result from the tax cuts that this Government is to introduce. It is quite interesting that in the Sydney Morning Herald of Wednesday, 25 September last year-just after the publication of the taxation proposals of this Government-there appeared a very good article written by Mr Ross Gittins under the heading `Business whingeing errs on side of exaggeration'. I thought that was an excellent article. I would like to take some of the time remaining to me to quote a couple parts from that article. Ross Gittins was talking about businessmen whingeing about paying tax. He said:
We all hate paying tax, but what gets me is the way businessmen never admit to a concern for their own pockets.
We have the old hip pocket nerve reaction all the time from those people. The article continued:
Their complaints are invariably couched in terms of concern for what the tax changes will do to others: employees, customers, renters, the economy.

It is the same line that the agrarian socialists on the other side were pushing here this afternoon. The issue is never about making a quid; it is always about initiative and enterprise. I have a rule that whenever I hear a businessman rabbiting on about the disincentive to enterprise I ask myself: What lurk has this bloke been working? Does that say it? I think it does. I think it says it exactly. I think it says it 100 per cent.

Quite clearly this capital gains tax before us today will make the system much fairer, for a number of simple reasons. Those reasons are spelled out clearly in the major features of the tax. It will apply only to gains on assets acquired on or after 20 September 1985. Assets acquired before that are exempt. That is it-full stop. When an asset which is exempt because it was acquired before 20 September 1985 is disposed of, the new owner will be assessed for capital gains the next time that asset changes hands. That is all. The family home or farm house and a reasonable amount of surrounding land will be exempt. What is the whinge about that? Honourable members opposite will find one.

Also exempt will be the capital gains on motor vehicles of any value and on personal use items sold for less than $5,000. Again, what is the whinge about that? I cannot think of one. Capital losses in money terms will be able to be offset against capital gains. There will be an indexation for the inflation rate. Where is the harm in that? I cannot see any harm in that. What is the point of the continual whinge from honourable members opposite and those representing business interests who say that this will severely affect business. They say it will result in a big downturn in business. It is just not on. Of course, the tax also will definitely not apply when assets are transferred at death. That was one of the biggest complaints being levelled by honourable members opposite this afternoon. They are not here now. Where are the agrarian socialists who were arguing that the big factor was the transfer of their farms and so on after death. They have gone. They have disappeared from the place. Obviously they do not have the courage of their convictions.

The capital gains tax is one of the most significant parts of the tax reform package that this Government has introduced over the last couple of days and, in fact, over the last couple of weeks. It has been put together carefully. It has been thought through carefully. It is aimed at meeting the commitment and the need of the general taxpayers of this economy to have a fair system instituted. We are not in the business of protecting the tax avoiders and the tax evaders. We are in the business of collecting a fair share of tax so that those receipts can then be disbursed for all the important things that this Government needs to do. I refer to the important social programs and the other economic programs that this Government is pursuing. That cannot be done without the necessary fund raising. As the Treasurer has suggested, this tax and the other taxes we have dealt with in the last couple of weeks are revenue neutral because we are passing that revenue on in the form of tax cuts. Is that fair or is that fair?

This package of Bills is excellent. I commend the Bills to the House. I am only sorry that people such as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and other high flyers out there such as Bob Ansett are going around bagging this tax and every other tax. In this morning's Sydney Morning Herald Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen is quoted as saying `We won't pay', that there will be a High Court challenge and so on. He is saying that the tax is criminal. I can tell honourable members that I know what is criminal-and it is not these taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very brief contribution to this debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and to respond to some of the furphies put around by the Government concerning the nature of the Opposition's position on these measures and also to say something about reform of the Australian taxation system. I think that two things ought to be said at the outset. Firstly, what is now before the Parliament does not represent the original tax package that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government wanted. I can recall saying after the National Taxation Summit last year that at the end of the day all we would be left with would be the nasties of option A. Basically, that is what is now in front of the Parliament. Everyone knows that the Treasurer wanted to change the Australian taxation system to one with a greater reliance on indirect tax. Everyone knows that at the end of the day the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got together with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and dumped the Treasurer on that issue and made a deal which ultimately produced the nasties of option A.

SPEECH.PARA: The second great canard regarding this whole issue is that the revenue from the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the foreign tax credit system and all the other measures imposing new taxes is needed to finance the cuts in personal income tax which are to be given. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), who has just finished speaking, used that argument throughout his speech. I want to remind the House that in the second year, if the Government keeps its word about the tax cuts, something like 70 per cent or more-indeed, close to 80 per cent-of the revenue that will be needed to finance those tax cuts will not come from the measure now before the Parliament but will come from that old friend fiscal drag. In other words, all that the Government is doing is giving back to Australian taxpayers the additional moneys being ripped off them by the present inordinately high inflation rate. Whenever members of the House hear a Government speaker say that by opposing the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, or the foreign tax credits system the Opposition is being hypocritical in not opposing personal tax cuts, my reply is simply to throw in that speaker's face the fact that basically tax cuts are financed out of the automatic increase in tax collections arising from the impact of the high rate of inflation on our progressive taxation system under this Treasurer (Mr Keating). Therefore, I immediately put to one side this proposition that we are in some way being hypocritical in taking that attitude, because all the Government is doing is handing back to the Australian public the additional tax that it has taken from them through the impact of inflation on a progressive taxation system.

The Government talks a great deal about fairness and morality in the Australian taxation system. I think that it goes without saying that we would all, ideally speaking, like to see a fair tax system where everybody pays their fair share of taxation. That was certainly my view when in government, and it will be the view of the future Government. That is why the former Government was the one that smashed the tax avoidance industry in this country. It is interesting that there has been virtually no tax avoidance legislation introduced by the present Treasurer. The reason he has not introduced any tax avoidance legislation is that all tax avoidance of substance in the 1970s was destroyed by legislation that I introduced as Treasurer. I will match my record in smashing the tax avoidance industry in this country with the record of any Treasurer, present or past, because it was our legislation, particularly new Part IVa, that did more to annihilate the tax avoidance industry than any other measure taken by any other Treasurer in Australian history.

The other general comment that has to be made is that one can talk until blue in the face about perks, lurks and tax avoidance, but until the Government does something about the cash economy it will not cripple tax evasion in Australia because the real tax evasion in Australia now is in the cash economy. The Government will not do anything about it, it has done nothing about it in this package, and I swear that it will not do anything about it for the rest of the 18 months or so that it is in government. Any person who knows the first thing about the Australian taxation system knows that the real rip-offs now go on in the cash economy and, while this Government depends increasingly in its taxation system on personal taxation as a source of revenue, it will fall more and more behind in the fight against the cash economy. The Opposition opposes this capital gains tax measure. We have said repeatedly that we will repeal it when we are elected to government.

As recently as a week ago-no, I do him an injustice; it was as recently as two days ago-the Treasurer came into this Parliament and said that Australia is a capital scarce country. For once he was right-Australia is a capital scarce country. What is this Government's solution to the fact that Australia is capital scarce? It introduced more taxes to make capital even scarcer. This is an extraordinary situation; the Government has a problem with capital scarcity; so what does it do? It decides to impose a new tax which will make people even less likely to invest. This Government will impose a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. What is wrong with a capital gains tax is not only its actual impact but also its psychological impact, because capital gains taxes will psychologically act against capital accumulation by small business in Australia. I think that the thing we need more than anything else in this country is more people taking more risks more of the time. One of the ways to stop that stone dead is to introduce a capital gains tax. Honourable members opposite can present me with all the arguments in the world about the alleged fairness of a capital gains tax, but I simply point to the fact that an additional penalty placed on capital accumulation, no matter how many qualifications there are at the end of the day, will discourage the accumulation of capital. I cannot think of anything that more grievously runs against the medium and long term interests of this country than to impose a tax that discourages people from saving. It is a madness, when there is a terrible shortage of domestic savings in Australia, to be imposing a tax that actually discourages people from saving.

The fringe benefits tax has been paraded by the Treasurer as a great exercise in fiscal morality. He says that it is a tax to clobber all of the perks in the Australian taxation system. I do not deny that there are abuses in the area of fringe benefits and, in saying on behalf of the coalition that existing legislation will be thrown out, I want to make it quite clear that there are alternative ways of tackling abuses in the fringe benefits area and that they will be tackled by the Opposition when we come into Government. I do not want anybody to get the impression--

TALK.START.PARA: —But what about the--

—The honourable member will have plenty of opportunity, because during the election campaign in the seat of Hunter, which I am visiting at the weekend, we will have great delight in ramming that right down the honourable member's throat. He will be one of the great oncers of this Parliament and is on my hit list. The honourable member is on my hit list in large letters and, boy, are we going to have fun. The honourable member for Hunter seeks to interject again, but one thing that was remarkable about today was that, as the decibel rating of the response of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to my question during Question Time rose, so the psychological quietude of the people behind him became more and more evident. If ever there were a glum lot of back benchers and oncers, they were sitting right behind the Prime Minister today. They know some lousy national accounts when they see them, even if the Treasurer does not. They know exactly the sorts of political difficulties that they are facing. What is unfortunate is that honourable members opposite do not realise that in imposing these new taxes they will make the present situation worse. How on earth can they justify, at a time when business is not investing-and everybody agrees on this; we have rare unanimity of opinion on the fact that the business community is not investing; the ACTU says it, the Government says it, and the business community says it-
—Simon says it.

—Yes, and Simon says it. I say it-we all say it. What is the Governments response to that? We know what is the Government's response-`This is outrageous. We will make it even harder and less attractive for the business community to invest'.
—What about--

—The honourable member can seek to interject and talk about profit share, but I say again that the real measure of the business investment climate is not profit share but the after-tax rate of return on investment. Until the Government improves that, it will not get the business community to invest. All of these measures will make the after-tax rate of return on investment lower. That is the fundamental economic reason why the Opposition is opposed to these Bills. It is worth recalling, of course, as I know everybody does, that famous promise-and let me repeat it so that even members of the Government will understand and so that there can be no doubt about it-made during the 1983 election campaign: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Of course, that promise was made by none other than the present Prime Minister of Australia. He is the man one can trust!

SPEECH.PARA: There was something else that he said at about the same time, which was an absolute purler. Honourable members know what he said during 1983 and Gerry should listen to this because privately Gerry Hand, the honourable member for Melbourne, does not mind somebody having a go at Bob-he really quite enjoys it. Do honourable members know what our present Prime Minister said during the 1983 election campaign? He said: `You know, the Australian Public has had enough of those politicians that dispose of their promises as soon as they get into government.' Of course, the psychology of this Government on tax promises was borne out eloquently by the Treasurer when he was asked about the attitude he had taken on a capital gains tax when he was addressing the mates at the New South Wales Australian Labor Party Conference. The language he then used about a capital gains tax, when playing to a different constituency, and before he was Treasurer, was that a capital gains tax was absolute anathema to him because it hit hard at middle Australia. He happened to have that right. When he was asked about that after he became Treasurer and a capital gains tax was in the breeze, he said: `What you say when you're in Opposition, at party conferences, is for the purpose of getting into government. It doesn't really count once you get in'.

I say to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister that everything they said in order to get into government will count. It will be counted against them by all the Australian people. But, apart from counting against them, it will count against Government back benchers because they are in the electoral firing line. It is all right for the Treasurer. A 25 per cent swing would be needed to remove him from his seat of Blaxland. He is okay. I do not think the swing will be that big. I do not think there are quite enough small businesses in Blaxland to lap up to his electorate shores. But Government back benchers are in very big trouble. Well may they sit here during this debate.

This tax package is being rammed through this Parliament-so much so that the Taxation Institute of Australia wrote to the Prime Minister three days ago-obligingly, I have been provided with a copy of the letter-in the following terms:

The Taxation Institute of Australia, representing some 9,000 lawyers and accountants practising in the taxation field, deplores your Government's proposal to guillotine the taxation bills through the House of Representatives today and tomorrow.
But it get even better--
It has taken the Government almost a year since the Taxation Summit to bring down the bills in relation to capital gains tax and foreign tax credits.
Why is the Australian public being denied the opportunity for informed debate on the actual legislation effecting the most significant tax changes this country has seen.

Yet the legislation is being guillotined over a couple of days. It shows the absolute contempt that the Government has. I make it perfectly clear that the Opposition is opposed to these measures. I remind the House that, in regard to the tax cuts that we may receive, I notice that the Prime Minister has provided a `Dear Don letter. He has written to Senator Chipp, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, in these terms: `I promise you-and I am happy to provide it in writing-that we will introduce the personal tax cuts not later than 1 December'. I think the Australian public will believe that when those personal tax cuts arrive. What they ought to remember when those personal taxation cuts arrive-if they do arrive-is that they are not the result, in the main, of the measures now before the Parliament and they are not the result of any taxation reform; they are the result of the Government handing back to the Australian taxpayer money that it has ripped off the taxpayer through the operation of inflation on a progressive taxation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you did about the tax cuts after the 1977 election.
—Do not let any Government member, Minister or the Treasurer get away with any kind of argument about that.
—Come on; tell us this: What did you do after the 1977 election?
—Of course, one of the other measures that we have before us ought to interest the Prime Minister. He has waxed lyrical--
—You took them back. You promised them with the one hand and took them back with the other.
—Order! The Minister will be silent.

—I do not mind. He helps; he is terrific. I would like Gorky Square to join in, too. The Prime Minister has waxed lyrical over the last few days-he did it in Parliament today-about the burgeoning relationship between Australia and China, Australia and Japan and Australia and South East Asia. Yet he is proposing to introduce a foreign tax credits system, the immediate impact of which will be to discourage investment by Australian companies in South East Asia. The foreign tax credit system will have no other result than to make it less attractive for Australian companies to invest in South East Asia. Even one of the Government back benchers is nodding his approval of what I am saying. I thought about having a foreign tax credit system when I was Treasurer. I announced it; I put it forward as a proposal and, as a result of the representations I received from the Australian business community, I did not go ahead with it. I am glad I did not go ahead with it because it would have been a mistake. I think it is a great mistake that this Government is going ahead with it. I listened to what the Australian business community had to say on that occasion. I think it is a great shame for the future of this country's investment in South East Asia that the Government is going ahead with this stupid foreign tax credit system.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that the Opposition believes that it defies description for the Government to introduce these measures at a time when business investment is depressed and the figures and falling down into the ground in front of the Government's eyes. All of the hype and all of the bold talk about the state of the economy has been demonstrated to have been false and misleading. This week we have seen the most depressing investment figures imaginable. We have seen a set of national accounts that show that the economy has been contracting for the past two quarters and the 7 per cent growth that the Treasurer boasted about has now become 1.4 per cent. The domestic economy-the alleged jewel in the Treasurer's crown-is contracting and, ironically, the export sector has made a positive contribution over the last six months.

At a time like this, when what we need more than anything else is a better climate for business investment, the Government is imposing new taxes that will discourage business investment. They will not bring greater fairness to the tax system. What is fair about some of the impacts of the fringe benefits tax? What is fair about a tax that will impose, for the first time ever in Australia, a liability on a local church congregation to pay a tax in relation to private occupancy of the clergyman's residence? I say to the House that the advice that the Treasurer is giving in this Parliament is different from the advice the Australian Taxation Office is giving to people who are ringing up the Tax Office. I have had representations from clergymen in my electorate who have been told that a portion of the occupancy of a residence by a clergyman will be taxable in the hands of the provider of that residence. I defy the Treasurer to disown that statement. Government members glibly say that charities, non-profit bodies, are exempt. They do not address the charge I make. I challenge the Treasurer to disprove that that is its impact under the existing legislation. I think that is a mark that this is not a perks tax; it is a nark's tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Opposition members are leaving the chamber. I want to say something about Gorky Square. At least I do not harbour quislings and people whose performances during the last world war were questionable, as does the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. The previous speaker, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)-the former Treasurer of this country-talked about what he would do in terms of tax relief when he is returned to office. We all remember what he did on the last occasion that he was in office. In 1977, he promised tax cuts, gave them, got re-elected and took them away from the people of Australia. I think his record of tax reform is well known to everybody in Australia. So when he talks about what he intends to do when he is returned-if ever; and I doubt if he ever will be-to the treasury bench, I think people will dismiss him with the 16 per cent support that he currently receives throughout Australia. It is interesting to note that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is present. He is Mr Two per cent. He put out a Press release to the effect that he speaks for 197,361 Australians, according to a 1986 gallup poll. If one multiplies that figure by eight, one can calculate the number of people who support the Leader of the Opposition. I think that the message that the honourable member for Denison is trying to put across in his Press release is that he is gaining rapidly on the current Leader of the Opposition. I think that it will not be difficult for him to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Inclusion of a capital gains tax is an intrinsic and essential element in the Government's tax reform package on the grounds of equity, fairness, efficiency and the striking out of avoidance. Indeed, the capital gains tax proposal represents one of the more important in-principle innovations of the tax measures we are introducing. Principles of equity and fairness do not rank highly among members of the Opposition, particularly the ones who are leaving the chamber at the moment, so it is not surprising that they have gone into a state of quasi-hysteria over this proposal. I would have thought that their fetish for efficiency and neutrality would have been so powerful that it would override even their strong antipathy for creating a fairer tax system.
Quite frankly, I find the attitude of those few honourable members opposite who have remained to be extraordinary and hypocritical. I note that I am now getting pressured and harassed by one of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Denison will resume his correct seat.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is a bad practice for an honourable member to engage in that sort of activity in this chamber. Honourable members opposite say that they will not support this tax. This tax will remove a distortion in the operation of the capital market. I thought neutral outcomes and free markets were what they espoused in their political philosophy. Again, it just goes to show that the Australian people cannot believe what the Opposition says.

SPEECH.PARA: The equity argument is understood by just about everybody else involved in the tax debate, except perhaps the speculators and the tax rip-off merchants, whom those opposite condone and support. Yesterday, before the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), was turfed out on his ear, he spoke about the tax issues. I said to him, and I will say again to members of the Opposition, that they allowed the greatest rip-off ever of this nation through their lack of activity in the tax collection area. They did nothing about it. When we attempted to recoup the bottom of the harbour money to pass it on to the pensioners of this country, they would not allow us. Honourable members opposite should not come into this House and talk about how they feel, how they are hurt and upset about tax reforms. They allowed the economy of this country to be torn to pieces by people engaged in ripping off the tax system. So the credibility of the Opposition is absolutely zilch.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is 2 per cent lower than the popularity of the honourable member. That is the credibility of the Opposition in the taxation area-nothing. The principle of horizontal equity is abused since people who obtain some or all of their income from capital gains receive extremely favourable tax treatment. The principle of vertical equity is also abused. It is primarily the wealthier section of the community who own capital assets. These are the people whom those opposite are trying desperately to support.

SPEECH.PARA: What the White Paper said and what the Government understands is that the omission of a general capital gains tax has not just facilitated tax avoidance activities; it has been at the very heart of the problem in this country. As the tax base became smaller a greater and greater burden fell on ordinary wage and salary earners, who simply did not have the means to do anything but pay their fair share of taxation. As it turned out, they paid a part of the tax share that should have been picked up by other people. What we are on about in the proposals in the package of Bills that have been debated over the last two days is to make everybody pay a fair share of the cake-no more, no less. That is what this Government is attempting to do.

For too long in this country the pay as you earn taxpayer has carried on his or her back the burden of keeping the finances of this nation going. When honourable members opposite were in government they attempted to let people off paying their fair share. Now they are in Opposition they are trying to generate a state of hysteria in the community over the taxation changes. All those changes attempt to do is to bring about a fairer system. Peter Groenewegan, Professor of Economics at the University of Sydney, noted in his assessment of the tax package:

The general efficiency and equity case for capital gains taxation is well known and the screams of the Opposition on the present exceedingly mild proposal can only be interpreted as a rejection of economic rationality.

So much for the economic rationality of the economic rationalists within the coalition's ranks! I now wish to turn in some detail to the effects of this tax on investment. As I said earlier, the lack of a general capital gains tax has had a very disturbing impact on investment decisions. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated in his second reading speech that it had produced an inappropriate pattern of investment, preventing Australia from achieving the best possible economic growth rate. This distortion is something with which I would have thought the Opposition would concern itself, but apparently not.

To return to the issue, the concession to capital gains has served to produce an extremely conservative pattern of savings and investment totally unsuited to the capital requirements of a dynamic and growing economy. Rather, it has encouraged savings to be put into speculative activities such as property. In this respect I think it is important to note that in the five years to 1984 just over 40 per cent of investment by the household sector went into property. To a certain extent this form of investment has been influenced by taxation considerations. Capital is a scarce commodity. If tax policy steers capital into the development of office buildings, Gold Coast apartments, flats and so on, there will be less capital for other users or other users will have to pay more. If we were looking for candidates to subsidise, I would have thought rental housing and competitive manufacturing would have been preferable to some of those activities.

The responses from those who stand to lose have been predictable.They say that investment will drop, the bottom will fall out of the property market, and so on. These arguments, like the arguments of those who have gone overboard on the fringe benefits tax issue, have no substance. Predictions were made by the Opposition that up to 80,000 jobs in the entertainment industry would be dispensed with when the fringe benefits tax was introduced. Nothing could be further from the truth. There is a shortage of people in that industry. There is a shortage of chefs. There is a shortage of `waitpersons', as Ross Gittins calls them. We cannot get enough people to work in the entertainment industry. So the arguments have proved to be untrue and the scare tactics and the demonstration at the front of Parliament House have proved to be unnecessary.

I am skipping massive pages in my speech in trying to make just half of it. On the assessment and comparison of capital gains tax, so far much of the heat surrounding the capital gains tax proposal appears to have been dissipated by the fringe benefits tax debate. Those who worked themselves up into a senseless, mindless frenzy over that tax proposal have perhaps worn themselves out. That is obvious from the number of honourable members opposite who have not bothered to come in to hear this debate. They are probably just resting for the last bout, when we will undoubtedly hear the same wild allegations and exaggerations about the impact of this tax on ordinary people.

Fringe benefits and capital gains taxes are connected because they are both seen as nasties-not to be confused with those members of the New South Wales coalition parties who are known as the uglies-by the same self-interested people. They are also connected in a more fundamental way in that they are both base-broadening measures. As such they are integral to the establishment of a comprehensive income tax base and a fairer tax system. In this light, I was extremely pleased to read an unemotional presentation of the fringe benefits tax debacle by Ross Gittins in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald in an article that I suggest honourable members opposite should take time to read.

I make the point that this is a very mild tax. I was therefore astonished, to say the least, to read Peter Costigan's story in last Friday's Melbourne Herald. I was going to quote from that article, but again I suggest that those people who still read the Melbourne Herald should read that article, because it contains an exaggeration of the facts. The facts in the article are quite clearly not supported. Mr Deputy Speaker, I checked with the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) and I now ask the House for leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table on how other countries tax capital gains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time has just about run out. I will conclude by going through a couple of points. The tax package we have introduced recently into this Parliament is about redistribution of the wealth in this country. Under honourable members opposite the distribution of wealth resulted in the burden falling on the backs of working men and women because they had to pay their tax every week, and it was deducted from their pay. The Opposition when in government allowed tax rip-offs of huge proportions. It did nothing about them. A while ago the Leader of the Opposition came into this Parliament and referred to what he would do when he becomes the Treasurer. I make the point again that when he was the Treasurer the system was ripped off as it had never been ripped off before.

SPEECH.PARA: I am getting wind up signals from all around the chamber, but I want to say this: I believe that Australians will not trust the Opposition with the Treasury benches of this country, if for no other reason simply because of its performance in the distribution of wealth and administration of the tax system of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill which is being rammed through the House, along with the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill, under a guillotine today legislates for two things-a broken promise and a new tax. We heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today recount that promise that was made in 1983, and I will repeat it because I believe it needs repeating and we certainly intend to ram it down the throats of Government members. In the 1983 election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be no capital gains tax.

This legislation also introduces a new tax. Neither broken promises nor new taxes are new to this Government. In fact, breaking promises is its full-time occupation. This Government told us that there would be no death tax and of course that is included in the proposal before us today. This Government told us that interest rates would come down. What has happened? They have gone up. In the South Australian State election campaign this Government told the electorate that the ceiling on home loan interest rates would be maintained. As soon as the election was over the Government lifted that ceiling, as predicted by the Leader of the Opposition. This Government told us that inflation would come down to around 5 per cent. What has happened? Inflation is going up and currently it is at 9.2 per cent. If ever there was a case of Whitlam revisited, this is it. Many people in the electorate will remember the massive inflation of the Whitlam years.

This Government promised us 10,000 youth traineeships. We have just heard the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) make a speech in the House. One of the promises of any Labor government is a monopoly on compassion for the homeless in our community, yet that very same member a few months ago in his capacity as the President of the ALP in Victoria told us that under Labor homelessness was on the increase. This Government told us that one of its hallmarks would be honesty and propriety, yet as soon as a senior Minister breached the line as defined by the Prime Minister, the Government rewrote the rule book. This Government went into the last election promising pensioners that their pensions would reach 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have not heard much more about that since then. This Government recently promised tax cuts on 1 September. Those have gone out the window and the Government is now talking about 1 December. On the basis of our experience of this Government I think we should take the attitude that we will believe it when we see it.

New taxes are an everyday event for this Government. It rammed a fringe benefits tax through this House only a few days ago. It has introduced an entertainment tax and it claims that no one has lost his or her job as a result. I can assure honourable members that jobs have been lost in my electorate as a result of that tax. The superannuation tax was another recent addition to this Government's taxes. Petrol taxes have been going up virtually every day. There is no doubt that this is the biggest spending, biggest taxing and biggest deficit-creating government that we have ever had in this country. The Government talks about figures. Under Labor tax revenue is up 6.2 per cent a year in real terms. What a comparison with the 2.8 per cent of the Fraser years. The average annual increase in real tax revenue per person is 5.9 per cent under this Government; under the Fraser Government it was a mere 1.2 per cent. If people do not wish to accept the views of a member of the Opposition perhaps they would be more convinced by Eric Risstrom's comments in Melbourne yesterday. He said:
Most Australians face a tax increase and not a cut, even if the promised tax changes are delivered in September.

Mr Risstrom said that people earning between $18,000 and $28,000 a year were in the firing line for higher tax, with the typical married man being $3.50 a week worse off. He also said that next year millions of people would pay more in tax, partly because incomes would be higher due to inflation. He then said:
Income tax next year will bite deeper into every dollar earned by 90 per cent of Australians-and even more will be taken if the promised September tax cuts are deferred or watered down.

In those circumstances it is no wonder that we have a burgeoning tax revolt in this country. That revolt is not just by people who can afford to put advertisements in the Australian, but also by the man in the street. I had a letter yesterday from a man who I have known personally for a number of years-I do not know him terribly well, but we are acquainted. He wrote a letter to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which I shall quote. He said:

My wife and I shall not be paying any of these projected taxes. We have decided to retire as from 28 June. At the same time our income will be reduced substantially so you will also lose in income tax.
For many years we have conducted a successful and progressive business. Apart from our personal success we feel that we have added to the common wealth--
a dirty word in Labor circles--

through taxation, community service, employment of local youth, raising a family (which is now itself productive) and those many other things that we ordinary hard-working people do. Because of your intended impositions (along with superannuation, etc.) we are to withdraw our capital and our experience and live on our past efforts even though we are young enough and competent enough to contribute for many more years.
You have wasted us.

That is the end of the letter from my constituent. If that is not an indication of the ramifications of the Government's tax net I do not know what is. Honourable members should have no doubt that that tax net is widening. The Pony Club Association of Victoria contacted me a couple of weeks ago. It has received a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation which is hard to believe because it is a voluntary, non-profit, youth organisation. That letter asked the association to put in a taxation return if its income exceeded $416 a year. I find that absolutely unbelievable. Not only are we getting more taxes on a daily basis, but also find that the Government is pulling in the net and bringing in sporting clubs. It is not just pony clubs that are affected. Other sporting clubs such as those involved in carting, aerobatics, motor sports, polo, power boats and rodeos-to name a few-are also affected.

This latest tax package follows the 1984 election campaign when the Prime Minister, without a tax policy, announced that he would conduct a summit. He asked us basically for a blank cheque. All I can say is that he has been filling in that cheque ever since. Government Ministers went off to the National Taxation Summit-the Summit at which the Treasurer claimed that if he could not get his consumption tax through it was not worth his while being in politics. It was on for young and old. Everybody came to Canberra for a big talkfest. But of course the whole deal was settled one night in a dusty, murky motel room where the Prime Minister got his riding instructions from Kelty and Crean, who said: `Listen Bob, consumption tax is no good but we quite like the anti-business tax. Here are your riding instructions, get stuck into business'. Is it a good idea to proceed with these anti-business taxes? Perhaps there would be no better person to ask than the Treasurer. Perhaps we should ask him how things are going in the economy, whether things are good or not so good. Recently he spoke to John Laws on the radio in Sydney. He said:
The problems are more intractable as it is our fourth year of office.

That is great, is it not? The Government has been in office four years and things are getting worse. That is a contradiction of what he has been saying during the last three and a bit years. Talking about the prices of commodities, the Treasurer said:
That's a fact of life now-it's got nothing to do with the Government.
Ah! Pontius Pilate-nothing to do with the Government. At least he has stopped blaming us, which is something. Then he said that, given certain conditions:
The prognosis is . . . to close the economy down.
That is pretty encouraging! He continued:
If we don't do anything then you have gone, you are a banana republic.

He contradicted himself because one minute he said it was all the fault of somebody overseas and the next minute he recognised that the Government had to do something or Australia would become a banana republic. Thus the ball is in the Government's court, and what does it do? It brings in another tax to discourage investment. If that is not schizophrenia, I do not know what is. The Treasurer's speech, in introducing this Bill, indicated more of that schizoprenic attitude. He talked about smashing the basis of tax avoidance, yet there are many arguments that tax avoidance will not be found in the capitalisation of assets. He says the tax will make investment patterns more appropriate and fairer. All I can say is that the way this country is going there are not going to be any investment decisions to make at all. The national accounts figures are out today. I do not want to go too much into figures, but one would think that in the national accounts generally things would be up 1, 2 or 3 per cent. Gross fixed capital expenditure for the last quarter is down-not up-2.7 per cent. The figure for the last 12 months is minus 2.3 per cent. The fact is that we are going backwards.

One of my other concerns about the capital gains tax proposal is that it is just the thin end of the wedge. Let me say, in the context of whether investment patterns are appropriate, that I do not think there is any doubt about what most people are going to do. If they have any spare cash, they are not going to put into some productive enterprise. They are going to add on to the family home. I think that is just obvious. It is all very well for the Government to talk about productive enterprises. Those with capital will simply whack it into their home. The same sort of thing happened in regard to the assets test; millionaires continue to receive the pension.

This proposal attacks incentive. There is no point in taking a risk if one is going to be taxed by government. There is no point in building up goodwill or making capital improvements. Australia is a young country. We need to be attracting capital to create wealth and jobs. Contrary to what the Government is telling us, the level of unemployment unfortunately is higher now than it was for all but five of the 86 months of the Fraser Government. Of course, youth unemployment has been nothing but on the climb.

I want to conclude by saying a couple of things about what we are going to do. I think it is fair enough when we attack a piece of legislation like this and give a commitment to vote against it and repeal it-which is what we are going to do-to point out what we are going to do. I want to mention very briefly a couple of things that we are going to do. Firstly, we have to cut back government expenditure. There is just no point in moving the chairs on the Titanic. Secondly, we want to support families. We are talking about income tax, and we are very strong on income tax splitting and rebates for child care. We have to stop this silly business of a superannuation scheme based on 3 per cent of earnings which will give more power to the trade unions. We have to start to create in this country an investment climate which will encourage people to take a risk. The other thing we are going to do is cut back the power of the unions.

What remarkable hypocrisy it is for the Treasurer and Mr Crean to go to next week's summit and say that the trade unions have done their bit for the economy-that is pretty questionable-and it is now the turn of business to increase investment when yesterday Mr Crean led and encouraged a national strike and today we are debating the Treasurer's capital gains tax. We are going to vote against this tax and when we get back into government we will throw it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The misinformation and hysteria which the Liberal and National parties have sought to fan in recent weeks in the tax debate is, I believe, clear proof of the hypocrisy and lack of principles of the conservative parties in Australia. I think this debate really reached its nadir this afternoon when the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), came into this chamber and quoted the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He sought to use that quotation to make fun of the Prime Minister. I would like to throw this quotation back in the face of the Leader of the Opposition. In 1983 the Prime Minister said that the Australian public had had enough of politicians who disposed of tax promises once they were elected to office. The man to whom the Prime Minister was referring is the current Leader of the Opposition. That honourable gentlemen demonstrates complete hypocrisy when he seeks to attack us for breaking promises on taxation, when the history of his term as Treasurer from 1978 to 1983 is simply a litany of broken promises. We all remember the famous fistful of dollars advertisements in the 1977 election. At the first opportunity after the election the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), as Treasurer, withdrew the fistful of dollars tax cuts. Not only did he do that but he imposed a 1.5 per cent temporary tax surcharge. Do honourable members remember? It was supposed to be a temporary 12-months tax surcharge. Of course, in the following Budget he broke that promise as well because it was decided by the Fraser Cabinet that the temporary income tax surcharge would continue. We all remember his promises on full tax indexation. In his first Budget he broke that promise and applied only 50 per cent tax indexation. In his second Budget he totally wiped indexation of the income tax scales. So if the Australian community wishes to make a decision about which side of the House is better at breaking promises on taxation, the Leader of the Opposition would win hands down.
—That is the only thing he will win.
—It is the only thing he will win, as the Minister for Territories suggests. This legislation simply seeks to establish a mild capital gains tax and finally to put it on the statute books.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the claims made by the Opposition, Australia is one of the few remaining members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which does not have a capital gains tax. In fact, as the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) pointed out, the United States of America, perhaps the bastion of free enterprise, has had a capital gains tax since 1913. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has sought to suggest that the capital gains tax will, to use his phrase, stifle incentive. He suggested that it was anti-entrepreneurial and would destroy small businesses and farms. He was supported in this by many honourable members opposite. I put this simple question to him: Why has incentive not been stifled in the United States, which has had a capital gains tax since 1913? Why has entrepreneurial initiative not been destroyed in the United States? Why do businesses and farms still exist in the United States-which, I repeat, has had a capital gains tax since 1913?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not ripped off in other ways.

—Even in Australia, under section 25 (a) and section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, we already have a capital gains tax on short term capital gains. If the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) buys shares on the stock exchange and sells them within a year he has to pay capital gains tax under the existing legislation.
—Fair enough.

—The honourable member interjects that that is fair enough. The simple question I put to him is: If he sells his shares a year and a day after buying them, why should he be exempt from capital gains tax? I believe that there is an excellent argument for having a capital gains tax on short term and long term investments.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar also suggested that the capital gains tax would hurt the businessman who works for less than award wages in order to build up his business and obtains a capital gain when he sells it. I am sure that every wage and salary earner in my electorate and most wage and salary earners in Australia would love to have a scheme whereby they could avoid paying tax on part of their income which they could collect as a tax free lump sum superannuation payment when they decided to change their employment. That is an option which those small businessmen have under the current loopholes-an option which the ordinary wage and salary earners do not have.

I think it is very important for us to realise which groups within the community will be paying the capital gains tax. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a simple table contained in the Government's White Paper on taxation which explains the position in Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. That table demonstrates that a very small proportion of the income of people earning less than $50,000 a year comes from assessable capital gain-in fact, less than 0.5 per cent. The figure for people earning from $50,000 is 2.5 per cent; for those earning from $100,000 to $150,000 it is 5 1/2 per cent; and for people in the top bracket earning over $150,000 it is more than 15 per cent. So we can see, as we would expect, that those in the highest income brackets are making the largest amounts in capital gains. Therefore, if we continue to have a loophole in our tax legislation whereby capital gains are not assessed and are not taxable, the people who gain the greatest benefit will be the people in the top income brackets.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) sought to suggest that the capital gains tax would affect the private residential rental market. An interesting article which I came across in the Brisbane Sunday Mail of 1 December 1985 stated:
Capital gains and other tax changes will benefit the property market, a Brisbane investment consultant said yesterday.
This view, a heresy in real estate circles, comes from investment consultant, financial columnist and real estate agent Mr Noel Whittaker, who said: `Capital gains is not the problem-ignorance is.'
But Mr Whittaker agreed that the tax changes could dampen some of the more frenetic property booms seen in the past.
`I never thought such booms were a good thing,' he said. `A few sharks make some money and a lot of little people get burnt.'

The Opposition is seeking to protect the sharks who get involved in speculation and make big profits. The honourable member for Deakin suggested that the capital gains tax would destabilise the private residential rental market. If anything will destabilise the housing industry it is the Opposition's proposal to abolish grants under the first home owners scheme. I am outraged that the shadow spokesman on housing, the honourable member for Deakin, has not backed away from his proposal to abolish grants under the first home owners scheme which, more than anything, inject vitality and investment in the housing market. The Opposition's proposal to abolish the first home owners scheme will do more to damage the private residential rental market than any proposal to impose a capital gains tax. In fact, the absence of a capital gains tax is distorting Australia's investment market. Investment decisions are not made today as to what yield will be returned to the business; those decisions are often governed by the ratio of the return which will be in the form of a tax-free capital gain and how much of the return will be assessable income.

We all recall that under the stewardship of the honourable member for Bennelong tax avoidance and evasion was Australia's fastest growing industry in the Fraser years. As the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) said earlier today, the tax avoidance industry was costing ordinary Australian taxpayers almost $7 billion in lost revenue, which worked out at about $30 a week for the average household.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amazing!

—That is amazing, as the honourable member for Macarthur suggests. The honourable member for Bennelong had to be dragged kicking and screaming into this chamber to take action against the rorts and ramps exposed by the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which the honourable member for Bennelong sought to dismiss as a stunt. The mild capital gains tax which the Labor Party is proposing in this legislation has many exemptions which I commend to the House. The principal residence, the family home, and reasonable curtilage for farmers are totally exempt from capital gains tax, as are all assets which were purchased before the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on taxation on 18 September 1985. In addition, capital gains tax will be payable only when that capital gain is realised; that is, when the asset is sold. In addition, the Treasurer has agreed to average any assessable capital gain over five years, which again provides a concession to those who will be affected; that small proportion of the population who will have to pay the capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to compare the Government's mild measures with the Opposition's proposals as outlined by its spokesman on taxation and finance, Senator Messner. I quote from an interview Senator Messner gave to the Australian Financial Review on 8 October 1985, in relation to the capital gains tax legislation, when he said:

. . . as long as the law was modified, possibly to merely have specific time limits on sale of assets for capital gains, such as the existing Section 26aaa, would sufficiently serve the purpose of a capital gains tax on speculative profits.

This Government is exempting the family home and is reducing the capital gain as it is affected by inflation and the tax is payable only when the asset is realised, whereas the Opposition's proposal, as outlined by Senator Messner, is to hit capital gains at the full marginal rate. The Opposition's proposal does not wash out the effect of inflation. The proposal of the Liberal Party of Australia is punitive and would affect a much larger number of Australians. I am sure that it is something that everyone on this side of the House rejects out of hand. I join with other Labor members in congratulating the Treasurer on introducing Australia's capital gains tax legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might give the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) a lesson or two, because he does not understand even the existing taxation laws. The Commissioner of Taxation can declare as a trader a person who sells assets after one year. That person could be paying capital gains tax, and that has been the case for years. The honourable member does not understand even the elementaries of the tax laws, yet he has come in here lecturing us and telling us how marvellous for Australia are the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. We have listened to speeches and politics of inspired hate from honourable members on the other side of the House. The legislation is continually justified by references to people being tax cheats and dodgers. Government members are shaking their heads in agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Many little people, honest Australian citizens, will be caught up by this legislation. They have been deeply offended, not only by the rhetoric of Government members but also by this legislation. Since the Labor Government has been in power we have seen the attack on the superannuation of elderly people. They were supposed to be cheats and they had to be rounded up! Then we saw the attack on elderly people with the assets test.
