People who spent their lives working, instead of putting their money through the urinals in the hotels, were suddenly described as cheats who had to be rounded up and lose their pensions. That was the second group.

The fringe benefits tax will affect those salesmen who spend all day driving around the towns and cities of this country in vehicles which are not air-conditioned, trying to sell products to make a living and to keep their companies functioning. Suddenly, they have become branded as tax dodgers and cheats because they have a vehicle which they take home at night. That philosophy of the Government has been spelt out very clearly week after week, even going back to the time of the National Taxation Summit almost a year ago. That rhetoric of hate is justified on the grounds that we are moving in to crush the cheats. I refer to the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when, in justifying this tax, he said:
It will make the tax system much fairer by smashing the basis of much of the rampant tax avoidance that occurred under our predecessors.

Do honourable members know what the take will be on this tax? In the first year it will be $5m and in five years time it will be $25m. Government members would spend that in five minutes, yet tax avoidance is supposed to be rampant and the people out there are supposed to be cheats. The Government will collect at best only $25m in five years time, so it cannot have been very rampant; there cannot have been many people ripping off the system, as Government members have claimed in attempting to justify the legislation.

The Tax Summit was opened by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this very chamber on 1 July last year. What a charade that was. The Summit could not come to any final agreement. As the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) said, the decision was finally made in a pub in Canberra by Bob Hawke, Bill Kelty and Simon Crean, probably sitting over orange juice and a couple of beers. All the talk that had gone on in this chamber for days went down the drain because the key deciding factor was what the Australian Council of Trade Unions thought. It was the power broker at this Summit and all those dumb businessmen, who came in here thinking they were going to the rescue of the nation, who were duped. They are the people whose companies, as a result of the reforms in this legislation, have had the gizzards ripped out of them. These companies are struggling to survive and make good under the approach of the Australian Labor Party in government. The most prophetic words at that Summit were the words of the Prime Minister's introductory speech, when he said:
I have stressed the role of this Summit as part of a democratic process uniquely Australian.

It was unique-four or five days later it was all settled in the pub with Kelty and Crean. It was uniquely Australia all right, and so prophetic were his words at that time. I want to turn to the nine points that were espoused by the Prime Minister at that time as being so important in bringing about tax reform in this country. His fourth point stated:
. . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand more easily . . .

When the Tax summit started in Canberra last year there were 1,100 pages of tax laws in this country. People have been complaining for years about the thickness of the tax laws and how few Australians have an opportunity to understand them. Here we have the great white hope, the Prime Minister, who said a couple of years earlier: `There will be no capital gains tax.' He said that we must have a simpler system. Ladies and gentlemen of Australia, what this Government's legislation has done in the last few weeks is to add another 625 pages to the tax laws of this country. It has taken us 86 years to gather 1,100 pages of tax law and in six months the Hawke Government, which is promising to simplify the system, adds another 625 pages, which is a 57 per cent increase in one ruthless, senseless swipe. The entertainment tax Bill consists of 55 pages, the fringe benefits tax Bill 139 pages, the capital gains tax Bill 103 pages, and nine other tax Bills another 328 pages.

The only people who will make a good living in this country in future will be the lawyers and the accountants because every Australian, even the little battler out there, will need an accountant to fill in an S form with the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and all these other taxes. No wonder the Australian Taxation Office has abandoned wanting to check everyone's return and it wants everyone to assess themselves. It will not take responsibility for it. The Commissioner of Taxation has shed his responsibility; he cannot get out of it quickly enough. He wants to put more people out there, chasing the little people to see whether he can rip a little more out of their pockets. Whilst I am mentioning Mr Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, might I say that I have never seen a Taxation Commissioner bringing so much missionary zeal to his job as he has done. I refer to the letter he sent out with the fringe benefits tax booklet which was really pre-empting the Australian Parliament because the legislation has not even gone through the Senate. Mr T. P. Boucher-God help my tax returns from now on-sent out these booklets. I believe that $3m of Australian taxpayers' money was spent in sending out that booklet with his little letter. The second last paragraph of that letter states:

The Fringe Benefits Tax is an integral part of the Government's tax reform package, the overall aim of which is to cut personal marginal income tax rates and finance other benefits for the Australian community.
What a political line that is!

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member would say `Hear, hear'; he is a Labor man. I am wondering what Trevor Boucher is, too, when he indulges in politics of this type. He is trying to tell people out there that taxes are good for them. Australians have had a gutful of taxes; they have had a gutful of this Government's tax reform. One thing that the Australian Labor Party did not even put on the agenda at that Tax Summit was the question of how government can get out of spending. Year in, year out, governments in this country go further and further into people's pockets. When I came to this place 20 years ago, in 1967, the first Budget that I saw introduced by the Holt Government amounted to less than $7 billion. Today, 20 years later, governments are spending about $80 billion and all that money has come from only one place-the pockets of the Australian taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: The plea out in the community is for the Government to stop thinking that it knows best how to spend people's money, to leave the money in people's pockets and let them look after themselves. They do not want handouts and they do not want charity. All they want is a lucky break. They want the monkey to get off their backs and leave them alone. I really believe with all my heart that those few words epitomise the feelings of so many Australians. They want this Government to leave them alone. They do not mind paying tax but they object to the level of tax they are expected to pay.
I draw the attention of the House to the words I uttered in this place on 21 November last year, when this Government was first mooting the tax cuts it was going to give. These were my words:
I believe that, as an Opposition, we should reject the whole package--
meaning the taxes--

because I do not believe the Government will be able to sustain all the promised goodies that it offered to off-balance the nasties. I do not think that the Government has the ability or the financial resources to do so.

I was predicting then what has happened right now. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) spends more time in the Australian Democrats den than he does in his own office, trying to get them to allow him to put off the reduction of the marginal tax rates for as long as possible because he cannot balance the books. This Government is desperate to keep the tax rates as high as it can for as long as it can.

Unfortunately, I have been allocated only ten minutes in which to speak and I will abide by the agreement between the Opposition and the Government. I just hope that Mr Boucher has learnt how the Parliament functions. He should wait for legislation to go through before he starts telling people that they had better send in forms. I hope that every Australian business person tore up that form he sent out because their first real obligation on the fringe benefits tax will be towards the end of October. I cannot wait for us to get back into government to get rid of these iniquitous taxes.

Government members are destroying incentive in Australia. Let me mention for the benefit of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) the little shopkeeper he goes to at 11 o'clock at night, who has been open since 6 o'clock in the morning selling sausages, cigarettes, milk and bread. His hourly rate of earnings for the 17 to 18 hours he has been open would be miniscule. He has been prepared to make sacrifices during those years he has been in the shop, believing that when he finally sells out he will get a sufficient increase in the value of the shop he bought years previously to have made it all worth while. Now this Government is going to put its hand into the ice cream bucket and take its share. It is going to destroy the incentive of the average Australian.

Finally, I comment that a lot of people on the other side who have academic backgrounds and failed trade union backgrounds really do not understand what it is like to be out there battling. If we are going to put a tax on success, perhaps this country should be thinking about introducing a tax on those who have permanency in occupation. It is worth thousands of dollars to know that one has gone into a job that one will have until one retires and that one will never be sacked from it. But nobody ever thinks of that. The politics and the hymns of hate are directed at those who work their guts out just to try to make an honest quid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just listened to the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) for 10 minutes, let me say that that speech personified the reason why this Parliament is spending the time it is on reforming the tax system. We listened for 10 to 12 minutes to platitudes and slogans-nothing of substance. We heard 2,000 words of emotive junk. The reason why we have come into office and we are reforming the tax system is that from the period 1975 to 1983 the previous government allowed the tax system to get into the mess it did. It did nothing to give the Commissioner of Taxation any chance whatsoever. It encouraged the tax avoidance industry and let it prosper. Honourable members opposite should sit there with shame on their faces as we undertake the hardest task that any Australian government has had to undertake since the Second World War-cleaning up the mess the previous Government left.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. I want to touch on something that is a constant theme in the rhetoric of most honourable members opposite. I must say that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) at least was reasonable in his approach to this. Honourable members opposite have constantly referred to--

TALK.START.PARA: —The kiss of death.

—At least the honourable member for Flinders has been honest. It is the kiss of death over there, my friend. At least he has treated this continuing claim about the broken promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) honestly because he referred to the National Taxation Summit. Before this Government was elected to office in March 1983 the Prime Minister said that there would be no capital gains tax, and during the term of office of that Government there was no capital gains tax. Every time one of the honourable member's troops goes out and makes that claim it is yet another piece of emotional junk being peddled. In the lead up to the November 1984 election the Prime Minister said very clearly to the people of Australia that tax reform would become the main priority of the Government. This Government got a very clear mandate to set about tax reform, and that is what we have done. We have been prepared to take the hard decisions. We have been prepared to consult the people of Australia in that process, and honourable members opposite know that.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the extent of the capital gains tax, as many members from this side of the House have clearly and succinctly put forward in the debate so far today, the capital gains tax adds a key element of fairness. It is a mild tax which is intended to direct investment in Australia towards more productive enterprise and more productive sources than those which members opposite encouraged during their time in office. At an investment seminar that I attended in my electorate a few weeks ago many key speakers talked particularly about investment in the building industry and referred to the capital gains tax as being both fair and mild. One of those speakers was in fact Mr Eric Risstrom from the Taxpayers Association of Australia, who pointed out quite clearly the facts about this tax-the fact that it is mild and fair and that it is not a problem in any way to genuine bona fide investors. I shall come back to that issue a bit later.

Of course honourable members opposite have used the opportunity provided by this debate to wander off on to another key element of the tax reform package, namely, the fringe benefits tax. Nothing could put the position more clearly than a cartoon that was featured in the Australian Financial Review yesterday. It shows the Treasurer (Mr Keating) speaking to the Leader of the Democrats (Senator Chipp) about his constant meanderings on tax reform and pointing to some captains of industry-the people that honourable members opposite represent. This cartoon says it better than a thousand words. Mr Keating says to Mr Chipp: `Will you keep those bastards honest?'. He is pointing to leading business people, with their slogan: `We won't pay tax-never have and never will'. That is the position adopted by the people that honourable members opposite represent, those who were encouraged and fostered not to pay tax and to opt out of the system; that is, that they will not pay tax, that they never have and never will. I can assure honourable members opposite that, because we are in office and because we are fair dinkum, from now on they will.

During this process of tax reform we have seen every single interest group come out and bleat. In Victoria today we saw the Municipal Association of Victoria, the body that represents the senior executives in local government, come out and say, with yet another piece of bleating, that the tax will add $2.2m to the annual rates bill in Victoria which ratepayers will pay. All I have to say about that is that, if the MAV had decided to put a little more expertise and concentration into running its investment fund instead of having that go down the gurgler at significant cost to many of the councils that subscribe to it, ratepayers in Victoria would not have some of the problems that have been referred to. That is the sort of thing with which we have to deal in this attempt to reintroduce a fair system in Australia.

Let us consider the position of those honourable members opposite-honest John's crew-who were pledged to give credit where credit was due. Every single step that this Government has taken to produce a fairer system has produced a response of emotional junk and scare tactics. When the assets test was introduced the scream to pensioners was: `Put your money in a tin and hide it under the bed'. What a disgraceful claim to make. Members opposite scared every pensioner in Australia. Of course, the 97 per cent of pensioners whose pensions were not affected now know that they were subjected to an emotional scare tactic by members of the Opposition. In relation to the superannuation lump sum measure, members opposite let every worker in Australia believe-in fact they actively peddled this proposition-that every worker in Australia would have a third or more of his superannuation lump sum taken from him. Of course, now those people know that that was just rubbish.

In relation to the rural situation, members opposite have been out there talking up the rural depression to the point where now farmers who are leaving the land cannot get a bidder on their land because all those who hive off these sorts of situations are sitting back waiting for the price to fall lower so that they can make a bigger killing at the expense of small farmers who have difficulties. The banks have added a loading to lending to farmers as a result of honourable members opposite being out there continually talking up this stuff. Let us consider the restaurant tax. Every restaurant in Australia was going to close down, apparently, and thousands of jobs were going to be lost. What is the situation now? In fact, there has been a growth in the restaurant industry. That is a further example of this emotional junk. The more honourable members opposite peddle this emotional junk, the more they are being exposed out there in Australia as being simply part of a rabble Opposition who will simply oppose things for the sake of doing so.

Today I met a small business proprietor who believed that for his two company cars he would have to pay a fringe benefits tax of $8,000. He told me that that is what one of the Liberals told him. When we had sat down and done the sums and I had shown him exactly the way it would work it worked out that the amount involved would be $1,500. So there we go. I have no problems with that at all. If members opposite were smart, if they were not so out of touch, they would have seen the results of the survey published in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, clearly stating that the majority of Australians favour the introduction of the tax; they believe it is going to cut out abuses of the system, that it will help reduce tax avoidance-that honourable members opposite prospered-and that it will enable them to get a reduction in their PAYE tax rates and a better take home pay. I conclude by saying this: The Government, in bringing down this tax package, has confronted head on the issue of tax reform and we have been willing to consult the people of Australia. We have been willing to consider seriously and responsibly the issues involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are committing suicide.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition interjects and says that we are committing suicide. That is a clear indication of what the position was of honourable members opposite-no guts and no willingness to go out there and to say to people: `Hey, this is the deal, this is how it is being ripped off'. They had no guts whatsoever, were not prepared to provide any leadership, and ran away from any hard decisions. We have been willing to take hard decisions. They are essential to securing the future economic well being of the nation. They are essential if we are to recover respect and integrity for the tax system, and if all Australians are to be treated with fairness and equity. The Government is confident that the people of Australia will recognise that these measures have been introduced in the best interests of the nation and for the greater good of every single Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the two minutes that my long-winded colleagues have allowed me to speak tonight I want to express a few of my views in regard to the legislation that is before the House this evening, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill. The first thing I want to say is that I believe that the capital gains tax legislation stinks. It will not be, as honourable members opposite say, an unobtrusive and small tax. It will be a tax which will interfere with and affect every facet of Australian life. In fact, I shall quote from an article in the Australian Financial Review of 30 October last year. This contribution was written by Mr Kevin Burges, Chairman of the Taxation Committees of the Law Society of New South Wales and the Law Council of Australia, who in a nutshell says the very thing that I think will be the long term ramification of this new capital gains tax legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The tax will be very hard on a person who starts up a business from virtually nothing and builds up to a significant enterprise. On disposal, he will pay tax on the whole of the goodwill component, as he would have no base cost to which the indexation adjustment can be applied. This discourages entrepreneurial effort at the very time it should be encouraged.
If this is not the time when we need to encourage people who have incentive and motivation to help make this country a better and wealthier nation to live in, I will be damned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in this debate in support of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 I want to make clear that I welcome this legislation as being one of the means available to improve the social wage. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated in his second reading speech, the Bill represents a fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system which is aimed at destroying the immoral and virtually criminal tax avoidance schemes which were allowed to flourish under the previous Liberal-National Party Government. The tax avoiders are the friends of the Liberal and National parties, as must be quite evident to those people who have been listening to the speeches of Opposition members in support of their unscrupulous business friends and in condemnation of a tax which will strike at those who have disguised their income as capital and thus not paid their fair share of tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible to trace the enormous growth of tax avoidance from its early beginnings in 1975 to 1979 when the High Court of Australia found in favour of Westraders Pty Ltd and against the Commissioner of Taxation in a case of blatant tax avoidance involving dividend stripping. Justice Barwick in making his judgment in favour of the tax avoider, Westraders Pty Ltd, made the now infamous statement:

Parliament having prescribed the circumstances which will attract tax, or provide occasion for its reduction or elimination, the citizen has every right to mould the transaction into which he is about to enter into a form which satisfies the requirements of the statute.

In plain language His Honour said that if a potential taxpayer wanted to avoid tax he could legally do so. Above all else that statement invited ingenious tax accountants and solicitors to arrange the affairs of their business clients in a manner that would enable their clients to avoid their fair share of tax. Justice Barwick's judgment made no mention of the immorality of avoiding tax and he also discarded all suggestions that he should consider what the Parliament had intended when he stated:

It is not for the court to mould or to attempt to mould the language of the statute so as to produce some results which it might be thought the Parliament may have intended to achieve, though not expressed in the actual language employed.

It was from that date that tax avoidance became a legitimate and lucrative business in Australia, amounting during the final years of the Liberal-National Party Government, under the stewardship of the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), to thousands of millions of dollars. While this tax rort was going on the bulk of wage and salary earners were not only paying their fair share of taxes but also having to make up the shortfall in taxes arising from the tax avoidance schemes of the unscrupulous business friends of honourable members on the opposite side of the House.

Despite the ill-informed comments of honourable members opposite, surveys of taxation systems overseas make it quite clear that, in comparison, Australia is not a highly taxed nation. Let me emphasise that, whilst direct comparisons are misleading because of the contributing social security programs of other governments, nevertheless we are lightly taxed by international standards. Of the 23 member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Australia ranks somewhere near the bottom when its taxation revenue is compared with the total of its gross domestic product.

In general, taxation is a method used by governments to use a proportion of the incomes of the more wealthy members of society for distribution in the form of benefits for the poorer and disadvantaged sections of that society. It is not unreasonable for governments to use taxation for such purposes when one takes into account the fact that the top one per cent of Australian adults hold around 25 per cent of private wealth; the top 5 per cent, above 50 per cent; and the top 10 per cent, more than 60 per cent. These figures are taken from a survey of the distribution of wealth in Australia by John Piggott of the Australian National University. That survey also indicated the complex problems involved in obtaining the necessary information and making valid analyses to arrive at the correct figures. It is also interesting to note that the survey proves the self evident fact that great wealth is associated with high income. The survey also showed that the inequality of wealth revealed between the top 10 per cent of wealth holders and other people in Australia is the same as existing in 1915. With conservative governments in office during most of this period it is not surprising that there has been no change. At this point in my speech it is relevant to quote from a statement made on 15 April by the Director the Australian Institute of Family Studies, Dr Don Edgar, in relation to a preliminary submission made to the Economic Planning Advisory Council. He said:

Much of the discussion and many of the tax proposals made so far ignore the basic purpose of raising taxes in the first place. Taxes are raised to improve the quality of life, to ensure everyone has a basic share of the nation's resources and to provide services that neither individuals nor families on their own can provide. Yet our submission shows there has been a 54.4 per cent increase in the number of two-parent families below the poverty line and a 38.6 per cent increase of one-parent families below the poverty line between 1979 and 1982.
Of course, this is a period when the Liberal and National parties were in power. He continued:

This means an estimated 382,000 families, with three quarters of a million children, were living in poverty in 1982. The more unemployment figures rise, the more family breakdowns there are, the worse this will become. The two are linked and a better system of both raising tax revenue and distributing it to families in need must be found.

The problem, as I see it, is that unless governments are prepared to reintroduce a form of estate duty or inheritance tax there will never be a substantial redistribution of wealth in this country. Nevertheless, the capital gains tax measures set out in the Bill are another important method of redistributing wealth. This Bill should signal to the High Court of Australia that the Government considers tax avoidance to be immoral and that when legislation makes clear the intention of a government which has been given a mandate by the people in an election to carry out tax reforms it is the duty of justices of the High Court to stop preaching about a free society, as was done in their 1979 decision, and to have regard to the intention and wishes of the majority of the Australian people.

The existing so-called capital gains tax which is contained in certain provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 has always suffered from a number of serious defects which the present Bill will overcome. One has to ask the question why an increase of wealth due to skill and effort should be treated differently because it is deemed to be of a capital nature rather than of a revenue nature. The difference between these two concepts is frequently difficult to establish in legal terms and mostly impossible to establish in economic terms. Dividend stripping tax avoidance arrangements and other such notorious schemes have shown that the lack of a capital gains tax has encouraged people to engage in transactions which do not lead to an increase in the resources of Australia but rather lead to a misallocation of those resources.

Of course, as the Treasurer has pointed out, section 26aaa of the existing Income Tax Assessment Act will continue to apply a capital gains tax on assets bought and sold within 12 months. This is reasonable because it is obvious in such cases that the intention of the proprietors of the businesses concerned is to indulge in short term capital speculation for income purposes. It is unfortunate, however, that the present Bill will not be able to catch those people who have taken advantage of the lack of a capital gains tax on property bought before 19 September 1985. As I mentioned previously, the only way to introduce real equity in our taxation system is to introduce an inheritance tax which would catch the pre-19 September 1985 tax avoiders who took advantage of the ideological sympathy which the previous Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition, has for those Australians not willing to pay their fair share of taxes.

Apart from ideological sympathies, from a purely economic point of view, the strident attacks we hear from honourable members opposite are hard to understand. A tax favoured treatment of capital gains causes distortion in those sectors of the economy which receive the greatest benefit from capital gains. The major beneficiaries include the real estate and minerals sectors of the economy. There is no doubt that the huge capital investments in real estate and mining ventures have caused a serious structural imbalance in our economy, particularly as the corollary has been a lack of investment in our manufacturing industry. The lack of a capital gains tax has also distorted the choice between different forms of business organisations such as partnerships, private companies, public companies and trusts. Financial decisions involving the pay-out decisions of companies have also been distorted. Some people gain and some people lose; obviously, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is going to lose as a result of the ingenious systems of tax avoidance practised by the tax cheats. The bottom line is that Australian society as a whole stands to lose, and has lost very heavily over the past decade, as a result of the economically inefficient allocation of our resources which has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. I ask that the honourable member withdraw the imputation that I am in some way a tax cheat.
—I did not say anything about the honourable member being a tax cheat. I said that you were suffering at the hands of tax cheats.
—Order! The honourable member for La Trobe will speak through the Chair.
—I am sorry, Madam Speaker.
—Did the honourable member for La Trobe make any imputation against the honourable member for Mayo?
—I did not, Madam Speaker.
—There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for La Trobe.

—The importance of the present Bill in relation to our taxation system has been emphasised by the Treasurer, who has rightfully described it as an important fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system. Unless all the types of income from capital can be taxed in a comprehensive, consistent and uniform manner our income tax system can never be described as efficient and equitable. I compliment the Treasurer on this Bill and, indeed, on the other taxation Bills which he has introduced in this House during the past few weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not often have the opportunity to congratulate officers of Treasury as I frequently find myself in disagreement with them. However, on this occasion, in commending the Bill to the House, I congratulate all those public servants, both in the Treasurer's office and in Treasury, who have been involved in the preparation and explanation of the comprehensive and important package of tax Bills which have been presented to the House this month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this iniquitous capital gains tax, I will begin by taking up a few points with the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I think that we heard one of the typical diatribes that come from the other side of the House on the question of the politics of envy-we must try to cut people down and reduce everyone to the lowest common denominator, and if we cannot get them in that way we will get them another way. It is interesting to note that the honourable member talked of tax avoidance, but we hear nothing from him or his ilk about the problems of the cash economy. I have read that the size of the cash economy is approaching $30 billion. I wonder what the member for La Trobe will do about that. I wonder whether he is even concerned about it. He talks of tax avoidance, yet right before his eyes is the greatest form of tax avoidance in this country today-the cash economy. As I said, estimates show that it is approaching $30 billion, yet the honourable member remains remarkably silent when we talk about that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that every person listening tonight took in very carefully his words about death duties. It is interesting to note that, as part of this politics of envy, we have Government spokesmen calling for the reintroduction of death duties. I would have thought Australians would have realised what a terrible thing death duties are, what terrible things they can do to people such as farmers, and what a wonderful decision it was of the previous Government in 1977 when, as part of its election policy, it promised their abolition. The honourable member for La Trobe ought to have a close listen to some of his colleagues in the Victorian State Government, because when the Premier, Mr Cain, decided that he might reintroduce some form of death duties he had to back down because the community will not accept them, and for very good reason.

It might also be interesting to note some of the comments of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) when he was questioned about both capital gains taxes and death duties whilst in Horsham just prior to the last election. It is amazing how the Minister for Primary Industry can say one thing just before an election and after that election remain remarkably silent on the same issue. It is something that I guess we have got used to with this government. As many speakers on this side of the chamber have already reminded us, it was only back in 1983 when the Prime Minister made that wonderful statement-`Let us put it in a way that not even our opponents can misunderstand; there will be no capital gains tax'. We are now in 1986 and that announcement in relation to a capital gains tax was made less than three years ago. Therefore, had the first Hawke Government run its normal term it would have broken its promise in relation to that matter in its first term. I do not think that Government members can say that this is a new parliament and that, therefore, what was said in 1983 does not matter.

The Minister for Primary Industry, when asked whether he would oppose a capital gains tax, an assets tax and death duties, if such issues arose in Cabinet, was reported as saying that he would oppose such measures in the strongest terms, that he had seen the effect of probate, that it split a farm and made it less viable, and that so, too, would a capital gains tax. I suggest that the honourable member for La Trobe should take on board some of those words, because, when the Minister for Primary Industry was saying that, it was not some cheap election gimmick; he was speaking from experience and saying what he believed. The honourable member for La Trobe overlooked the fact, when talking about reintroduction of death duties, capital taxes and wealth taxes, that Australia already has a wealth tax. Anybody who owns a bit of land pays rates on it on an annual basis, and those rates are nothing more than a wealth tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't mention a wealth tax.

—It is the same thing; it is tax on capital and something that the honourable member for La Trobe ought to take into account when talking of new capital taxes. He talks of welfare problems. Naturally, we are all concerned about welfare problems, but I suggested to the honourable member that one of the great causes of welfare problems is the high tax regime that his Government is bringing upon this country. If taxes were reduced, a lot of welfare problems would evaporate. I suggest that the honourable member think about that, and exercise his mind as to how to reduce the cost of government and reduce taxes, because that would do an awful lot to solve some of the welfare problems that are so enormous in this country today.

SPEECH.PARA: In opposing this capital gains tax I will highlight a number of reasons for so doing. First, I point out its complexity. I think that this is an extremely complex bit of legislation. It consists of over 100 pages, and is something that 95 per cent of Australians would probably find extremely difficult to understand, if they could understand it at all. It is also extremely complex for those people trying to comply with it. It is all very well to say that this tax must be introduced, but, because it is as complex as it is, inevitably people will make mistakes and will have extreme difficulty in trying to comply with it. Also, it will divert a lot of productive resources to people trying to understand what is going on and trying to keep the sorts of records necessary to comply with this legislation.

The other reason I believe this tax is plain stupid is that it will be extremely costly to administer. It will cost the Taxation Office, and therefore the Government, an awful lot of money to administer. And what for? In the first year it is expected to net $5m in a Budget that this year will probably exceed $70 billion. Some tax! I think that honourable members will find, if they look further, that not only will the revenue gained be small but also, I suggest, the Government will lose out in the long run because it will discourage investment and risk taking.

It is also a highly discriminatory tax, as the Minister for Primary Industry knows. I am pleased to see that he has come into the chamber. He knows what it can do to a family farm or to a capital intensive industry. Obviously it is highly discriminatory against industries that are capital intensive. Farming is a classic example of that. I would have thought that, if the Minister is to represent primary producers, as he is supposed to do, he would have made a slightly greater effort to carry out that great promise he made in Horsham in 1984.

I think that another point about this matter is that it is quite obvious that the Government will not go to the trouble of bringing in such a complex piece of tax legislation for $5m in the first year and maybe $25m after five years unless there is a hidden agenda. There is no doubt that this hidden agenda involves raising the rates. As we already know, the rates for the capital gains tax are extremely high. They are probably the highest of any capital gains tax in the Western world. At the moment-I emphasise `at the moment'-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said: `We will allow a discount for the rate of inflation'. I suggest that that will be the easiest way to start raising the rate of this tax. Once the Treasurer has gone through the painful process of introducing it, when he thinks people have accepted it, there is little doubt that he will seek ways to increase the revenue.

When all is said and done, these new taxes-the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and all the other taxes we have been debating in the last few days-are there for one reason, and one reason alone. They are there because this Government must find more revenue. It is a big taxing government. It is the highest taxing government since the last war. One has only to look at the increase in Budget receipts from the time this Government came to office to the current financial year. Heaven knows what the figures will be next year. We see that, in the last Budget of the Fraser Government, total Budget receipts were just over $48 billion. It is estimated that in 1985-86 they will be over $64 billion-a huge increase of nearly $16 billion.

There is no doubt that, even though this Government has screwed taxpayers for every dollar it can get, it still needs more taxes. That is why we are looking at all of these various new taxes that have been introduced in the last few days. Since the Minister for Primary Industry is still present, I would like him to take on board the fact that this tax is a form of death duty. I do not care how it is dressed up; if is a form of death duty. Let me give a simple example. If a husband dies and leaves a property, shares or whatever to his wife and the market happens to be down-something that is occurring in agriculture right now-and it is rolled over at what is considered to be a fair market value, if the wife finds, 18 months later, that because of various family commitments she must sell that piece of land, shares or whatever and the market has risen, she will be taxed, and taxed heavily under this capital gains tax. If that is not a form of death duty, I would like to know what on earth it is.

We must look at this measure and remember that the capital gains tax breaks one of the Prime Minister's great principles. I refer to his nine principles, including the one about the simplicity of tax. The fourth principle was this:
. . . any reform must lead to a simpler system, which therefore all Australians can understand easily.

Under any criterion, this tax is a failure. It is a failure under the Prime Minister's principles that he brought to the Tax Summit. Furthermore, I think I can demonstrate that the report of the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, which the Government is often fond of quoting, shows that the capital gains tax fails. As the Asprey report stated:

It is a tax which, in any administrable form, must be complex and difficult, and produce some anomalies and inequities of its own. There is no doubt whatever that any revenue it raises could be more cheaply and easily raised in other ways. By the criterion of simplicity it fails.
So it is condemned again. Members of the Government are very keen to support it, but they need only read what the experts have said to learn that it will be a failure.

Madam Speaker, my time is restricted. I will cut short my remarks at this point. I must say that the Opposition is totally opposed to this capital gains tax. It is complex, it will discriminate, it will discourage investment, and it will discourage risk taking. It is the thin end of the wedge. It is obvious that the Government is looking at was of bringing it in at the minimum revenue level and, after it has been introduced, it will look at ways of increasing it. There is absolutely no reason why this Parliament should support this tax. It will fail on all the criteria that the Prime Minister set up. It will be highly discriminatory. It is yet another tax of the `politics of envy' type that I spoke about at the beginning of my remarks. The Opposition is opposing it now and we have stated very clearly that when we are returned to government we will throw out Labor's capital gains tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very disappointed to hear the contribution of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I had thought better of him. I want to correct one of the serious allegations he made concerning the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). It is true that the Minister said that he was opposed to a capital gains tax that would have the effect of splitting up family farms. What the honourable member for Wannon fails to recognise, concede or understand is that there is an effective exemption for family farms, without creating a tax shelter. Whilstever the family farm remains in the family's hands, no capital gains tax will ever be paid. The honourable member for Wannon failed to address the principle that there should be a capital gains tax. What is there to stop people transforming income into capital gains and never paying tax? This has meant that family farmers have had to pay more tax to subsidise the tax avoiders.

SPEECH.PARA: I say this about the honourable member for Wannon: He talked about the expenditures of the Hawke Government. I will cite one statistic to the Opposition-that is, the record of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the present Leader of the Opposition, when he was Treasurer, concerning the size of the government deficit. In 1981-82 the deficit, as a percentage of gross domestic product, was 0.8 per cent. What happened in 1982-83? That deficit climbed to 3.2 per cent-a 400 per cent increase in the government deficit as a percentage of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Honourable members opposite are laughing. They should look at the Budget Papers and they will see those figures.
—I have them here.

—Page 388 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows an increase from 0.8 per cent to 3.2 per cent. That was what happened under the economic wizard who is acclaimed by the Opposition but who has been completely and utterly rejected by the people of Australia.
—What was it the next year?
—It was 4.8 per cent and it is down to 3.2 per cent. That is not a 400 per cent increase. Does the honourable member not understand mathematics?

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in general terms to a comment made in the debate on taxation measures yesterday by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) when he stated:
I am pleased that the Liberal Party in Western Australia is lodging a complaint on behalf of the Australian people.

Let me tell honourable members about the Western Australian Liberal Party. That branch of the Liberal Party was completely penetrated and taken over by tax evaders, tax avoiders and bottom of the harbour merchants. We had the scandalous situation, under the Government of which the present Leader of the Opposition was a member, whereby the Attorney-General's Department in Western Australia not only assisted avoiders and evaders but also ran a brothel from a Commonwealth Government office. That was absolutely disgraceful. I find it extremely offensive that the Liberal Party in Western Australia should be proclaimed in glowing terms to the people of Australia.

What Opposition members fail to understand is that the average person-the great bulk of Australians-recognises that the Government's trials and travails in regard to taxation will provide a fairer system. By and large, Madam Speaker, You will find that the majority of people in Australia support the Government's approach. They concede that fringe benefits and capital gains are unfair. They are pleased that this Government is taking action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Let us look at the capital gains tax. The honourable member might well laugh. He is one who advocates that fringe benefits tax should be paid by employees. I hope he tells that to all of his constituents. As I was saying in regard to the taxation package and capital gains in particular, we have heard scream after scream from the Opposition about how terrible this will be for Australia and Australians. What will this measure raise? In the first year, for all the screams by the Opposition, it will raise $5m. That is what we are talking about-a measure that will raise $5m. As this vicious and pernicious tax gathers strength, after five years we will have a massive amount of $25m.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia recognise the hypocrisy of honourable members opposite. Quite frankly, if we want to have a serious discussion about this tax, I can say that I have reservations about capital gains tax. Let me tell honourable members why. Every time the Australian Labor Party has attempted to do something in a reasonable way about this anomaly in our taxation system, we have been belted around the head by the Opposition, which has done nothing but use scare tactics and put fear into every Australian. I well remember the 1980 campaign and those rotten advertisements the coalition ran suggesting that everyone's home would be subject to capital gains.

TALK.START.PARA: —The lies.

—They were. I must say that it was a most dishonest campaign. What it has really done is set back tax reform and sensible discussion by many years. This Government has had the courage to say in an election campaign that it would tackle the problem, and it would tackle it by a process of consensus and consultation. It is true to say that not everything the Government wanted to do has been done, but this is the most significant tax reform package this country has seen in a long time. I say, with respect, that we will not see anything like it in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: What has been the role of the Opposition? I appreciate that it is difficult being in opposition. I hope that honourable members opposite are learning well and I trust that they will be in opposition for a while. Let me just ask this: Did honourable members opposite take a bipartisan approach? Did they say: `Here is Australia-a country we love. We want to do something for the people of Australia. We want to right a wrong. We want to take part in this process. We are not saying to the Government that we are committed to it every inch of the way'. Did honourable members opposite take that approach? Did they attend the National Taxation Summit, which was attended by business leaders, trade union leaders, and a whole variety of Australians concerned about reforming the taxation system? Did they come as an opposition and say: `We want to play a constructive role'? Of course they did not. The people of Australia understand that. They understand the hypocritical approach the Opposition is taking towards the reformation of the taxation system. This is its death knell as it claws away to save its supporters and to save the rorters.

As each proposal has come forward has the Opposition said: `On balance we can support this, but we have some reservations'? Is there one taxation bill the Opposition has supported? Of course there is not. The people of Australia understand that the Opposition is not furthering a bipartisan process. The Leader of the Opposition spoke in this debate and said the Government was suddenly bringing on taxation reform. I think the people will realise that this reform has been a long and painful process. Its timing was not of our making, but we are committed to reforming the taxation system. We have a mandate from the Australian people to reform it, and we will reform it, but without one scintilla of assistance from members of the Opposition. Frankly, I think democracy is the poorer for that. Undoubtedly issues will arise for this nation that will require political parties, whether they be in government or in opposition, to come together for the good and for the betterment of the nation. I would have thought that after the Opposition's sorry experience of having so many evaders and rorters in its midst it would have seized this opportunity in both hands, but I am afraid that it has not.

I was very disappointed with the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition. I want to remind honourable members of some of the outrageous things the Leader of the Opposition did when he was Treasurer in relation to taxation measures and economic measures. One of the problems for honourable members opposite is that the people do not forget. The new element in this debate on taxation matters is that as surely as night follows day, it is quite clear that the popularity of the Leader of the Opposition is failing. It is quite clear that, as surely as night follows day, the shadow Treasurer the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), is not performing, and that as surely as night follows day, it is clear they will not survive come the Ides of March. The real question is who will go first.

What did the Leader of the Opposition do in his term as Treasurer? My colleague the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) outlined on a previous occasion the seven honest mistakes of honest John, and I want to refer to a few of them. We can recall the outrageous fistful of dollars advertisement in 1977. On one side of the television screen was a fistful of dollars, with the message `Liberals give'. On the other side of the television screen was an empty hand, with the message `Labor takes'. The advertisement appealed to the Liberal Party's greatest backstop, a backstop used by the Liberals in every election campaign. That backstop is greed.

The advertisement referred to an income tax cut announced in the 1977 Budget and to a promise by the honourable member for Bennelong, the present Leader of the Opposition, to implement full tax indexation of all income tax brackets. This tax cut and the tax indexation promise were the centrepiece of the Liberal Party's platform in 1977. What happened? The Government decided that as a temporary measure for 1978-79 only the standard rate of personal income tax would be increased by 1.5 per cent. That increase was to be effective from 1 July, and therefore an extra deduction was to be made from taxpayers' wages or salaries after 1 November, designed to meet his or her additional tax liability for the whole of 1978-79. In one hit the former Treasurer's two tax promises were broken. That is the sorry record.

I could go on to outline to the House the other broken promises of the honourable member for Bennelong. As I have said-I want to conclude on this note-I have always had a great deal of hesitation about a capital gains tax because of the way capital gains has been used and abused by members of the Opposition at election time to instil fear. I am pleased that the Government has come to grips with this issue in its total tax package. No longer will members of the Opposition be able to intimidate and instil fear in and frighten ordinary Australians. They will know that the sum total of the effect of the capital gains tax will not be as was painted by honourable members opposite in their horror stories in election campaign after election campaign, but that in fact, this measure will bring in $5m in its first year and, after five years, $25m. I am pleased to support the legislation. Like most Australians, I welcome this package. It will lead to fairer taxation-something to which members of the Opposition are bitterly opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that people are tuned in around Australia and that they are listening to the debate on the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. I do not think our constituents want us to criticise each other across the floor, because things are rather desperate in Australia today. If we wanted to be constructive I am sure we would join together as a team to look at the future of the country, and particularly at the economy of Australia. I do not think our constituents want to hear us criticising each other for what we have failed to do. Maybe this is why we as parliamentarians get a very bad name with the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the people want us to look at Australia as they see it. So many people say to me: `I think about my children and my grandchildren in later years'. I wonder whether we are thinking about this. I wonder whether the Government is thinking about this. I wonder whether we have considered what the people of this country expect us to examine, to act upon and to be constructive about. I have a feeling that a great majority of the people of this country have lost faith in the ability of the Parliament actually to adopt difficult measures. We may have to do bad things in the short term, but in the long term those measures will get this country back on the footing on which the pioneers had it.

These legislative tax measures that are before the Parliament are not those that this country should be expected to adopt; neither are they measures that our friends around the Western world would want us to adopt. Looking deeper into the problems we have today, I even doubt whether the Opposition parties' industrial relations policy will be adequate to cater for this land of ours in the years to come. I think the people of this nation believe that this country is in such an economic mess today that they want the Opposition to return to power and do something constructive. I believe that there are members on the Government side who would like to see this happen as well. One only has to look at the faces of honourable members opposite at Question Time each day to see that they are well meaning people who are trying to represent their constituents. They see the Treasurer having a job to answer questions put by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not happy.

—As the honourable member for Dawson says, they are not happy. We must be statesmen in this place. We must recognise the problems facing Australia today. I believe that the average worker, the person who wants to get a job, the person who wants to see more young people employed in the community and the person who wants to see Australia, an exporting nation, producing goods at reasonable costs all realise that we are living in a fools' paradise. One realises that it is a fools' paradise when one looks at our working week from Monday to Friday with time and a half and double time at weekends, our payroll taxes, our 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading; and the wages of some people in the unions. The expedient measures that are operating in this country today make us believe that surely we must go back to taws. It is a shame that we have to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said in my electorate of Lyne that perhaps we should have a wages pause. However a wages pause is really not the answer to this. A wages pause certainly helped this Government over its first years, but it is feeling the pressure now. A wages and prices pause is not the answer. We must tackle the problem of this nation from the floorboards up-from the foundations. We must be prepared. We in opposition must be prepared to do this because those in Government are not. Some of those people from industry and elsewhere who attended the National Taxation Summit agreed that there should be a capital gains tax and I was certainly surprised by that. But honourable members opposite cannot tell me that those people would say the same thing today. Given the situation that this country is now in, those people would take the opposite view. If we went to them now and said `Do you think we should still have a capital gains tax in Australia?' I do not think they would agree to it. We must engender in the Australian people some incentive and some of the confidence that we do not have at present. We should be ashamed of ourselves. What other people in the world could turn around a young country like Australia with its great natural resources in the ground and on our soil, and the natural resources that Australians have within them, and make it uncompetitive with the rest of the world?

My colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I had a seminar in Taree a week ago and 400 people turned up. The honourable member for Dawson spoke and he was very well received. He did not make a political speech, he simply cited the problems that are facing Australia today. This was what our people wanted to hear. It is certainly what people in rural areas want to hear. I believe that this message is going forward into our big provincial towns and our major cities. The National Farmers Federation and the Small Business Association are helping to take the message there and I wish them well. They realise that this is the last chance that we have to get this country back on the rails.

I am not saying much about the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill, although I could quote it verse by verse. I am not so concerned about those issues. We will talk about them later. I am concerned about the future of this nation. I am concerned about having a sensible monetary fund, a sensible economy if we can get back on the rails and giving to the people of Australia the incentive for which they are looking. It is so important that we do this. Let us look at the position of our friends in other parts of the world in relation to these tax proposals. Many people on this side of the House have compared us with other western countries in relation to inflation, unemployment and so on. It is true that we are lagging far behind them. We have had the examples of Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and other countries which have gone through difficulties. These people have had the experience. Honourable members should realise that we are no better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are following in their footsteps.

—We are following in their footsteps day by day. The Government claims to be responsible yet it is introducing into this Parliament legislation which it has been forced to bring in, not of its own wish, but by the wish of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government is full of faceless men and the Australian public does not want this. We know that the Government is dominated by the people in the ACTU and I doubt whether those people really have the interests of this nation at heart. Perhaps I can give an example. As a result of the Russian nuclear accident the other day radioactive fallout is floating around the countryside and damaging many people. However, did we see many demonstrations in this country against that accident? Had there been a leak at Lucas Heights, had the Americans or the British had an accident, the protesters would have stormed out in their hundreds of thousands. We must wake up. Unless this country wakes up and gets back on the track again we will be in trouble. No wonder groups such as the NFF and the Small Business Association are saying to us: `If the Opposition parties cannot put people into Parliament, we will'. But they will come on our side because they realise that we face up to our responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members should look closely at these tax Bills before the House and think about their provisions-capital gains tax, negative gearing, fringe benefits tax. If one goes back a little further one remembers the tax on superannuation which our servicemen, who are there to defend our country, will have to pay on their retirement. Then of course there was the assets test. These are all part of the Government's formula; it is one thing after the other. The Government is achieving its aim and this is the important factor. This Government is achieving its aim in the policies it is introducing for this nation. We in the Opposition and the people of this country must stand up and say that we do not agree with the Government's policies. We must put our policies before the Australian people and tell them our plans for taxation and incentive. Let us not stop foreign capital from coming into Australia. Look at this capital gains tax Bill. It includes disincentives to people from other countries--

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't come in.

—As the honourable member for Dawson says, they will not come here and spend money to employ our people so that we can invest capital in overseas countries. This has been how Australia has grown in past years.
—For 200 years.

—As the honourable member for Farrer says, this is how it has been for 200 years. We are letting down the people who had faith in us, who bred us and who put us into the House of Representatives and the Senate to do the job of representing them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us all be reasonable. Let us stop and think about this. If we overtax the people we give them no incentive. We should give them incentive in the way that Ronald Reagan gave the American people incentive when he became President. I understand that he reduced personal income tax by 20 per cent and created 6.1 million new jobs in America. That is why America is thriving. America is strong and President Reagan has no worries. He will not be told what to do about MX missiles; he does not have to go to the unions of America to get advice. This country needs strength and I am afraid it is not getting it. The Australian people expect it. These taxation Bills before the House are a worry. They are detrimental and they are causing great concern to the great majority of Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I compliment the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). However, my compliment is a bit of a back hander. He gave his usual, predictable National Party speech of gloom and doom, but what was missing was the hysteria that has accompanied every other speaker from the Opposition-an hysteria lacking any rationale or rationality in its attack on the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes. We are debating the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986 which, as the other speakers have said, is just one measure in a complete package of tax reform introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The package includes such fundamental reforms as rationalising sales tax, acting on negative gearing and clamping down on entertainment expenditure, the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the overall package is revenue neutral, and that is important in regard to the total impact on the macroeconomics of this country. I think we should also realise that it is revenue neutral because huge cuts will be made in the marginal rates of personal income tax as a result of revenue being gained elsewhere. There is to be an end to double taxation on dividends. Yet we do not hear any of the members of the Opposition referring to the goodies in the tax package. They refer only to what they see as the nasties. The overall tax package will restore equity to the tax system. It will reintroduce fairness and progressiveness to the tax system. More important than that, it will restore public faith in the tax system. The honourable member for Lyne asked what he would tell his children and grandchildren in the years to come about this episode that is occuring in this Parliament. If he is honest, if is decent, if he is rational and if he is objective, he will tell his children and grandchildren that this Government reintroduced fairness into the taxation and economic systems so that no longer will the rich get richer and the haves get more while the have-nots remain in the poverty cycle and the lower income brackets. There will be a fair go for all. He should tell his children and grandchildren that this Government did not shirk its responsibility in respect of tax reform whereas time and time again over many years the Opposition, in government, turned their back on that responsibility, put it in the too-hard basket and was not prepared to grasp the nettle in that difficult area.

Each major reform has met with a campaign of personal interest and self-based hysteria. Hysteria is no substitute for rational argument; it is no substitute for decent opposition. Let us just take the reaction to the tax on entertainment. The Opposition came in here and told us that thousands would be put out of work, that the restaurants would be putting up the `closed' signs. None of this happened. What did happen was that the catering industry, the hotel industry and the restaurant industry grew by 19,000 jobs. We see advertisements for more staff for restaurants. We now see a healthy industry standing on its own feet, appealing to the customers in the right way and not depending on the tax lurks as they had. What did we hear from the Opposition? What was its reaction when on 2 May we introduced the fringe benefits tax? There was more hysteria.

Over the weeks since then this hysteria has reached fever pitch. Those who are usually the law and order men of our society are now advocating breaking the law. These people include Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the Premier of Queensland. He has said that people should refuse to pay that legitimate tax. We heard Bob Ansett say: `Let us have a modern Boston tea party'. That campaign in early America was based soundly on the principle of no tax because of no representation. But the Bob Ansetts of the world and the Joh Bjelke-Petersons of the world have their representatives and they have been put into Opposition because the people of Australia did not vote them into office. They voted this Government into office on a sound and practical tax reform mandate. Even the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria recognised, in the Australian context, the corollary of the Boston tea party and the principle behind it when he rightly castigated those who advocated breaking the law, saying that the right way, the correct way, was to accept the law of the democratically elected Government and to use the ballot box to replace that Government if the public was not satisfied. The big snag in that scenario is that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who sits opposite in this Parliament, does not have the courage to say that he would reject the fringe benefits tax when he assumed office, should he ever do so-and what a tragedy that would be for this country. He refuses to indicate whether he would remove the new tax because the truth-and he recognises it-is that the fringe benefits tax is fair, just and right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition has just said that we will repeal the tax.

—It is a pretty poor performance that, after three weeks of tramping backwards and forwards around this country, he has been cajoled and badgered into finally making the weak statement that he apparently made today. I would have thought that a leader of the Liberal Party of Australia would have had the courage, the conviction, to stand up on the first day and utter those words. Now we find that, mealy-mouthed, he crawls into this Parliament and in a few apologetic words says that now he might consider removing the fringe benefits tax. The trouble with those--
—I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition has said that a coalition Government will remove the fringe benefits tax.

—That is hardly a point of order. The point of this debate and the order of this debate lie firmly with this Government, which is getting on with the proper tax reform as it was elected to do at the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to my next point. The Leader of the Opposition must have come across the airwaves today to our listening public as quite a character when he led a singsong in this Parliament like a choirmaster. The Opposition delivered a rather puerile effort in singing: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Fancy reducing an argument or debate on such an important matter as tax reform in this country to a singsong. The Leader of the Opposition has completely forgotten that there was another election after the one during which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that there would be no capital gains tax. In that election in 1983 the Opposition was soundly trounced. The Opposition was soundly trounced again in 1984 after the Prime Minister had gone to the people and said: `We will have tax reform in this country. We will hold full consultations with the wider community to develop the right route to tax reform'. The Leader of the Opposition has completely forgotten that. Honourable members opposite have conveniently forgotten also that the then Leader of the Opposition went from corner to corner, capital to capital in this country saying: `If you do not want a capital gains tax, vote for me'. What did the people do? They voted in their thousands for the Government that now sits on these benches. They voted in their thousands for tax reform. It is hard to imagine a clearer, more definite or stronger mandate than that given in the election of 1984, when people said to the Government of this country: `We want fair tax; we want just tax; we are sick of paying excessive tax for those who enjoy the lurks and perks of fringe benefits and those who are able to adjust their affairs so that they can turn their income into capital to escape their just and fair burden of tax'.

As I said in respect of the fringe benefits tax, and as I say again in respect of the capital gains tax, the rort is over. This is a very mild form of capital gains tax compared with any other capital gains tax in the world. It is indexed for inflation. Also, small business will be allowed 20 per cent of its capital gains or goodwill before the taxation provisions are applied. One must realise that capital gains tax does not apply to a farm unless it is sold by the family. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that farms handed down from father to son or daughter do not attract capital gains tax. Even if a farm were disposed of outside the family, the private residential house and a decent curtilage would not be subject to the capital gains tax. In fact, no home, no principal residence in this country, will come under the capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your father would be ashamed of you.

—We know that the Opposition, by using hysterical outbursts such as that one by the honourable member for Fisher, which I could not understand, and mumbo-jumbo, has tried to muddy the waters and confuse the people. We know that the people know that these Bills will make a significant contribution to the equity, fairness and acceptance of our taxation system. No longer will people be able to arrange their affairs so as to take their income as capital and avoid paying their fair share of tax liability. As I have said, these Bills have the full support of the electorate, the Australian people. They have my support also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill will impose a new tax-a capital gains tax. The honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) would have us believe that this new capital gains tax is a mild tax. Nothing could be further from the truth. This new tax is one of the toughest taxes of its type in the world for those who will have to pay it. The reason is that it is levelled at the marginal tax rate of the person required to pay the tax. That could be anything from 30 per cent to 60 per cent of the amount of profit on which that person is required to pay tax. That makes it a very tough tax. It needs to be understood that, in comparison with other taxes imposed in the world, this one is tough.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation needs to be considered against its economic impact upon the nation and the financial gain to government as a result of its introduction. If one reads the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum, it is clear that, while this tax is tough for those who will have to pay it, it is not expected to gain significant revenue for the Government. If our economic problems at the moment are such that increased taxation is the order of the day to get the nation out of its economic malaise, there may be some justification for it, but the financial impact statement associated with this Bill states:
The estimated revenue gain from introducing the tax on capital gains is $5m in 1987-88 rising to $25m in the fifth year of operation.

That point needs to be understood. In the Government's own statement, the impact is said to be absolutely minimal and will pay no regard to assisting this nation out of its parlous economic situation. Why are we seeing this legislation introduced at this time? It is not for the reasons of equity given to us by the honourable member for Streeton but because this Government, in the context of the economic debate that has been going on, has to appease the Left of the trade union movement. This tax has been introduced to appease the unions.

The second point I make is that the tax is designed to appease the bureaucracy; those people who, because they opt for security rather than the willingness to take a risk, have very little prospect or expectation of having assets other than their own home and a superannuation benefit, two groups of assets excluded from the legislation. Of course, the efforts of the Left of the Australian Labor Party ought to be understood in relation to this matter. This tax is based on envy and nothing else; it is certainly not based on equity or any expectation that it will get this nation out of its parlous economic situation.

That brings me to another point I wish to make in relation to this legislation. The tax is being introduced at a time when our economy is most fragile. If the Australian people-my children and your children, Mr Deputy Speaker-are to have any future at all, something needs to be done to get the Government and this nation back on track. Our economic growth has slowed significantly in the last six months. In the June quarter last it fell to 2.6 per cent, in September to 1.4 per cent and in December to 0.5 per cent. The Treasury and all the independent economic commentators and indicators suggest that economic growth will continue to fall. The value of the Australian dollar fell considerably in 1985, particularly against the yen and the trade weighted index.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has only halved against the yen.

—It has only halved. Total unemployment has remained above 600,000 people-over 8 per cent of the total work force. Australia's inflation rate is three times the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average-that is, the average inflation rate of the developed nations of the world-and similar figures exist in relation to those countries with which we compete. As against Australia's inflation rate of 9.2 per cent, Japan has 1.1 per cent, the United States of America has 2.3 per cent, West Germany has 0.1 per cent and the United Kingdom has 4.1 per cent. This is the worst comparative disadvantage Australia has suffered in terms of inflation for more than 25 years. In terms of the balance of payments, the deficit on trade for the last 10 months of this financial year was $12.1 billion, the worst result since 1951-52. Our foreign debt has doubled from $35 billion to $70 billion in 2 1/2 years. This represents $6,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Interest rates are at excessive levels, as anybody who has to pay them would know. The prime rate for businesses-for those people regarded as a good risk-is 18 per cent. Those interest rates are well above the interest rates that our competitors have to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill needs to be considered against that background. The Government has to address these factors urgently if this nation is to have any future at all. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) knows this. We have heard him try to emphasise the magnitude of the problem we face, but his colleagues refuse to recognise what has to be done.
