While the Opposition has a multi-faceted approach to addressing these questions, the Government seems to be falling back upon one criticism; that is, to find a scapegoat for what is happening at this time. That scapegoat is business. The Government and the trade union movement are saying that if we are to get out of our present malaise we need new investment by business. At every turn we hear the trade union movement arguing that business has to reinvest in Australia. We are being warned of a possible strike of capital. Those are the sorts of arguments we have heard from such distinguished commentators as Mr Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is crucial, if we are to see any investment, that business has confidence in the direction in which we are going. The Government has committed itself to a conference to try to work out these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —A summit.

—The Government does not wish to call it a summit, but that was one of the statements that came out of the meeting at which it was announced that this particular meeting would take place. The fact of the matter is that in the September and December quarters of last year fixed business investment fell. I know that honourable members opposite do not wish to hear this, but not only has fixed business investment fallen for those two quarters but also yesterday we saw figures which demonstrate that investment by business has declined further. This is now overwhelmingly a trend. The question that the Government and the unions have to ask themselves is: Why is this happening? It is not a right wing plot or a strike by capitalists.

SPEECH.PARA: All of the reasons for this lack of confidence by business are in the hands of the Government. My discussions with business have revealed that there are two causes for this falling off in business investment in this country. The first is the high interest rates we now suffer; the second is the new business taxes this Government has imposed, and first and foremost amongst those new business taxes is the capital gains tax. We also have the fringe benefits tax, which is clearly a payroll tax on employers, increased company tax from 46 per cent to 49 per cent, and the foreign tax credit schemes. Each of these increased taxes has occurred while net profits to shareholders on funds invested have fallen over the last 15 years from 11 per cent to 4 per cent. Is it any wonder that people want to invest in government bonds, government paper, at 16 per cent? Why would prudent investors want to put new capital into plant and equipment in this situation?

In my view, the only avenues left to the Government to solve this problem are to reduce taxes that impact upon business. Its capital gains tax could go immediately and the impact upon the economy, on the taxation revenue of the Government, would be minimal-according to the Government's own statement a measly $5m this year. It needs to be understood that the tax is a disastrous tax. Business knows that it is the toughest tax in the world. It is paid on the marginal tax rate. The Government knows that it is taxing a scarce resource-capital. The Government knows that, if it is to get out of the enormous difficulties we face, it will have to abandon this proposal along with its fringe benefits tax, and the sooner the better. I think that announcement should be made at the meeting the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will be attending with business in the next few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures before the House tonight are part of a fundamental reorganisation of the tax system of our nation. They are an attempt to reintroduce fairness, honesty and decency to a tax system that was presided over by those opposite for so long that it has almost ceased to be relevant to Australia as a modern nation. The capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and other measures that will come before the House in this session of the Parliament are designed so that the payment of tax by the select few is no longer optional but, as it is for the vast majority of the population, it is their right and their obligation.
—Their obligation, not their right.

—No, it is their right. It is important to note that these taxation measures, of which the capital gains tax is a part, are revenue neutral-that is, the revenue from the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax is all ploughed back to taxpayers in lower rates of income tax. If there is one thing that is long overdue in this nation it is reduced income tax. Honourable members opposite talked about it for years. The gabfest-that is the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-have talked about lower taxation for longer than I have been on the earth but they have never delivered it. This Government is now in the process of doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: The vast majority of Australians will be better off. I estimate that at least 98 per cent of the people in my electorate of Barton, in the southern suburbs of Sydney, will be better off. The overwhelming majority of my constituents have been paying their fair share of taxes all their lives and, as a result, they have been subsidising those who have not. The Sydney North Shore representatives in this House must really question whether their constituents have been paying their fair share of tax, as mine have, and they should relate that very directly to the measure before the House tonight. This capital gains tax exempts the family home. It is discounted fully for inflation, for costs and capital investments. Very importantly, it has a 20 per cent exemption for goodwill for small businesses, as the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) has already pointed out to this House.

This capital gains tax is not the capital gains tax of 1980, as proposed by the Australian Labor Party at that election. That tax would have been unfair. This capital gains tax is demonstrably fair. As proof of that and has been admitted by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the revenue raised by this capital gains tax is only $5m in the first year, rising to $25m in the fifth year. The raising of $5m is hardly an impost that will send the business community of this nation broke. Rather than being a revenue measure, it provides a solid platform under the tax system to stop the minority of greedy would-be taxpayers-who, like any minority, always cruel it for the majority-who have been converting income for many years into capital to avoid paying their fair share of tax. Of course, every dollar that those people have avoided paying in tax is another dollar that my constituents and the vast majority of the constituents that we on this side of the House represent have to pick up. Every dollar that is evaded by converting income into capital is a dollar our constituents have to pay over and above their fair share of tax. That is simply immoral. It is not right. It has to stop, and we are stopping it now.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask in all fairness: Can those opposite honestly say that this is really a harsh measure? Let me give honourable members one very good example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us two examples.

—All right, for the benefit of the honourable member for Melbourne, I will give two examples. The capital gains tax of the United States of America, the Ronald Reagan Republican capital gains tax, is struck at 40 per cent of the nominal capital gain. It is then taxed at the normal rate of tax with no discount for inflation. The second example I cite is the current Packwood proposal that is being mooted in the United States taxation reform debate. That would be levied at a full level of 27 per cent, but it would be levied on 100 per cent of the capital gains. Therefore, it would actually be even worse than the current American capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give honourable members an example so that even those opposite can understand-I do not want to cast any aspersions on the intelligence of those opposite-of how that works in dollars and cents. Let us take a $100,000 investment, an inflation rate of 10 per cent, with a capital gain of $10,000. In the United States, under the Ronald Reagan Republican capital gains tax one would pay $2,000 capital gains tax. Under the Packwood proposal that is now being mooted one would pay $2700 capital gains tax. In Australia, under the Hawke-Keating proposal one would pay no such tax because our capital gains tax is discounted for inflation, and that is more than fair and reasonable. The United States capital gains tax hits the ordinary man; it hits the small business community of the United States. On the contrary, ours is a fat cat capital gains tax which hits those who deserve to be hit. Australia and Britain are the only nations I know of that provide a full discount for inflation. I ask those opposite, those devotees of Katharine West: Is Ronald Reagan a socialist? Is Ronald Reagan a mad dog commo? Is he sending business broke? Is he destroying private enterprise? Of course not. Our capital gains proposal is far less harsh and far more lenient than his. It is about time that honourable members opposite recognised those facts.

Honourable members opposite have been talking for 30 years about representing the business community, but all they have done is to send a good number of them broke. Providing a fair and equitable tax system in this country must have two spontaneous effects. It must firstly be to the very great betterment of the national economy, both on the fiscal side and in terms of the economic morality of the nation. Secondly, let me say this to honourable members opposite: In the current climate of our having to re-evaluate the relationships between business, unions and the national share of income, it is important that every working man and woman of this country sees that each and every one of their fellow Australians is paying his fair share of tax. One cannot expect the wage and salary earners of this nation to give more while so many whom honourable members opposite represent pay none. One cannot expect the working men and women of this nation to carry a greater burden for the economic survival and enhancement of this nation when many of those whom honourable members opposite represent do not make any contributions whatsoever, or, at the very least, they do not make the contribution they should make to the national purse.

All Australians benefit from the services of government, be it local, State or Federal. It is morally incumbent on every Australian to pay his fair share. This Government is no longer going to retain a tax system that benefits the people on the north shore of Sydney to the detriment of the constituents of my electorate and other electorates where wage and salary earners comprise the vast majority of the population. It is now time for a fair deal. We are restoring morality to the tax system. The thing that I like most about it, Mr Deputy Speaker, if I can conclude on this, is that every time we bring a measure into this House to bring honesty, fairness and decency back into the taxation system the Opposition squirms-and that is what I like best about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing that the previous speaker mentioned that I agree with is that he said he would conclude. What a diatribe, what utter nonsense this Parliament has been treated to for the past 10 minutes. I refer to the words of the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) when he was Leader of the Opposition. On 16 February 1983 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.
On 19 September 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told Federal Parliament:
The Government has decided to introduce a capital gains tax.

That proved once and for all that Mr Hawke is the Prime Minister whose promises have a use-by date. It also proves that the so-called honourable Paul Keating, Treasurer of Australia, is the dishonourable Paul Cheating, who masquerades as the temporary Treasurer of this country until such time as the people of Australia at the next election sweep this Government from office. We all understand why this Treasurer is called the bowser bandit-and, I know that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is going to say, the fiscal ferret. It is a tragedy that these people stand up before Australians and announce what is going to happen and then just a couple of years down the track we find there is a complete and utter about-face and that the promises, made with a view to attracting votes in order to become the government of Australia, are in fact torn up. We simply cannot believe what the Australian Labor Party chooses to tell the people of Australia. It was 245 days from 19 September 1985 until 22 May this year when finally the Income Tax Assessment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill were introduced into Parliament. They were 245 days of uncertainty, 245 days of fear and 245 days of terror. People are frightened as to what is going to be the effect of this tax-and they are frightened with just cause.

Labor's capital gains tax will raise a very small amount of money in fiscal terms. It is going to raise $5m in 1986-87, and in the fifth year it will raise $25m. So, from an economic point of view there are no real grounds for introducing this legislation. It is a quid pro quo, a sell-out to the trade union movement. An article in the Age of 21 September 1985 referred to the capital gains tax as follows:

The introduction of some sort of capital gains impost was a necessary price to pay for keeping alive the wages accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and for the Labor left's reluctant acceptance of cuts in the top marginal rates of income tax.

Why is it that the Australian Labor Party has decided to slap in the face the many people in middle Australia, some of whom are swinging voters and therefore determine the composition of the party or parties which from time to time occupy the treasury bench? People who trade, people in the business of buying and selling for the purpose of profit making by sale, have always paid capital gains tax. The people who are being caught are the average Mr and Mrs Australia, the average person who largely is on pay as you earn tax, and the idea of making a capital gain was one of the few methods that these people have had to get ahead.

The ALP has written its own obituary. In fact, the ALP is ensuring that it cannot be returned at the next election, because the people who, rightly, have such an influential say in who governs Australia are being slugged; they are being hurt and are being treated with utter disdain and contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—The honourable member for Mayo agrees with what I am saying, because I am correct.
—Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for Deakin agrees as well. Obviously he also shares the vision that I have that we must have in this country less tax. The National Party will not have a bar of Labour's capital gains tax or its fringe benefits tax. We are utterly opposed to the abolition of negative gearing, because we believe that in Australia there should be reward and incentive for initiative and hard work.
—Why are they taxing the churches and charities?

—I do not know why they are taxing the churches and charities, but what they are doing will ensure that they are condemned by the people of Australia. We find that this capital gains tax is the toughest and the highest in the world. The taxpayers who have to pay it will be taxed at the marginal tax rates-anything from about 30 per cent to over 60 per cent, or thereabouts, of the profit. I do not know why the Government insists on doing this and the people of Australia will be asking that question at the time of the next election. The Institute of Chartered Accountants, an eminently reputable and respected body, has criticised the Government's proposed capital gains tax. In its annual tax submission, released recently, it said.

SPEECH.PARA: Even allowing for the indexation of tax thresholds, the tax would seriously hamper development and limit growth. There would be a disincentive against factory owners moving from unsuitable and inefficient premises to better sites if owners were to be taxed on profits gained from selling their existing factories. Businesses would also be discouraged from expanding into new fields if money gained from selling obsolete assets were to be subjected to a capital gains tax.

Why will the Government not take note of the prevailing climate in Australia? Why will it not take note of how Australians feel? We should remember and we should think on the various points, the various principles of tax reform which the Government has outlined. The ninth principle was that any reform package must have widespread community support. What a sick joke! There is absolutely no community support for this capital gains tax-absolutely none whatsoever. In fact the futures of many small businesses have been shattered because prices will now drop dramatically to reflect the capital gains tax. Why will this Government continue to act like an ostrich with its head in the sand until such time as the next election comes along?

We in the National and Liberal parties are 100 per cent in favour of lower taxes. That is why we can discount most of what the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) said before. The Nationals in Queensland spearheaded the abolition of gift duties, probate duties and success duties. The Nationals in the Federal Parliament spearheaded the abolition of the Commonwealth estate and gift duties in 1978. The Australian newspaper of 30 September 1985 contained a report on the Australian Small Business Association. The spokesman for that organisation, Mr Boyle, is reported as saying:
. . . the ASBA was strongly opposed to the capital gains tax because it would be a tax on enterprise and hard work and could mean the loss of thousands of jobs in small businesses.

This indicates the idle rhetoric of the Australian Labor Party when it claims to be the party which is encouraging job and employment prospects. John Leard, one of the great gurus of economics in Australia, has pointed out that the family home would be included in the capital gains area within a decade. He is reported as saying:
It will become a tax shelter unacceptable to the Left-wing people in this country . . .

It is interesting that the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) is laughing because obviously he is part of the Left of the ALP. One of my colleagues asked me before why it is that the Government is taking such a strong line against charities. Proposed new section 160y provides that where a post-19 September 1985 asset of a person who dies after that date passes to a tax exempt beneficiary, such as a church, a charity, a school, a university, an art gallery or a sporting club, the asset is deemed to have been disposed of by the deceased for its market value at the date of death, and the estate of the deceased would have to pay a capital gains tax on such assets. It is quite clear that this proposal will lessen the desire to make bequests as the capital gains tax will have to be funded out of the other assets of the estate. This is a criminal impost on organisations that are attempting to assist the under-privileged in our society. Once again we find after 245 days this Bill has been brought into the Parliament. Insufficient time has been given to members of the Opposition to debate it. This very complicated package of Bills brought in by the Australian Labor Party in recent times will add 625 pages to the already existing 1,100 pages of tax legislation-a 57 per cent increase, as was pointed out today by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). The legislation does not simplify the law as the ALP would have us believe. The time for debate has been chopped. This is unfortunate.

In conclusion, I would like to outline to the House the terms of a letter which I received today from Mr C. E. Redenbach of Western Australia. He said that the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are `horrendous' and `draconian' and are `another nail in the coffin of small business'. He went on to say:

Government and politicians can no longer even pay lip service to the so-called encouragement of the Small Business sector and have now shown a complete disregard and contempt for the largest employers of labour in this country.
He said further:
Big Government
Big Unions
Big Business
and
Big Brother
The Anzac tradition, incentive, and the rugged Australian individualists are all dead.

It is a tragedy that Labor's capital gains tax will be, and is, in effect, capital punishment being imposed on the Australian economy. The ALP stands condemned. There is no doubt that it will be tossed from office at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986. I support a capital gains tax. As happened when I spoke in the debate on the fringe benefits tax legislation, once again we hear from the Opposition cries of fear and the scaremongering that is so typical of honourable members opposite. With this legislation we propose to reform the tax system into one that will be fairer for all. What we find is that, because some of those people who support honourable members opposite are now going to have to pay their fair share of tax, those honourable members come in here screaming and saying that this is unfair and not right because their people will have to pay tax for the first time. Honourable members opposite are saying: `When we were on the Government benches we looked after them. We made sure they did not pay any tax'. We are now bringing in a fairer taxation system which means that those people who have been avoiding paying their tax and not carrying their fair share of the load will have to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The lack of a capital gains tax in Australia has meant that for many years investment in Australia has been in non-productive areas in which people have been getting a quick quid. What we are seeking to do by introducing a capital gains tax is to redirect those investments into areas where we will see jobs created-areas where investment will now become attractive-instead of areas where there is no job creation. It is not surprising to hear representatives of the National Party of Australia stand up here and criticise the legislation because they do not understand what it is about. They should be one group supporting the capital gains tax because if anybody has suffered in Australia through the lack of a capital gains tax it has been the farmers. The investors and speculators have been buying up land, forcing up prices and putting genuine farmers behind the eight ball. I do not intend to cover all the ground covered by my colleagues previously because most of them have covered all of the benefits of a capital gains tax extensively.

We are hearing in this debate the same cries about inequity as we heard from honourable members opposite in the debate on the fringe benefits tax. When we look at the whole package of legislation brought forward covering the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax and look at the groups of people in the community and who receives what we can see which people honourable members opposite represent. They represent the minority groups who receive all the benefits. If, for instance, we take some of the fringe benefits about which honourable members have been screaming we find that of the people who represent the 11 per cent of highest wage and salary earners in this country one in six receives private transport, one in seven receives an entertainment allowance, one in 12 enjoys employer provided or employer subsidised housing and one in 12 has his medical or hospital costs paid.

Let us look at what happens at the other end of the scale. What sort of fringe benefits do the 74 per cent of wage and salary earners who are paid below average earnings get? Only one in 20 receives a private transport fringe benefit, only one in 50 receives an entertainment allowance, less than one in 17 gets a telephone benefit, only one in 35 gets a housing benefit, and only one in 40 receives any form of medical cost. We can see whom honourable members opposite are screaming for. They are screaming for the privileged in the community, those people who have not paid their fair share.

In talking about this tax package I refer honourable members to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald the other day which described a company complaining about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on it. That company had 14 vehicles. It was going to cost the company $16,000 a year in fringe benefits tax. What sorts of cars did that company have that were going to cost $16,000 a year? It had one Holden, five Ford Falcons and six Sigmas. It had a Porsche and a Mercedes. We can guess who had those cars; it was not the salesmen. The co-directors said that they liked their cars because they were the small pleasures that made working worth while. That company was going to keep all its cars because they were essential and because all were used for sales work during the week. We can imagine the co-director driving around in the Mercedes knocking on doors and selling stuff. Of course, they had two vehicles for prestige. We do not dispute the fact that there are people out there who genuinely need cars and who are provided with them for work purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills on the capital gains tax show only too clearly that the Australian Labor Party is not concerned about the need for capital accumulation in this economy. When the investment figures came out yesterday showing that for the third consecutive quarter private sector investment in Australia had fallen and when our economy, according to national account figures, is going backwards, it is staggering that the Government has the audacity to bring before this House legislation which taxes capital and is a disincentive to investment-above all, a disincentive to investment in the small business sector. If I had only had time, I would have read out the submission of the small business corporation in South Australia condemning this capital gains tax and pointing out the effects it will have on incentives to invest and on the livelihoods of so many people in that small business sector. The impact is not so great on big business, but the impact on small business is, without doubt, absolutely devastating. To do this at a time when investment is desperately sought in our economy, and at a time when our economy is clearly moving backwards and our national accounts show that for two consecutive quarters the Australian economy has been contracting, is in my view a staggering indictment of this Government. It is concerned not about wealth creation, but only about wealth redistribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax evasion and avoidance have become issues of importance in recent years. Emphasis has been placed on schemes which, while legal, result in reduced tax obligations and those who have indulged in such arrangements have been accused of indulging in ramps, rorts and ripoffs. In my view, of greater import are blatant avoidance arrangements where people knowingly defraud the revenue and do so by deceit and dishonesty. It has therefore been of great disappointment to me that evidence has been adduced and a prima facie case established to the satisfaction of a magistrate that, in the area of our sales tax law, serious breaches occurred, and involved in those breaches have been a person, or people, involved in a charitable organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The breaches involved the forging of exemption status certificates, the avoidance of sales tax and breach of valuation requirements for State stamp duty assessments on the sale of motor vehicles. In the cases about which I speak, motor vehicles were purchased by a charity and then on-sold to third parties. The vehicles were purchased free of tax, for use by the charity but were sold in a market where a considerable profit and the tax avoided, could be taken. I have asked questions about these matters of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) but he has declined to give this House details. His justification was the secrecy provisions in taxation law.

I have now placed questions on notice to ascertain whether these matters have been referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions for advice and prosecution. To date I have had no reply to these questions. They must be answered for the Parliament to be satisfied that the sales tax law is being properly and fairly applied. By reading the questions, numbered 3853, 3854 and 3855, honourable members will be aware that the charity to which I have referred is the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys' Club and the person principally involved was a former policeman, Chris Jones.

The reason why I speak about this matter is news reports and particularly the item in the National Times of 16 May last. It reveals that, of 36 charges for which Jones was committed for trial, 21 have been dropped by the New South Wales Attorney-General. Prima facie evidence was established in hearings before Mr McKenzie, SM, on 2 August 1984. I understand five of the charges dropped relate to charges of defrauding the Commonwealth, relating to the purchase and re-sale of motor vehicles through the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys' Club. My source is the Daily Telegraph of 15 May last.

I have now asked, by question No. 4046, whether the Commonwealth was consulted in relation to this no bill by the State Attorney-General. If the answer is no, the Commonwealth, it seems to me, must now proceed with these charges itself. At the very least, the Director of Public Prosecutions must consider the question independently, as is his duty.

This matter has the potential to be a major public scandal. The public and the Parliament need to be satisfied that the charges have not been the subject of some special plea bargaining, where the Commonwealth's rights have been traded away to avoid embarrassing questions arising out of the Police Boys' Club scandal. Important questions include: Were the five charges the only cases of sales tax fraud involving this club and other Police Boys' Clubs in New South Wales? I suspect they were not. Are other police or individuals involved? For how long did these schemes operate? Did the tax avoided go to the organiser, the Club, or was the benefit shared with the purchasers of the motor vehicles? What action has been taken to recoup the tax lost? Do the unusual circumstances of the discontinued proceedings involve any attempted cover-up of the wide issues involved in this case? What measures have been instituted in the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that excessive car purchases by charities are brought to notice?

These questions require full and frank explanations to the Parliament from the Treasurer and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I informed both that I would be raising matters tonight which impact upon their portfolios. Finally, and incidentally, what is the role of others in this matter? For instance, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has told the House that he was at the relevant time a director of the Parramatta Police Citizens Boys' Club. To what extent was the Board involved? Did it supervise the purchase and re-sale of motor vehicles in the Club's name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 September 1985, I asked the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), a number of questions in relation to Commonwealth support funding for privately funded universities. In particular, I referred to a feasibility study into the establishment of a privately funded international university in Western Australia. The reply from the Minister, given on 30 April, stated in essence that, as universities are established under State government legislation, the Federal Government has no direct power to prevent the establishment of private universities. The Minister also stated that the Commonwealth Government had decided not to support the establishment in Australia of private institutions for the marketing of education overseas. Existing policy allows for marketing of award courses at full cost to overseas students in Commonwealth-funded higher educational institutions. I have made it clear that I am opposed to the policy of marketing of award courses at full cost to overseas students. It is in my view manifestly unfair to have some students enrolled in courses paying full fees while other students are paying part fees and still others are not paying fees at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall policy of the Australian Labor Party is presently to maintain the provision of free tertiary education. It is, of course, true that the policy could be said to relate to Australian students only and that the students who are paying fees or part fees are overseas students. Apart from the fact that many overseas students are in poverty as a result of being required to pay 35 per cent of a full course fee this year, rising to 45 per cent next year, I am sure that those ALP members who helped to frame the policy had not anticipated that the policy would be qualified to exclude overseas students. However, I have no doubt that this matter will be debated at length at the July 1986 National Conference and finally decided one way or another at that time. So I will say no more here about the apparent contradictions between our platform and Government policy.

I am concerned at the latest reports from Western Australia in relation to negotiations between the Western Australian Institute of Technology and Yanchep Sun City, a subsidiary company of a Japanese multinational, Tokyo Corporation, for an expansion of WAIT teaching facilities to Sun City. As the reply to my question of 29 April has indicated, the Federal Government does not have the constitutional power to approve or deny the proposed establishment of a private tertiary education institution in Western Australia. The Federation of College Academics, in its May issue of the Journal of Advanced Education, expressed its concern at the proposal. An article in the journal states:

. . . why are WAIT management able to claim that initial negotiations between themselves and YSC do not require Commonwealth Government approval, but only agreement between WAIT, YSC and the State Government? If this signifies that the Federal authorities are in the process of surrendering decision-making power on major issues, is it because a change in ALP policy is underway? Are State Governments to be elevated in status along the lines previously favoured by the opposing, conservative parties?

As I pointed out, however, the Commonwealth Government does not have the power to intervene, even if it wished to intervene. The article in the journal was also concerned about the support of the State Government for the marketing of land in Sun City which the journal claims is the reason why WAIT is being encouraged to move to Sun City. My own concern is that it should be made very clear that Commonwealth funding will not be provided to support the establishment costs of the proposed private tertiary institution. The article in the journal also states:

If WAIT, YSC and the State Government are able to conclude initial negotiations on the deal without receiving the approval of the Commonwealth Government, as one senior administrator claimed on the Bentley campus recently, what are the implications for Australian federalism? WAIT, YSC and the State Government will be able to force the Commonwealth Government to long-term commitments on recurrent, and probably also capital, expenditure without the Federal administrative machinery having been a party to initial negotiations. By presenting agreement as an accomplished fact, great pressure will be exerted on national authorities to come to the party, possibly even to provide up to 20% of the initial capital costs of the project.

I hope that the Minister for Education will make it very clear that the Commonwealth Government will not provide any funding for this project, whether by way of direct funding or by way of hidden subsidy. Hidden subsidies would relate particularly to permitting WAIT to use any of its administrative facilities which are supported by Commonwealth funding, such as the student records office or the Bursar's office, to support the establishment of the new institution. I hope the Minister can assure me that my concerns are unfounded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to discuss briefly the conduct of Australian affairs by the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Mr Whitlam. During Question Time on 22 May I asked the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), whether he could confirm that Mr Whitlam had been responsible for the unauthorised dis- closure-the leaking-of confidential Geneva Group decisions to the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr M'Bow, as stated in an article in News Weekly by the respected Washington-based Australian journalist, Peter Samuel. Let me remind the House that the Geneva Group is the name given to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development or Western United Nations members, including Australia. The Geneva Group decisions dealt with the tenure of Mr M'Bow and directors-general of the United Nations agencies, and in particular, with the decision that tenure should be limited to two terms, a decision with which the Australian Government agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: The article by Peter Samuel reported the substance of a telegram to the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, in Washington, from the United States mission in Geneva, which stated that Mr Whitlam had leaked Geneva Group decisions concerning Mr M'Bow to Mr M'Bow. The article went on to say:

At least one United States State Department officer is outraged that Australia, through Ambassador Whitlam, has been leaking information about confidential Western tactics and breaching understood Western alliance arrangements. Far from apologising for his leaking, Mr Whitlam has threatened to leak more!

Peter Samuel quoted the number of the telegram, its date, and the signature on the telegram as evidence of authenticity. He stated that he had sent a copy of the telegram to Mr Schultz, the Secretary of State. I do not think anyone would doubt the authenticity of that telegram, in view of all the evidence given. In any case, no one has doubted it. In answer to my question on 22 May, the Minister for Defence, representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, said that he did not know the circumstances and would rather leave the question for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to answer on his return.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs gave his answer yesterday, which I read as confirming the accuracy of the Peter Samuel article and the claims about Mr Whitlam's leaking the telegram. However, this morning the Sydney Morning Herald reported the Minister's answer under the heading: `Whitlam did not leak United Nations documents, Hayden says'. In these circumstances, with the Sydney Morning Herald interpreting the answer from the Minister for Foreign Affairs so differently from the way in which I think it must be interpreted-that is, as confirming Peter Samuel's statement-I want to spell out what I believe is the correct reading of the Foreign Minister's answer.

The Minister's answer outlined these basic facts. Firstly, on 20 March or 21 March the Geneva Group agreed on the principle of limiting to two terms the tenure in office of the heads of specialised agencies and other United Nations bodies. Secondly, on 11 April the Geneva Group, including Mr Whitlam, agreed that the co-chairman of the Geneva Group should take up this decision formally with Mr M'Bow on 30 April. Thirdly, the Minister for Foreign Affairs said that on 23 April, one week before it was agreed that the co-chairmen would see Mr M'Bow on this matter, Mr Whitlam saw Mr M'Bow and leaked everything to him, in blatant breach of his agreement at the Geneva Group meeting on 11 April. This was clearly a disclosure unauthorised by the Geneva Group of which Mr Whitlam is a member and which had settled on 30 April as the date on which the co-chairmen of the Geneva Group would see Mr M'Bow.

The Foreign Affairs Minister said in his answer to my question that Australian policy was and is to have discussions with Mr M'Bow about his tenure. Mr Whitlam did this, but of course the Foreign Minister did not-naturally did not-say that it approved having these discussions at a time which breached an agreement made by and within the Geneva Group. The Minister's answer clearly states that Mr Whitlam was an unauthorised leaker. There is no other way of reading his answer, although he uses rubbery words. But the fact are plain so despite the Sydney Morning Herald's headlines, it is important that this House know how Mr Whitlam handles himself and Australian business in UNESCO. He leaks, in breach of agreements with Australia's allies, and apparently does it all the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again we have listened to an unfounded attack by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) on Australia's Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. It compounds the offence of asking the question the other day. His question was adequately answered yesterday afternoon by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). SPEECH.PARA: I was going to devote my time this evening to talking about some of the cant that is so often heard in this chamber. Over the last couple of nights in the adjournment debate we have heard speeches on tax measures, and we have heard such speeches again today. I recommend to members of this House that they read the Ross Gittins article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, which I think sums up the whole issue and indicates what nonsense some honourable members are talking. Some of the greatest cant I have heard recently in this House was in the contribution of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) on Tuesday evening in regard to a film, which I think was called Hail Mary. Listening to the view expressed that evening by the honourable member for Fisher, one would think that this Hawke socialist Government had made the viewing of this film compulsory for all Australians. I say to honourable members: Let us face it. Most people would not even know about the film were it not for the campaign to have it banned. The distributors of the film Hail Mary must be rubbing their hands together in glee. It will really ensure that it gets a good audience. I doubt whether the honourable member for Fisher has seen the film. I most certainly have not seen it, but after all the information we have heard about it, I am thinking of going up to Sydney this weekend to try to see the film.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) summed up what most enlightened people would be thinking when he said that those who might find the film offensive-I admit there may be some-should not go to see it. I really thought that honourable members opposite were in favour of free choice, but no, they are not in favour of free choice when it comes to censorship. It wants to enforce its narrow bigoted views on everyone. There is really nothing wrong in portraying biblical situations in a modern setting. The same happens in the case of plays on historical events. Last weekend, I happened to see a performance of Shakespeare's Winter's Tale, in a modern setting. I found it most enjoyable. Those people who, like those opposite, want to ban everything only want views expressed that coincide with their own. Honourable members opposite come into this House day after day, wrapped in the flag, and call for censorship.

Honourable members might remember that a few years back they wanted the Life of Brian banned. This film has brought enjoyment to millions of people throughout the world, but honourable members opposite wanted it banned. Not so long ago Australian became the laughing stock of the world when some people in this country-I am not saying that honourable members opposite were involved-actually wanted to ban the display in Sydney of Michelangelo's masterpiece David. Finally, the honourable member for Fisher called for the sacking of the Film Censorship Board. As a practising Catholic I believe that those who want to see the film should have the right to do so. Those who might find the film offensive would not bother to go to it. It is really nonsense for the honourable member for Fisher to come into this House and make a speech such as the one he made on Tuesday night about this film. As I said before, it will have a great audience now. It would have been a film very few Australians would have heard about, but now the honourable member has ensured that it will have a wide distribution and a wide audience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, as you are well aware-you have met these young people today-on two occasions each year I arrange to bring two students from the high schools of my electorate to Canberra so that they can participate in the operations of the Parliament and get some idea of its workings. They are then able to transmit that information to their colleagues. As part of that process I request that they write a very short speech about their schools and districts. Tonight I wish to present those speeches for Dean Watts and Anthony Watson, who are in the House tonight. The first speech is by Dean Watts and it states:

SPEECH.PARA: My name is Dean Watts and I come from Narrogin, one of the many country districts in the State. I live in a small town not far from Narrogin called Pingelly, where I have lived all my life and where I have attended both primary and high school.

Once I completed high school, I successfully applied for the course at Narrogin Agricultural College where I am in my second year. It is most enjoyable and I think that the two year course is a must for anyone wanting to become a farmer.

The town of Narrogin is situated 190 kms south east of Perth and has a population of 5200. It is the regional centre for the Upper Great Southern area of W.A. Most of the town's industry is concerned with servicing the well established farming community. The main emphasis in the area is on sheep with cropping, beef and pigs being other major income earners. The town has good facilities for its active cultural, service and sporting clubs. Education is well catered for with three primary schools, a high school with a large hostel and an agricultural college.

Narrogin Agricultural College, of which I have been elected college captain, is of a type peculiar to Western Australia. The college provides a two-year residential course in vocational agriculture, at the secondary level of education. The college caters for 108 students and typically most students enrolling at the college will return to family farms or gain employment in industry associated with farming.

The course at the college is divided approximately 50:50 between theory and practical work. Theory subjects are concerned with crop and animal husbandry and economic practices of farm management. A student's practical time is split between learning skills on the college's 1000-hectare farm and the manual arts workshops. Farm construction techniques and maintenance methods are practiced within this section of the course.

It is not all work and no play at the college. Students spend a considerable part of their free time on a variety of sports. A number of future state representatives have been produced during the college's 70 or so years.

The college has taught 3 generations of farming families and is now well established in the farming community. With this sort of progress, Narrogin Agricultural College, like Narrogin itself, seems assured of a strong future.
Anthony Watson writes:

My name is Anthony Watson and I was honoured to be selected by my school, St. Patrick's College, Geraldton as the recipient of the Wilson Tuckey Scholarship. On behalf of the College, I would like to thank Mr. Tuckey for creating this scholarship, which enables students to gain a first hand understanding of the Australian Federal Parliament.

My family has lived in Geraldton for 68 years and I am in my matriculation year. St. Patrick's College is a boarding and day high school conducted by the Christian Brothers for boys from Kununurra in the north to Ravensthorpe in the South. The Principal is Brother John Murray and I am the head prefect. This year the college celebrates its Diamond Jubilee.

St. Patrick's is only one of the many educational institutions in Geraldton. Geraldton is the educational hub of the mid-west and although opportunities are available for tertiary and technical education, we fall short of the opportunities and amenities available in the city. Being the centre of a rapidly expanding and progressive community, we would like to see more funds made available for the extension of these services.

Geraldton has a population of 22,000 and will be acknowledged as a city in 1988, with celebrations incorporated with the Bicentennial. Geraldton is proud of its rock lobster industry which has been established along its coast line and the Abrolhos Islands. This unique asset is one of the major export earning industries for the town.

The port of Geraldton is also an outlet for rich mineral sands, and the agricultural and pastoral production of the region. We look forward to the proposed expansion and upgrading of the facilities of the port.

The employment of Geraldton youth depends heavily on the primary and service industries, which brings about a critical need for the development of the secondary industry. Job creation and youth training schemes are activities I would like to see maintained in the Geraldton region.

The tourist potential of the Geraldton region is just being tapped and with the introduction of the Batavia Coast concept of promoting the industry, we can look forward to an ever-increasing tourist flow. The bizarre history of the Abrolhos Islands-where the `Batavia' of Batavia Coast was wrecked-coupled with the existence of the southern most coral reefs in Australia, could see these islands developed as an attraction of world-wide fame. Due to this attraction, I extend an invitation to all of you to make the trip to Geraldton and experience this unspoilt country town of the mid-west of western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The irradiation of food using radioactive cobalt 60 is a highly controversial issue. This is a recently developed process whereby pallets of food are passed through a concrete chamber and irradiated by the radioactive cobalt 60. The gamma rays, which are equivalent to those used in more than two million chest X-rays, have to be contained in concrete buildings with walls some two metres thick. At present there are two irradiation plants operating in Australia-one in Dandenong in Victoria and the latest one in the Sydney suburb of Wetherill Park. Both plants have been restricted to the irradiation of cosmetics, medical and surgical materials and wine corks. However, this could be greatly expanded to include cereals, fruit and dried fruits, poultry, herbs and spices, vegetables and dehydrated vegetables.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has just recently endorsed regulations that will accommodate the irradiation of food using radioactive Cobalt 60. Draft regulations prepared by the Food Standards Committee of the Public Health Committee provided for a reasonable system of labelling irradiated food. However, in some very mysterious way, those labelling provisions were watered down and to date we have been unable to find out by whom or for what reason. The most obvious reason would be to allow the irradiation of food to be covered up. In fact, it will lead to the consuming public being deceived in a most underhand way. It is this cover-up that I particularly want to raise.

It is no accident that the labelling provisions are being covered up in this way. Consumers in the United States of America are experiencing exactly the same problems. The Australian draft regulations for food irradiation required that the label on irradiated food should say `treated with ionising radiation'. But then they were changed, changed in the dark of night, and now they allow for `or words having the same or similar effect'. Honourable members might well say that that is okay. But before they do they should look at just how devious the supporters of food irradiation can be. One word contrived as having the same or similar effect was `picowave'. An employee of the United States Food and Drug Administration said that `picowave' was not even in the dictionary. The word was contrived by Mr E. Nielson, the President of Emergent Technologies Inc., of California, as a way to avoid the term `food irradiation'. `Picowave' described the wave lengths of ionising radiation in the electromagnetic spectrum. One food irradiation processor, Radiation Technologies Inc., went even further. It called the food `picofresh'.

The alterations to the labelling provisions in Australia will now allow this type of gross deceit, but we, as legislators, must not let this happen. Some other contrived words being used include `radappertisation'. Perhaps the editorial of the Adelaide Advertiser best sums up this deception. The title of the editorial is `Cute nukespeak' and it says:

A radioactive treatment of food has been cleared by most health authorities, including Australia's, as a safe way of increasing shelf life, and thus national health. But caution is needed with all new technologies, which was a lesson of Challenger and Chernobyl, and some community unease is inevitable about irradiating food.

Proponents of such treatment have done themselves no service by adopting the nukespeak of ``picowave'' as a marketing term for irradiation. Words are tools of conventional meaning, and the public will suspect that if the irradiators cannot use the conventional word they must be hiding something. Even if they convince all that irradiation is no bad thing, by refusing to use the conventional word they would be hampering freedom of choice of those who for whatever reasons wanted to shun food treated with Cobalt 60.

As I said at the beginning, the irradiation of food using radioactive cobalt 60 is an extremely controversial subject. Some scientists are telling us that it is safe. However, these same scientists were telling us 10 years ago that ethylene dibromide or EDB was safe. Now we know it is carcinogenic. They say that irradiation of food will stop the use of EDB, but other scientists are saying that aflatoxins, which are some 1,000 times more cancer causing, have been found more abundantly after irradiation by gamma rays. Whom do we believe? Why should the consuming public have this questionable food processing system deposited on them and not have the right to know that the food they are eating has been treated with radioactive cobalt 60? The consumers of Australia have a right to know whether their food has been irradiated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring forward a matter which a constituent of mine has drawn to my attention. In so doing I realise that sometimes an elected member has some difficulty in trying to balance what is in the public interest and at the same time not wishing to undermine public support for an institution that does in fact need public confidence. In fact, I am referring to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I think every honourable member would realise the importance of the Bureau and the need for public confidence in the Bureau if it is to function properly. In this case I am talking about the agricultural census form which is sent out to all farmers once a year. I guess all honourable members would know that the material collected in the census is of great assistance both to governments and to farming groups in the development of policies which are in the best interests of agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the agricultural census have the confidence of those people who are filling in the form. In particular, they must feel confident that the details of what is actually going on in a farmer's business, many of which are very private, are in fact kept confidential. I think any breach of confidentiality would have to be seen as totally unacceptable. The case that has been drawn to my attention involves a blatant breach of this confidentiality-a blatant breach of the confidentiality of the private business affairs of two farmers. I would also have to hasten to add that this case obviously shows the incompetence of an officer of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I draw the attention of honourable members to section 19 (1) of the Census and Statistics Act, which states very clearly:
A person who is, or has been, the Statistician or an officer shall not....
either directly or indirectly, divulge or communicate any information furnished in pursuance of this Act to any person (other than the person from whom the information was obtained).
That is fairly clear. Section 20 (1) of the Act states:
An offence against this Act, other than an offence against sub-section 19 (2), shall be prosecuted summarily.

My constituent filled in the ABS farm census form believing what he was told-that is, that the form was sent out to farmers in every State. A dodger sent out with the form explained under the heading `Confidentiality':
You should note that you are obliged by law to fill in this form. However, the law protects the confidentiality of the information you provide.
The following words appear at the beginning of the statistics form itself:

This return is collected under the authority of the Census and Statistics Act 1905 which provides for the compulsory furnishing of a completed form. Individual returns remain confidential to the ABS and statistics are only released in the form of aggregated data.

My constituent filled in the form and a few weeks later he was surprised to be asked to fill in another form because, apparently, the Bureau did not have his form. So he said: `Okay, send me some new forms'. Two forms did arrive but they turned out to be forms completed by other farmers. My constituent's first reaction was quite natural. He said: `Someone else's forms have been sent out. Where are mine?'. He told the Bureau he would not fill in any new forms until his were brought to him. The Bureau said that not only would he have to fill in more forms but he should also return the two that he had been sent. He got a rather threatening phone call to this effect from someone within the Bureau. Quite obviously the Bureau was desperately trying to stop the cat getting out of the bag.

The long and short of it is that someone has bungled. Someone has breached this confidentiality. I think the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who is the Minister responsible for the Bureau, is going to have to do something about this extremely serious matter. If the Bureau wants people to divulge private and confidential information, it has to respect that confidentiality. It is quite obvious in the case that has been drawn to my attention that this confidentiality has been breached and in fact two farmers have filled out forms which, unbeknown to them, could have fallen into the hands of unscrupulous people and become public knowledge.
