SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cross-border attacks by the South African army on three of its neighbouring countries last week were acts of state terrorism. They were a totally unacceptable intervention into the internal affairs of other sovereign nations and showed complete disregard for international law and convention. The demolition of homes in the settlement at Crossroads outside Capetown taking place at this moment is further evidence of the inhuman ruthlessness of the South African Government. These events confirm the interpretation of the anti-apartheid organisations in South Africa, that there has been no change in the nature of the South African regime. Speakers for these organisations are correct in saying that recent changes in South Africa are only cosmetic.

SPEECH.PARA: While great publicity has accompanied the ending of the pass laws, the invidious Registration of the Population Act is still in force. Under this law last year more than 1,000 people were reclassified from one race to another, 702 coloured people became white, 19 whites became coloured, one Indian became white, three Chinese became white, 50 Indians became coloured, 249 blacks became coloured, while 20 coloureds became black. What a joke in bad taste! Significantly, no blacks became white and no whites became black. This is the system which the raids on Harare, Lusaka and Gaborone were designed to protect.

The South African raids on Zimbabwe, Zambia and Botswana coincided with the arrival in South Africa of the Commonwealth's Eminent Persons Group. This is the surest sign we have yet seen of the total disregard which the Government of President Botha has for a negotiated settlement. While it remains to be seen whether the Eminent Persons Group will produce any substantial change, the recent events direct our attention towards much stronger measures which must be taken by Commonwealth countries, including Australia, should it not succeed.

For some time now anti-apartheid leaders in South Africa have been urging the international community to play a greater role in hastening the end of apartheid by the imposition of economic sanctions. On 2 April this year, Bishop Tutu-who had hitherto stopped short of advocating sanctions-announced that he now unequivocally supported the call for economic sanctions. He added:
We are heading for a catastrophe in this country and only actions by the international community, the exertion of pressure, can save us.

Later in April, 33 South African Catholic bishops, in a pastoral letter read in churches throughout the country, called for economic pressure against the Government of South Africa to compel it to dismantle apartheid. This letter describes economic pressure as the most effective form of non-violent action and implicitly calls for sanctions and disinvestment.

Australia voted at the United Nations Security Council last week in support of comprehensive mandatory sanctions against South Africa. The United States of America and Britain vetoed that resolution. Australia must continue to advocate to these two countries the importance of economic sanctions as a last chance for peaceful transition to a non-racial, democratic, just and peaceful South Africa. Yesterday the Prime Minister of Malaysia called for the expulsion of Britain from the Commonwealth if it would not agree to back sanctions. That demonstrates the strength of feeling in the Commonwealth about the issue. Should the United States and Britain not respond to the rest of the international community, and should the South African Government continue with its intransigence, the Australian Government must be prepared immediately to expel South African diplomats, to withdraw landing rights from South African Airways, to ban the import of all minerals and agricultural products from South Africa and to strongly discourage tourism from Australia to South Africa.

The greatest problem South Africa faces now is the escalation of violence in the townships and the urban areas. It is clear that the violence of the state and of the apartheid system has led many opponents of apartheid into further arbitrary violence as their only response. Without economic sanctions, it is very difficult to see how intensifying violence can be avoided in the transition to democracy in South Africa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax will savagely hit Australia's churches and charities. Once sacrosanct, the churches of Australia will now fall victim to this wicked and vicious legislation which can be described only as anti-Christ. Two-thirds of the residential value of every rectory, presbytery and manse in Australia will attract the fringe benefits tax payable by the employer, namely, the church. I ask honourable members to contemplate that, as the legislation has gone through our chamber, two-thirds of the residential value of every rectory, presbytery and manse in Australia will attract the fringe benefits tax.
—I raise a point of order. I believe that the honourable member for Denison implied that we on this side of the House were anti-Christ. I believe that that is not correct.
—There is no point of order.

—That fringe benefits tax will be payable by the employer, which is the church. This means that the Church of England, the Catholic Church and every single church in Australia is, under the legislation, the employer and is obliged to pay the fringe benefits tax on two-thirds of the residential value of each rectory, presbytery and manse occupied by a minister. That is absolutely disgraceful and totally indefensible. I am appalled that in 1986 such legislation could come before this Parliament and, worse still, would be forced through the House of Representatives by weight of numbers.

SPEECH.PARA: The second aspect of the legislation which I find totally objectionable is the provision of proposed new section 160y in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill, under which every bequest of property acquired or purchased after 20 September 1985 to every church and charity in Australia will fall foul of the Hawke-Keating capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!
—I agree with the honourable member for Higgins; it is shameful. I read into the Hansard the provisions of proposed new section 160y, sub-sections (1), (2) and (3):

SPEECH.PARA: Asset bequeathed to tax-exempt person

``160y. (1) A person is a tax-exempt person in relation to the year of income for the purposes of this section if the person is a person whose income of the year of income is exempt from tax by virtue of a relevant exempting provision.
``(2) Where-
(a) a person died on or after 20 September 1985;
(b) an asset that formed part of the estate of the deceased person and was acquired by the deceased person on or after that date has passed to a beneficiary in the estate of the deceased person; and
(c) the beneficiary is a tax-exempt person in relation to the year of income,
section 160x does not apply in respect of the asset but the following provisions of this section have effect.
``(3) The asset shall be deemed for the purposes of this Part to have been disposed of by the deceased person, and acquired by the beneficiary--
that is, a church, charity or school--
immediately before the death of the person for a consideration equal to the market value of the asset at the date of the death.
That means that all property which has been bequeathed to churches from 20 September last year to the present date will now be subject to payment of capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what?

—That capital gains tax will be payable by virtue of the provisions of proposed new section 160y, which the honourable member opposite clearly has not read. I repeat: Under proposed new section 160y in this disgraceful and iniquitous Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill every bequest of property acquired or purchased after 20 September 1985 to every church and charity in Australia will fall foul of the Hawke-Keating capital gains tax. That is disgraceful. This sacrilegious Government will extract its 30 pieces of silver from the churches of Australia at the Judas rate of 46 per cent, rising to 49 per cent on 1 July 1987-the date of the Feast of the Precious Blood and the anniversary of the death of Martin Luther. Shame on the Government! Every church in Australia will condemn it for what it has done in this Parliament. It has behaved in a manner which is absolutely contemptible, shameful and totally indefensible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has a write-up in the current edition of Matilda, after a speech such as that. I doubt whether he will have 2 per cent support in the community after that sort of contribution.
—You will read it in every church newspaper in Australia, comrade.
—One of these days the churches and other people will wake right up to you, because you would have to be the greatest phoney that this place ever produced.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will direct his remarks through the chair.

—I want to raise the question of the attack on recipients of benefits from the Government. I do so because I am concerned about the tone of this attack which has been waged against people who are not able to defend themselves. I refer to the general broad brush approach of spokespersons of the New Right and the Opposition and the way in which they have tackled this question. I am also going to say that I believe that some members of the Government have been a bit careless in the way they have approached this.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite were quiet, they may learn something. The facts are that $3.5 billion in tax is outstanding. In the year we took office approximately $2.9 billion was outstanding. It seems to me that the first priority for the Government ought to be to get back taxation that is owed. There is a possibility that the Australian Taxation Office, through its various branches, would be able to supply the names and addresses of those people who owe money. On the other side we have an obsession by people to make a broad brush attack against those who are not able to defend themselves. I am sure that those people who take the time to read the Hansard would know that the members of this Government are addressing this problem. It has been addressed by the various departments in quite deliberate ways, such as the introduction of computers, tougher proof of identity procedures, direct deposits of pensions and benefits into bank accounts and a more stringent review of the processes.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me to be a tragedy that we are chasing hypothetical figures on how many people are engaged in this fraud. If people are engaged in fraud, I make no apology for saying that I believe that they ought to pay back that money and they ought to cease the fraud. The inference in the debate which has been carried on is that all people in receipt of Commonwealth benefits of one form or another are engaged in fraud. That is a tragedy. I do not think anybody in this House would want to create that impression, but unless we take heed of ourselves and act in a responsible manner, that is the impression which we will all be a party to creating in the community. I do not believe that anybody in this chamber or the other chamber would want to become engaged in that. I make a plea, on behalf of those people in receipt of benefits, for people to be a little more careful with the type of language they use when they blandly get up and blast off and make those accusations. We ought to be more concerned about the levels of income these people are receiving. It seems to me that in a community where millions, or even billions, of dollars are hurled around the stock exchange every day, when we look at the levels of income that these people are expected to live on we see that something is not quite right in our society. We ought to be paying more attention to the collection of taxes that were owed under the previous Government and which are owed under this Government. If we are able to get in that $3.5 billion, which exceeds the total amount of money paid out in unemployment benefit--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the cash economy?

—I will deal with the cash economy another day. This happens to be fact. This is the Auditor-General's report which states that $3.5 billion is owed. We quibble and we score points off each other over a piddly amount of money such as the value of the unemployment benefit or the supporting parent's benefit.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), I can understand the situation he has referred to, but does he not realise that he and his Government are responsible for this? There are many social welfare schemes in Australia today, and we have developed such a welfare state that there are many people around the place who expect the Government to keep them. The reason for this is the reason the honourable member for Melbourne was talking about. For months we have had taxation and other legislation in this chamber which will have the effect of bleeding those who have the money-the workers. How long can this country afford to keep up its social welfare payments? If the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, has any common sense, and I am sure he has because he applies himself fairly well to matters in the House, how long does he think the Government and the taxpayers of this country can afford to support our welfare system? I do not think we can afford to support it for very long. Honourable members opposite should be reversing their thinking. Instead of the legislation we have before the Parliament, they should be giving some incentive to some of the young people who leave school and cannot get jobs. In every honourable member's electorate there are people between 40 and 50 years of age who are honest, hard working people and who have no future.
—What about their sons and daughters?

—I know that the honourable member for Melbourne is talking about people in this chamber. He will hear more about this. As the weeks go on and the Budget is brought down in August this year, honourable members should look at that and at the rest of the legislation that is introduced. They will have every reason to get to their feet night after night in this House and talk about the things that are being said not only in this chamber but also by people outside. The honourable member for Melbourne should look at himself. He is a member of the Left. The honourable member for Melbourne dictates to Ministers, to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and those who sit on the Treasury bench of this country. He is the one who does that, yet he turns around and accuses people of talking about others who should not be drawing social security benefits. The honourable member for Melbourne had better have a look at himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker, when you look at the speakers' list you will see that I spoke on the taxation Bills this afternoon. I would love to have said something about the various clauses of those Bills but I did not get around to that. I purposely did not do that because, as I have said, the average person in Australia is darned concerned about the future of this nation of ours. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is the man who will pull it around, and the people will elect him, make no mistake about that. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and others are prepared to get up and say what they think should be happening in this land of ours. The honourable member for Melbourne is adding to this nation's problems day after day, in this support, with the rest of the Left, of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and others who are running this nation. To a degree the ACTU ran the previous Government, but it will not run us next time. I did not really get on my feet to talk for very long about this subject, but that issue is much more important than some of the other issues we quibble about day and night in this chamber. The Australian people expect better of us.

Let me conclude by saying that I am concerned about the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport because it is inadequate to take the aircraft from overseas and from around Australia and the commuter aircraft that will use it in the years to come. I want to register my grave concern about it because the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) and the Government have no intention whatsoever of proceeding with a new airport for Sydney. They have to acquire land, they have to find the money to build it, and they have to go through the construction process, which will take about 14 or 15 years. As far as I am concerned, as a representative of a country electorate, this is not good enough for the people of Sydney or for the people of Australia. We are looking for tourist trade and we are looking to getting people into and our of the metropolitan area. That airport will not be able to cope simply because the Minister will not agree to another runway being built. That is a great shame. If we looked at issues such as that instead of worrying about these other things we would be better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to continue dealing with what I believe is the most important issue facing Australia today. I spoke about it last night on the adjournment debate. I wish to continue reading into Hansard the Nobel Peace Prize lecture which was given last year by Bernard Lown. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: It is sheer hubris to pretend that there would be human survival after such a man-made catastrophe.
We know, therefore, that a nuclear war must never occur. Is this merely a hope or a certainty?

Since no national interest would justify inflicting genocide on the victim and suicide on the aggressor, a prevalent misconception is that a nuclear war will never be fought. But the realities of our age compel an opposite assessment. In no previous epoch were adversaries so continuously and totally mobilised for instant war. It is a statistical certainty that hair-trigger readiness cannot endure as a permanent condition. Furthermore, the unrelenting growth in nuclear arsenals, the increasing accuracy of missiles, and the continuing computerisation of response systems all promote instabilities that court nuclear war by technical malfunction, miscalculation, human aberration, or criminal act. The ever-decreasing time between missile launch and nuclear detonation relegates critical decision making to computers programmed by fallible human beings.

The possession of these weapons has been justified by the theory of deterrence. Such a view of human affairs has held sway throughout the ages. But the Roman adage Si vis pacem, para bellum has consistently been a prelude to war, not a guarantor of peace. No more untenable view of human affairs has ever gained such widespread public acceptance. In order to be effective, nuclear deterrence must operate perfectly and forever.

No such expectations are permissible for any human activities. The pretension to inhibit aggression by threatening to inflict unacceptable damage is jarred with contradictions. How is one to account for an overkill capacity equivalent to more than 1 million Hiroshimas? Would annihilation of only a few major cities not inflict unacceptable damage? A single modern submarine has approximately eight times the total firepower of World War II-sufficient to destroy every major city in the Northern Hemisphere. Why, then, the stockpiling of 18,000 strategic weapons? In this race, the runners are no longer in control of their limbs.

How did we reach such a dangerous and tragic impasse? Since the dawn of history, the tools forged by humans have imposed their laws on behaviour. As tools were transformed into ever more complex machines, technology shaped our consciousness while providing mastery over our environment. This was not to be some Faustian bargain. Technology was intended to serve human interests-to enlarge the domain of freedom against life's compelling necessities. Increasingly, though, as Thoreau observed, ``We are becoming the tools of our tools.'' Worse still, our tools are beginning to operate against our will and to threaten us with extinction.

An additional misperception propels the arms race. Throughout human history, when confronted with what was deemed a deadly enemy, the fixed human response has been to gather more rocks, muskets, cannons, and-now-nuclear bombs.

Nuclear weapons have no military utility-indeed, they are not weapons but instruments of genocide-but this essential truth is obscured by the notion of an ``evil enemy.'' The ``myth of the other,'' the stereotyping and demonising of human beings beyond recognition, is still pervasive and now exacts inordinate economic, psychological, and moral costs. The British physicist P. M. S. Blackett anticipated this state of paranoia when he said, ``Once a nation bases its security on an absolute weapon, such as the atom bomb, it becomes psychologically necessary to believe in an absolute enemy.'' The imagined enemy is eventually banished from the human family and reduced to an inanimate object whose annihilation loses all moral dimension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night in the adjournment debate the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) made a rather uncalled for and unnecessary attack on the Opposition's most effective Waste Watch Committee, which is becoming increasingly well known to honourable members opposite in exposing gross extravagance by Government departments and by the Government itself. In this uncalled for attack on the Waste Watch Committee the honourable member for Canning made two basic points to support his argument: First, he objected to the Waste Watch Committee exposing the funding by taxpayers of a whole range of union activities; and, secondly, and even more extraordinarily, he attacked the Waste Watch Committee for using questions on notice and freedom of information requests in order to get information on what the Government is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to respond quite clearly and unequivocally to the points that were raised by the honourable member for Canning. First, the Waste Watch Committee is by no means contrite about its attacks on the Government for its funding of union activities. When one considers that the top 20 unions of Australia have assets of some $118m it is really not fair that the taxpayer be asked to spend thousands upon thousands, indeed millions upon millions, of dollars topping up the coffers of the trade unions. I could understand it if a member of this House were outraged if the Western Mining Corporation, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd or some other big company in Australia were to receive hand- outs for story tellers in residence or for muralists or to put on concerts, and so on. Of course one would be outraged. However, the double standards of the Labor Party know no bounds because, apparently-according to the honour- able member for Canning-to spend taxpayers' money, to spend other peoples' money on employing artists in residence or muralists or on concerts by trade unions and all those sorts of activities is justifiable. In South Australia, just since the Hawke Government has been in power, the trade union movement has received a grant getting on towards half a million dollars, and so much of this money has been spent on strange things, such as concerts for the Trade and Labour Council centenary, commissioning the writing of a centenary song for the Trades and Labour Council and putting on a whole range of plays. The Waste Watch Committee is by no means contrite in its activity of drawing to the attention of the Australian taxpayers what the Government is doing with their money.

I want to take up the second point that the honourable member for Canning made, and I refer to his quite extraordinary objection to members of parliament on this side of the House trying to find out what the Government is doing. The Labor Party, to its enduring credit, has argued in favour of open government. Of course, it took the Fraser Government to introduce the freedom of information legislation, but nevertheless the Labor Party has always supported these sorts of initiatives. Apparently, when it comes to the Opposition seeking information through freedom of information requests the honourable member for Canning objects. Apparently, if we put questions on notice to find out how the taxpayers' money is being spent, the honourable member for Canning objects to that as well. I wonder whether he is concerned that the Waste Watch Committee is going to find still more things on which the Government is wasting the taxpayers' money. He can rest assured that we will.

One point made by the honourable member for Canning related to me personally. He complained that I had put on notice some 80 questions and implied that there was something wrong with that. I point out to the ignorant member that the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) has asked not 80 questions-I am glad to see him in here-but has put on notice 322 questions. That is all right, I do not object to that; but why does the honourable member for Canning object to that? The honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) has apparently put 114 questions on notice, and there is nothing wrong with that. I do not object to honourable members seeking information. Why does the honourable member for Canning do so? If that is the strength of the Labor Party's attack on the Waste Watch Committee, all I can say is that, first, we have had enormous success in exposing government waste and, in the second place, the Labor Party must really be panicking if the best it can do is attack members of parliament for genuinely seeking information on how taxpayers' money is spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Melbourne.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. It is not often one gets two bites of the cherry here. I would like to continue--
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker--

—I am sorry, the honourable member for Wakefield stood. He has not spoken tonight. I am obliged to give him the call. I did not see him stand. The honourable member for Wakefield stood in the first round of standing and I did not see him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Speaker, for your interpretation of Standing Orders. I appreciate your protection.
—I will call a quorum on you after that.

—I invite the honourable member for Melbourne so to do if he desires, Madam Speaker. I rise tonight on two accounts. First, I was prompted to speak after Mr Goodman of the National Diabetic Association convened a breakfast, at which he encouraged all Australians to consume foods that were in the interests of their good health. This coincided with a letter to me that arrived from the almond industry. It is in the context of those two events that I wish to address the chamber this evening. The almond industry has had a unique history in terms of horticultural industries in Australia. It has been an industry of marked growth and the consumption of health foods, particularly nuts and especially almonds, in Australia has quadrupled since the 1970s. One can understand people wanting to keep their cholesterol and sugar levels to what are considered nationally to be acceptable levels for good health being, concerned about what they eat and one can understand their turning to healthy foods, such as nuts, as an essential part of their diet.

SPEECH.PARA: I represent a group in South Australia which grows in excess of 80 per cent of all of the almonds grown in Australia. This group is known as the Almond Co-operative Ltd and it has 300 growers who farm large and productive areas along the River Murray, in the Gawler area and south of Adelaide in the Willunga area, in the electorate of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). These farmers have modern farms, mostly in excess of 50 hectares, and they run their farms using modern techniques. They grow 2,000 tonnes of almonds per annum at an estimated value of $8.75m, and they recently entered into a joint agreement with Berrivale Orchards-formerly Berri Fruit Juices-so that the crop could be most efficiently processed. It is interesting to note that in Australia there is a real shortfall of almonds available for consumption and that 60 per cent of almonds consumed in Australia are imported from the United States of America. The growth in consumption has meant that imports from the USA have increased from 900 to 2,500 tonnes per year. It also means that the price paid to Australian growers largely depends on the price dictated by the American market, thus keeping Australian growers at their efficient best. The letter from the Almond Co-operative Ltd, which prompted me to address the House tonight, states:
Dear Mr Andrew
I am writing to you under instruction from the Board of Management of the Almond Co-operative Limited.
The Co-operative recently purchased some equipment from Spain to upgrade our Almond blanching process at Berri. This equipment was purchased at a cost of A$150,000.

The equipment arrived in Melbourne on 26 March, it then took 31 days to arrive in Berri. Strikes within the Victorian rail system for some 2 to 3 weeks held the equipment on a rail siding in Victoria. We were unable to either trace the consignment or have it trans-shipped to road transport.
Our Board's concern is that this equipment was urgently needed. We had product sold under contract and yet due to an industrial dispute the equipment was laying idle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Madam Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want very briefly to refer to some remarks made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) on the question of the relative importance, if I might say so, of the unpaid taxation debt as opposed to overpayments in relation to the social security system. I think that it is important that the House recognise that the honourable member for Melbourne was making an extremely important point in terms of the relative dollars involved in the two systems.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand, we have a problem in terms of assessed but unpaid tax in this country running into billions of dollars. However, today we have seen the Opposition obsessed with measures designed to tighten up the tax system and to reduce fraud and the avoidance and evasion of tax in this country. The Government is concerned to introduce those measures; the Opposition is fighting tooth and nail to stop them. On the other hand, we have suggestions and imputations day in and day out that somehow tens of millions of dollars, indeed hundreds of millons of dollars, are being ripped off the social security system as a result of fraud. However, there has not been a single occasion on which any member of the Opposition has advanced a scintilla of evidence to support the figures that are regularly repeated within this Parliament. Of course, the reason that they have not been able to do that is that it is impossible to assess accurately to what extent there is fraud, although there are estimates which I have made available to the House from time to time relating to outstanding debt in the social security system. Of course, that runs into a substantial amount of money. However, that is relatively small money compared with the total social security bill. Certainly the outstanding debt accumulated over a number of years and running into something like $100m is very small money compared with, for example, the figure of $3 billion for the social security system as a whole. I think that the relativities are extremely important.

Of course, what the Opposition is about essentially is attacking those people who, as the honourable member for Melbourne said, are least able to defend themselves. It is not talking about the big people but talking about the smallest people. These are the people who are unfortunate enough to be living on extremely low levels of payment. In relation to this, I want briefly to refer to an interview tonight on the Willesee program with Peter Sawyer. I want to make the point that Mr Sawyer is proposing, apparently, to publish a book entitled Dole Bludging for Beginners. In that book he explains to people who are stupid enough to take any notice of what he says how to rip off the social security system. The extraordinary thing about this is that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who has come into the House tonight, has never at any point sought, as far as I am aware-certainly, he has not sought it in this House--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.
—Let me read from a transcript of an interview with the honourable member. The compere said in reference to the book:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a bit of a mongrel act isn't it?

He was referring to the publication of that book with the theme of how to rip off the social security system. What did the honourable member say? Did he say: `Yes this is a terrible thing for someone to be doing; it is appalling that someone should be suggesting to people how to rip off a system.'? Did he say: `That would be similar to a former bank manager suggesting to people how they might rob a bank.'? But no; he says that what he is trying to do is to alert the Government and the Minister to the real problems in social security. In other words the honourable member for Richmond seeks to avoid the point. He wants to make use of Sawyer for his own miserable purposes. That is extremely unfortunate. There is no integrity in the honourable member for Richmond, no integrity in the Opposition on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. I find the Minister's references to me offensive and I ask him to withdraw.
—I am happy to withdraw.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired. As no other Minister has risen, the Minister may continue.

—We see dishonesty and hypocrisy in the Opposition in relation to these matters. It will be remembered that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) was talking about a section of the population which is, in many respects, the poorest in the community. One must remember on the other hand that we have heard today the Liberal Party and the National Party defending people who have been avoiding tax and opposing changes in the tax laws that would mean that people would pay their fair share of tax. The matter should be put in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: So Opposition members raise questions which go to their lack of responsibility. If the honourable member for Richmond is right, for example, about New Zealanders who are on unemployment benefit in Australia, he should know that the agreement with New Zealand under which people are paid unemployment benefit in this country goes back to the late 1940s. At no time since then have we seen the Opposition, when in government, seeking to amend that agreement to limit that payment. The honourable member for Richmond knows that I told him soon after I became Minister that I would seek to renegotiate that agreement. There has been no acknowledgement of that because it makes political capital for the honourable member for Richmond to go on radio on Sunday nights and to put out a Press Release attacking the New Zealanders and attacking people in this country without any attempt to be discriminatory.

Let me take a second example. Yesterday, there came into the hands of the honourable member for Richmond some documents suggesting that some people on remand were being paid sickness benefit. On investigating the matter I discovered that since 1947 the position has been that people on remand in prison, people not convicted of crimes, have been paid sickness benefits. Successive Liberal governments for the whole of that period did absolutely nothing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that make it right?

—It might just make it right. Have successive governments sought to stop people being paid sickness benefit in psychiatric hospitals, in refuges and in every situation where they are receiving some other support from the Government? Of course not. It so happens that there is an association there which the honourable member for Richmond sought to exploit. He is on about the cheapest kind of attack which has nothing to do with the development of policy in social security and nothing to do with the well-being of low income people in this community. He is not on about thinking through a policy; he is on about lambasting the poor and attacking people in an indiscriminate way. This results in stereotyping and in a situation where people who are on very low levels of payment and in extremely difficult circumstances have to wear the kind of stigma that is being dished out by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We deserve in this country in respect of social security a higher standard of debate than that evidenced by the honourable member for Lyne and other members of the National Party who appear on any kind of radio program and answer any kind of question which they believe will help in this process of making them sound like policemen rather than people who are concerned about the well-being of the social security system in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate having concluded, the House stands adjourned until Monday next at 2 p.m. in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce: Compensation and Legal Expenses

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 23 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister provide details of all expenditure within his Department in 1984-85 for compensation and legal expenses as outlined in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86.
(2) What was the (a) amount and (b) nature of the expenditure in each case for (i) compensation and (ii) legal expenses.
(3) What was the name of each recipient of payment for legal expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The expenditure in 1984-85 for compensation and legal expenses as outlined in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) was $1,291,062.
(a) (ii) Expenditure on legal expenses in 1984-85 was $369,569.

(b) (i) Compensation expenditure consisted of: regular payments to former employees; payments to medical practitioners; payments to chemists and hospitals; lump sum settlements; and payments for damage to property and clothing.

(3) Recipients of payments from the Department of Industry Technology and Commerce for legal expenses in 1984-85 were:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the answer given by the former Minister for Defence to my Question No. 1492 (Hansard, 4 September 1984, page 557) stating that Australia's co-operation with the US on electromagnetic launcher weapons projects was not related to any possible strategic or space applications.

(2) Is it a fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs stated on 16 November 1984 that Australia would suspend high velocity weapons research with the US immediately if the research was contributing to the US Strategic Defence Initiative (SDI).
(3) What restrictions are there on access of (a) US scientists, (b) the US Defense Department and (c) the US Arms Control and Disarmament Agency to Australian electromagnetic gun research.

(4) Has Australia indicated to the US and the USSR its policy in respect of development of weapons which could breach anti-ballistic missile, chemical, outer space and other weapon limitation treaties; if so, what statements were made to those countries.
(5) Have published papers for scientists involved in Australia's rail gun research discussed their work's potential for development as outer-space weaponry.
(6) Is the US Defence Advance Research Projects Agency (DARPA) the principal US party to the agreement for transfer of Australian rail gun research findings to the US.
(7) Has DARPA directly funded Australian research.

(8) Is the Minister able to say whether (a) DARPA Head, Dr Robert Cooper, told the US Congress in March 1984 that DARPA (i) is represented on the SDI Executive Committee, (ii) gets SDI budget funds for electromagnetic guns technology and (iii) will co-operate with SDI in all fields and (b) during the same Congress hearings, US Under-Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, Dr Richard De Lauer, indicated 5 technical areas of SDI including kinetic energy weapons, such as interceptor missiles and hypervelocity guns.

(9) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report on guns in Aviation Week and Space Technology of July 1984, which indicated that past conventional rail gun concepts were overshadowed by the concept of basing the gun in space to fire 60 shots per second at over 100 km per second to ranges over 1600 km, with research proceeding, among other fields, on generators and plasma drive systems, and with prospects of SDI applications rather than those of particle beams or high-energy lasers; if so, is Australia proceeding with those 2 fields of rail gun research.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (4) The Minister for Foreign Affairs has answered these parts of the question in his response to Question No. 2405 (Hansard 14 February 1984, page 802).

(3) No restrictions have been placed on access to Australian Defence electromagnetic propulsion research work. Indeed, in 1981, Australian media representatives attended a comprehensive presentation on the electromagnetic propulsion research program at Materials Research Laboratories (MRL) in Melbourne.

(5) Papers published by defence scientists working at MRL on rail gun research have not discussed the application of this work to outer-space weaponry. A scientist from the Australian National University was attached to MRL for consultation on electromagnetic rails guns in 1984. One of his papers, which gave his current address as MRL, treated the speculative question of using a rail gun for launching large objects from the earth into space. This was based on his previous work at ANU.

(8) No. If the honourable member could give me explicit references to any such statements I would be pleased to answer any questions he has about them. However, I am aware that the Annual Report to the Congress for FY 1987 of the US Secretary of Defense lists the exploration of technologies relating to precision rocket interceptors and hypervelocity guns under the Kinetic Energy Weapons Technology element of the SDI research program.

(9) Yes. `Generators' i.e. suitable power sources for rail guns and `plasma drive systems' i.e. the means of transferring this power to the projectile, are common to all electromagnetic gun systems. MRL has studied these fields in the context of tactical applications, but not `with prospects of SDI applications' MRL is not proceeding with these two fields of research.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the existence of the Lismore-based North Coast Helicopter Rescue Ser- vice which serves the far north coast region of N.S.W.
(3) What level of support is the Government providing to (a) the North Coast Helicopter Rescue Service and (b) any other helicopter rescue services in 1985-86.
(4) Will he consider increasing the level of support in future years for the North Coast Helicopter Rescue Service.
(5) Will he consider establishing a review of the funding and operational needs of helicopter rescue services with a view to giving these services a stable funding base in future years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Government does not provide subsidy to any helicopter rescue service. Payment to these organisations is made for services rendered.

(4) The Department of Aviation has undertaken a program of training selected semi-dedicated fixed wing operators. These selected operators are paid for aircraft hire as part of the training program. It is proposed to extend the semi-detached Search and Rescue program to helicopters during 1986.
(5) No review is proposed at this stage.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Display of Portraits at Australian Missions Overseas

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that chemical weapons activities in the Soviet Union include a large chemical warfare organisation directed by the Headquarters Chemical Troops in the Ministry of Defence.
(2) Is he also able to confirm that the organisation is headed by a 3-star General and numbers more than 45,000 officers and enlisted men in the ground forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its forces. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defence Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether the Soviet Union's chemical industry has the capability to produce toxic chemical warfare agents at manufacturing rates sufficient to meet military needs and can supply a variety of chemical agents as blister, choking, blood and nerve gases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is not aware that the Soviet Union has made public sufficient detail concerning its chemical industry to permit a firm judgment to be made. It is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled ``Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985'' by the United States Defense Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it. It seems reasonable to suppose that a country with the capabilities of the Soviet Union could produce all the agents listed in the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether on 15 October 1985 the Nicaraguan Government suspended civil liberties such as freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression and freedom from arbitrary imprisonment.
(2) Did he make representations to the Nicaraguan Government concerning this suspension.
(3) If so, when and to whom; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. On that date the Nicaraguan Government reimposed a State of Emergency which was originally declared in March 1982 and had been partially lifted for the election of November 1984.
(3) I made representations to senior members of the Nicaraguan Government on the State of Emergency and other human rights issues well before October 1985.

I raised Australian concerns over restrictions of civil rights in Nicaragua with the Nicaraguan Minister for Foreign Trade, Dr Martinez, during his visit to Australia in February 1984. During my visit to Nicaragua in September 1984, I raised Australian concerns on the issues of pluralism, freedom of worship, and expression, and the State of Emergency with President Ortega and Foreign Minister d'Escoto.

Following the reimposition of the State of Emergency, the Prime Minister and I raised Australian concerns over the human rights situation in Nicaragua with Foreign Minister d'Escoto during his visit to Canberra in late November 1985.

Earlier representations were made, on my instructions, by officers of the Australian Embassy in Mexico City to the Minister-Counsellor of the Nicaraguan Embassy on 30 October 1985 expressing the Government's concern over the reimposition of a State of Emergency in Nicaragua.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to confirm whether since the late 1970s, the Soviets have constructed several new chemical agent-weapon test facilities at the Shikhany Chemical Warfare Proving Ground and construction is continuing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its military activities. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defense Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether there are research institutes in the Soviet Union that are actively engaged in developing the theoretical foundations for producing chemical warfare agents of even greater lethality than already available and designing the equipment necessary to make them; if so, did he raise the matter with the relevant Soviet officials during his visit to the Soviet Union; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its research activities. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defense Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it. I would point out that such activity is not currently constrained by existing international agreements: These matters were not therefore raised during my last visit to the Soviet Union.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to confirm that the Soviets have developed the firing data required to use chemical weapons in battle situations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its forces. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defense Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that the Soviets have long held a policy and doctrine that acknowledges the military utility of chemical weapons in warfare.
(2) Is he also able to confirm that the Soviets are exploiting state-of-the-art technology for new or improved chemical warfare agents with the intent of extending their advantage over the West.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its military activities. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defense Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that the Soviets have an unmatched capability to survive and operate on a contaminated battlefield.

(2) Is he also able to confirm that all Soviet forces receive extensive training in chemical protection; if so, did the Minister raise the matter with the relevant Soviet officials during his last visit to the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its forces. The Government is aware, however, of statements to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defence Intelligence Agency. I would point out, however, that NATO forces also receive extensive training in chemical protection and the suggestion in the question that the Soviet Union has an unmatched capability to survive and operate on a contaminated battlefield involved judgments on a number of factors.

The ability to survive and operate in a battlefield contaminated by chemical weapons, and training in chemical protection, are not prohibited under existing international law. These matters were not therefore raised during my last visit to the Soviet Union.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that almost all Soviet conventional weapons systems from mortars to long-range tactical missiles have compatible chemical ammunition or warheads, and are available to their land, air and naval forces. If so, did the Minister raise the matter with the relevant Soviet officials during his last visit to the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Soviet Union does not make such information available about its forces. The Government is aware, however, of a statement to this effect in a publication entitled `Soviet Chemical Weapons Threat 1985' by the United States Defence Intelligence Agency and has no reason to dispute it. As a general principal, however, possession of such munitions is not contrary to existing international law. This matter was not therefore raised during my last visit to the Soviet Union.

Australia is however committed to the early conclusion of a comprehensive chemical weapons convention which would ban the production, stockpiling and use of all chemical weapons and which would provide the destruction of all existing chemical stocks of chemical weapons and their production facilities. This is a high priority of the Australian Delegation to the Conference on Disarmament where negotiations towards a chemical weapons convention take place.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Alleged Soviet Use of Chemical Weapons in Afghanistan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he reply to my question No. 1981 (Hansard, 30 November 1985, page 4087) on the use of mycotoxins, nerve gases, blister agents and incapacitants by the Soviet Union in Afghanistan that the Government had noted the inconclusive nature of much of the evidence, nevertheless the Government viewed these reports and allegations with considerable concern.
In part 2 of Question 1981, I asked the Minister whether he had raised the matter on his last visit to the Soviet Union.
(2) Did he also reply that this particular issue had not been raised with the Soviet Union on his last visit there.
(3) In view of community concern over chemical warfare will he now make representations to the Soviet Union over this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The Government is not satisfied that there are sufficient grounds for it to make representations to the Soviet Union specifically about these particular allegations. The Government has made clear to the Soviet Union-and indeed to the international community at large-its strong opposition to the use of chemical weapons in any circumstances. It has also expressed support for standing measures to investigate all such reports. Australia is engaged in direct negotiations with the Soviet Union and other countries for the conclusion of a Convention to ban the possession, production or use of chemical weapons and to require the destruction of existing stocks of such weapons and their means of production.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Advance to the Minister for Finance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Why was $1,102,000 required from the 1985 Advance to the Minister for Finance for salaries and payments in the nature of salaries for the overseas service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Foreign Affairs did not require an amount of $1,102,000 from the 1985 Advance to the Minister for Finance for salary and payment in the nature of salary for the overseas service. It did, however, request the sum of $1,566,500 from this Advance as supplementation for exchange rate variations, of which $1,222,346 was eventually expended. The full reason given to the Department of Finance for this request was as follows:

Supplementation for exchange variation under this sub-division was not sought in the Additional Estimates because slightly favourable exchange rates during the first seven months of the financial year had cushioned the immediate effect of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. In the period following finalisation of the Revised Estimates, the average depreciation against major currencies was 7.8% and an amount of $1,481,600 was thus sought from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to meet overseas salaries commitments. Funding of $84,856 to cover the unforeseen retirement of a senior Head of Mission was also provided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Foreign Affairs Officers were there in (a) 1975 and (b) 1985, overseas and (c) in his Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 20 March 1986.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Australia (a) voted in favour of the Lima Declaration on 27 March 1975, (b) is a signatory to it and (c) has subsequently ratified the declaration.

(2) Do points numbered 59(c) and 61(d) of the Declaration militate against the interests of Australian manufacturers by suggesting that certain productive capacities be redeployed to developing countries.
(3) If so, why has the agreement been signed.
(4) Will the Government implement the points contained in the Declaration; (b) if so, what is the time-frame for this to be achieved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) and (c) The so called `Lima Declaration' is a declaration agreed to by the Second General Conference of the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation at Lima, Peru, in March 1975. It is not an international instrument requiring either signature or ratification.
(2) (3) and (4) As explained above, Australia has not signed the Lima Declaration.

In supporting the Declaration in 1975 the leader of the Australian delegation presented a statement of reservation and interpretation in which the Australian Government's position was effectively explained. In that statement the delegation leader said, inter alia: `The Australian delegation has supported the Declaration and Plan of Action because of the aspirations it embodies for a fairer, more co-operative and more progressive world order. We have done so notwithstanding reservations on a number of matters.' Reference was then made to Australian reservations made on the program of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order (NIEO) and on the Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States (CERDS). The delegation leader then expressed specific reservations or interpretations on a number of paragraphs in the Declaration, including paragraphs 17, 19, 28, 40, 42, 43, 44, 47, 59(c) (d) and (e) and 60(e) and (f).

Around the time that statement was made and subsequently, a more difficult economic environment and increasing competition, particularly from developing countries in the region, was revealing major deficiencies in Australian manufacturing industry. This resulted in a significant change in the Government's approach to manufacturing industry policy.

That policy is now aimed at making the manufacturing sector more internationally competitive, export-oriented, flexible and innovative, and capable of operating in the longer-term with minimal levels of government assistance and regulatory intervention.
A recognised consequence of this approach is the need for a gradual restructuring of industry.

The Government also continues to be actively involved as appropriate in assisting the process of industrialisation in developing countries. Means by which Australia pursues this objective include the Australian System of Tariff Preferences, the foreign aid program, and involvement in a range of activities under the auspices of the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO) and the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting (CHOGRM) Working Group on Industry.

The Government will continue to pursue its broad industry policy which is aimed at achieving a high and sustained rate of economic growth, and a resultant improvement in overall living standards and increased employment. Continued pursuit of this policy will be to the overall benefit both of Australia and the developing countries of the world.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did he state on 26 August 1983 that he wanted to see a public inquiry into penalty rates; if so, what action has been taken to establish an inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 26 August 1983 I reiterated my desire to see a public inquiry conducted into penalty rates and accompanying low base rates of pay as they affect the tourism industry. I stressed however that such an inquiry should take place only with the full participation of the industries concerned, the trade union movement and various State Governments as well as the Federal Government.
I have also acknowledged that the question of penalty rates is not one to be looked at in isolation.
Recent independent studies into the effect of penalty rates on employment opportunities have been inconclusive.

Tourism, as a seven-day-a-week industry, needs a sensible wage formula and greater flexibility in award provisions to fulfil its potential for job generation but this can only be achieved if all interests are considered.

The Government considers that the issue of penalty rates should be discussed in the appropriate forum-the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-where the merits of any particular proposal can be fully examined taking into account the interests of all parties involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims that Australian citrus juice producers are suffering as a result of market penetration by low cost Brazilian citrus juice concentrate imports.
(2) Will the Minister initiate an investigation into the claim to ensure the protection of the Australian citrus industry against dumping action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of concerns raised by members of the citrus industry. However, it must be noted that world prices for orange juice concentrate have fallen recently from the high levels achieved during 1984-85. The prices of imported juice can therefore be expected to also drop in line with world trends.

The Australian market for orange juice has traditionally been supplemented by imports, mainly from Brazil. However, Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Data shows that imports peaked at 13.8 million kg TSS (total soluble solids) in 1983-84 and have since declined to around 7.6 million kg TSS in 1984-85. In the 7 months to January 1986 imports were 2.3 million kg TSS indicating a continued drop in imports.
At the same time Australian production has increased steadily both on an absolute and on a market share basis.
(2) The Australian Customs Service has the responsibility for conducting a dumping investigation upon the lodgement of a formal dumping complaint including sufficient prima facie evidence of
a causal link between the dumped imports and the alleged injury.
I am advised that a dumping complaint has not been lodged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did Australia abstain in a vote on a Security Council resolution condemning Israel for the interception of an aircraft returning from a meeting of terrorist organisations in Libya; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 6 February 1986, Australia, with Denmark, France and the United Kingdom, abstained in the Security Council on a draft resolution (S/17796/Rev.1) concerning the interception by Israel of a Libyan aircraft.

In an explanation of vote, Australia expressed understanding for Israel's motives in seeking to act against international terrorism. The explanation of vote also made clear that the Government deplored the interception of the Libyan aircraft over international waters which, in the circumstances, could not be justified.

There were elements in the draft resolution which Australia could support but there were some aspects with which we could not agree. One example was the portrayal of the interception as ``piracy''. The accepted definition of piracy is that it is an act perpetrated for private purposes. The Israeli action did not fit into this definition.
The United States vetoed the draft resolution.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 11 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to my question No. 2758 (Hansard, 11 March 1986, page 1134) concerning notification of dangers to shipping, what co-operative arrangements has the Commonwealth made with Western Australia concerning the implementation of (a) the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974 and (b) the United Nations Convention on the Territorial Sea and the Contiguous Zone by the Fremantle Port Authority.
(2) Does the Commonwealth remain responsible and accountable for the implementation of the conventions; if not, who is responsible.
(3) Who is responsible for ensuring that notifications of dangers to shipping are issued in the appropriate manner.
(4) What other co-operative arrangements exist between the States and the Commonwealth in relation to these conventions and what is their legal and legislative status.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The co-operative arrangement between the Commonwealth and Western Australia in respect of responsibility for notification of dangers to shipping stem from an exchange of letters between the Prime Minister and the Premier of Western Australia in 1934. This arrangement provides that the responsibility of the Commonwealth in regard to provision and maintenance of lights and other aids to navigation ends with erection and maintenance of those aids necessary for ocean navigation. Provision of port, river and minor aids to navigation is a matter for the State Government or local authority. In this context radio warnings are regarded as `other aids to navigation'. Information contained in radio warnings issued by the Federal Department of Transport is to advise mariners of dangers that exist at sea and to assist mariners to safely reach the entrance ports. The provision of aids to navigation (including radio warnings) within the port limits is a matter for State Governments or local authorities. It is not necessary for the co-operative arrangement with Western Australia to identify the Western Australian local authority or authorities concerned, that being a matter for the Western Australian Government.

(2) At international law, although the Commonwealth accepts international obligations and benefits from rights under international treaties, the means by which any such obligations are to be given effect domestically is a matter for the Commonwealth. Consistent with international law, responsibility for implementation of such obligations domestically can rest with the Australian States for areas within the jurisdiction of the States. Any question regarding any adverse effect on an Australian citizen of an alleged failure by Australia to comply with international law is a matter to be determined solely in accordance with arrangements in Australian law, both Commonwealth and State.

(4) In relation to those provisions of the Conventions concerning notification of dangers to shipping, co-operative arrangements similar to those described in (1) above exist between the Commonwealth and each of the States. These provisions of the Conventions can be implemented by administrative means and do not require legislation. In relation to other provisions of these Conventions, the broad terms of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on responsibility for regulation of shipping and navigation were confirmed as part of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement of 1979. Commonwealth and State legislation reflects these arrangements in giving effect to those provisions of the Conventions which require legislation for implementation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia vote in favour of UN Security Council Resolutions 574 and 577 requesting member states to extend assistance to the People's Republic of Angola to strengthen its defence capacity and economic infrastructure; if so, why.
(2) Will the Government provide assistance to the People's Republic of Angola in order to (a) strengthen its defence capacity and (b) reconstruct its economic infrastructure; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia voted in favour of UN Security Council Resolutions 574 and 577, condemning South African armed aggression violating the sovereignty, airspace and territorial integrity of the People's Republic of Angola. Both of these resolutions were adopted unanimously. Australia's support for these resolutions is based on its concerns over South African actions and its rejection of South Africa's claims to any rights to violate the territorial integrity of its neighbours.

(2) Amongst their various provisions, the two resolutions together request Member States of the United Nations to consider assistance to the People's Republic of Angola towards strengthening its defence capacity and economic infrastructure so that it may better withstand South African aggression. It is a matter for each Member State to determine the extent to which it will respond-within its own policy and resource priorities and constraints-to Security Council requests. For its part, Australia:
(a) Does not have a tradition of bilateral defence programs in Africa. It is unlikely that this situation will change in the near future;

(b) Currently provides no bilateral aid to Angola. As at 24 April 1986, however, Australia had provided an estimated $919,200 worth of food aid to Angola as part of its multilateral food aid program for 1985/86. Australia will continue to participate in multilateral aid programs for Angola.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 16 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government implemented a decision to reduce the free supply of colostomy bags; if so, how many users in each State and Territory will be affected.
(2) What are the expected cost savings and how are they calculated.
(3) Will he review the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) With effect from 1 April 1986 the maximum quantities for a number of ostomy bags were reduced. This decision was part of the result of a review of the Stoma Appliance Scheme undertaken by my Department in late 1985. In the initial stages of this review various bodies associated with the supply of stoma appliances expressed concern that the listed maximum quantities for some items were far in excess of the requirements for a month's supply.

Accordingly the Department in its review consulted with manufacturers, some stomal therapists and a number of Ostomy Associations to obtain information as to what the appropriate maximum quantities for a month's supply should be. The revised maximum quantities were considered by the manufacturers and Associations to be sufficient for one month's supply and represented an average usage rate of 2 bags per day.

On 5 April 1986 the Annual General Meeting of the Australian Council of Stoma Associations was held in Launceston. At this meeting affiliated State Associations supported the changes to the Stoma Appliance Scheme with modifications to increase the maximum quantity for closed bags from 60 to 90 and to increase the maximum quantity of wafers from 20 to 30. I supported these modifications and my Department implemented the changes with effect from 1 May 1986.

It is not known how many users in each State and Territory might have been affected. However, Associations consider that with the changes implemented from 1 May, few users will be affected. Provision does exist for those users who require more than the listed maximum quantity to obtain a medical certificate to authorise Associations to issue the required quantity free of charge.
(2) There are no expected cost savings as the changes only reflected what some Associations and patients were doing in practice.
(3) There was a review after comments were received from the Australian Council of Stoma Association and affiliated State Associations.
